webTitle: Holly, yule logs and Norway spruce: trees of Christmas
trailText: Jane Perrone profiles the trees that make Christmas, from prickly holly to the nordmann fir
headline: Holly, yule logs and Norway spruce: trees of Christmas
standfirst:
Jane Perrone profiles the trees that make Christmas, from prickly holly to the nordmann fir

  • Read part one on the foliage plants of Christmas here
  • Read part two on the houseplants of Christmas here
body:
Holly

This tree<83><82><82><82><84>s jolly red berries and prickly leaves adorn every conceivable piece of Christmas paraphernalia, from napkins to wrapping paper. And yet one of the oft-asked questions when it comes to this tree in the garden is <83><82><82><82><93>why doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t my holly have any berries?<83><82><82><82><9d> The plant family Ilex - of which the European holly Ilex aquifolium is a member - consists mostly of dioecious plants, meaning there are distinct male and female specimens, and only the female bears berries - and that<83><82><82><82><84>s provided there<83><82><82><82><84>s a male plant in the vicinity.

There are exceptions: I. aquifolium <83><82><82><82><9c>Pyramidalis<83><82><82><82><84> and <83><82><82><82><9c>JC van Tol<83><82><82><82><84> are both self-fertile, so they don<83><82><82><82><84>t need another plant for cross pollination and can produce berries all on their own. Their leaves are also much less spiny than regular I. aquifolium, which may or may not appeal. For more information on the vast range of hollies for gardens, check out this feature by Naomi Slade from the Guardian archive .

Non-festive fact: if you suffer from cats defecating on your seed beds, try laying some holly branches (preferably as spiny as possible - pyracantha is another option if you don<83><82><82><82><84>t have holly) across the bare soil. They won<83><82><82><82><84>t come near.

Christmas tree


What is a Christmas tree, exactly? The term is a catchall for an awful lot of different species around the world. In New Zealand, a tree that features on many a Christmas card is Metrosideros excelsa, a member of the myrtle family known to Maori people as pohutukawa. Settlers, noting its habit of producing beautiful red bottlebrush flowers around Christmas time, dubbed it the New Zealand Christmas tree. It<83><82><82><82><84>s too tender to grow outside in the UK unless you happen to live in the Isles of Scilly. In San Francisco, on the other hand, it grows rather too well. Australia has the New South Wales Christmas bush, Ceratopetalum gummiferum: it too turns red in December, although the colour is the result of the sepals of the seed capsules, not the preceding flowers, which are white.

Back in Britain, the Christmas tree tradition, though it<83><82><82><82><84>s been going strong over several centuries, has embraced more than a dozen different trees. The needle-shedding Christmas tree of my youth, the Norway spruce (Picea abies), has gradually been elbowed out of British front rooms in favour of other trees that hang onto their foliage far longer - the Nordmann fir (Abies nordmanniana) leading the way, followed by the noble fir (Abies nobilis), the blue spruce (Picea pungens Glauca Group), and most recently the Fraser fir (Abies fraseri).

The origins of the practice of decorating a tree for Christmas are far from clear, but most agree it originates in central Europe, perhaps some time in the 1500s. Even in his 1850 short story The Christmas Tree, Charles Dickens refers to it as <83><82><82><82><93>that pretty German toy<83><82><82><82><9d> (you can hear Simon Callow read this tale aloud here). If you want to read more about its history, I highly recommend the book Inventing the Christmas Tree by Bernd Brunner. For a different perspective, try palaeobotanist Susannah Lydon<83><82><82><82><84>s blogpost on the Christmas tree as a survivor from Mesozoic times.

For strictly practical advice on keeping your real Christmas tree alive as long as possible, try the British Christmas Tree Growers Association.

Yule log

As festive customs go, the yule log has fared far worse than the Christmas tree. In the dining hall of Hever Castle in Kent hangs the nineteenth century painting Yule Log by Robert Alexander Hillingford. A man and a boy use ropes to haul a hefty section of the trunk of an oak tree, preceded by a prancing spaniel. They are headed for a huge fireplace, where this giant log will be burn from Christmas Eve right through until Twelfth Night. And there<83><82><82><82><84>s the rub, for us in the 21st century, where such fireplaces are a relative rarity, replaced by modern contrivances such as radiators and underfloor heating.

But of course the yule log predates Christmas anyway, having its origins in pagan winter solstice celebrations that took place across Europe in many variations, where a tree or log (oak or ash in England, but different woods elsewhere - cherry in France, for instance), was burned to ward off evil spirits. There<83><82><82><82><84>s much more detail to delve into on regional variations of the yule log tradition in Chambers<83><82><82><82><84> Book of Days.

Today, you<83><82><82><82><84>re much more likely to be enjoying the chocolate replica, or if you are in the US, watching the now-traditional TV broadcast of a burning yule log. If you fancy making your very own a chocolate yule log, here<83><82><82><82><84>s the perfect recipe.

Boswellia

Boswellia may not be a familiar treename to you, but you will know the fragrant gum resin drawn from the trees of this genus from its key role in Christmas carols and nativity plays. Frankincense was one of the gifts bought by the three kings to the infant Jesus, according to the book of Matthew in the Bible.

My favourite Frankincense fact is that the Egyptians called it <83><82><82><82><93>sweat of the gods fallen to earth<83><82><82><82><9d>. In fact it was highly valued by several cultures in ancient times, including the Romans, the Greeks and the Babylonians. For a full account of its uses, visit Marquette University<83><82><82><82><84>s Historians@Work blog.

Frankincense is still prized today, as an ingredient for making incense, for cosmetics, perfumes and so on. The boswellia tree still grows wild Oman, Ethiopia, Somalia, and Yemen, and it is harvested in the same way as ancient times: the bark is cut and the resin that exudes is collected. Unfortunately Boswellia sacra is classed as near-threatened on the IUCN red list of endangered species. If you would like to see one of these trees in the flesh, there is a specimen of B. sacra growing in the Princess of Wales conservatory at Kew Gardens in London.

Myrhh

Myrhh is the product of another family of trees, Commiphora, that grow in the same part of the world as Boswellia. It<83><82><82><82><84>s another gum resin that is used for just the same purposes as frankincense: incense, perfumes, medicines and the like. In fact both trees are members of the Burseraceae or incense tree family.

Read the verse about myrhh in the carol We Three Kings of Orient Are and the role of this <83><82><82><82><93>bitter perfume<83><82><82><82><9d> as a symbol of death is clear: Jesus<83><82><82><82><84>s body was embalmed with pounds of it, according to the account in John 19 (myrhh means <83><82><82><82><93>bitter<83><82><82><82><9d> in Arabic). Like Boswellia, Commiphora is a shrubby desert tree: it is adapted to the harsh conditions with spines to discourage grazing animals. If you fancy trying to grow your own myrhh tree, you can buy a young Commiphora myrrha seedling from The Curious Plant Company in the UK, but bear in mind you will need to grow it as a houseplant so you<83><82><82><82><84>re unlikely to be harvesting resin from it.

  • Read parts one and two of gardening editor Jane Perrone<83><82><82><82><84>s series on the plants of Christmas.

webTitle: Norway reprieves 32 of 47 wolves earmarked for cull
trailText: Under Norwayâs endangered predator laws, only 15 lone wolves proved to pose a threat to livestock
headline: Norway reprieves 32 of 47 wolves earmarked for cull
standfirst: Under Norwayâs endangered predator laws, only 15 lone wolves proved to pose a threat to livestock
byline: Tone Sutterud and Elisabeth Ulven, Oslo
body:
The Norwegian government has issued a last-minute reprieve for 32 of the 47 wolves that had been earmarked for a cull to protect sheep flocks.

The plans to kill two-thirds of the country<83><82><82><82><84>s wolves caused outrage among conservationists at home and abroad when they were announced by local predator management boards in September, with warnings the cull would be disastrous for the species.

But on Tuesday Vidar Helgesen, minister of climate and the environment, refused to sanction the cull, saying lawyers at the justice ministry had concluded it would contravene domestic biodiversity legislation and the international Bern convention.

The laws state that culling of endangered predators <83><82><82><82><80><9c> there are an estimated 68 wolves in Norway <83><82><82><82><80><9c> can only be granted if there is a satisfactorily documented risk of damage to livestock. This proved not to have been the case with 32 wolves from four packs in the county of Hedmark.

Related: Norway plans to cull more than two-thirds of its wolf population

The other 15 animals which will still be hunted are young lone wolves which range over greater distances and are more prone to killing livestock, and environmental groups have not objected to these being culled.

<83><82><82><82><93>This is a great day and the best Christmas present you could wish for,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Nina Jensen of WWF Norway. <83><82><82><82><93>At last the government has shown that Norwegian wolves also have protection in law. It is a protected species that is critically endangered and has a natural place in Norwegian fauna.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Today<83><82><82><82><84>s pardon for the 32 wolves caused surprise among both the conservation and hunting lobbies, as the government had been expected to support the cull. More than 300 hunters who were cooperating with the police and the county governor to prepare for the hunt, due to start on 2 January, now have to put away their guns.

<83><82><82><82><93>This was a surprising decision based on odd reasoning,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Arnfinn Nerg<83><92><82>rd, director of the predator management board in Hedmark county.

The framework for predator management has been set by parliament, with local predator management boards setting hunting and culling quotas when population targets have been achieved. The final decision for a cull, however, is given by the government.

The rejection of sanctioned culls, coupled with continuing rural community concerns over wolves, has raised the prospect of illegal poaching.

Nerg<83><92><82>rd declined to comment on the possibility of poaching, but said the wolf population has recovered considerably after six local poachers were imprisoned in an unprecedented case two years ago. <83><82><82><82><93>This may suggest that extensive poaching was taking place,<83><82><82><82><9d> he conceded.

Related: Norway's wolf cull pits sheep farmers against conservationists

Environmental groups attribute their victory not only to the wolf<83><82><82><82><84>s iconic status, but also to more than 70,000 Norwegians who signed a petition protesting against the proposed culling. Helgesen received close to 7,000 emails in both Norwegian and English, and the story made headlines around Europe.

<83><82><82><82><93>It proves that pressure from environmental groups and public opinion matters,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Silje Ask Lundberg of Friends of the Earth Norway. <83><82><82><82><93>Predator management in Norway has not always been based on sound knowledge. The Berne convention clearly states that endangered predators can only be culled if the individuals have been proven to cause extensive damage.

<83><82><82><82><93>That has not been the case with these wolves who over a period of six years have only been documented to kill 10 sheep, and that was due to a hole in a fence.<83><82><82><82><9d>
text: The Norwegian government has issued a last-minute reprieve for 32 of the 47 wolves that had been earmarked for a cull to protect sheep flocks. The plans to kill two-thirds of the countrys wolves caused outrage among conservationists at home and abroad when they were announced by local predator management boards in September, with warnings the cull would be disastrous for the species. But on Tuesday Vidar Helgesen, minister of climate and the environment, refused to sanction the cull, saying lawyers at the justice ministry had concluded it would contravene domestic biodiversity legislation and the international Bern convention.  The laws state that culling of endangered predators  there are an estimated 68 wolves in Norway  can only be granted if there is a satisfactorily documented risk of damage to livestock. This proved not to have been the case with 32 wolves from four packs in the county of Hedmark.   Related: Norway plans to cull more than two-thirds of its wolf population  The other 15 animals which will still be hunted are young lone wolves which range over greater distances and are more prone to killing livestock, and environmental groups have not objected to these being culled.  This is a great day and the best Christmas present you could wish for, said Nina Jensen of WWF Norway. At last the government has shown that Norwegian wolves also have protection in law. It is a protected species that is critically endangered and has a natural place in Norwegian fauna. Todays pardon for the 32 wolves caused surprise among both the conservation and hunting lobbies, as the government had been expected to support the cull. More than 300 hunters who were cooperating with the police and the county governor to prepare for the hunt, due to start on 2 January, now have to put away their guns. This was a surprising decision based on odd reasoning, said Arnfinn Nergrd, director of the predator management board in Hedmark county. The framework for predator management has been set by parliament, with local predator management boards setting hunting and culling quotas when population targets have been achieved. The final decision for a cull, however, is given by the government. The rejection of sanctioned culls, coupled with continuing rural community concerns over wolves, has raised the prospect of illegal poaching. Nergrd declined to comment on the possibility of poaching, but said the wolf population has recovered considerably after six local poachers were imprisoned in an unprecedented case two years ago. This may suggest that extensive poaching was taking place, he conceded.   Related: Norway's wolf cull pits sheep farmers against conservationists  Environmental groups attribute their victory not only to the wolfs iconic status, but also to more than 70,000 Norwegians who signed a petition protesting against the proposed culling. Helgesen received close to 7,000 emails in both Norwegian and English, and the story made headlines around Europe.  It proves that pressure from environmental groups and public opinion matters, said Silje Ask Lundberg of Friends of the Earth Norway. Predator management in Norway has not always been based on sound knowledge. The Berne convention clearly states that endangered predators can only be culled if the individuals have been proven to cause extensive damage.  That has not been the case with these wolves who over a period of six years have only been documented to kill 10 sheep, and that was due to a hole in a fence.

webTitle: Norway is green  but not green enough, say students
trailText: The countryâs environmental policies are among the best in the world, but these young campaigners argue thereâs more to be done
headline: Norway is green â but not green enough, say students
standfirst: The countryâs environmental policies are among the best in the world, but these young campaigners argue thereâs more to be done
body:
Norway is a country of contradiction. Internationally it<83><82><82><82><84>s seen as a green role model, what with its pledge to become climate-neutral by 2030, a reliance on hydropower and ambitious plans for electric cars. But at the same time, it<83><82><82><82><84>s one of the world<83><82><82><82><84>s largest exporters of oil and gas.

It<83><82><82><82><84>s a paradox that has made a new generation of young Norwegians more environmentally conscious than ever. They are challenging politicians on their decisions over oil exploration <83><82><82><82><80><9c> by filing a lawsuit against the government, for instance <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and campaigning for a more sustainable future.

Related: Norway pledges to become climate neutral by 2030

Students are also scrutinising Norwegian companies on environmental issues. <83><82><82><82><93>There<83><82><82><82><84>s definitely a push for sustainability in Norway right now,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Lauren Guido, 21, who studies international development and environmental studies at the Norwegian University of Life Sciences. <83><82><82><82><93>The green movement is on people<83><82><82><82><84>s minds.<83><82><82><82><9d>

And students are at the heart of it. <83><82><82><82><93>Young people understand the urgency. We are the ones that will have to inherit the problems,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Arnstein Vestre, 25, a student who works part time at Greenpeace Norway.

Legal action against <83><82><82><82><9c>hypocrisy<83><82><82><82><84>

Nature and Youth, a youth group with around 8,000 members aged 13-25, have filed a lawsuit against the Norwegian government, along with Greenpeace and other independent activists, over a decision to open up the Barents Sea for oil exploration. <83><82><82><82><93>Oil is the issue that<83><82><82><82><84>s most difficult to talk about in Norway,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Ingrid Skjoldv<83><92><82>r, 23, leader of Nature and Youth. <83><82><82><82><93>We<83><82><82><82><84>re seen as the good guy internationally, but we<83><82><82><82><84>re not doing what<83><82><82><82><84>s necessary at home. So we need to walk the walk.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The case centres around a claim that the government has violated part of the Norwegian constitution that says future generations have a right to a healthy environment. <83><82><82><82><93>It<83><82><82><82><84>s unique because this clause hasn<83><82><82><82><84>t been cited before, so it<83><82><82><82><84>s exciting,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Skjoldv<83><92><82>r.

<83><82><82><82><93>Norway aspires to be a global leader on climate change and to inspire others to action,<83><82><82><82><9d> adds Vestre. <83><82><82><82><93>But if we want to do that, we can<83><82><82><82><84>t have this kind of hypocrisy.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Related: Want to make a difference at university? Join the clubs

Facing up to politicians

Younger school students also have strong views on Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s environmental issues. At <83><82><82><82><93>my city, my responsibility<83><82><82><82><9d>, a project organised by InterBridge, a social enterprise that aims to empower citizens to participate in global issues, 19 school children were given a platform to make their demands of politicians. After four weekends of workshops and discussions, they presented their ideas in front of them, and the public, at Oslo City Hall. These included making greater use of renewable energies, reducing meat and dairy consumption, and making bicycles more easily available to the public.

Amanda Anvar, 14, told politicians she worries about Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s global effect. <83><82><82><82><93>I want my children to grow up in a city where energy comes from a credible source, and where people on the other side of the world don<83><82><82><82><84>t have to suffer for us to use it,<83><82><82><82><9d> she says.

<83><82><82><82><93>Norway should focus on renewable energy, rather than our precious dirty gold, meaning our oil,<83><82><82><82><9d> adds Michelle Ann Wurschmidt, 16. <83><82><82><82><93>Presenting to politicians was an emotional rollercoaster. But I want to show them that young people are capable of more than just using their parents<83><82><82><82><84> money.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Challenging companies

As school pupils take the politicians on, Norwegian university students are infiltrating corporations and challenging them to be more sustainable.

As part of a project enabled by social enterprise the Innovation Effect, students are conducting research on Orkla, one of the largest companies in Norway, which sells food and home products and employs 30,000 people across more than 40 countries. The team of students has been scrutinising the company to see how it could be more environmentally friendly.

Guido says that working inside an organisation, while remaining independent, puts you in a powerful position. <83><82><82><82><93>A lot of people think of big companies as the bad guys.<83><82><82><82><9d> But working with business can make change happen, she adds. <83><82><82><82><93>We can be the bridge between them and the public.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The team of students presented their findings, which included a need for greater transparency and for more affordable sustainable products, to Orkla at Oslo Innovation Week this month. They spoke to a room full of business leaders <83><82><82><82><80><9c> including Orkla <83><82><82><82><80><9c> in the hope of inspiring other Norwegian businesses to take note.

<83><82><82><82><93>Everyone says we have to save the world,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Erlend Hjert<83><92><82>, 22, who studies at Kristiania University College. <83><82><82><82><93>And by challenging Norwegian companies, we<83><82><82><82><84>re giving an example of how we can do it.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Related: Why I started an LGBT club at my all-girls school

A disruptive force

This new generation of environmentally conscious students is well placed to make a difference. <83><82><82><82><93>When you<83><82><82><82><84>re young you have so many ideas and you<83><82><82><82><84>re not as naive as the big firms believe,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Caroline Str<83><92><82>mme, 25, studying at BI Norwegian Business School. <83><82><82><82><93>You<83><82><82><82><84>re not controlled by any firm because you<83><82><82><82><84>re not employed by them.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Guido agrees. <83><82><82><82><93>We have grit,<83><82><82><82><9d> she says. <83><82><82><82><93>Because you can<83><82><82><82><84>t just go to university and get a job now. You have to be creative.<83><82><82><82><9d>

But young people need to communicate their values to older generations effectively, they say. <83><82><82><82><93>A lot of older people say climate change is in the distance,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Anette Gutter<83><92><82>d, 22, studying at Kristiania University College. <83><82><82><82><93>We don<83><82><82><82><84>t think like that. But we need to say it in a way the older generation understands.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Growing up in a country with some of the world<83><82><82><82><84>s best environmental policies, as well as an economy based on oil wealth, means young Norwegians have strong opinions on the environment. But even more of this generation need to raise their voices too, says Wurschmidt. <83><82><82><82><93>Many teenagers believe they don<83><82><82><82><84>t have a say in the decision-making going on in the world, but of course we have a say in the making of our future. We, the youth, need to claim the voice that is ours.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Keep up with the latest on Guardian Students: follow us on Twitter at @GdnStudents <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and become a member to receive exclusive benefits and our weekly newsletter.

The green movement is on peoples minds. And students are at the heart of it. Young people understand the urgency. We are the ones that will have to inherit the problems, says Arnstein Vestre, 25, a student who works part time at Greenpeace Norway. Nature and Youth, a youth group with around 8,000 members aged 13-25, have filed a lawsuit against the Norwegian government, along with Greenpeace and other independent activists, over a decision to open up the Barents Sea for oil exploration. Oil is the issue thats most difficult to talk about in Norway, says Ingrid Skjoldvr, 23, leader of Nature and Youth. Were seen as the good guy internationally, but were not doing whats necessary at home. So we need to walk the walk. The case centres around a claim that the government has violated part of the Norwegian constitution that says future generations have a right to a healthy environment. Its unique because this clause hasnt been cited before, so its exciting, says Skjoldvr. Norway aspires to be a global leader on climate change and to inspire others to action, adds Vestre. But if we want to do that, we cant have this kind of hypocrisy.  Related: Want to make a difference at university? Join the clubs  Younger school students also have strong views on Norways environmental issues. At my city, my responsibility, a project organised by InterBridge, a social enterprise that aims to empower citizens to participate in global issues, 19 school children were given a platform to make their demands of politicians. After four weekends of workshops and discussions, they presented their ideas in front of them, and the public, at Oslo City Hall. These included making greater use of renewable energies, reducing meat and dairy consumption, and making bicycles more easily available to the public. Amanda Anvar, 14, told politicians she worries about Norways global effect. I want my children to grow up in a city where energy comes from a credible source, and where people on the other side of the world dont have to suffer for us to use it, she says. Norway should focus on renewable energy, rather than our precious dirty gold, meaning our oil, adds Michelle Ann Wurschmidt, 16. Presenting to politicians was an emotional rollercoaster. But I want to show them that young people are capable of more than just using their parents money. As school pupils take the politicians on, Norwegian university students are infiltrating corporations and challenging them to be more sustainable. As part of a project enabled by social enterprise the Innovation Effect, students are conducting research on Orkla, one of the largest companies in Norway, which sells food and home products and employs 30,000 people across more than 40 countries. The team of students has been scrutinising the company to see how it could be more environmentally friendly. Guido says that working inside an organisation, while remaining independent, puts you in a powerful position. A lot of people think of big companies as the bad guys. But working with business can make change happen, she adds. We can be the bridge between them and the public. The team of students presented their findings, which included a need for greater transparency and for more affordable sustainable products, to Orkla at Oslo Innovation Week this month. They spoke to a room full of business leaders  including Orkla  in the hope of inspiring other Norwegian businesses to take note. Everyone says we have to save the world, says Erlend Hjert, 22, who studies at Kristiania University College. And by challenging Norwegian companies, were giving an example of how we can do it.  Related: Why I started an LGBT club at my all-girls school  This new generation of environmentally conscious students is well placed to make a difference. When youre young you have so many ideas and youre not as naive as the big firms believe, says Caroline Strmme, 25, studying at BI Norwegian Business School. Youre not controlled by any firm because youre not employed by them. Guido agrees. We have grit, she says. Because you cant just go to university and get a job now. You have to be creative. But young people need to communicate their values to older generations effectively, they say. A lot of older people say climate change is in the distance, says Anette Gutterd, 22, studying at Kristiania University College. We dont think like that. But we need to say it in a way the older generation understands. Growing up in a country with some of the worlds best environmental policies, as well as an economy based on oil wealth, means young Norwegians have strong opinions on the environment. But even more of this generation need to raise their voices too, says Wurschmidt. Many teenagers believe they dont have a say in the decision-making going on in the world, but of course we have a say in the making of our future. We, the youth, need to claim the voice that is ours. Keep up with the latest on Guardian Students: follow us on Twitter at @GdnStudents  and become a member to receive exclusive benefits and our weekly newsletter.

webTitle: Norway faces climate lawsuit over Arctic oil exploration plans
trailText: Campaigners say decision to open up the Barents Sea violates the nationâs constitution and threatens the Paris climate agreement
headline: Norway faces climate lawsuit over Arctic oil exploration plans
standfirst: Campaigners say decision to open up the Barents Sea violates the nationâs constitution and threatens the Paris climate agreement
body:
A lawsuit has been filed against the Norwegian government over a decision to open up the Barents Sea for oil exploration which campaigners say violates the country<83><82><82><82><84>s constitution and threatens the Paris climate agreement.

The case is being brought by an alliance including Greenpeace, indigenous activists, youth groups, and the former director of Nasa<83><82><82><82><84>s Goddard institute for space studies, James Hansen.

Norway is seen internationally as a green role model by many for its pledge of climate neutrality by 2030, its reliance on hydropower and ambitious plans for electric cars.

But Conservative prime minister, Erna Solberg, could now be forced to appear before an Oslo city court on charges of violating Article 112 of the country<83><82><82><82><84>s constitution, which guarantees every citizen<83><82><82><82><84>s right to a healthy, diverse and productive environment.

Truls Gulowsen, the director of Greenpeace Norway, said: <83><82><82><82><93>Signing an international climate agreement while throwing open the door to Arctic oil drilling is a dangerous act of hypocrisy. By allowing oil companies to drill in the Arctic, Norway risks undermining global efforts to address climate change.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The case hinges on licences handed out to 13 oil companies - including Statoil, Chevron and Aker BP - allowing oil exploration in the Barents Sea, the most northerly point yet prospected.

Several exploratory wells are planned to open in 2017, and these could help wreck the Paris climate agreement<83><82><82><82><84>s ambition of holding global warming to 1.5C, the plaintiffs say.

In a letter to the prime minister seen by the Guardian, Hansen compares Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s behaviour to that of a <83><82><82><82><93>climate rogue state<83><82><82><82><9d>.

<83><82><82><82><93>I will not mince words, Mrs Solberg,<83><82><82><82><9d> he says. <83><82><82><82><93>Your government<83><82><82><82><84>s actions are utterly at odds with the scientific consensus that underpins the Paris agreement. Norway appears hell-bent on sabotaging the treaty before it has even come into effect.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Speaking to the Guardian from Oslo, Hansen added: <83><82><82><82><93>Norway is not all that green. It is burning 70% more fossil fuels per person than Sweden, and mining 20 times more fossil fuels than it needs for its own use. It is using that to create wealth but it is going to have to decide: does it want to be a rogue state or does it want to obey the rule of law?<83><82><82><82><9d>

Next month, a ruling is expected in a similar civil rights-style class action that Hansen and his grand-daughter, Sophie, filed against the US government, along with 20 other young people.

Shifting the climate fight towards the courts is a new strategy for campaigners, with high-profile legal actions being heard in the Netherlands and the Philippines in the last two years. Several more lawsuits are being prepared around the world, although campaigners will not yet share details.

The Norwegian case focuses on a constitutional amendment <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Article 112 <83><82><82><82><80><9c> passed in 2014 that has never been tested in a court of law.

This stipulates that <83><82><82><82><93>every person has a right to an environment that is conducive to health and to a natural environment whose productivity and diversity are maintained. Natural resources should be managed on the basis of comprehensive long-term considerations whereby this right will be safeguarded for future generations as well.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Gulowsen said: <83><82><82><82><93>The constitutional passage is unexplored territory but our lawyers believe we have a very strong case. The factual basis [of the claim] is there. The question is how the court will deal with the facts.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Another litigant, Ingrid Skjoldv<83><92><82>rfrom the Nature and Youth group, added: <83><82><82><82><93>We will argue in court that the Norwegian government has an obligation to keep its climate promises and will invoke the people<83><82><82><82><84>s right to a healthy environment for ours and future generations. This is the People vs Arctic oil!<83><82><82><82><9d>

One firm which is not participating in the new Arctic oil rush is Shell, which pulled out of a drilling project in Alaska<83><82><82><82><84>s Chukchi Sea last year, privately conceding reputational damage.

Publicly, Shell blames low oil prices for its retreat from the Barents this time. Tor Arnesen, the director of A/S Norske Shell, said: <83><82><82><82><93>Despite knowing we could have explored safely, both environmentally and technically, the current conditions are such that we globally have to prioritise activities with a shorter return on investment.<83><82><82><82><9d>

webTitle: The hunt for Norway's perfect Christmas tree
trailText: Each year, deep in a Norwegian wood, a tree destined for Trafalgar Square is carefully chosen and ceremoniously felled. Christian House shares the moment
headline: The hunt for Norway's perfect Christmas tree
standfirst: Each year, deep in a Norwegian wood, a tree destined for Trafalgar Square is carefully chosen and ceremoniously felled. Christian House shares the moment
body:
High above me, veiled in a freezing mist, a woodsman is climbing up
a colossal spruce in the name of Anglo-Norwegian relations. I<83><82><82><82><84>m in the depths of Oslomarka, a network of coniferous forests on the edge of Oslo where, every year since 1947, a tree has been felled, to be shipped to London and presented as the Trafalgar Square Christmas tree. There it will stand, decorated in traditional Norwegian style, until 6 January. The <83><82><82><82><93>Queen of the Forest<83><82><82><82><9d> (as locals call it) is given in gratitude for Britain<83><82><82><82><84>s assistance during the second world war. This year<83><82><82><82><84>s chosen one is 27 metres tall, weighs some 4 tonnes and is 95 years old. Oslo is surrounded by natural beauty; edged with woodland and a fjord, it is often described as <83><82><82><82><93>the blue, the green and the city in between.<83><82><82><82><9d> It feels truly wild, populated with moose, lynx, roe deer and even the odd wolf. <83><82><82><82><93>Two wolves live out here now,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Oslo mayor, Marianne Borgen. <83><82><82><82><93>They are not hunted, they are welcome.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Oslo is edged with woodland and a fjord, it is often described as <83><82><82><82><93>the blue, the green and the city in between.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Locals love the proximity of the countryside. <83><82><82><82><93>In the winter, you can take your skis, get on the tram and be on the slopes in 20 minutes <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and be back easily for city life in the evening,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Borgen, as we warm ourselves with cups of Norwegian coffee. <83><82><82><82><93>You can walk around for hours without meeting anyone.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Or try out a range of winter activities <83><82><82><82><80><9c> hiking the many trails, mountain biking, ice skating, fishing, picnicking and, of course, skiing and tobogganing the timeworn runs. If you don<83><82><82><82><84>t want to head straight back to Oslo, you can stay in municipal sports cabins, very reasonably priced, and scattered throughout the woods.

More than 80% of Oslo inhabitants visit the forest, says head forester Jon Christiansen. <83><82><82><82><93>My father used the forest, my grandfather, my great grandfather.<83><82><82><82><9d> Christiansen<83><82><82><82><84>s team scours the area, talent-spotting trees for London: the chosen few are then groomed like X Factor hopefuls to encourage a strong and symmetrical growth. <83><82><82><82><93>We mark it and we tend them through the years,<83><82><82><82><9d> he explains. <83><82><82><82><93>The most important thing is to clear the space around so it gets light from all angles.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The forest was also a muse to Edvard Munch, who created etchings and paintings of vampires creeping about in its shadows

Standing on a snow-fringed track, we are surrounded by trees and ice. A half-frozen lake cracks and creaks, cubist rock forms jut out of the earth, and in every direction legions of pines dissolve into the white haze.

A 20-minute trip back into the city, and I<83><82><82><82><84>m sheltering from the rain in the National Gallery. I find familiar compositions of mossy boulders and sopping wet firs in the pen and watercolour works of 19th-century romantics Johan Christian Dahl and August Cappelen. The forest was also a muse to Edvard Munch, who created etchings and paintings of vampires creeping about in its shadows.

From the city the T-bane train takes me north. It<83><82><82><82><84>s like getting from the Strand to the Cairngorms in 10 tube stops. I arrive at the Holmenkollen Park Hotel, north-west of Oslo and the unofficial gatehouse to the forest. Built in 1894 as a sanitarium, this fairytale mansion typifies Dragestil <83><82><82><82><80><9c> dragon style <83><82><82><82><80><9c> which blends medieval stave church architecture and Viking woodcraft. The hotel<83><82><82><82><84>s planed-log interiors and pointed tower will soon feature in the film of Jo Nesbo<83><82><82><82><84>s The Snowman.

The Holmenkollen Park Hotel's planed-log interiors and pointed tower will feature in the film of Jo Nesbo<83><82><82><82><84>s The Snowman

The following morning, the sky is cobalt blue and the air is sharp. Emboldened on a breakfast of rye toast and brunost <83><82><82><82><80><9c> sweet brown cheese <83><82><82><82><80><9c> I brave it to the top of the Holmenkollen ski jump. Looming dramatically behind the hotel, its launch platform is 200ft above the ground and delivers a knee-trembling panorama, from the crystal waters of the fjord to the rolling green woodland. Up in the Norse gods the view is humbling, almost spiritual.

Beneath the jump is the Ski Museum, which provides a good introduction to Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s national sport. There are skis made in 600AD, examples of trugers (snow shoes for ponies) that look like giant bagels, and a wind-force machine that can simulate the effect of a downhill slalom. And the museum<83><82><82><82><84>s stuffed elk is a masterpiece of taxidermy.

Leaving Holmenkollen, I set off on a two-mile ramble towards Frognerseteren, once a mountain dairy farm and now a popular restaurant. This is where the forest really takes over. Decent walking boots and thick socks are essential. The few hikers I encounter are sporting some serious kit. An ice-runner darts past with a fleeting <83><82><82><82><93>Hei-hei<83><82><82><82><9d> as I continue on, tentatively, up the hill. The constant tinkle of streams is the only other sound.

During the winter, walkers need to keep an eye on the time, as dusk sets in about 4pm. For Christiansen<83><82><82><82><84>s foresters, the challenge is to manage this terrain in a way that pleases the public. Visitors want a scar-free and diverse landscape, with trees of <83><82><82><82><93>all ages and all sizes at the same spot<83><82><82><82><9d>, rather than the uniform vistas created by commercial forests.

Arriving at Frognerseteren, I look back over the treetops to Oslo<83><82><82><82><84>s outlying homes. There is constant pressure from property developers to impinge on these woods but
Mayor Borgen is determined it won<83><82><82><82><84>t happen. <83><82><82><82><93>We don<83><82><82><82><84>t want to build,<83><82><82><82><9d> she says, simply. <83><82><82><82><93>We want to secure this for the people.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Essentials

Norwegian flies from London to Oslo from <83><80><9a><82>59 return (norwegian.com). Rooms at the Scandic Holmenkollen Park Hotel start at <83><80><9a><82>89 per night (holmenkollenparkhotel.no). The National Gallery is open Tuesday to Sunday, entry <83><80><9a><82>9, and the Holmenkollen Ski Jump and Ski Museum is open daily, joint entry <83><80><9a><82>12 (visitoslo.com)

We want to secure this for the people. Norwegian flies from London to Oslo from 59 return (norwegian.com). Rooms at the Scandic Holmenkollen Park Hotel start at 89 per night (holmenkollenparkhotel.no). The National Gallery is open Tuesday to Sunday, entry 9, and the Holmenkollen Ski Jump and Ski Museum is open daily, joint entry 12 (visitoslo.com)

webTitle: Norway denies rejecting Liam Fox request for trade deal taskforce
trailText: Official says Norway willing to âinitiate a dialogueâ, after report said country feared move would jeopardise EEA agreement
headline: Norway denies rejecting Liam Fox request for trade deal taskforce
standfirst: Official says Norway willing to âinitiate a dialogueâ, after report said country feared move would jeopardise EEA agreement
body:
The Norwegian foreign ministry has denied local press reports that it rejected a British request to set up a formal joint taskforce aimed at preparing a post-Brexit free trade deal between the two countries.

The business daily Dagens N<83><92><82>ringsliv earlier reported that Britain<83><82><82><82><84>s international trade secretary, Liam Fox, had asked Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s trade and industry minster, Monica M<83><92><82>land, to form a bilateral trade working group at a meeting on 14 September.

The paper said the request was passed to the Norwegian foreign ministry, which is coordinating Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s Brexit response, where it was turned down as likely to jeopardise Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s European Economic Area (EEA) agreement and <83><82><82><82><93>inappropriate<83><82><82><82><9d> while Britain was still a full member of the EU.

But a ministry spokeswoman said M<83><92><82>land had confirmed in a letter to Fox that Norway was willing to <83><82><82><82><93>initiate a dialogue<83><82><82><82><9d> in an attempt to <83><82><82><82><93>minimise any potential future disruption to the bilateral trade relationship<83><82><82><82><9d>. The letter said Norway was <83><82><82><82><93>flexible concerning the format of the dialogue, within the framework of our respective obligations<83><82><82><82><9d>.

No 10 said it was not true that Fox had asked for a joint working group on trade with Norway: <83><82><82><82><93>That did not happen. Liam Fox has had dialogue with Norway. It was part of an ongoing dialogue between the Department for International Trade and individual states. It was a friendly conversation as opposed to any specific requests.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The format <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and formality <83><82><82><82><80><9c> of preliminary bilateral trade talks is a highly sensitive issue. Fox is eager to begin work on negotiating new trade agreements with non-EU member states, but the UK is legally barred from signing any while it remains an EU member.

Last month the Australian trade minister was forced to row back on earlier enthusiastic noises about setting up a bilateral working group to <83><82><82><82><93>scope out the parameters of a future ambitious and comprehensive Australia-UK free trade agreement<83><82><82><82><9d>.

Steven Ciobo said any formal work on a bilateral post-Brexit deal would take second place to Australia<83><82><82><82><84>s trade talks with the EU, and could not begin until Britain had fully exited from the bloc.

Norway is not a member of the EU but has access to the single market though its membership of the EEA, which groups EU member states plus three of the four members of the European Free Trade Association (Efta) <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein.

Norway has said it could block an eventual UK bid for Efta membership. The European affairs minister, Elisabeth Vik Aspaker, said in August it was <83><82><82><82><93>not certain it would be a good idea to let a big country into this organisation. It would shift the balance, which is not necessarily in Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s interests.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The <83><82><82><82><93>Norwegian model<83><82><82><82><9d> had been held up by some pro-Brexit campaigners as a possible way for the UK to access the EU single market via the EEA, although the government<83><82><82><82><84>s insistence on controlling immigration and regaining parliamentary and judicial sovereignty after Brexit may rule that out: EEA membership requires the four EU freedoms, including the free movement of people.

Trygve Slagsvold Vedum, the leader of Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s Centre party, had accused the Norwegian government of dragging its feet in response to the Brexit vote, telling Dagens N<83><92><82>ringsliv that Britain was Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s biggest export market.

Britain accounts for about a quarter of Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s exports <83><82><82><82><80><9c> principally oil and gas, which account for nearly 90% of the total, and seafood <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and about 6% of its imports.
text: The Norwegian foreign ministry has denied local press reports that it rejected a British request to set up a formal joint taskforce aimed at preparing a post-Brexit free trade deal between the two countries. The business daily Dagens Nringsliv earlier reported that Britains international trade secretary, Liam Fox, had asked Norways trade and industry minster, Monica Mland, to form a bilateral trade working group at a meeting on 14 September. The paper said the request was passed to the Norwegian foreign ministry, which is coordinating Norways Brexit response, where it was turned down as likely to jeopardise Norways European Economic Area (EEA) agreement and inappropriate while Britain was still a full member of the EU. But a ministry spokeswoman said Mland had confirmed in a letter to Fox that Norway was willing to initiate a dialogue in an attempt to minimise any potential future disruption to the bilateral trade relationship. The letter said Norway was flexible concerning the format of the dialogue, within the framework of our respective obligations. No 10 said it was not true that Fox had asked for a joint working group on trade with Norway: That did not happen. Liam Fox has had dialogue with Norway. It was part of an ongoing dialogue between the Department for International Trade and individual states. It was a friendly conversation as opposed to any specific requests. The format  and formality  of preliminary bilateral trade talks is a highly sensitive issue. Fox is eager to begin work on negotiating new trade agreements with non-EU member states, but the UK is legally barred from signing any while it remains an EU member. Last month the Australian trade minister was forced to row back on earlier enthusiastic noises about setting up a bilateral working group to scope out the parameters of a future ambitious and comprehensive Australia-UK free trade agreement. Steven Ciobo said any formal work on a bilateral post-Brexit deal would take second place to Australias trade talks with the EU, and could not begin until Britain had fully exited from the bloc. Norway is not a member of the EU but has access to the single market though its membership of the EEA, which groups EU member states plus three of the four members of the European Free Trade Association (Efta)  Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein. Norway has said it could block an eventual UK bid for Efta membership. The European affairs minister, Elisabeth Vik Aspaker, said in August it was not certain it would be a good idea to let a big country into this organisation. It would shift the balance, which is not necessarily in Norways interests. The Norwegian model had been held up by some pro-Brexit campaigners as a possible way for the UK to access the EU single market via the EEA, although the governments insistence on controlling immigration and regaining parliamentary and judicial sovereignty after Brexit may rule that out: EEA membership requires the four EU freedoms, including the free movement of people. Trygve Slagsvold Vedum, the leader of Norways Centre party, had accused the Norwegian government of dragging its feet in response to the Brexit vote, telling Dagens Nringsliv that Britain was Norways biggest export market. Britain accounts for about a quarter of Norways exports  principally oil and gas, which account for nearly 90% of the total, and seafood  and about 6% of its imports.

webTitle: King of Norway reigns on Facebook after diversity speech
trailText: King Harald shook up the royal garden party with a speech in support of refugees and gay rights which has since gone viral
headline: King of Norway reigns on Facebook after diversity speech
standfirst: King Harald shook up the royal garden party with a speech in support of refugees and gay rights which has since gone viral
body:
A 79-year-old monarch is perhaps not the most likely person to deliver a rousing speech in support of refugees, religious tolerance, diversity and LGBT rights, and a royal garden party may not be the most likely place to hear it.

But an impassioned five-minute address on the need for inclusiveness and acceptance by Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s King Harald last week to 1,500 slightly startled <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but ultimately delighted <83><82><82><82><80><9c> guests in the park of the Royal Palace in Oslo has gone viral.

A spokeswoman, Marianne Hagen, said the palace had received a huge number of requests for an official English translation of the speech, which had received nearly 80,000 likes and been viewed more than 3m times on Facebook.

Interest in the speech has been such that Harald, who celebrated 25 years on the Norwegian throne earlier this year, was quizzed about it at length during a state visit to Finland this week, Hagen said.

Explicitly backing gay rights, the king, who will be 80 in February, said Norwegians were <83><82><82><82><93>girls who love girls, boys who love boys, and girls and boys who love each other<83><82><82><82><9d>. He also voiced support for religious diversity, saying Norwegians believed <83><82><82><82><93>in God, in Allah, in the universe <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and in nothing<83><82><82><82><9d>.

Calling on people to embrace <83><82><82><82><93>trust, solidarity and generosity<83><82><82><82><9d>, he said the notion of home could not be confined within national borders. <83><82><82><82><93>It is not always easy to say where we are from, what nationality we are. Home is where our heart is.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Norwegians came, the king continued, in all ages, abilities, heights, family statuses and careers, just as their musical tastes varied from Edvard Grieg to DJ Kygo. <83><82><82><82><93>In other words,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said. <83><82><82><82><93>Norway is you. Norway is us.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Rightwing, anti-immigration rhetoric has been mounting in Norway since the election three years ago of a centre-right coalition that has been widely criticised for trying to deport asylum seekers to Russia and last month suggested erecting a fence along the two countries<83><82><82><82><84> Arctic border.

The Nordic nation of 5 million is struggling to integrate an estimated 30,000 asylum seekers who arrived last year, including 5,500, most of them Syrian, who rode bikes across from Russia.

Harald insisted Norwegians came not only <83><82><82><82><93>from north Norway, central Norway, southern Norway and all the other regions<83><82><82><82><9d>, but from <83><82><82><82><93>Afghanistan, Pakistan and Poland, from Sweden, Somalia and Syria<83><82><82><82><9d>.

If they were surprised by the unexpected royal intervention, many of his citizens seemed genuinely pleased. <83><82><82><82><93>I<83><82><82><82><84>m immeasurably proud to be Norwegian, and to have such a great king and royal family,<83><82><82><82><9d> said one commenter, Yngve Gasoy Romdal. <83><82><82><82><93>Yes, we love this country!<83><82><82><82><9d>

Another expressing approval on the state broadcaster NRK<83><82><82><82><84>s Facebook page, Lars Jacob Sch<83><92><82>rer, said it was <83><82><82><82><93>really hard to be republican with this royal family <83><82><82><82><80><9c> they are unique, and down-to-earth like most Norwegians. What an example of Norwegian values in practice!<83><82><82><82><9d>

Even more enthusiastic was Rizwan al-Huq: <83><82><82><82><93>This is why we have you, dear king. When monarchy can live hand in hand with democracy, why not support a diverse society and a nation that chooses his own identity with such fine words?<83><82><82><82><9d>

Harald, a champion sailor who in his younger days represented his country three times in the Olympic Games, praised Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s beauty, from the <83><82><82><82><93>high mountains and deep fjords<83><82><82><82><9d> to <83><82><82><82><93>lush farmland and rolling moors<83><82><82><82><9d>, but urged its unity.

<83><82><82><82><93>My greatest hope for Norway,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said, <83><82><82><82><93>is that we will be able to take care of one another. That we will continue to build this country. That we will feel that we are <83><82><82><82><80><9c> despite our differences <83><82><82><82><80><9c> one people.<83><82><82><82><9d>
text: A 79-year-old monarch is perhaps not the most likely person to deliver a rousing speech in support of refugees, religious tolerance, diversity and LGBT rights, and a royal garden party may not be the most likely place to hear it. But an impassioned five-minute address on the need for inclusiveness and acceptance by Norways King Harald last week to 1,500 slightly startled  but ultimately delighted  guests in the park of the Royal Palace in Oslo has gone viral. A spokeswoman, Marianne Hagen, said the palace had received a huge number of requests for an official English translation of the speech, which had received nearly 80,000 likes and been viewed more than 3m times on Facebook. Interest in the speech has been such that Harald, who celebrated 25 years on the Norwegian throne earlier this year, was quizzed about it at length during a state visit to Finland this week, Hagen said. Explicitly backing gay rights, the king, who will be 80 in February, said Norwegians were girls who love girls, boys who love boys, and girls and boys who love each other. He also voiced support for religious diversity, saying Norwegians believed in God, in Allah, in the universe  and in nothing. Calling on people to embrace trust, solidarity and generosity, he said the notion of home could not be confined within national borders. It is not always easy to say where we are from, what nationality we are. Home is where our heart is. Norwegians came, the king continued, in all ages, abilities, heights, family statuses and careers, just as their musical tastes varied from Edvard Grieg to DJ Kygo. In other words, he said. Norway is you. Norway is us. Rightwing, anti-immigration rhetoric has been mounting in Norway since the election three years ago of a centre-right coalition that has been widely criticised for trying to deport asylum seekers to Russia and last month suggested erecting a fence along the two countries Arctic border.  The Nordic nation of 5 million is struggling to integrate an estimated 30,000 asylum seekers who arrived last year, including 5,500, most of them Syrian, who rode bikes across from Russia. Harald insisted Norwegians came not only from north Norway, central Norway, southern Norway and all the other regions, but from Afghanistan, Pakistan and Poland, from Sweden, Somalia and Syria. If they were surprised by the unexpected royal intervention, many of his citizens seemed genuinely pleased. Im immeasurably proud to be Norwegian, and to have such a great king and royal family, said one commenter, Yngve Gasoy Romdal. Yes, we love this country! Another expressing approval on the state broadcaster NRKs Facebook page, Lars Jacob Schrer, said it was really hard to be republican with this royal family  they are unique, and down-to-earth like most Norwegians. What an example of Norwegian values in practice! Even more enthusiastic was Rizwan al-Huq: This is why we have you, dear king. When monarchy can live hand in hand with democracy, why not support a diverse society and a nation that chooses his own identity with such fine words? Harald, a champion sailor who in his younger days represented his country three times in the Olympic Games, praised Norways beauty, from the high mountains and deep fjords to lush farmland and rolling moors, but urged its unity. My greatest hope for Norway, he said, is that we will be able to take care of one another. That we will continue to build this country. That we will feel that we are  despite our differences  one people.

webTitle: Summer activity breaks in Norway, Denmark and Sweden: readers tips
trailText: Scandinaviaâs great outdoors offers scenery on a gigantic scale, perfect for getting lost in on foot, two wheels or boat. Here are 10 of the best trips from our intrepid readers
headline: Summer activity breaks in Norway, Denmark and Sweden: readersâ tips
standfirst: Scandinaviaâs great outdoors offers scenery on a gigantic scale, perfect for getting lost in on foot, two wheels or boat. Here are 10 of the best trips from our intrepid readers
body:
Winning tip: Spectacular bike/train trip, Norway

Take the scenic 2<83><80><9a><82>-hour train journey from Bergen to Finse, the highest railway station in Norway (1,222 metres), which is close to the Hardangerj<83><92><82>kulen glacier, the film location for the planet Hoth in The Empire Strikes Back. From there hire a bike from Finse 1222 and spend the rest of the day biking Rallarvegen or the postal road. You<83><82><82><82><84>ll climb 100 metres in rocky high mountain landscape surrounded by glaciers before descending 1,300 metres (and 33 miles) to sea (or fjord) level, past waterfalls, through forested valleys and fjord farm landscapes to the town of Fl<83><92><82>m. Drop the bike off in Fl<83><92><82>m and return to Bergen by ferry, train or bus, or continue to Oslo.
<83><82><82><82> Railway timetable at nsb.no, day bicycle rental from <83><80><9a><82>67, finse1222.no
Brotherkin

Fast RIB trip out of Kirkenes, Norway

A fantastic way to see the Varangerfjord in the Arctic Circle in northern Norway is to take a trip on a fast RIB on to the fjord out of Kirkenes, followed by a spot of king crab fishing. You return to shore to cook and eat the fresh crab. All wet-weather gear is provided and the skipper has interesting information about the history of the region. It<83><82><82><82><84>s not an inexpensive trip but it<83><82><82><82><84>s a fun and exhilarating way to spend three hours. We thought it was one of the best things we<83><82><82><82><84>ve ever done and if you love seafood this is definitely something to do if visiting Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s far north.
<83><82><82><82> Three-hour RIB trip from <83><80><9a><82>140pp, pasvikturist.no
Fourpaws

Raudmelen mountain hike, Norway

One of the most spectacular but still accessible hikes in the famous Sognefjord region is this route up 972-metre Raudmelen (a six-hour round trip). The views of mountains, fjords, towns and glaciers are incredible. The walk starts in thick forest but soon you are on moss-covered tracks; as you near the top you may well encounter patches of snow even in summer. An extraordinary experience.
<83><82><82><82> bikeandhikebalestrand.com, balestrandofnorway.com
britysk

Lofoten archipelago, Norway

For the most breathtaking landscapes (with, unfortunately, breathtaking prices too) I recommend Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s Lofoten archipelago. I<83><82><82><82><84>ve visited only in the greener months so far. May brings snow-free lower elevations but if you<83><82><82><82><84>re a hiker you<83><82><82><82><84>ll very quickly be walking across white landscapes and need to take care due to melting and small avalanches. So aim for June to September. Kayaking and fishing should be possible too, but check your dates as the season is short and popular. Buses and ferries can get you around but plan ahead. As for where to stay, I suggest magnificent Moskenes<83><92><82>ya island, where there is the Lofoten <83><92><82><80> hostel (twin bed private room from $71) and rorbuer fishermen<83><82><82><82><84>s cabins (sleeping 2-6, from about <83><80><9a><82>145).
Unguarded

Family campsite, Jutland, Denmark

Hvidbjerg Strand near Blavand has loads of activities for children and adults. It offers cottages, camping and motorhome spaces. Facilities include indoor and outdoor play centres, swimming pools, trampolining, soccer, organised activities, routes for cycling and horse riding, and swimming from south-west facing beaches in the not-so-cold North Sea. You can either cook the fish you catch at the lake or buy a pizza on site and eat it around a fire on the beach. Residents get free use of the Wellness Spa. Usefully, the site is one hour from Legoland Billund. Dogs are welcome.
<83><82><82><82> Pitches from <83><82><80><9a><82>58 a night for a family of four, rooms for up to four from <83><82><80><9a><82>90 a night, all including activities and spa, hvidbjergstrand.com
Gordon Hargrave

Kayaking around Copenhagen

Taking in the sights on a kayak from the water is much more relaxing than using the busy roads, and it<83><82><82><82><84>s not so dear. There are plenty of canals around the city and you<83><82><82><82><84>ll get unusual views of the city centre, Christiania, and the opera house. We used Kayak Republic, located by a floating beach and cafe in B<83><92><82>rsen. The company offers guided trips, too, with double kayaks.
<83><82><82><82> One hour from <83><80><9a><82>17, kayakrepublic.dk
emilydevon

Family rafting adventure in Sweden

Building our own timber log raft was a real family team exercise: our 13-year-old became the knots and rope expert, the 15-year-old provided the brawn and the eight-year-old verbally supervised. Once it was constructed (overseen by instructors from Nature Travels) we had seven days to float down the Klar<83><92><82>lven river, enjoying wildlife, fishing, swimming and relaxing. Each night brought the excitement of finding the perfect camping spot in a grassy dell or spotless beach and the opportunity to explore using the Canadian canoe that we towed behind the raft. There were challenges: extracting the raft from overhanging branches using a folding saw, trying to stop a two-tonne raft by wrapping a rope around a tree on shore and holding tight. But these all added to the adventure.
<83><82><82><82> Five/eight days <83><80><9a><82>270/<83><80><9a><82>325 adult, <83><80><9a><82>135/<83><80><9a><82>163 child, including wild camping; provisions package <83><80><9a><82>88, naturetravels.co.uk
Coralies66

Cycling around B<83><92><82>stad, Sweden

From B<83><92><82>stad, we cycled from our house exchange holiday stay along the coast for about two hours to Torekov. From there we took the ferry across to the island of Hallands V<83><92><82>der<83><92><82>, a beautiful place with a small beach hut serving as a cafe on the east side and a lighthouse on the west side. There are many little bays where you can swim in, believe it or not, warm water, during the summer, which was amazing. Also there<83><82><82><82><84>s lots of wildlife on the island due to the low impact of humans. It truly was a great day trip along the coastal cycle path, with great views of the sunset in the evening when we were cycling back to B<83><92><82>stad.
Hamish Kale

Floating sauna near Uppsala, Sweden

Just outside Uppsala, around one hour north of Stockholm, lies the picturesque outdoor adventure area of Fj<83><92><82>llnora. Here you can swim, rent kayaks or go fishing in the summer or go ice skating on the frozen lake in the winter. Best of all is the floating sauna, which is amazing all year round. In the summer the feeling you get gazing at the huge blue skies and scenery reflected in the lake as the traditional wood-fired sauna warms you through is wonderful. In the winter, after your sauna, you can plunge in to the lake through a hole carved in the ice (or climb carefully down the steps) if you are so inclined. There are barbecue pits dotted all over with wood provided, so take sausages for dinner.
<83><82><82><82> destinationuppsala.se
Jacob Seabrook

Climbing Bl<83><92><82>rhammar mountain, Sweden

Two hours<83><82><82><82><84> drive from the Norwegian city of Trondheim is one of Sweden<83><82><82><82><84>s best-kept secrets: Bl<83><92><82>hammar mountain. A 10km trail (20km round trip), starting from Storvallen or Storulv<83><92><82>n, takes you across plains covered in heather and bracken. Following the lines of sticks to guide skiers in the deep snow, you can pick wild cloudberries to keep your energy up, and marvel at wild reindeer reflected in glassy mountain lakes. The view from the top of Bl<83><92><82>hammar makes it well worth the hike. Stop in the small fj<83><92><82>llstation rest stop at 1,086 metres for a cup of energising blueberry s<83><92><82>ppa and rest for a few minutes on the Scandinavian pine benches before the hike back down to civilisation. There is a train from Trondheim to Storlien, which is 4km from Storvallen.
<83><82><82><82> jamtland.se
gavingreene

Youll climb 100 metres in rocky high mountain landscape surrounded by glaciers before descending 1,300 metres (and 33 miles) to sea (or fjord) level, past waterfalls, through forested valleys and fjord farm landscapes to the town of Flm.
