webTitle: Norway has learned nothing from Anders Breivik massacre, says author
trailText: Ãsne Seierstad, author of a detailed study of the killer and his background, tells Edinburgh book festival audience âwe are hiding it under a carpetâ
headline: Norway has learned nothing from Anders Breivik massacre, says author
standfirst: Ãsne Seierstad, author of a detailed study of the killer and his background, tells Edinburgh book festival audience âwe are hiding it under a carpetâ
body:
Norway has learned nothing from the terrible events of 22 July 2011, when Anders Breivik killed 77 young people on the island of Ut<83><92><82>ya, according to Norwegian author and journalist <83><92><82><80>sne Seierstad.

<83><82><82><82><93>We are hiding it under the carpet and I don<83><82><82><82><84>t think we have learned anything from it,<83><82><82><82><9d> the writer told the Edinburgh international book festival.

<83><82><82><82><93>To some extent it wants to forget about it,<83><82><82><82><9d> she said of Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s reaction to the horror. <83><82><82><82><93>It doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t want to deal with what happened.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Seierstad, a foreign correspondent in Russia, China, Kosovo and Afghanistan before she turned her attention to the shattering events in Oslo and on Ut<83><92><82>ya, painstakingly researched Breivik<83><82><82><82><84>s life and the events leading up to the massacre for her book One of Us: the Story of Anders Breivik and the Massacre in Norway.

She also researched the lives of those who had been murdered, talking at length to the families of the dead, keen to represent them as <83><82><82><82><93>not just victims being hunted<83><82><82><82><9d>. Though the events she was describing were <83><82><82><82><93>as terrible as it gets<83><82><82><82><9d>, it had been rewarding, she said, to meet the parents and learn about the lives of the young people who had been attending the Labour party<83><82><82><82><84>s summer youth camp. The family members were given the right of veto over Seierstad<83><82><82><82><84>s manuscript; none of them exerted it and royalties from the book are to be donated to charities of the families<83><82><82><82><84> choosing.

The inadequate and slow police response to reports of the killings had been particularly notable, she said: <83><82><82><82><93>It wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t just one person who didn<83><82><82><82><84>t do his job but 35 or 40,<83><82><82><82><9d> she said. There had been what she called a <83><82><82><82><93>wait-and-see attitude<83><82><82><82><9d> <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but for every minute wasted, another life had been lost.

Security measures had not been much altered in Norway as a response to the tragedy, she said <83><82><82><82><80><9c> politicians deciding that to increase security for obvious targets of terrorism would increase the risk for softer targets such as schools and kindergartens.

Seierstad, whose previous book was the bestselling The Bookseller of Kabul, also said that Breivik had much in common with Islamic State. <83><82><82><82><93>He was building a new state in his head,<83><82><82><82><9d> she said. His fantasy Europe was white and Christian, in which apostates would be killed, or in certain cases forced to pay special taxes: a kind of reverse image of Isis<83><82><82><82><84>s vision.

And yet the violent anti-Islamic rhetoric that he espoused was not the most important motivation for the killings, she had concluded.

After examining Breivik<83><82><82><82><84>s life in detail <83><82><82><82><80><9c> including speaking to his mother days before she died from cancer <83><82><82><82><80><9c> she found <83><82><82><82><93>a childhood that a child shouldn<83><82><82><82><84>t have<83><82><82><82><9d>. Breivik was the son of a dysfunctional marriage that, when it ended, left him alone with his troubled mother, who had probably been the victim of childhood abuse.

At the age of four, the child had already been monitored by social services, and his inability to smile, play or connect with other people noted. His mother ricocheted between signs of hatred for her son <83><82><82><82><80><9c> telling him she wished he had never been born <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and displays of affection. <83><82><82><82><93>Love hate, love hate: the worst thing you can do to a child,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Seierstad.

Having been denied the opportunity to form relationships with his parents, he then struggled to relate to other children. A pattern was formed in which Breivik attempted to befriend, or failing that, impress, peers: first schoolmates, then contacts made online through games such as World of Warcraft; and later those he met on the web via rightwing and anti-Islamic groups. <83><82><82><82><93>If you are not loved you want to be admired; if you are not admired you want to be feared, in the end,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Seierstad.

Having failed to connect with the people around him, he also failed to connect with wider society: <83><82><82><82><93>His hatred for society, for social democracy and Norway came so much earlier than his anti-Muslim and anti-immigration ideas,<83><82><82><82><9d> she said, although these thoughts had formed the basis of a series of texts, distributed electronically on the day of the massacre, setting forth his views.

Seierstad said that she had believed Breivik to be gay for some time, but at length rejected the idea. <83><82><82><82><93>He was not afraid of women <83><82><82><82><80><9c> just afraid. He was afraid of getting close to people and being unmasked,<83><82><82><82><9d> she said.

His attempts to show off to those he encountered and attempted to befriend were rebuffed.

Even when he forayed to <83><82><82><82><93>the darker sides of the internet<83><82><82><82><9d> <83><82><82><82><80><9c> sites where conspiracy theories and fantasies about Muslims taking Europe were shared<83><82><82><82><80><9c> he was rejected. <83><82><82><82><93>Not because he was so weird, but because he was so boring,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Seierstad. She said that she believed that Breivik was not in fact truly committed to the anti-Islamic rhetoric he espoused. <83><82><82><82><93>He was never racist<83><82><82><82><9d>, she said, but it was among the far right that <83><82><82><82><93>he met his crew of hatred<83><82><82><82><9d>.
text: Norway has learned nothing from the terrible events of 22 July 2011, when Anders Breivik killed 77 young people on the island of Utya, according to Norwegian author and journalist sne Seierstad. We are hiding it under the carpet and I dont think we have learned anything from it, the writer told the Edinburgh international book festival. To some extent it wants to forget about it, she said of Norways reaction to the horror. It doesnt want to deal with what happened. Seierstad, a foreign correspondent in Russia, China, Kosovo and Afghanistan before she turned her attention to the shattering events in Oslo and on Utya, painstakingly researched Breiviks life and the events leading up to the massacre for her book One of Us: the Story of Anders Breivik and the Massacre in Norway. She also researched the lives of those who had been murdered, talking at length to the families of the dead, keen to represent them as not just victims being hunted. Though the events she was describing were as terrible as it gets, it had been rewarding, she said, to meet the parents and learn about the lives of the young people who had been attending the Labour partys summer youth camp. The family members were given the right of veto over Seierstads manuscript; none of them exerted it and royalties from the book are to be donated to charities of the families choosing. The inadequate and slow police response to reports of the killings had been particularly notable, she said: It wasnt just one person who didnt do his job but 35 or 40, she said. There had been what she called a wait-and-see attitude  but for every minute wasted, another life had been lost. Security measures had not been much altered in Norway as a response to the tragedy, she said  politicians deciding that to increase security for obvious targets of terrorism would increase the risk for softer targets such as schools and kindergartens. Seierstad, whose previous book was the bestselling The Bookseller of Kabul, also said that Breivik had much in common with Islamic State. He was building a new state in his head, she said. His fantasy Europe was white and Christian, in which apostates would be killed, or in certain cases forced to pay special taxes: a kind of reverse image of Isiss vision. And yet the violent anti-Islamic rhetoric that he espoused was not the most important motivation for the killings, she had concluded. After examining Breiviks life in detail  including speaking to his mother days before she died from cancer  she found a childhood that a child shouldnt have. Breivik was the son of a dysfunctional marriage that, when it ended, left him alone with his troubled mother, who had probably been the victim of childhood abuse. At the age of four, the child had already been monitored by social services, and his inability to smile, play or connect with other people noted. His mother ricocheted between signs of hatred for her son  telling him she wished he had never been born  and displays of affection. Love hate, love hate: the worst thing you can do to a child, said Seierstad. Having been denied the opportunity to form relationships with his parents, he then struggled to relate to other children. A pattern was formed in which Breivik attempted to befriend, or failing that, impress, peers: first schoolmates, then contacts made online through games such as World of Warcraft; and later those he met on the web via rightwing and anti-Islamic groups. If you are not loved you want to be admired; if you are not admired you want to be feared, in the end, said Seierstad. Having failed to connect with the people around him, he also failed to connect with wider society: His hatred for society, for social democracy and Norway came so much earlier than his anti-Muslim and anti-immigration ideas, she said, although these thoughts had formed the basis of a series of texts, distributed electronically on the day of the massacre, setting forth his views. Seierstad said that she had believed Breivik to be gay for some time, but at length rejected the idea. He was not afraid of women  just afraid. He was afraid of getting close to people and being unmasked, she said. His attempts to show off to those he encountered and attempted to befriend were rebuffed. Even when he forayed to the darker sides of the internet  sites where conspiracy theories and fantasies about Muslims taking Europe were shared he was rejected. Not because he was so weird, but because he was so boring, said Seierstad. She said that she believed that Breivik was not in fact truly committed to the anti-Islamic rhetoric he espoused. He was never racist, she said, but it was among the far right that he met his crew of hatred.

webTitle: Utya four years on: what's the mood in Norway?
trailText: Norway has reopened its summer camp on the island of UtÃ¸ya for the first time since 69 people were killed there in 2011. Weâd like to know the reaction in the country
headline: UtÃ¸ya four years on: what's the mood in Norway?
standfirst: Norway has reopened its summer camp on the island of UtÃ¸ya for the first time since 69 people were killed there in 2011. Weâd like to know the reaction in the country
body:
For the first time since Anders Behring Breivik killed 69 people on the island of Ut<83><92><82>ya, youths are returning to attend its annual political summer camp.

Four years after the nightmare in July 2011, the youth organisation of the Norwegian Workers party (AUF) have invited people to return to Ut<83><92><82>ya. The summer camp was reopened in 2013 but has since taken place in different locations, until this year. More than 1,000 young people are expected to attend the camp, which runs from 7-9 August, with activities and seminars planned for the weekend.

We<83><82><82><82><84>d like to hear what the mood is like in Norway. How do you feel about the reopening of the summer camp at Ut<83><92><82>ya? What is the reaction like in the country? We<83><82><82><82><84>d also like to hear from those attending the camp to help us better understand how Norway and Norwegians are affected by the event.

You can share your views with GuardianWitness by clicking on the blue <83><82><82><82><93>Contribute<83><82><82><82><9d> buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for <83><82><82><82><93>GuardianWitness assignments<83><82><82><82><9d>. We will feature a selection in our reporting.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers<83><82><82><82><84> content on the Guardian. Contribute your videos, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.

Four years after the nightmare in July 2011, the youth organisation of the Norwegian Workers party (AUF) have invited people to return to Utya. The summer camp was reopened in 2013 but has since taken place in different locations, until this year. More than 1,000 young people are expected to attend the camp, which runs from 7-9 August, with activities and seminars planned for the weekend. Wed like to hear what the mood is like in Norway. How do you feel about the reopening of the summer camp at Utya? What is the reaction like in the country? webTitle: Celebrating Norway: share your photos and stories
trailText: As Norway prepares to celebrate its National Day this weekend, weâd like you to tell us what makes your country so special. Share your photos and stories
headline: Celebrating Norway: share your photos and stories
standfirst: As Norway prepares to celebrate its National Day this weekend, weâd like you to tell us what makes your country so special. Share your photos and stories
body:
May 17 is Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s Constitution Day, an annual holiday where Norwegians celebrate the signing of the constitution declaring Norway an independent kingdom in 1814.

It<83><82><82><82><84>s known as a day of national celebration, and children<83><82><82><82><84>s parades take place across the country. The elementary schools and their marching bands walk through their respective communities and in the capital, Oslo the parade stops at the Royal Palace where the royal family greet the crowds from their balcony.

Constitution Day is celebrated amongst the Norwegian diaspora across the world. Many Norwegian immigrant communities in the United States and Canada organise festivities for the day. There are also celebrations in London with the Norwegian community holding their annual celebration in Southwark Park.

Are you taking part in the celebrations on the 17 May this year? Have you ever visited Norway and taken part in the festivities? We<83><82><82><82><84>d like find out what makes Norway unique. What are your favourite Norwegian customs?

Whether you are a Norwegian who<83><82><82><82><84>s celebrating 17 May in your homeland, or in one of the many Norwegian communities throughout the world, or someone who has fond memories of traveling around the country exploring its identity and customs, we<83><82><82><82><84>d like to see you photos and experiences. We will use the most interesting contributions on the site.

You can share your Norway photos and stories by clicking on the blue <83><82><82><82><9c>Contribute<83><82><82><82><84> button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for <83><82><82><82><9c>GuardianWitness assignments.<83><82><82><82><84> If you<83><82><82><82><84>d like to share your photo via Instagram, you can do so by using #GuardianWitness

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers<83><82><82><82><84> content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.
text: May 17 is Norways Constitution Day, an annual holiday where Norwegians celebrate the signing of the constitution declaring Norway an independent kingdom in 1814.  Its known as a day of national celebration, and childrens parades take place across the country. The elementary schools and their marching bands walk through their respective communities and in the capital, Oslo the parade stops at the Royal Palace where the royal family greet the crowds from their balcony.  Constitution Day is celebrated amongst the Norwegian diaspora across the world. Many Norwegian immigrant communities in the United States and Canada organise festivities for the day. There are also celebrations in London with the Norwegian community holding their annual celebration in Southwark Park.  Are you taking part in the celebrations on the 17 May this year? Have you ever visited Norway and taken part in the festivities? Wed like find out what makes Norway unique. What are your favourite Norwegian customs? Whether you are a Norwegian whos celebrating 17 May in your homeland, or in one of the many Norwegian communities throughout the world, or someone who has fond memories of traveling around the country exploring its identity and customs, wed like to see you photos and experiences. We will use the most interesting contributions on the site.  You can share your Norway photos and stories by clicking on the blue Contribute button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for GuardianWitness assignments. If youd like to share your photo via Instagram, you can do so by using #GuardianWitness

webTitle: Hanging with rock stars: affordable hikes in western Norway
trailText: The Norwegian fjords may sound like a pricey choice for hikers, but a new shuttle bus linking top trails with smart and comfortable huts makes Celia Toppingâs trip affordable as well as spectacular
headline: Hanging with rock stars: affordable hikes in western Norway
standfirst: The Norwegian fjords may sound like a pricey choice for hikers, but a new shuttle bus linking top trails with smart and comfortable huts makes Celia Toppingâs trip affordable as well as spectacular
body:
We walk like pilgrims, heads bowed, following in the footsteps of the man in front across the snow, some with walking sticks, others carrying heavy packs, all with the steadfast belief that we are damn well going to get a photo of ourselves on the Troll<83><82><82><82><84>s Tongue doing a star jump. The Trolltunga, as it<83><82><82><82><84>s known in Norwegian, is a spit of rock jutting out from a sheer face, about 700m above Ringedal lake in the Hardangerfjord region of south-west Norway, and the photo has become a tourist must-do over the past few years. It<83><82><82><82><84>s not the simplest of snaps to bag though: it involves a 22km circular hike from the starting point at the activity centre down in the valley at Skjeggedal.

This is my third hike in as many days, and I can feel my leg muscles protesting <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a rest day might have been a good idea. But touring the <83><82><82><82><93>Big Three<83><82><82><82><9d> of western Norway <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Kjerag, Preikestolen (Pulpit Rock) and Trolltunga <83><82><82><82><80><9c> is irresistible. The wonderful scenery combined with dramatic rock formations at each location make these three among the most popular trails in the country, plus the photo ops and bragability factor of standing out on these seemingly precarious rocks is a great draw. The fjord region in particular gets most footfall because of the excellent infrastructure, with well-marked paths and cabins for overnight stays.

And now an express bus route has linked these three hikes. Previously they were only reachable by car, but the bus <83><82><82><82><80><9c> with tickets from 490 NOK (<83><80><9a><82>39, bookable at tide.no, no cash taken on the buses) <83><82><82><82><80><9c> makes this notoriously expensive country much more accessible. Plus there<83><82><82><82><84>s budget accommodation at each stop, so the whole five-day trip costs me under <83><80><9a><82>500, including flights and breakfasts. Packed lunches can be made from the breakfast spread for a small fee at most huts and hotels, and <83><80><9a><82>15 is about the average cost of an evening meal. Alcohol is still a sticking point <83><82><82><82><80><9c> if you want to do Norway cheaply, go teetotal, or decant a bottle of duty-free hooch into a plastic trekking bottle.

The bus runs through the summer season. In the Stavanger region, where Kjerag and Preikestolen are found, it runs from June to the end of August and to Trolltunga in the Hardanger region, from July to August. I visit as soon as the bus route to Trolltunga opens at the beginning of July.

The snow should have disappeared a month ago, but it has been a long winter, and our small guided group, booked through Trolltunga Active (eight-hour guided walk <83><80><9a><82>43pp, trolltunga-active.com), has to negotiate the snowy path quite slowly. We reach our destination after five-and-a-half hours, shovelling down our packed lunches while taking in the views across the fjord. It<83><82><82><82><84>s a gloriously sunny day, and the mainly young crowd creates something akin to a festival atmosphere while we queue to get <83><82><82><82><93>that shot<83><82><82><82><9d> on the tongue.

When I peer breathlessly over the precipice, Daniel, our guide, tells me: <83><82><82><82><93>These hikes provide some of the most spectacular views of Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s natural wonders. They are not just sightseeing trips, but real challenges. You feel like you have really earned the thrill of standing on the edge.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Related: Norway's amazing hiking cabins

My trip had begun three days earlier in the pretty harbour town of Stavanger, where I stayed the night before making the three-hour bus journey to <83><92><82><9c>ygardst<83><92><82>l, for the first hike to Kjerag boulder, a tough five-hour walk including an ascent of a sheer rock face using metal rungs that ended in a gale force wind hitting me like a smack in the face on the cliff top. Sunglasses, hats, loose clothing and anything that isn<83><82><82><82><84>t fastened down is whipped off and flung over the side of the cliff, as if some mischievous invisible troll is having fun.

Without the late snow, the Kjerag boulder can be enjoyed in its full-suspended glory, wedged miraculously between two cliff faces, for the more intrepid to walk out on to. But with the buffeting wind and snowy conditions, I thought better of it and enjoyed instead the spectacular waterfall, mighty with snowmelt, cascading into Lysefjord, 1,000m below.

I celebrated afterwards with a beer at the <83><92><82><9c>ygardst<83><92><82> hut at the bottom but, because it<83><82><82><82><84>s not possible to stay overnight here, I took a (free) shuttle bus down to the Lysebotn mountain accommodation on the fjord shore. These cabins are part of an impressive network of more than 500 across the country, run by the Norwegian Trekking Association, and consist of small, neat chalet blocks around a common room and dining area. A dorm bed costs <83><80><9a><82>25 a night, including breakfast. At dinner, I sat on the small veranda to watch the sun not set, with my warming bowl of <83><82><82><82><93>hippie<83><82><82><82><9d> vegan stew and chatted to hikers from as far afield as Malaysia and the US, all here for the natural wonders.

A ferry takes hikers to the next challenge, through the dramatic Lysefjord, to Forsand, where a bus (<83><80><9a><82>22 return) runs up to the Preikestolen mountain hut for the starting point of the second trail. This hut couldn<83><82><82><82><84>t be less of a <83><82><82><82><93>hut<83><82><82><82><9d>. It is a magnificent Scandi-modern building, with hotel-standard rooms, fjord views and dorm beds again for <83><80><9a><82>25. Meals are served on giant slate tables in front of the hut and feature five courses of dishes such as tomato soup with egg, poached salmon, pork neck and salads, then home-baked cakes.

Related: Oslo on a budget <83><82><82><82><80><9c> from wild camping to city highlights for less

The second walk, from here to Pulpit Rock, is by far the easiest of the three, with toddlers and elderly people among those enjoying the two-hour trek up to a large flat shelf of granite projecting out over the fjord.

We are lower here (604m) than at Kjerag so the snow is not a problem, in fact, there are large freshwater pools connected by streams that are warm enough to swim in at this time of year, and I happily plunge in for a cooling dip on my way back down.

It was then a five-hour bus ride up to Odda for the Trolltunga hike, but the journey flew by while I gawped at a landscape peppered with spectacular waterfalls, which has earned this route the moniker of <83><82><82><82><93>most beautiful bus route in Norway<83><82><82><82><9d>.

The basic Trolltunga Hotel was my base in Odda, convenient for the shuttle service ferrying hikers up to the start of the trail in the morning. Such organisation and reliable services make a short hiking trip to revel in the majesty of the three <83><82><82><82><93>rock stars<83><82><82><82><9d> of Norway so easy ... the only thing to worry about is the aching muscles at the end of it.

  • Flights were provided by SAS, which flies to Stavanger from London, Aberdeen and Edinburgh from <83><80><9a><82>95 return, and BA (London to Bergen from <83><80><9a><82>84 return)

webTitle: Hungary 2-1 Norway (agg: 3-1): Euro 2016 play-off second leg  as it happened!
trailText: Minute-by-minute report: Hungary punished Norwayâs profligacy across both legs to reach a first major tournament in 30 years â though this was a game likely to have had the neutral reaching for the remote
headline: Hungary 2-1 Norway (agg: 3-1): Euro 2016 play-off second leg â as it happened!
standfirst: Hungary punished Norwayâs profligacy across both legs to reach a first major tournament in 30 years â though this was a game likely to have had the neutral reaching for the remote
body:
9.36pm GMT

Full-time! Hungary 2-1 Norway (agg: 3-1)

90 min +3: Hungary are through. Norway had so much possession, so many chances but could only score when 3-0 down on aggregate. This was poor viewing for the neutral but the Magic Magyars are back in a tournament for the first time in 30 years and they are dancing jubilantly on the pitch. We<83><82><82><82><84>ll see them in France in June. Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s players can book their couple of weeks in the sun. Thanks for reading. Bye!

Updated at 9.37pm GMT

9.34pm GMT

90 min +2: Bode is offside and, already on a booking, kicks the ball away to kill a few more seconds. Lucky not to be sent off, there.

9.33pm GMT

90 min: There will be three minutes added on. Three minutes that won<83><82><82><82><84>t seem too long when Hungary have been waiting 30 years for some success.

Updated at 9.33pm GMT

9.32pm GMT

90 min: Helland shoots acrobatically from the edge of the area. It trickles out for a goal-kick and that should snap Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s final straw.

9.31pm GMT

89 min: Helland has a pop from range. Kiraly smothers it. Hungary need to hold their bottle.

9.30pm GMT

Goal! Hungary 2-1 Norway (Henriksen 87; agg: 3-1)

87 min: And with the game beyond their reach Norway finally score! Berget is denied by Kiraly but Henriksen is on hand to convert the rebound, the ball nestling in the bottom right corner.

9.26pm GMT

Goal! Hungary 2-0 Norway (Henriksen 83og; agg: 3-0)

83 min: The 30-year wait is over! Dzsudzsak sends in a corner Bode flicks it on at the near post and it looks like Henriksen deflects the ball into his own net with no time to react. Hungary are on their way to France. Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s players can have the summer off.

Updated at 9.35pm GMT

9.24pm GMT

80 min: Bode is booked for a ludicrous wrestling tackle on Hovland. And Berget is on for Norway, in the place of Skjelbred.

9.22pm GMT

79 min: Another Norway chance <83><82><82><82> and again it fails to find the target. Johansen<83><82><82><82><84>s curling attempt is a few inches too high.

9.19pm GMT

76 min: A chance for Norway: Pedersen, after a Tettey attempt is not cleared, shoots low but is denied by the diving Kiraly.

9.18pm GMT

75 min: Hungary<83><82><82><82><84>s final substitution sees Nemeth replaced the hard-working Kleinheisler.

9.14pm GMT

72 min: And still Hungary look more dangerous. Dzsudzsak evades Allesami and his low drive is well saved by Nylland.

Updated at 9.16pm GMT

9.13pm GMT

70 min: The 24th corner is cleared. The 25th is delivered by Helland. It<83><82><82><82><84>s half-cleared to Skjelbred, whose shot is blocked and eventually Hungary get fully rid.

9.11pm GMT

9.08pm GMT

66 min: Hungary attack again. Lovrenscics shoots from a tough angle but can only find the side-netting.

9.07pm GMT

64 min: A rare Hungarian attack in this half sees Lovrenscics cross from the left after Kleinheisler<83><82><82><82><84>s decent through ball. Bode rises to meet the delivery but is called up for a foul on Hovland.

9.05pm GMT

63 min: Second change for the hosts sees the goalscorer, Priskin, replaced by Bode <83><82><82><82><80><9c> although the announcer in the stadium has got it the wrong way round. Chuckle, my pedantic friends, chuckle!

9.04pm GMT

61 min: Helland crosses from the right and Henriksen rises above Kadar but the Norwegian<83><82><82><82><84>s attempt is headed away for a corner. Helland delivers and Pedersen is whistle up incorrectly for a foul on Kiraly, who had actually dived for the cross but missed it completely.

9.02pm GMT

60 min: Forren sends a pass that is more hopeless than hopeful forward. Norway are now resorting to punts forward.

9.01pm GMT

57 min: Norway passing it back and forth but there are red shirts in front of them. When they inevitably lose possession, Hungary break again and the captain, Dzsudzsak has a go from a tightish angle on the right of the box after cutting in on his left. It takes a deflection and loops onto the bar. That was close to sealing it, though it<83><82><82><82><84>s a struggle to figure out where Norway will score once, nevermind twice.

8.59pm GMT

Seeing as the game is poor, let<83><82><82><82><84>s stare at wonder at this!

8.57pm GMT

55 min: Helland puts in another free-kick! His fourth set-piece since coming on nine minutes ago! This one is poor and Kiraly collects. At least there is a really good atmosphere to enjoy, because the football is poor <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and that<83><82><82><82><84>s being kind.

8.55pm GMT

53 min: Forren makes a fine but tough tackle on Priskin as Hungary attempt to break. That<83><82><82><82><84>s the first thing Norway have done that deserves credit so far.

Updated at 9.01pm GMT

8.54pm GMT

51 min: Norway win another free-kick. Helland takes once more, but from the left on this occasion. It bounces unchallenged in the area. Nobody gets on it and Kiraly saves. That<83><82><82><82><84>s awful from both sides <83><82><82><82><80><9c> nobody there to defend a dangerous cross but no attacker on hand to even attempt to convert it.

8.51pm GMT

48 min: Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s formation appears to remain the same despite those changes, with Henriksen the lone frontman. Helland delivers from a free-kick on the right. Three white shirts try to get on the end of it but none can connect and Hungary have a goal-kick.

8.49pm GMT

47 min: Helland<83><82><82><82><84>s first act is to deliver a corner. It<83><82><82><82><84>s hit long and Tettey heads wide at the rear stick.

8.48pm GMT

Kick-off

46 min: We are underway again. What can Norway do? Changes are certainly what the doctor ordered considering how short they were of ideas in attack.

Updated at 8.49pm GMT

8.47pm GMT

One change for Hungary <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Pinter on for Elek. And two changes for Norway <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Pedersen on for Elyounoussi and Helland on for Odegaard, who still looks out of his depth at international level.

8.33pm GMT

Half-time! Hungary 1-0 Norway (agg: 2-0)

Priskin<83><82><82><82><84>s early goal <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a stunner following a counter-attack <83><82><82><82><80><9c> has Hungary with one foot in next summer<83><82><82><82><84>s tournament. Norway remain short on ideas up front and really need to improve quick.

Updated at 8.46pm GMT

8.31pm GMT

45 min: There will be one minute added on. Norway are pushing a little more <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the break is coming at the wrong time for them.

8.31pm GMT

44 min: Norway go close! They win a corner. Another ball is crossed in by Odegaard and Hovland rises and connects well but is denied by Kiraly<83><82><82><82><84>s right-hand post.

8.29pm GMT

43 min: Another Norway cross. Elyounoussi delivers from the left after Allesami fed him. It<83><82><82><82><84>s too long for Odegaard and the ball trickles out harmlessly for a goal-kick.

8.27pm GMT

42 min: Priskin, still running hard after that dreamy goal, fouls Allesami near Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s endline.

8.26pm GMT

40 min: And that means Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s only real threat comes from crosses. Elabdellaoui sends one in from the right, Guzmics puts it out for a corner. Hungary clear and break. The counter ends up with Priskin but Elabdellaoui gets across to block just as he shot from about eight yards.

Updated at 8.52pm GMT

8.24pm GMT

37 min: Allesami tries to cross from deep on the left but sends the ball into the stands. Dismal. Norway have had one attempt on goal, Hungary have had four on target. The visitors lack someone capable of picking out a defence-splitting pass. They also don<83><82><82><82><84>t have anybody capable of running directly.

8.22pm GMT

35 min: Norway have had almost 70% of the ball but Hungary still look more likely to score. Kleinheisler sends a teasing cross in from the right and Lovrenscics arrives at the backpost but heads narrowly wide.

8.19pm GMT

33 min: Dzsudzsak ambitiously attempts to catch out Nylland by shooting from a free-kick wide on the right but it bounces once before the Norway keeper makes a simple collection.

8.16pm GMT

30 min: Hungary pass it across the back to a chorus of oles from the home support but a dawdling Fiola is closed down by Johansen and ends up kicking the ball out for a throw-in under pressure.

8.14pm GMT

27 min: And they create a decent chance! Allesami has an attempt blocked before Elyounoussi<83><82><82><82><84>s rebound is saved well by Kiraly, who gets down low. Odegaard takes the ensuing corner and Henriksen cannot direct his header towards goal.

8.12pm GMT

26 min: Hungary are by no means an impressive side but Norway really are a limited outfit <83><82><82><82><80><9c> perhaps illustrated by playing a 16-year-old in midfield.

Updated at 8.30pm GMT

8.11pm GMT

25 min: Norway are playing in what Pep Guardiola calls the ineffective U <83><82><82><82><80><9c> attempting to work it down one flank, finding no way through before going back and trying their luck on the other wing. Before going back again until they eventually run into trouble and squander control of the ball.

8.09pm GMT

22 min: Hungary are also working hard to press Norway in possession and when Kelinheisler dispossess Skjelbred, the Norway captain cynically and frustratedly commits a foul on halfway.

8.07pm GMT

20 min: Skjelbred is fouled by Kadar just inside the Hungary half on the right. But Norway continue to find very little space to squeeze through in attack. Odegaard, born eight years after the last time Hungary were in a major tournament, has been anonymous thus far.

8.04pm GMT

18 min: Hungary are now on top since the goal, probing for the goal that will end Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s challenge. Dzsudzsak does some dancing before a shot from around 25 yards is blocked by Forren.

8.02pm GMT

15 min: That also means no extra-time! But, obviously, Norway still only need two goals to progress.

8.00pm GMT

Goal! Hungary 1-0 Norway (Priskin)

14 min: Wow! A long ball is played forward by Kadar to Priskin on the left channel. He turns Forren before rifling a stunning effort home from just inside the area, leaving Nylland with no chance. Are Hungary back in the big time?

Updated at 8.18pm GMT

7.59pm GMT

12 min: Kleinheisler picks up possession in midfield and tries to play in Priskin, but Hungary<83><82><82><82><84>s lone striker is offside.

7.58pm GMT

10 min: Another cross on the left, this time from Allesami, is more threatening but Hungary defend well again and Dzsudzsak is allowed to break. Johansen is across to stop him quickly <83><82><82><82><80><9c> sliding in and picking up a yellow card for a foul. The Hungary captain rolls half a dozen times before immediately picking himself up once he noticed the referee, Senor Velasco Carballo reaching for his pocket.

7.55pm GMT

9 min: Henriksen crosses deep from the left but it troubles nobody and Lang heads it calmly back to Kiraly.

7.54pm GMT

7 min: It sounds like there is an amazing atmosphere in Budapest though! Norway are presently enjoying plenty of the ball in their own half but are struggling to find a way past Hungary, lined up in a compact 4-2-3-1.

7.51pm GMT

3 min: Hungary, having had such little of the ball in the first leg, will have to do a lot of defending again this evening. Gabor Kiraly, in goal for the hosts, is wearing trackies of course.

7.48pm GMT

1 min: Promising start for the hosts. Dzsudzsak has a shot from range that is saved by Nylland. The Hungary captain then wins a corner that is taken short to Kleinheisler <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Norway clear at their near post.

7.46pm GMT

Kick-off

1 min: Norway, in white with navy shorts, kick-off to a deafening chorus of boos. Hungary are in red with white shorts.

7.45pm GMT

We will now have a minute of applause in memory of those who lost their lives in the terrorist attacks in Paris on Friday night, plus recently deceased former players Marton Fulop and Pal Varhidi.

Updated at 7.57pm GMT

7.42pm GMT

I<83><82><82><82><84>m watching this on Hungarian TV due to a problem with our office box here in London. Unusually, the pundits and presenter are wearing the Hungarian kit! Can you imagine Pougatch, Dixon, Wright and friends sat in the studio with the three lions on their shirt? Actually, you probably can imagine Wright.

7.39pm GMT

The teams are out and the anthems are imminent.

6.58pm GMT

The starting cast

Hungary: Kiraly; Fiola, Guzmics, Lang, Kadar; Elek; Lovrenscics, Kleinheisler, Nagy, Dzsudzsak; Priskin. Subs: Bogdan, Vanczak, Szalai, Bosnjak, Nemeth, Bode, Pinter, Nikolic, Stieber, Leandro, Juhasz, Megyeri.

Norway: Nylland; Elabdellaoui, Forren, Hovland, Allesami; Johansen, Tettey, Odegaard; Skjelbred, Henriksen, Elyounoussi. Subs: Jarstein, Hogli, Strandberg, Nordtveit, Pedersen, Soderlund, Linnes, Valon Berisha, Berget, Selnaes, Helland, Hansen.

Referee: Carlos Velasco Carballo (Spain).

Updated at 7.06pm GMT

6.21pm GMT

Preamble

Remember when Hungary were a big name in international football? World Cup winners! They played in the Match of the Century against England at Wembley in 1953. But they have not been at a major tournament since the 1986 World Cup. Hungary are also mourning the tragic death of their former goalkeeper Marton Fulop to cancer at the far too young age of 32 and the passing of Pal Varhidi, who played in that 1953 game at Wembley.

They are only 90 minutes away from a long-awaited return thanks to Laszlo Kleinheisler<83><82><82><82><84>s 26th-minute goal. Norway were utterly dominant in Oslo though <83><82><82><82><80><9c> having 83% of possession but failing to score from 23 attempts on goal. Pal Andre Helland had a late header come back off the bar and even though they are away this evening are still fancied to haul themselves back into the tie.

Team news will be along shortly but while we wait here is that aforementioned match! Kick-off is 7.45pm GMT.

Updated at 6.23pm GMT
text: 9.36pm GMT 90 min +3: Hungary are through. Norway had so much possession, so many chances but could only score when 3-0 down on aggregate. This was poor viewing for the neutral but the Magic Magyars are back in a tournament for the first time in 30 years and they are dancing jubilantly on the pitch. Well see them in France in June. Norways players can book their couple of weeks in the sun. Thanks for reading. Bye! Updated at 9.37pm GMT  9.34pm GMT 90 min +2: Bode is offside and, already on a booking, kicks the ball away to kill a few more seconds. Lucky not to be sent off, there.  9.33pm GMT 90 min: There will be three minutes added on. Three minutes that wont seem too long when Hungary have been waiting 30 years for some success. Updated at 9.33pm GMT  9.32pm GMT 90 min: Helland shoots acrobatically from the edge of the area. It trickles out for a goal-kick and that should snap Norways final straw.  9.31pm GMT 89 min: Helland has a pop from range. Kiraly smothers it. Hungary need to hold their bottle.  9.30pm GMT 87 min: And with the game beyond their reach Norway finally score! Berget is denied by Kiraly but Henriksen is on hand to convert the rebound, the ball nestling in the bottom right corner.  9.26pm GMT 83 min: The 30-year wait is over! Dzsudzsak sends in a corner Bode flicks it on at the near post and it looks like Henriksen deflects the ball into his own net with no time to react. Hungary are on their way to France. Norways players can have the summer off. Updated at 9.35pm GMT  9.24pm GMT 80 min: Bode is booked for a ludicrous wrestling tackle on Hovland. And Berget is on for Norway, in the place of Skjelbred.  9.22pm GMT 79 min: Another Norway chance  and again it fails to find the target. Johansens curling attempt is a few inches too high.  9.19pm GMT 76 min: A chance for Norway: Pedersen, after a Tettey attempt is not cleared, shoots low but is denied by the diving Kiraly.  9.18pm GMT 75 min: Hungarys final substitution sees Nemeth replaced the hard-working Kleinheisler.  9.14pm GMT 72 min: And still Hungary look more dangerous. Dzsudzsak evades Allesami and his low drive is well saved by Nylland. Updated at 9.16pm GMT  9.13pm GMT 70 min: The 24th corner is cleared. The 25th is delivered by Helland. Its half-cleared to Skjelbred, whose shot is blocked and eventually Hungary get fully rid.  9.11pm GMT 23 corners now for Norway over the two legs. No goals.  9.08pm GMT 66 min: Hungary attack again. Lovrenscics shoots from a tough angle but can only find the side-netting.  9.07pm GMT 64 min: A rare Hungarian attack in this half sees Lovrenscics cross from the left after Kleinheislers decent through ball. Bode rises to meet the delivery but is called up for a foul on Hovland.  9.05pm GMT 63 min: Second change for the hosts sees the goalscorer, Priskin, replaced by Bode  although the announcer in the stadium has got it the wrong way round. Chuckle, my pedantic friends, chuckle!  9.04pm GMT 61 min: Helland crosses from the right and Henriksen rises above Kadar but the Norwegians attempt is headed away for a corner. Helland delivers and Pedersen is whistle up incorrectly for a foul on Kiraly, who had actually dived for the cross but missed it completely.  9.02pm GMT 60 min: Forren sends a pass that is more hopeless than hopeful forward. Norway are now resorting to punts forward.  9.01pm GMT 57 min: Norway passing it back and forth but there are red shirts in front of them. When they inevitably lose possession, Hungary break again and the captain, Dzsudzsak has a go from a tightish angle on the right of the box after cutting in on his left. It takes a deflection and loops onto the bar. That was close to sealing it, though its a struggle to figure out where Norway will score once, nevermind twice.  8.59pm GMT Seeing as the game is poor, lets stare at wonder at this! Evolution of the European Championship football #EURO2016 #ADIDAS pic.twitter.com/yTE3Snk2Nk  8.57pm GMT 55 min: Helland puts in another free-kick! His fourth set-piece since coming on nine minutes ago! This one is poor and Kiraly collects. At least there is a really good atmosphere to enjoy, because the football is poor  and thats being kind.  8.55pm GMT 53 min: Forren makes a fine but tough tackle on Priskin as Hungary attempt to break. Thats the first thing Norway have done that deserves credit so far. Updated at 9.01pm GMT  8.54pm GMT 51 min: Norway win another free-kick. Helland takes once more, but from the left on this occasion. It bounces unchallenged in the area. Nobody gets on it and Kiraly saves. Thats awful from both sides  nobody there to defend a dangerous cross but no attacker on hand to even attempt to convert it.  8.51pm GMT 48 min: Norways formation appears to remain the same despite those changes, with Henriksen the lone frontman. Helland delivers from a free-kick on the right. Three white shirts try to get on the end of it but none can connect and Hungary have a goal-kick.  8.49pm GMT 47 min: Hellands first act is to deliver a corner. Its hit long and Tettey heads wide at the rear stick.  8.48pm GMT 46 min: We are underway again. What can Norway do? Changes are certainly what the doctor ordered considering how short they were of ideas in attack. Updated at 8.49pm GMT  8.47pm GMT One change for Hungary  Pinter on for Elek. And two changes for Norway  Pedersen on for Elyounoussi and Helland on for Odegaard, who still looks out of his depth at international level.  8.33pm GMT Priskins early goal  a stunner following a counter-attack  has Hungary with one foot in next summers tournament. Norway remain short on ideas up front and really need to improve quick. Updated at 8.46pm GMT  8.31pm GMT 45 min: There will be one minute added on. Norway are pushing a little more  the break is coming at the wrong time for them.  8.31pm GMT 44 min: Norway go close! They win a corner. Another ball is crossed in by Odegaard and Hovland rises and connects well but is denied by Kiralys right-hand post.   8.29pm GMT 43 min: Another Norway cross. Elyounoussi delivers from the left after Allesami fed him. Its too long for Odegaard and the ball trickles out harmlessly for a goal-kick.  8.27pm GMT 42 min: Priskin, still running hard after that dreamy goal, fouls Allesami near Norways endline.  8.26pm GMT 40 min: And that means Norways only real threat comes from crosses. Elabdellaoui sends one in from the right, Guzmics puts it out for a corner. Hungary clear and break. The counter ends up with Priskin but Elabdellaoui gets across to block just as he shot from about eight yards. Updated at 8.52pm GMT  8.24pm GMT 37 min: Allesami tries to cross from deep on the left but sends the ball into the stands. Dismal. Norway have had one attempt on goal, Hungary have had four on target. The visitors lack someone capable of picking out a defence-splitting pass. They also dont have anybody capable of running directly.  8.22pm GMT 35 min: Norway have had almost 70% of the ball but Hungary still look more likely to score. Kleinheisler sends a teasing cross in from the right and Lovrenscics arrives at the backpost but heads narrowly wide.   8.19pm GMT 33 min: Dzsudzsak ambitiously attempts to catch out Nylland by shooting from a free-kick wide on the right but it bounces once before the Norway keeper makes a simple collection.  8.16pm GMT 30 min: Hungary pass it across the back to a chorus of oles from the home support but a dawdling Fiola is closed down by Johansen and ends up kicking the ball out for a throw-in under pressure.  8.14pm GMT 27 min: And they create a decent chance! Allesami has an attempt blocked before Elyounoussis rebound is saved well by Kiraly, who gets down low. Odegaard takes the ensuing corner and Henriksen cannot direct his header towards goal.  8.12pm GMT 26 min: Hungary are by no means an impressive side but Norway really are a limited outfit  perhaps illustrated by playing a 16-year-old in midfield. Updated at 8.30pm GMT  8.11pm GMT 25 min: Norway are playing in what Pep Guardiola calls the ineffective U  attempting to work it down one flank, finding no way through before going back and trying their luck on the other wing. Before going back again until they eventually run into trouble and squander control of the ball.  8.09pm GMT 22 min: Hungary are also working hard to press Norway in possession and when Kelinheisler dispossess Skjelbred, the Norway captain cynically and frustratedly commits a foul on halfway.  8.07pm GMT 20 min: Skjelbred is fouled by Kadar just inside the Hungary half on the right. But Norway continue to find very little space to squeeze through in attack. Odegaard, born eight years after the last time Hungary were in a major tournament, has been anonymous thus far.  8.04pm GMT 18 min: Hungary are now on top since the goal, probing for the goal that will end Norways challenge. Dzsudzsak does some dancing before a shot from around 25 yards is blocked by Forren.  8.02pm GMT 15 min: That also means no extra-time! But, obviously, Norway still only need two goals to progress.  8.00pm GMT 14 min: Wow! A long ball is played forward by Kadar to Priskin on the left channel. He turns Forren before rifling a stunning effort home from just inside the area, leaving Nylland with no chance. Are Hungary back in the big time? Updated at 8.18pm GMT  7.59pm GMT 12 min: Kleinheisler picks up possession in midfield and tries to play in Priskin, but Hungarys lone striker is offside.  7.58pm GMT 10 min: Another cross on the left, this time from Allesami, is more threatening but Hungary defend well again and Dzsudzsak is allowed to break. Johansen is across to stop him quickly  sliding in and picking up a yellow card for a foul. The Hungary captain rolls half a dozen times before immediately picking himself up once he noticed the referee, Senor Velasco Carballo reaching for his pocket.  7.55pm GMT 9 min: Henriksen crosses deep from the left but it troubles nobody and Lang heads it calmly back to Kiraly.  7.54pm GMT 7 min: It sounds like there is an amazing atmosphere in Budapest though! Norway are presently enjoying plenty of the ball in their own half but are struggling to find a way past Hungary, lined up in a compact 4-2-3-1.  7.51pm GMT 3 min: Hungary, having had such little of the ball in the first leg, will have to do a lot of defending again this evening. Gabor Kiraly, in goal for the hosts, is wearing trackies of course.  7.48pm GMT 1 min: Promising start for the hosts. Dzsudzsak has a shot from range that is saved by Nylland. The Hungary captain then wins a corner that is taken short to Kleinheisler  Norway clear at their near post.  7.46pm GMT 1 min: Norway, in white with navy shorts, kick-off to a deafening chorus of boos. Hungary are in red with white shorts.  7.45pm GMT We will now have a minute of applause in memory of those who lost their lives in the terrorist attacks in Paris on Friday night, plus recently deceased former players Marton Fulop and Pal Varhidi. Updated at 7.57pm GMT  7.42pm GMT Im watching this on Hungarian TV due to a problem with our office box here in London. Unusually, the pundits and presenter are wearing the Hungarian kit! Can you imagine Pougatch, Dixon, Wright and friends sat in the studio with the three lions on their shirt? Actually, you probably can imagine Wright.  7.39pm GMT The teams are out and the anthems are imminent.  6.58pm GMT Hungary: Kiraly; Fiola, Guzmics, Lang, Kadar; Elek; Lovrenscics, Kleinheisler, Nagy, Dzsudzsak; Priskin. Subs: Bogdan, Vanczak, Szalai, Bosnjak, Nemeth, Bode, Pinter, Nikolic, Stieber, Leandro, Juhasz, Megyeri.  Norway: Nylland; Elabdellaoui, Forren, Hovland, Allesami; Johansen, Tettey, Odegaard; Skjelbred, Henriksen, Elyounoussi. Subs: Jarstein, Hogli, Strandberg, Nordtveit, Pedersen, Soderlund, Linnes, Valon Berisha, Berget, Selnaes, Helland, Hansen.  Referee: Carlos Velasco Carballo (Spain). Updated at 7.06pm GMT  6.21pm GMT Remember when Hungary were a big name in international football? World Cup winners! They played in the Match of the Century against England at Wembley in 1953. But they have not been at a major tournament since the 1986 World Cup. Hungary are also mourning the tragic death of their former goalkeeper Marton Fulop to cancer at the far too young age of 32 and the passing of Pal Varhidi, who played in that 1953 game at Wembley. They are only 90 minutes away from a long-awaited return thanks to Laszlo Kleinheislers 26th-minute goal. Norway were utterly dominant in Oslo though  having 83% of possession but failing to score from 23 attempts on goal. Pal Andre Helland had a late header come back off the bar and even though they are away this evening are still fancied to haul themselves back into the tie. Team news will be along shortly but while we wait here is that aforementioned match! Kick-off is 7.45pm GMT. Updated at 6.23pm GMT

webTitle: Bicycles used by Syrian refugees to enter Norway from Russia to be destroyed
trailText: Norwegian recycling firm asked to scrap bikes for not meeting safety standards as refugees turn to Arctic circle route to access Europe
headline: Bicycles used by Syrian refugees to enter Norway from Russia to be destroyed
standfirst: Norwegian recycling firm asked to scrap bikes for not meeting safety standards as refugees turn to Arctic circle route to access Europe
body:
About 3,500 bicycles used by refugees to enter Norway from Russia are to be destroyed because they do not meet the Scandinavian country<83><82><82><82><84>s standards.

Rune Larsen, manager of scrapyard and recycling company Masternes Gjenvinning, in Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s Arctic region, said on Wednesday that his firm had been asked to destroy the bikes, employed by refugees at the remote Storskog border crossing, where pedestrian traffic is banned and drivers of vehicles are fined if they carry passengers across without the proper documents.

The number of people making the journey, many of them Syrians fleeing civil war, increased dramatically in September and October after governments in southern Europe cracked down on people trying to enter by that route.

According to officials, many Syrians obtain business or study visas to enter Russia and then travel through Moscow and Murmansk to Nickel, a town of some 12,000 people named after the metal mined there.

They then buy bicycles, take them in taxis to the frontier and pedal the short distance between the Russian and Norwegian border posts. Once in Norway, most of the refugees ditch the bikes.

Norway says more than 3,600 asylum seekers this year <83><82><82><82><80><9c> mostly Syrians <83><82><82><82><80><9c> have ridden across the border at Storskog, the only crossing between the two countries

Larsen said that, earlier this month, police asked the firm to take care of 25 to 30 containers with bikes, weighing about 50 tons all together. He said the bikes, of which he estimates 90% are new, violate Norwegian rules, although he could not say how.

In 2013 a Facebook group that advises Syrians about how to reach Europe, said that Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s border with Russia was impenetrable. It suggested that Syrians in Russia should buy a hot air balloon and fly it to Norway, instead of attempting to cross by land.
text: About 3,500 bicycles used by refugees to enter Norway from Russia are to be destroyed because they do not meet the Scandinavian countrys standards. Rune Larsen, manager of scrapyard and recycling company Masternes Gjenvinning, in Norways Arctic region, said on Wednesday that his firm had been asked to destroy the bikes, employed by refugees at the remote Storskog border crossing, where pedestrian traffic is banned and drivers of vehicles are fined if they carry passengers across without the proper documents. The number of people making the journey, many of them Syrians fleeing civil war, increased dramatically in September and October after governments in southern Europe cracked down on people trying to enter by that route.  According to officials, many Syrians obtain business or study visas to enter Russia and then travel through Moscow and Murmansk to Nickel, a town of some 12,000 people named after the metal mined there.  They then buy bicycles, take them in taxis to the frontier and pedal the short distance between the Russian and Norwegian border posts. Once in Norway, most of the refugees ditch the bikes.  Norway says more than 3,600 asylum seekers this year  mostly Syrians  have ridden across the border at Storskog, the only crossing between the two countries Larsen said that, earlier this month, police asked the firm to take care of 25 to 30 containers with bikes, weighing about 50 tons all together. He said the bikes, of which he estimates 90% are new, violate Norwegian rules, although he could not say how.  In 2013 a Facebook group that advises Syrians about how to reach Europe, said that Norways border with Russia was impenetrable. It suggested that Syrians in Russia should buy a hot air balloon and fly it to Norway, instead of attempting to cross by land.

webTitle: The Norway option: what is it and what does it mean for Britain?
trailText: Some Eurosceptics advocate a Brexit and a Norway-style relationship with the EU. We look at six key questions about this model
headline: The Norway option: what is it and what does it mean for Britain?
standfirst: Some Eurosceptics advocate a Brexit and a Norway-style relationship with the EU. We look at six key questions about this model
body:
Many of those who would like to see the UK leave the EU say Norway is the model to emulate.

The Nordic country retains many of the benefits of membership <83><82><82><82><80><9c> crucially, access to the EU<83><82><82><82><84>s common market <83><82><82><82><80><9c> without the same degree of <83><82><82><82><93>interference<83><82><82><82><9d> from Brussels. But euro enthusiasts counter that Norway also misses out on other key benefits while still making substantial contributions.

In an intensification of his engagement with the EU debate, David Cameron, the UK prime minister, will take on the arguments for this semi-detached relationship with the EU during a visit to Iceland on Wednesday.

Related: Cameron tells anti-EU campaigners: 'Norway option' won't work for Britain

So what is the Norway option?

You might call it the <83><82><82><82><93>nearly but not quite<83><82><82><82><9d> model for EU membership. Britain would have access to the single market but it would have no vote over EU rules.

Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s trade is dominated by the EU, and Norway is the trading bloc<83><82><82><82><84>s fifth most important import partner. Whether or not the country should apply for full membership has been one of the most dominant and divisive issues in modern Norwegian political debate.

After two referendums, the first in 1972 and the second in 1994, which both ended in marginal victories for the no side, Norway has negotiated a semi-detached relationship with the EU through its membership of the European Economic Area.

What does membership of the European Economic Area provide?

EEA membership gives Norway full access to the EU<83><82><82><82><84>s internal market, allowing it to trade goods with EU states without customs fees, except food and drinks which are subsidised by the EU. Iceland and Liechtenstein are also members of the EEA.

In return for that access Norway is obliged to implement all the EU<83><82><82><82><84>s laws relating to the internal market. As a result, Norway has had to implement about three-quarters of all EU legislation, including the working time directive.

What say does Norway have over EU rules?

None. Norway has representatives in EU institutions, but they have no decision-making power in how EU rules are drafted.

The country has been granted participation rights, but no voting rights, in several of the union<83><82><82><82><84>s programmes, bodies and initiatives, including the European Defence Agency, Frontex, Europol and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction.

Related: We pay, but have no say: that<83><82><82><82><84>s the reality of Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s relationship with the EU | Espen Barth Eide

Is the Norway option cheaper?

Yes, but not by much. In 2012, Norway was paying <83><82><80><9a><82>340m (<83><80><9a><82>245m) a year into the EU budget <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the tenth-highest contributor. The thinktank Open Europe estimates that the UK would pay 94% of its current costs (<83><80><9a><82>31.4bn annually) if it left the EU but adopted a Norway-type arrangement.

What about immigration?

The UK has more control over its borders than Norway, which is part of the Schengen border-free area. As a result, Norway has higher per capita immigration than the UK. However, as a signatory to the agreement, it does have a say in how it operates.

Are there alternatives?

Switzerland has a slightly more remote relationship with the EU. Its deal rests on some 120 separate bilateral agreements, many of which Switzerland started to negotiate after it rejected EEA membership in 1992.

These require Switzerland to follow EU law in the areas that give it access to the EU market. The Swiss also pay into the EU budget but less than the Norwegians. And they also have no say in how the rules are made.

Also, where the EEA is dynamic <83><82><82><82><80><9c> which means it trails the developments of EU policy in all relevant areas <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the Swiss arrangements are static. Crucially, too, they do not cover services, which are so central to Britain<83><82><82><82><84>s economy. If the UK adopted the Swiss model then financial services would probably not have access to the EU common market.
text: Many of those who would like to see the UK leave the EU say Norway is the model to emulate. The Nordic country retains many of the benefits of membership  crucially, access to the EUs common market  without the same degree of interference from Brussels. But euro enthusiasts counter that Norway also misses out on other key benefits while still making substantial contributions. In an intensification of his engagement with the EU debate, David Cameron, the UK prime minister, will take on the arguments for this semi-detached relationship with the EU during a visit to Iceland on Wednesday.   Related: Cameron tells anti-EU campaigners: 'Norway option' won't work for Britain  You might call it the nearly but not quite model for EU membership. After two referendums, the first in 1972 and the second in 1994, which both ended in marginal victories for the no side, Norway has negotiated a semi-detached relationship with the EU through its membership of the European Economic Area. EEA membership gives Norway full access to the EUs internal market, allowing it to trade goods with EU states without customs fees, except food and drinks which are subsidised by the EU. Iceland and Liechtenstein are also members of the EEA. In return for that access Norway is obliged to implement all the EUs laws relating to the internal market. As a result, Norway has had to implement about three-quarters of all EU legislation, including the working time directive.  None. Norway has representatives in EU institutions, but they have no decision-making power in how EU rules are drafted.  The country has been granted participation rights, but no voting rights, in several of the unions programmes, bodies and initiatives, including the European Defence Agency, Frontex, Europol and the European Monitoring Centre for Drugs and Drug Addiction.  Related: We pay, but have no say: thats the reality of Norways relationship with the EU | Espen Barth Eide  Yes, but not by much. In 2012, Norway was paying 340m (245m) a year into the EU budget  the tenth-highest contributor. The thinktank Open Europe estimates that the UK would pay 94% of its current costs (31.4bn annually) if it left the EU but adopted a Norway-type arrangement.
