However, as a signatory to the agreement, it does have a say in how it operates.  Switzerland has a slightly more remote relationship with the EU. Its deal rests on some 120 separate bilateral agreements, many of which Switzerland started to negotiate after it rejected EEA membership in 1992. These require Switzerland to follow EU law in the areas that give it access to the EU market. The Swiss also pay into the EU budget but less than the Norwegians. And they also have no say in how the rules are made.  Also, where the EEA is dynamic  which means it trails the developments of EU policy in all relevant areas  the Swiss arrangements are static. Crucially, too, they do not cover services, which are so central to Britains economy. If the UK adopted the Swiss model then financial services would probably not have access to the EU common market.

webTitle: The Guardian view on the UKs Norway option: No say. Still pay. No way | Editorial
trailText: Editorial: David Cameron is right to start taking the fight to the Eurosceptics. But his dismissal of the Norway option must now become a more positive case for EU membership
headline: The Guardian view on the UKâs Norway option: No say. Still pay. No way
standfirst: David Cameron is right to start taking the fight to the Eurosceptics. But his dismissal of the Norway option must now become a more positive case for EU membership
body:
Few are the parts of Britain<83><82><82><82><84>s political culture that can long resist the siren allure of the Nordic model. Social democrats gaze across the North Sea and view the Nordic lands as bastions of a benevolent cradle-to-grave welfare state they wish we could have too. Liberals meanwhile invoke them as rationalist oases of justice, tolerance and internationalism and ask why we can<83><82><82><82><84>t be like that as well. Scottish nationalists idealise them as economically successful and socially cohesive proof that small is beautiful and dream of Scotland joining their club. Last but not least, Tory Eurosceptics imagine Viking nations that proudly cherish their sovereignty while plundering the best of both worlds in trade with an otherwise spurned and nannying European Union.

Related: If the Norwegian model is so flawed, why is it so popular in Norway? | Letters

All this is a tribute to the special status that the Nordic countries have always enjoyed in the British imagination from Hamlet to Borgen. Sooner or later, however, all these visions have had to confront the more complex realities of the Nordic nations. The Scandinavian welfare state is not, after all, the modern utopia that its admirers wish. The Nordic record on community relations and justice turns out to have blemishes of its own. And small nations face hard choices in a globalised economy much as large ones do. Although they can certainly teach us much on many fronts <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Britain remains depressingly insular in its thinking about policy <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the Nordics have not in fact solved the problems of the modern world as conclusively as their admirers sometimes like to imagine.

The latest wake-up call came on Wednesday in Iceland when David Cameron finally delivered a reality check to Tory Eurosceptics about their dream of Britain leaving the EU and adopting a so-called Norway option instead. Speaking in Reykjavik at a meeting of the Northern Future Forum, Mr Cameron could hardly have been clearer in his conclusion that Norway, which has twice voted narrowly against joining the EU, was a highly problematic model for a post-EU Britain to seek to emulate.

If the UK left Europe and tried to replicate Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s relationship with the EU, the prime minister said, it would face some sobering decisions. It would still have to implement many EU rules in a Norway-type association, while having no say in drawing them up, might still have to allow free movement of peoples from the EU, would be liable to contribute to the EU budget, would lose the advantages of existing EU trade deals and would still have to persuade 31 European governments and parliaments to accept such a pick-and-mix relationship.

It is a daunting list of objections. Yet, if anything, it understated the severity of the problems. As a member of the European Economic Area <83><82><82><82><80><9c> alongside Iceland, Norway and Liechtenstein <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the UK could indeed negotiate full access to the single market, just as Nigel Farage has said it should. Yet membership of the EEA would not be automatic or straightforward. The quid pro quo for joining EEA access to the EU single market would be the maintenance of most of the regulations that Eurosceptics pretend they could dispense with, as well as the acceptance of new ones. Norway, for instance, now implements 93 of the 100 costliest EU regulations. The UK would also have to pay for its access. Norway is currently the 10th largest financial contributor to the EU, despite not being a member.

Nor would membership of the EEA achieve the migrant-free nirvana that some advocates of withdrawal fantasise about. All the EEA nations are members of the passport-free Schengen zone and EEA countries have a higher rate of immigration per head than the UK. In short, not only would the UK be faced with a very close regulatory relationship with the EU if it tried to be like Norway, but the UK cannot assume either that it would be greeted with open arms by the EEA if it tried to join.

Mr Cameron<83><82><82><82><84>s speech on Wednesday was a welcome sign. It is reportedly the start of an intensification of his wish to make the case for Britain to stay in a reformed Europe. On past experience, it is likely to boost public support for staying in. But Mr Cameron has flattered to deceive before. He may do so again. Now that he has begun to climb off the fence, he must not scurry back on to it if his MPs make his life difficult. More than anything, though, Mr Cameron needs to go beyond the case for not leaving. He must set out a more positive case for the kind of Europe, and Britain<83><82><82><82><84>s role within it, that he seeks. He has to take the fight to the Eurosceptics. Wednesday was a good start. But bigger battles must now be fought and won.
text: Few are the parts of Britains political culture that can long resist the siren allure of the Nordic model. Social democrats gaze across the North Sea and view the Nordic lands as bastions of a benevolent cradle-to-grave welfare state they wish we could have too. Liberals meanwhile invoke them as rationalist oases of justice, tolerance and internationalism and ask why we cant be like that as well. Scottish nationalists idealise them as economically successful and socially cohesive proof that small is beautiful and dream of Scotland joining their club. Last but not least, Tory Eurosceptics imagine Viking nations that proudly cherish their sovereignty while plundering the best of both worlds in trade with an otherwise spurned and nannying European Union.  Related: If the Norwegian model is so flawed, why is it so popular in Norway? | Letters  All this is a tribute to the special status that the Nordic countries have always enjoyed in the British imagination from Hamlet to Borgen. Sooner or later, however, all these visions have had to confront the more complex realities of the Nordic nations. The Scandinavian welfare state is not, after all, the modern utopia that its admirers wish. The Nordic record on community relations and justice turns out to have blemishes of its own. And small nations face hard choices in a globalised economy much as large ones do. Although they can certainly teach us much on many fronts  Britain remains depressingly insular in its thinking about policy  the Nordics have not in fact solved the problems of the modern world as conclusively as their admirers sometimes like to imagine. The latest wake-up call came on Wednesday in Iceland when David Cameron finally delivered a reality check to Tory Eurosceptics about their dream of Britain leaving the EU and adopting a so-called Norway option instead. Speaking in Reykjavik at a meeting of the Northern Future Forum, Mr Cameron could hardly have been clearer in his conclusion that Norway, which has twice voted narrowly against joining the EU, was a highly problematic model for a post-EU Britain to seek to emulate. If the UK left Europe and tried to replicate Norways relationship with the EU, the prime minister said, it would face some sobering decisions. It would still have to implement many EU rules in a Norway-type association, while having no say in drawing them up, might still have to allow free movement of peoples from the EU, would be liable to contribute to the EU budget, would lose the advantages of existing EU trade deals and would still have to persuade 31 European governments and parliaments to accept such a pick-and-mix relationship. It is a daunting list of objections. Yet, if anything, it understated the severity of the problems. As a member of the European Economic Area  alongside Iceland, Norway and Liechtenstein  the UK could indeed negotiate full access to the single market, just as Nigel Farage has said it should. Yet membership of the EEA would not be automatic or straightforward. The quid pro quo for joining EEA access to the EU single market would be the maintenance of most of the regulations that Eurosceptics pretend they could dispense with, as well as the acceptance of new ones. Norway, for instance, now implements 93 of the 100 costliest EU regulations. The UK would also have to pay for its access. Norway is currently the 10th largest financial contributor to the EU, despite not being a member. Nor would membership of the EEA achieve the migrant-free nirvana that some advocates of withdrawal fantasise about. All the EEA nations are members of the passport-free Schengen zone and EEA countries have a higher rate of immigration per head than the UK. In short, not only would the UK be faced with a very close regulatory relationship with the EU if it tried to be like Norway, but the UK cannot assume either that it would be greeted with open arms by the EEA if it tried to join. Mr Camerons speech on Wednesday was a welcome sign. It is reportedly the start of an intensification of his wish to make the case for Britain to stay in a reformed Europe. On past experience, it is likely to boost public support for staying in. But Mr Cameron has flattered to deceive before. He may do so again. Now that he has begun to climb off the fence, he must not scurry back on to it if his MPs make his life difficult. More than anything, though, Mr Cameron needs to go beyond the case for not leaving. He must set out a more positive case for the kind of Europe, and Britains role within it, that he seeks. He has to take the fight to the Eurosceptics. Wednesday was a good start. But bigger battles must now be fought and won.

webTitle: Cameron tells anti-EU campaigners: 'Norway option' won't work for Britain
trailText: Prime minister will use summit in Iceland to challenge the Leave campaignâs claim that Britain could negotiate a semi-detached relationship with EU
headline: Cameron tells anti-EU campaigners: 'Norway option' won't work for Britain
standfirst: Prime minister will use summit in Iceland to challenge the Leave campaignâs claim that Britain could negotiate a semi-detached relationship with EU
body:
David Cameron is to signal his determination to maintain Britain<83><82><82><82><84>s membership of the EU by issuing a direct challenge to anti-EU campaigners who claim the UK could negotiate a semi-detached relationship with Brussels.

Amid growing fear among pro-EU Tories that the Leave campaign is making most of the running in the EU debate, Cameron will say he sees little future for Britain alongside European countries that have opted out of the EU.

The prime minister, who has faced strong pressure from pro-European Tories to highlight the benefits of the UK<83><82><82><82><84>s EU membership, will speak out during an appearance at the Northern Future Forum in Reykjavik, Iceland.

He will use the chance of a summit in a European capital outside the EU to issue a point-by-point challenge to the claim by the Leave campaign that Britain could negotiate a credible relationship with Brussels from outside the EU.

Related: We pay, but have no say: that<83><82><82><82><84>s the reality of Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s relationship with the EU | Espen Barth Eide

Cameron will focus on the <83><82><82><82><93>Norwegian option<83><82><82><82><9d>, often cited by the Leave campaign, which has allowed Oslo to enjoy access to the single market without joining the EU.

<83><82><82><82><93>The prime minister believes it is important to highlight the questions Britain would face if it left the EU and followed Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s model,<83><82><82><82><9d> a No 10 source said. Downing Street pointed out that Norway is the 10th largest contributor to the EU budget and is bound by the rules of the single market without any say in the decision-making process.

Cameron<83><82><82><82><84>s intervention is a conscious decision to up the tempo on the EU ahead of the first formal roundtable negotiations on Britain<83><82><82><82><84>s demands at the European summit in December.

Downing Street had always decided it would adopt a low profile in the run-up to the Polish election last Sunday that resulted in the election of the Tories<83><82><82><82><84> sister party, the Law and Justice party.

Cameron will now engage more actively on two levels. He will embark on a new round of meetings with EU leaders <83><82><82><82><80><9c> he hosted Luxembourg<83><82><82><82><84>s prime minister, Xavier Bettel, in No 10 on Tuesday <83><82><82><82><80><9c> before in mid-November laying down in writing his demands to the European council president, Donald Tusk. Cameron will also adopt a less neutral approach as he challenges the claims of the Leave campaign.

Downing Street sources said the new tactics do not mean the prime minister has decided that the UK should remain a member of the EU regardless of the outcome of his negotiations.

The No 10 source said: <83><82><82><82><93>The prime minister<83><82><82><82><84>s plan is to renegotiate the terms of the UK<83><82><82><82><84>s relationship with the EU <83><82><82><82><80><9c> with the aim of staying in a reformed EU. But he rules nothing out if that negotiation is not successful.<83><82><82><82><9d> That is code for saying that Cameron would be prepared to recommend a vote to leave the EU if his negotiations fail.

But senior Tories say there is a growing realisation in Downing Street that the prime minister would face a difficult finale to his premiership if the negotiations fail. George Osborne, who has long made clear in private that Britain would suffer a major loss of influence if it left the EU, would be severely damaged by a failure.

Related: The Norway option: what is it and what does it mean for Britain?

Cameron, who will meet the Norwegian prime minister, Erna Solberg, and the Icelandic prime minister, Sigmundur Dav<83><92><82><83><92><82> Gunnlaugsson, in Reykjavik, will challenge the Leave campaign to answer five questions if the UK followed the Norwegian option:

  • Would the UK still have to follow EU rules, with no vote over how they are drawn up? A report by the Norwegian government says Oslo accepts about three quarters of EU rules with no votes in the EU institutions that set them.
  • Would the UK still be obliged to follow EU rules on free movement? Norway is a member of the European Economic Area, whose members are bound by free movement.
  • Would the UK still be forced to pay an EU subscription fee? Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s Europe minister said the country<83><82><82><82><84>s contributions are <83><82><82><82><93>more or less on par<83><82><82><82><9d> with what it would pay if it were an EU member state.
  • What would happen to the UK<83><82><82><82><84>s existing trading deals? The UK would have to leave the EU<83><82><82><82><84>s common trade policy, which covers 52 states.
  • Would 31 other governments and parliaments agree to the UK<83><82><82><82><84>s new relationship with the EU? The deal would have to be agreed by the 27 other member states plus Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein and Switzerland.

A Guardian article by the former Norwegian foreign minister, Espen Eide, offers help to Cameron. Eide writes: <83><82><82><82><93>Those campaigning for Britain to leave the EU and choose the Norwegian way can hence correctly claim that a country can retain access to the single market from outside the EU.

<83><82><82><82><93>What is normally not said, however, is that this also means retaining all the EU<83><82><82><82><84>s product standards, financial regulations, employment regulations, and substantial contributions to the EU budget. A Britain choosing this track would, in other words, keep paying, it would be <83><82><82><82><9c>run by Brussels<83><82><82><82><84>, and it would remain committed to the four freedoms, including free movement.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Related: EU exit: 'Norway option' would leave UK with 94% of current costs <83><82><82><82><80><9c> thinktank

Speaking to the BBC, Frans Timmermans, vice-president of the European commission, confirmed that Norway <83><82><82><82><80><9c> which is part of the Schengen open-borders agreement <83><82><82><82><80><9c> would have to be part of the EU<83><82><82><82><84>s plan for resettling migrants.

He argued that Britain <83><82><82><82><93>is already in a position to control its own borders<83><82><82><82><9d>, but indicated it would probably be possible to accommodate the UK<83><82><82><82><84>s demand for an exemption from <83><82><82><82><93>ever closer union<83><82><82><82><9d> and greater powers to set domestic VAT rates.

The Vote Leave campaign director Dominic Cummings, who used to serve as Michael Gove<83><82><82><82><84>s special adviser, said: <83><82><82><82><93>Vote Leave does not support the <83><82><82><82><9c>Norway option<83><82><82><82><84> for Britain.

<83><82><82><82><93>After we vote leave, we will negotiate a new UK-EU deal based on free trade and friendly cooperation. We will end the supremacy of EU law.

<83><82><82><82><93>We will bring back control including over trade deals and migration. This is safer than voting to remain which means giving more power and money to Brussels every year.<83><82><82><82><9d>
text: David Cameron is to signal his determination to maintain Britains membership of the EU by issuing a direct challenge to anti-EU campaigners who claim the UK could negotiate a semi-detached relationship with Brussels. Amid growing fear among pro-EU Tories that the Leave campaign is making most of the running in the EU debate, Cameron will say he sees little future for Britain alongside European countries that have opted out of the EU. The prime minister, who has faced strong pressure from pro-European Tories to highlight the benefits of the UKs EU membership, will speak out during an appearance at the Northern Future Forum in Reykjavik, Iceland. He will use the chance of a summit in a European capital outside the EU to issue a point-by-point challenge to the claim by the Leave campaign that Britain could negotiate a credible relationship with Brussels from outside the EU.  Related: We pay, but have no say: thats the reality of Norways relationship with the EU | Espen Barth Eide  Cameron will focus on the Norwegian option, often cited by the Leave campaign, which has allowed Oslo to enjoy access to the single market without joining the EU. The prime minister believes it is important to highlight the questions Britain would face if it left the EU and followed Norways model, a No 10 source said. Downing Street pointed out that Norway is the 10th largest contributor to the EU budget and is bound by the rules of the single market without any say in the decision-making process. Camerons intervention is a conscious decision to up the tempo on the EU ahead of the first formal roundtable negotiations on Britains demands at the European summit in December. Downing Street had always decided it would adopt a low profile in the run-up to the Polish election last Sunday that resulted in the election of the Tories sister party, the Law and Justice party. Cameron will now engage more actively on two levels. He will embark on a new round of meetings with EU leaders  he hosted Luxembourgs prime minister, Xavier Bettel, in No 10 on Tuesday  before in mid-November laying down in writing his demands to the European council president, Donald Tusk. Cameron will also adopt a less neutral approach as he challenges the claims of the Leave campaign. Downing Street sources said the new tactics do not mean the prime minister has decided that the UK should remain a member of the EU regardless of the outcome of his negotiations. The No 10 source said: The prime ministers plan is to renegotiate the terms of the UKs relationship with the EU  with the aim of staying in a reformed EU. But he rules nothing out if that negotiation is not successful. That is code for saying that Cameron would be prepared to recommend a vote to leave the EU if his negotiations fail. But senior Tories say there is a growing realisation in Downing Street that the prime minister would face a difficult finale to his premiership if the negotiations fail. George Osborne, who has long made clear in private that Britain would suffer a major loss of influence if it left the EU, would be severely damaged by a failure.  Related: The Norway option: what is it and what does it mean for Britain?  Cameron, who will meet the Norwegian prime minister, Erna Solberg, and the Icelandic prime minister, Sigmundur Dav Gunnlaugsson, in Reykjavik, will challenge the Leave campaign to answer five questions if the UK followed the Norwegian option: A Guardian article by the former Norwegian foreign minister, Espen Eide, offers help to Cameron. Eide writes: Those campaigning for Britain to leave the EU and choose the Norwegian way can hence correctly claim that a country can retain access to the single market from outside the EU.  What is normally not said, however, is that this also means retaining all the EUs product standards, financial regulations, employment regulations, and substantial contributions to the EU budget. A Britain choosing this track would, in other words, keep paying, it would be run by Brussels, and it would remain committed to the four freedoms, including free movement.  Related: EU exit: 'Norway option' would leave UK with 94% of current costs  thinktank  Speaking to the BBC, Frans Timmermans, vice-president of the European commission, confirmed that Norway  which is part of the Schengen open-borders agreement  would have to be part of the EUs plan for resettling migrants.  He argued that Britain is already in a position to control its own borders, but indicated it would probably be possible to accommodate the UKs demand for an exemption from ever closer union and greater powers to set domestic VAT rates. The Vote Leave campaign director Dominic Cummings, who used to serve as Michael Goves special adviser, said: Vote Leave does not support the Norway option for Britain. After we vote leave, we will negotiate a new UK-EU deal based on free trade and friendly cooperation. We will end the supremacy of EU law. We will bring back control including over trade deals and migration. This is safer than voting to remain which means giving more power and money to Brussels every year.

webTitle: Norway v England: Women's World Cup 2015  as it happened
trailText: A blockbusting strike from Lucy Bronze gave England their first ever World Cup knockout win and completed their stirring comeback from a goal down; they now play the hosts, Canada, in Saturdayâs quarter-final
headline: Norway v England: Women's World Cup 2015 â as it happened
standfirst: A blockbusting strike from Lucy Bronze gave England their first ever World Cup knockout win and completed their stirring comeback from a goal down; they now play the hosts, Canada, in Saturdayâs quarter-final
body:
11.54pm BST

Anyway, thanks all for your comments and company - night-night.

11.50pm BST

FULL-TIME! NORWAY 1-2 ENGLAND!

What a result that is! England were miserable for the best part of an hour, but Steph Houghton<83><82><82><82><84>s perfectly cliched captain<83><82><82><82><84>s goal gave them an equaliser, and after that, the combination play of Scott and Taylor, allied to the bite of Chapman, the trickery of Carney and fitness and drive of everyone allowed them to take control. They<83><82><82><82><84>ll play Canada on Saturday night for a place in the semi-final, and, given the draw, will fancy themselves for the final. Well!

Updated at 11.59pm BST

11.49pm BST

90+2 min The crowd boo as Scott again burrows to the corner, and we<83><82><82><82><84>re at last chance time - but again, Scott finds he way to the flag and rinses more time. England have been excellent since going behind, and particularly since going ahead; Norway have had almost nowt.

11.47pm BST

90 min There shall be three minutes of stoppage time, as Scott again holds the ball in the corner - they<83><82><82><82><84>re not asking who she is anymore.

11.45pm BST

89 min England are perilously close to getting through!

11.44pm BST

88 min This is great from Hegerberg, running away from Scott down the left, cutting in, and crunching a shot from 20 yards just over the top.

11.43pm BST

87 min Wold departs, Utland arrives.

11.43pm BST

87 min <83><82><82><82><93>I<83><82><82><82><84>ve only watched the second half, so can<83><82><82><82><84>t say for certain,<83><82><82><82><9d> emails Andrew Gerrard, <83><82><82><82><93>but for the first 15 mins Norway were much faster and physical. Rather than the substitutions being the difference, is it possible that Norway are just knackered and England kept more in reserve in the heat?<83><82><82><82><9d>

Yes - as I said, Norway look shattered. Also, England have rotated through the competition, so, though you sacrifice cohesion, you get freshness.

11.42pm BST

85 min England looking for the corners now, and when they can<83><82><82><82><84>t find them, just to keep possession - they look comfortable and composed, Taylor almost happening upon a third when Lund and Thorisdottir gets themselves into a muddle inside their own box.

11.39pm BST

83 min Scott and Taylor haver made a difference, but the changes have also allowed Chapman into an area of the pitch where she can rattle Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s midfield, instead of hoping to get in the way of their attackers.

11.38pm BST

81 min Scott, again winde on the right, crosses into Carney, who lays back for Chapman, accepts the return, and from outside the box, hurries through a snap-shot that has Hjelmseth scurrying to shovel around the post.

11.37pm BST

80 min I<83><82><82><82><84>ll say it. There<83><82><82><82><84>s more chance of a third England goal than a Norway equaliser. I wonder if Sampson will reward the players who<83><82><82><82><84>ve changed the game with a start next time, should England his team win.

11.35pm BST

78 min Norway look absolutely shattered.

11.32pm BST

WHAT A GOAL! Norway 1-2 England (Bronze, 76 mins)

Scott, who always has time on the ball, exchanges passes with Taylor, the kind of composed little move that was beyond England in the first half. Scott then rolls back into the path of Bronze, just outside the box, right corner, and she absolutely annihilates a shot that screeches into the near top corner. WHAT A GOAL!

Updated at 11.45pm BST

11.31pm BST

74 min But there<83><82><82><82><84>s a warning, Gulbransen curving a ball between Bassett and Bronze - she<83><82><82><82><84>s a player - and Hegerberg burns by the latter, clattering a shot into Bardsley<83><82><82><82><84>s fingers. She could do with improving her finishing, and once she does, she<83><82><82><82><84>ll be a serious threat, because her pace is something else.

11.29pm BST

72 min It<83><82><82><82><84>s not all England, but it<83><82><82><82><84>s certainly significantly England. They<83><82><82><82><84>re pressing higher up the pitch and forcing errors from a side that looks like it<83><82><82><82><84>s tiring.

11.28pm BST

72 min On the subject of Houghton<83><82><82><82><84>s goal, it probably looks more like this:

11.27pm BST

70 min Thorsnes replaces Minde, and when a long cross eludes Houghton and Bassett, either side of Herlovsen, she stretches into a shot that flies only just over the bar.

11.25pm BST

68 min The ball ricochets around the Norway box as Scott laces over a low cross - Norway aren<83><82><82><82><84>t enjoying this now, but manage to scramble clear.

Updated at 11.26pm BST

11.24pm BST

67 min <83><82><82><82><93>My friends and I beat Al Murray, Pub Landlord, and his team in a pub quiz earlier this evening,<83><82><82><82><9d> emails Alys Barber-Rogers. <83><82><82><82><93>I<83><82><82><82><84>m taking this as an omen either that England will win because I<83><82><82><82><84>m on a roll or that they<83><82><82><82><84>ll lose because I<83><82><82><82><84>ve upset a classic English comic. I<83><82><82><82><84>m very conflicted.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Seems fairly clear that this is shaping up into an archetypal penalty defeat.

11.22pm BST

65 min Carney, who might be better in a central role, turns up in a central position and spreads right to Bronze. She clips a low cross into Taylor, showing early, but she can<83><82><82><82><84>t quite escape Lund. Still, a promising sign.

11.20pm BST

63 min Taylor replaces Duggan, and suddenly England have momentum. There<83><82><82><82><84>s also a stoppage as Chapman clatters Gulbransen.

Updated at 11.29pm BST

11.17pm BST

GOAL! Norway 1-1 England 1 (Houghton 61)

Scott clips the corner towards the penalty spot, and there<83><82><82><82><84>s Houghton with a captain<83><82><82><82><84>s goal, brilliantly losing her marker to run inside and thud-guide a header into the bottom-right. It<83><82><82><82><84>s not dissimilar in execution to this:

But also minds of this:

Updated at 11.50pm BST

11.17pm BST

60 min Williams sends a ball out wide to Scott, alone on the right. No help arrives, so she<83><82><82><82><84>s forced to win a corner.

11.16pm BST

60 min Minde sends a long ball over the top for Herlovsen, racing between Houghton and Bassett. But it pitches and skips away from her - just.

11.15pm BST

59 min Jodie Taylor looks like she<83><82><82><82><84>s ready to come on, which might help England - if nothing else, it might encourage them to get the ball into the box, even if the midfield balance still isn<83><82><82><82><84>t right.

11.13pm BST

57 min England are back to a 4-2-3-1, with Scott on the right, Carney on the left and Chapman in the middle, or, put another way, still no help for Duggan. It<83><82><82><82><84>s hard not to conclude that Sampson is outsmarting himself here.

Updated at 11.14pm BST

11.11pm BST

GOAL! Norway 1-0 England (Gulbransen)

A Steve Bould special. Mykjaland whips one into the near post, Gulbransen steals in front of Rafferty, and flicks it superbly off her forehead and behind, the ball whizzing in off the bar.

Updated at 11.23pm BST

11.10pm BST

54 min Avant-garde - Scott comes on for Kirby, with England defending a corner, needlessly conceded by Bardsley. That said, she<83><82><82><82><84>s a lot more use in the circumstance than who she<83><82><82><82><84>s replaced.

Updated at 11.12pm BST

11.09pm BST

52 min Jill Scott is taking some advice, and looks set to take the long walk to join us. Let<83><82><82><82><84>s hope she does some good getting in the way.

11.08pm BST

51 min Norway win a corner down the right, Mykjaland over to take it. She sends an outswinger into the middle, and Bardsley, who<83><82><82><82><84>s been England<83><82><82><82><84>s best player, is out to claim well.

11.05pm BST

49 min Williams, who<83><82><82><82><84>s passing hasn<83><82><82><82><84>t been great, looks for Duggan down the left. It<83><82><82><82><84>s not perfect, but the way the ball skips off the turf and away must be a right annoyance.

11.04pm BST

47 min Kirby, infield, sends Carney away down the right - and there<83><82><82><82><84>s Hegerberg, haring after her like nobody<83><82><82><82><84>s business, shoulder-charging her off the ball to win the throw.

11.02pm BST

46 min Bronze burrows down the right immediately, Wold eventually stopping her, but that<83><82><82><82><84>s the kind of positive start they needed to make.

11.02pm BST

46 min England get us off again.

11.01pm BST

England don<83><82><82><82><84>t look like they<83><82><82><82><84>re making any changes - slightly odd - while Norway bring Thorisdottir on for Ronning, the captain, presumed injured.

Updated at 11.03pm BST

11.00pm BST

Out come the players again...

10.59pm BST

Half-time email: <83><82><82><82><93>It doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t matter what would improve what,<83><82><82><82><9d> orders Matt Dony. <83><82><82><82><93>Surely, in the eyes of all right-thinking people, drum and bass/jungle (they<83><82><82><82><84>re near enough the same!) died the day Roni Size wandered off with Ok Computer<83><82><82><82><84>s Mercury Prize.<83><82><82><82><9d>

New Forms is a great album - granted, not as good, but still good, an exceptional live.

10.47pm BST

Half-time: Norway 0-0 England

Not at all good by England. They look like they<83><82><82><82><84>ve been sent out to combat, rather than assert, and it<83><82><82><82><84>s showing.

Updated at 10.48pm BST

10.47pm BST

45+1 min Kirby, now on the right, forces a mistake out of Mjelde, harrying her down the by-line. But with with the opportunity to shoot, she instead settled for a corner that there may not be time to take. There is, but - it<83><82><82><82><84>s headed clear, and Carney rams a shot over the top.

10.45pm BST

45 min There shall be a single, solitary added minute.

10.45pm BST

45 min Two more corners forced by England, the second drilled flat for Houghton. She times her run and jump well, but her header<83><82><82><82><84>s blocked, and an infringement or other allows Norway to reset.

10.44pm BST

42 min A suit at a top league club told me that Laura Bassett was an accident waiting to happen, but she<83><82><82><82><84>s been excellent so far. Again, she stands up well to a long ball looking for Minde, forcing the foul that allows England to clear.

10.41pm BST

40 min Bronze turns a backpass short, and Hegerberg is onto it in a trice, winding up a shot as Bronze leans right into her; if she goes down, it<83><82><82><82><84>s a penalty. But she stays up, welting a effort into Bardsley<83><82><82><82><84>s midriff, when a more studied finish could have given her no chance.

Updated at 11.04pm BST

10.39pm BST

39 min Talking of techno, I found myself in a discotheque on a boat on the Seine recently - I<83><82><82><82><84>d forgotten how horrific it is. England have changed to a 4-2-3-1, the specific aim to get Chapman on Mykjaland.

10.38pm BST

38 min <83><82><82><82><93>Human Traffic is the last word on the national anthem for me<83><82><82><82><9d>, says Tom Longfield. <83><82><82><82><93>Not quite jungle, but not only does it feature a techno emergency, and it<83><82><82><82><84>s got Danny Dyer in it.<83><82><82><82><9d>

There<83><82><82><82><84>s also Radiohead

And a favourite Danny Dyer because why not.

Updated at 10.38pm BST

10.36pm BST

36 min Duggan is starting to hustle well, and she chases into Ronning, dwelling on a bouncing ball. She can<83><82><82><82><84>t quite chest it into her path, but these last few minutes have seen England apply a little pressure.

10.35pm BST

35 min England win a free-kick 30 yards out, just right of centre, and Williams steps up to luz it over the bar.

10.34pm BST

33 min <83><82><82><82><93>Fun fact about Norways Herlovsen,<83><82><82><82><9d> emails Torbj<83><92><82>rn O. Karlsen <83><82><82><82><93>Her father was a Norway international and used to play professionally for Borussia M<83><92><82>nchengladbach in the Bundesliga. Anyone else out there on the artificial pitch with a similar pedigree?<83><82><82><82><9d>

Jordan Nobbs<83><82><82><82><84> da, Keith, played for Hartlepool. Nowt more illustrious than that.

Updated at 10.34pm BST

10.32pm BST

31 min England win their first corner of the game, overhit from the right by Williams. But they maintain the pressure, Carney turning, coming in off the left and bounding between two players before being run out of it inside the box. But still, better again.

Updated at 11.01pm BST

10.30pm BST

29 min A little ray of hope for England, Kiby appearing at inside-right and skipping past one challenge and bundling through another that eventually relieves her of possession - but at lastm some enterprise.

10.28pm BST

28 min Wold arcs over a cross into the middle, looking for Hegerberg, and she<83><82><82><82><84>s up early - but Bronze and Bassett, though not exactly marking, are either side enough to be in the way enough, and the ball skids off her head and wide.

10.26pm BST

27 min The players pause to <83><82><82><82><93>take on board fluids<83><82><82><82><9d>, also known as <83><82><82><82><93>having a drink<83><82><82><82><9d>, while Jeremy Dresner notes that <83><82><82><82><93>Norway are playing a wonderful shade of Egil Olsen stuff.<83><82><82><82><9d>

A little, but the movement of the front players is much better than England<83><82><82><82><84>s at the moment - it<83><82><82><82><84>s not just long-ball.

Updated at 10.27pm BST

10.25pm BST

25 min England just can<83><82><82><82><84>t get going here. Duggan is in unsplendid isolation, and the box in midfield means that the players aren<83><82><82><82><84>t close enough to one another; every pass is a risk.

10.23pm BST

23 min I should probably point out that it<83><82><82><82><84>s very warm out there - not Ottawa, rather Hottawa. Oh yes.

10.22pm BST

21 min Norway are on top here, Laura Bassett doing very well to insert a toe in front of Hegerberg as she chased Gulbrandsen<83><82><82><82><84>s long ball. I doubt it<83><82><82><82><84>ll be long before we see Sampson make an alteration.

10.20pm BST

18 min <83><82><82><82><93>Bach, in particular, would not benefit from a jungle makeover,<83><82><82><82><9d> reckons Alex Brown. <83><82><82><82><93>Might be interesting to plant HM and family in a Congolese rainforest though.<83><82><82><82><9d>

A kind of sunny, reality version of this classic show.

10.18pm BST

17 min Lovely diagonal ball over the top from Mykjaland, finding Minde at the far post. But it forces her just too wide, and she runs it into the side-netting from a narrow angle; Rafferty is relieved, because it was she who lost her runner.

Updated at 10.24pm BST

10.16pm BST

14 min <83><82><82><82><93>I don<83><82><82><82><84>t know if this proves or disproves your theory about everything sounding better given a jungle makeover,<83><82><82><82><9d> emails K<83><92><82>ri Tulinius, <83><82><82><82><93>but here<83><82><82><82><84>s a jungle remix of God Save the Queen. Mind you, it<83><82><82><82><84>s been long enough since I paid attention to genre differences that this might be something else than jungle.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Thought that counts. Tangentially, I once became involved in a prolonged Twitter row about whether or not there was a difference between jungle and drum n<83><82><82><82><84> bass. The correct answer, of course, is that there is.

10.13pm BST

12 min Mistake by Carney, left holding her heid as Herlovsen charges through the middle. But Bardsley is out very sharply, narrowing the angle, and Herlovsen, rushed, tries to flick it by her, instead finding her studs. Excellent keeping, but panicked finishing.

10.12pm BST

11 min Duggan seizes on a mistake by Mjelde and sends Kirby into the box, left side. But, unable to decide whether to take on her man or cut back to Duggan, she pauses and is run out of things.

10.10pm BST

9 min Bardsley kicks long, towards Duggan, and she leaps well, but no one<83><82><82><82><84>s within ten yards of her - England could do with sorting that. Perhaps Carney and Kirby might come in off the flanks, or Chapman be sent forward to help.

10.08pm BST

8 min Bit of composed possession for Norway, Hergerberg coming in off the left, but Houghton marshals her line well, and England get the ball away.

Updated at 11.05pm BST

10.07pm BST

6 min Mykjaland goes in the back of Carney with the ball long gone, and England have a free-kick, 5o yards out, towards the right touchline. Bassett goes long to the far post, looking for Chapman, but overhits the kick and that<83><82><82><82><84>s that.

10.05pm BST

5 min It really is a bit silly that this competition is taking place on artificial surfaces, and we see why when Carney nashes after a pass that runs away from her.

10.04pm BST

4 min Norway force consecutive corners down the right, and the second is slung in flat - it<83><82><82><82><84>s dangerous - but Bardsley does excellently to punch double-fisted, with Herlovsen waiting behind her.

10.03pm BST

2 min When the ball goes into touch, England look to build from the back, Bardsley tapping out, and they build well, Williams unfurling a scholesian inside-out pass to find Bronze pacing down the right. Her cross is good, too, but Duggan can<83><82><82><82><84>t get enough on the glance, and the ball slips off her forehead to safety.

10.00pm BST

1 min And off we go, Norway looking to get Minde at Rafferty immediately.

Updated at 10.01pm BST

9.57pm BST

Not that it<83><82><82><82><84>s hard, but God Save the Queen would be a lot better given a jungle makeover. But then, what wouldn<83><82><82><82><84>t.

Updated at 9.57pm BST

9.56pm BST

There<83><82><82><82><84>s been a lot of talk about how confident Norway are, and they certainly look like they enjoyed the tension of the tunnel more than England, who seem very focused.

9.55pm BST

Things you don<83><82><82><82><84>t expect to hear: Jonathan Pearce referencing Henrik Ibsen. Things you do expect to hear: Jonathan Pearce referencing that Norwegian commentary.

So, I suppose thry cancel out, but feel free to send in your unexpected hearings - and, while we<83><82><82><82><84>re here, sightings. One to get you going: a minor UK comedy actor sneakily smoking an e-cigarette during the sermon in synagogue (contravening the laws of the Sabbath).

9.51pm BST

Email, with Cathal Chu: <83><82><82><82><93>We<83><82><82><82><84>ve now reached the knock-out stages of the Women<83><82><82><82><84>s World Cup, but there has been no sign anywhere in Canada of the self-proclaimed <83><82><82><82><9c>godfather of women<83><82><82><82><84>s football<83><82><82><82><84>. I wonder why?<83><82><82><82><9d>

Think he<83><82><82><82><84>s at Butlins Minehead.

Updated at 9.52pm BST

9.45pm BST

So, Sampson has picked a team to counter the specific long-ball threat of Norway. Chapman - <83><82><82><82><93>ready for a big game<83><82><82><82><9d> - will help shield the defence, and the full-backs offer plenty going in both directions, with Bronze<83><82><82><82><84>s ability to stop the cross considered of particular value.

9.31pm BST

Back to the teams, England have made four changes - curiously, three at the back, where Bronze, Bassett and Rafferty come in. In midfield, Katie Chapman, who did not start the competition well, replaces Jordan Nobbs, Mark Sampson doing his best to ensure his team aren<83><82><82><82><84>t outworked or outmuscled.

9.26pm BST

The winners of this tie will meet Canada in the next round; they<83><82><82><82><84>ve just beaten Switzerland 1-0, and their manager is flexing his large muscles, already accentuated in tight-sleeved, turned-up shirt.

9.12pm BST

Teams!

Norway: Hjelmseth, Skammelsrud, Tofte Ims, Mjelde, Ronning, Gulbrandsen, Herlovsen,Wold, Mykjaland, Minde, Hegerberg.

England: Bardsley; Rafferty, Williams, Houghton, Bassett, Carney, Moore,Bronze, Chapman, Duggan, Kirby.

Updated at 9.49pm BST

8.12pm BST

Preamble

Sport, and football in particular, live, thrive and survive on hype and hyperbole. But occasionally, we find ourselves in a situation where none is necessary: we will shortly be entertained by the biggest game in English women<83><82><82><82><84>s football history.

And they really might win it. They started the group well enough and gradually improved, growing in confidence and conviction, and will consider Norway a difficult but surmountable obstacle; organised and physical, but without England<83><82><82><82><84>s flexibility and creativity.

Quite how England will line up is impossible to predict. Manager Mark Sampson has used all 20 outfield players, in a variety of formations and styles, and now, with Jodie Taylor available, can tweak even further. If she is as sharp as she says, and if Karen Carney can find her best form, his will be a difficult team to beat.

Kick-off: 10pm
text: 11.54pm BST Anyway, thanks all for your comments and company - night-night.   11.50pm BST What a result that is! England were miserable for the best part of an hour, but Steph Houghtons perfectly cliched captains goal gave them an equaliser, and after that, the combination play of Scott and Taylor, allied to the bite of Chapman, the trickery of Carney and fitness and drive of everyone allowed them to take control. Theyll play Canada on Saturday night for a place in the semi-final, and, given the draw, will fancy themselves for the final. Well!  Updated at 11.59pm BST  11.49pm BST 90+2 min The crowd boo as Scott again burrows to the corner, and were at last chance time - but again, Scott finds he way to the flag and rinses more time. England have been excellent since going behind, and particularly since going ahead; Norway have had almost nowt.   11.47pm BST 90 min There shall be three minutes of stoppage time, as Scott again holds the ball in the corner - theyre not asking who she is anymore.   11.45pm BST 89 min England are perilously close to getting through!   11.44pm BST 88 min This is great from Hegerberg, running away from Scott down the left, cutting in, and crunching a shot from 20 yards just over the top.   11.43pm BST 87 min Wold departs, Utland arrives.   11.43pm BST 87 min Ive only watched the second half, so cant say for certain, emails Andrew Gerrard, but for the first 15 mins Norway were much faster and physical. Rather than the substitutions being the difference, is it possible that Norway are just knackered and England kept more in reserve in the heat? Yes - as I said, Norway look shattered. Also, England have rotated through the competition, so, though you sacrifice cohesion, you get freshness.   11.42pm BST 85 min England looking for the corners now, and when they cant find them, just to keep possession - they look comfortable and composed, Taylor almost happening upon a third when Lund and Thorisdottir gets themselves into a muddle inside their own box.  11.39pm BST 83 min Scott and Taylor haver made a difference, but the changes have also allowed Chapman into an area of the pitch where she can rattle Norways midfield, instead of hoping to get in the way of their attackers.   11.38pm BST 81 min Scott, again winde on the right, crosses into Carney, who lays back for Chapman, accepts the return, and from outside the box, hurries through a snap-shot that has Hjelmseth scurrying to shovel around the post.   11.37pm BST 80 min Ill say it. Theres more chance of a third England goal than a Norway equaliser. I wonder if Sampson will reward the players whove changed the game with a start next time, should England his team win.  11.35pm BST 78 min Norway look absolutely shattered.   11.32pm BST Scott, who always has time on the ball, exchanges passes with Taylor, the kind of composed little move that was beyond England in the first half. Scott then rolls back into the path of Bronze, just outside the box, right corner, and she absolutely annihilates a shot that screeches into the near top corner. WHAT A GOAL!  Updated at 11.45pm BST  11.31pm BST 74 min But theres a warning, Gulbransen curving a ball between Bassett and Bronze - shes a player - and Hegerberg burns by the latter, clattering a shot into Bardsleys fingers. She could do with improving her finishing, and once she does, shell be a serious threat, because her pace is something else.   11.29pm BST 72 min Its not all England, but its certainly significantly England. Theyre pressing higher up the pitch and forcing errors from a side that looks like its tiring.   11.28pm BST 72 min On the subject of Houghtons goal, it probably looks more like this:  11.27pm BST 70 min Thorsnes replaces Minde, and when a long cross eludes Houghton and Bassett, either side of Herlovsen, she stretches into a shot that flies only just over the bar.   11.25pm BST 68 min The ball ricochets around the Norway box as Scott laces over a low cross - Norway arent enjoying this now, but manage to scramble clear.  Updated at 11.26pm BST  11.24pm BST 67 min My friends and I beat Al Murray, Pub Landlord, and his team in a pub quiz earlier this evening, emails Alys Barber-Rogers. Im taking this as an omen either that England will win because Im on a roll or that theyll lose because Ive upset a classic English comic. Im very conflicted. Seems fairly clear that this is shaping up into an archetypal penalty defeat.   11.22pm BST 65 min Carney, who might be better in a central role, turns up in a central position and spreads right to Bronze. She clips a low cross into Taylor, showing early, but she cant quite escape Lund. Still, a promising sign.  11.20pm BST 63 min Taylor replaces Duggan, and suddenly England have momentum. Theres also a stoppage as Chapman clatters Gulbransen.  Updated at 11.29pm BST  11.17pm BST Scott clips the corner towards the penalty spot, and theres Houghton with a captains goal, brilliantly losing her marker to run inside and thud-guide a header into the bottom-right. Its not dissimilar in execution to this: But also minds of this: Updated at 11.50pm BST  11.17pm BST 60 min Williams sends a ball out wide to Scott, alone on the right. No help arrives, so shes forced to win a corner.  11.16pm BST 60 min Minde sends a long ball over the top for Herlovsen, racing between Houghton and Bassett. But it pitches and skips away from her - just.   11.15pm BST 59 min Jodie Taylor looks like shes ready to come on, which might help England - if nothing else, it might encourage them to get the ball into the box, even if the midfield balance still isnt right.   11.13pm BST 57 min England are back to a 4-2-3-1, with Scott on the right, Carney on the left and Chapman in the middle, or, put another way, still no help for Duggan. Its hard not to conclude that Sampson is outsmarting himself here.  Updated at 11.14pm BST  11.11pm BST A Steve Bould special. Mykjaland whips one into the near post, Gulbransen steals in front of Rafferty, and flicks it superbly off her forehead and behind, the ball whizzing in off the bar.  Updated at 11.23pm BST  11.10pm BST 54 min Avant-garde - Scott comes on for Kirby, with England defending a corner, needlessly conceded by Bardsley. That said, shes a lot more use in the circumstance than who shes replaced.  Updated at 11.12pm BST  11.09pm BST 52 min Jill Scott is taking some advice, and looks set to take the long walk to join us. Lets hope she does some good getting in the way.   11.08pm BST 51 min Norway win a corner down the right, Mykjaland over to take it. She sends an outswinger into the middle, and Bardsley, whos been Englands best player, is out to claim well.   11.05pm BST 49 min Williams, whos passing hasnt been great, looks for Duggan down the left. Its not perfect, but the way the ball skips off the turf and away must be a right annoyance.   11.04pm BST 47 min Kirby, infield, sends Carney away down the right - and theres Hegerberg, haring after her like nobodys business, shoulder-charging her off the ball to win the throw.   11.02pm BST 46 min Bronze burrows down the right immediately, Wold eventually stopping her, but thats the kind of positive start they needed to make.   11.02pm BST 46 min England get us off again.   11.01pm BST England dont look like theyre making any changes - slightly odd - while Norway bring Thorisdottir on for Ronning, the captain, presumed injured.  Updated at 11.03pm BST  11.00pm BST Out come the players again...  10.59pm BST Half-time email: It doesnt matter what would improve what, orders Matt Dony. Surely, in the eyes of all right-thinking people, drum and bass/jungle (theyre near enough the same!) died the day Roni Size wandered off with Ok Computers Mercury Prize. New Forms is a great album - granted, not as good, but still good, an exceptional live.   10.47pm BST Not at all good by England. They look like theyve been sent out to combat, rather than assert, and its showing.  Updated at 10.48pm BST  10.47pm BST 45+1 min Kirby, now on the right, forces a mistake out of Mjelde, harrying her down the by-line. But with with the opportunity to shoot, she instead settled for a corner that there may not be time to take. There is, but - its headed clear, and Carney rams a shot over the top.   10.45pm BST 45 min There shall be a single, solitary added minute.   10.45pm BST 45 min Two more corners forced by England, the second drilled flat for Houghton. She times her run and jump well, but her headers blocked, and an infringement or other allows Norway to reset.   10.44pm BST 42 min A suit at a top league club told me that Laura Bassett was an accident waiting to happen, but shes been excellent so far. Again, she stands up well to a long ball looking for Minde, forcing the foul that allows England to clear.   10.41pm BST 40 min Bronze turns a backpass short, and Hegerberg is onto it in a trice, winding up a shot as Bronze leans right into her; if she goes down, its a penalty. But she stays up, welting a effort into Bardsleys midriff, when a more studied finish could have given her no chance.  Updated at 11.04pm BST  10.39pm BST 39 min Talking of techno, I found myself in a discotheque on a boat on the Seine recently - Id forgotten how horrific it is. England have changed to a 4-2-3-1, the specific aim to get Chapman on Mykjaland.  10.38pm BST 38 min Human Traffic is the last word on the national anthem for me, says Tom Longfield. Not quite jungle, but not only does it feature a techno emergency, and its got Danny Dyer in it. Theres also Radiohead  And a favourite Danny Dyer because why not. Updated at 10.38pm BST  10.36pm BST 36 min Duggan is starting to hustle well, and she chases into Ronning, dwelling on a bouncing ball. Karlsen Her father was a Norway international and used to play professionally for Borussia Mnchengladbach in the Bundesliga. Anyone else out there on the artificial pitch with a similar pedigree? Jordan Nobbs da, Keith, played for Hartlepool. Nowt more illustrious than that.  Updated at 10.34pm BST  10.32pm BST 31 min England win their first corner of the game, overhit from the right by Williams. But they maintain the pressure, Carney turning, coming in off the left and bounding between two players before being run out of it inside the box. But still, better again.  Updated at 11.01pm BST  10.30pm BST 29 min A little ray of hope for England, Kiby appearing at inside-right and skipping past one challenge and bundling through another that eventually relieves her of possession - but at lastm some enterprise.   10.28pm BST 28 min Wold arcs over a cross into the middle, looking for Hegerberg, and shes up early - but Bronze and Bassett, though not exactly marking, are either side enough to be in the way enough, and the ball skids off her head and wide.   10.26pm BST 27 min The players pause to take on board fluids, also known as having a drink, while Jeremy Dresner notes that Norway are playing a wonderful shade of Egil Olsen stuff.  A little, but the movement of the front players is much better than Englands at the moment - its not just long-ball.  Updated at 10.27pm BST  10.25pm BST 25 min England just cant get going here. Duggan is in unsplendid isolation, and the box in midfield means that the players arent close enough to one another; every pass is a risk.  10.23pm BST 23 min I should probably point out that its very warm out there - not Ottawa, rather Hottawa. Oh yes.   10.22pm BST 21 min Norway are on top here, Laura Bassett doing very well to insert a toe in front of Hegerberg as she chased Gulbrandsens long ball. I doubt itll be long before we see Sampson make an alteration.   10.20pm BST 18 min Bach, in particular, would not benefit from a jungle makeover, reckons Alex Brown. Might be interesting to plant HM and family in a Congolese rainforest though. A kind of sunny, reality version of this classic show.  10.18pm BST 17 min Lovely diagonal ball over the top from Mykjaland, finding Minde at the far post. But it forces her just too wide, and she runs it into the side-netting from a narrow angle; Rafferty is relieved, because it was she who lost her runner.  Updated at 10.24pm BST  10.16pm BST 14 min I dont know if this proves or disproves your theory about everything sounding better given a jungle makeover, emails Kri Tulinius, but heres a jungle remix of God Save the Queen. Mind you, its been long enough since I paid attention to genre differences that this might be something else than jungle. Thought that counts. webTitle: If the Norwegian model is so flawed, why is it so popular in Norway? | Letters
trailText: Letters: Many Norwegians may see the current model as striking a balance between benefits of ties and retaining autonomy over certain policy areas such as fisheries, regional policy, energy and foreign affairs
headline: If the Norwegian model is so flawed, why is it so popular in Norway?
standfirst: NA
body:
If the Norwegian model is so flawed (Editorial, 29 October), why is it so popular in Norway? David Cameron and many others have been eager to stress the limitations of the so-called Norwegian model, where my native country maintains close ties to the EU through the European Economic Area (EEA) without being a formal member. It is correct that the Norwegian model would not address many common concerns about Britain<83><82><82><82><84>s EU membership. Norway is obliged through the terms of the EEA to comply with much EU legislation, pay substantial EU contributions, and must maintain an open labour market without controls on immigration from the EU. But critics of the alleged flaws of the Norwegian model rarely bother to engage with the fact it appears to be popular in Norway.

Although the EEC/EU referendums in 1972 and 1994 returned relatively small <83><82><82><82><93>no<83><82><82><82><9d> majorities of 52.2% and 53.3%, current opinion surveys indicate that almost 75% are opposed to EU membership while over 60% express support for remaining in the EEA. One plausible interpretation is that many see the current model as striking an appropriate balance between benefits of ties and retaining autonomy over certain policy areas such as fisheries, regional policy, energy and foreign affairs. The Norwegian model may not be the most appropriate template for alternatives for British membership, given the vast difference between the countries, beyond just their size. But both UK and EU politicians could benefit from trying to understand how its popularity may inform reform efforts.
Professor Kristian Skrede Gleditsch
Department of Government, University of Essex

<83><82><82><82> The populations of both Iceland and Norway would comfortably fit into London with a couple of million to spare, so the influence of either to negotiate financial terms that suit their respective countries is strictly limited. Both need the EU more than Brussels need them. The UK can wield the type of power to broker suitable conditions from outside the union. German and French car manufacturers, for instance, would be severely affected if Brussels attempted to add tariffs on the UK. Turkeys, as they say, do not vote for Christmas.
Anthony James Sokol
Banbury, Oxfordshire

<83><82><82><82> Join the debate <83><82><82><82><80><9c> email guardian.letters@theguardian.com
text: If the Norwegian model is so flawed (Editorial, 29 October), why is it so popular in Norway? David Cameron and many others have been eager to stress the limitations of the so-called Norwegian model, where my native country maintains close ties to the EU through the European Economic Area (EEA) without being a formal member. It is correct that the Norwegian model would not address many common concerns about Britains EU membership. Norway is obliged through the terms of the EEA to comply with much EU legislation, pay substantial EU contributions, and must maintain an open labour market without controls on immigration from the EU. But critics of the alleged flaws of the Norwegian model rarely bother to engage with the fact it appears to be popular in Norway. Although the EEC/EU referendums in 1972 and 1994 returned relatively small no majorities of 52.2% and 53.3%, current opinion surveys indicate that almost 75% are opposed to EU membership while over 60% express support for remaining in the EEA. One plausible interpretation is that many see the current model as striking an appropriate balance between benefits of ties and retaining autonomy over certain policy areas such as fisheries, regional policy, energy and foreign affairs. The Norwegian model may not be the most appropriate template for alternatives for British membership, given the vast difference between the countries, beyond just their size. But both UK and EU politicians could benefit from trying to understand how itspopularity may inform reform efforts.Professor Kristian Skrede GleditschDepartment of Government, University of Essex  The populations of both Iceland and Norway would comfortably fit into London with a couple of million to spare, so the influence of either to negotiate financial terms that suit their respective countries is strictly limited. Both need the EU more than Brussels need them. The UK can wield the type of power to broker suitable conditions from outside the union. German and French car manufacturers, for instance, would be severely affected if Brussels attempted to add tariffs on the UK. Turkeys, as they say, do not vote for Christmas.Anthony James SokolBanbury, Oxfordshire  Join the debate  email guardian.letters@theguardian.com

webTitle: Norway hunter kills two moose with one single shot ... at the zoo
trailText: The hunter did not realize that his dog, who was trained to track moose, had led him into the Polar Park Arctic Wildlife Center when he fired at the animals
headline: Norway hunter kills two moose with one gunshot ... at the zoo
standfirst: The hunter did not realize that his dog, who was trained to track moose, had led him into the Polar Park Arctic Wildlife Center when he fired at the animals
body:
A Norwegian hunter tracking moose in the country<83><82><82><82><84>s wild north may at first have congratulated himself when he realized he had killed two of the majestic beasts with a single shot.

But he soon realized his success had little to do with marksmanship and more to do with fences: the animals, it turns out, were captives in a zoo.

On 7 October, the hunter <83><82><82><82><80><9c> whose name has not yet been released by police <83><82><82><82><80><9c> was with a group who had specially trained dogs to track the animals, according to CNN.

After one of the dogs caught the scent of the moose and went under the zoo<83><82><82><82><84>s fence, the hunter fired a shot. The bullet passed through one of the animals and was lodged in the other<83><82><82><82><84>s stomach. The first died immediately, the second had to be euthanized.

The Polar Park Arctic Wildlife Center in northern Norway originally had five moose, according to the Local, a Norwegian news site. Following the incident, the head of the hunting group approached Polar Park staff and explained what happened.

<83><82><82><82><93>I was surprised. I had my mouth open for a while,<83><82><82><82><9d> Polar Park<83><82><82><82><84>s CEO, Heinz Strathmann, told CNN. <83><82><82><82><93>This has never happened before <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and I don<83><82><82><82><84>t think it will happen ever again. It is a one of a kind.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Strathmann told the Local that the incident was <83><82><82><82><93>very sad<83><82><82><82><9d> and <83><82><82><82><93>not OK<83><82><82><82><9d>. But Arne Nysted, chairman of the wildlife tribunal in Troms County, said that it was <83><82><82><82><93>a regrettable mistake made in connection with lawful hunting on the outside of the park<83><82><82><82><9d>.

Hunting is popular but strictly regulated in Norway. Hunters must be over 16 years old and pass a proficiency test. The practice has been under increased scrutiny worldwide following the killing of Cecil, one of Africa<83><82><82><82><84>s most famous lions, by a Minnesota dentist.

The zoo has asked that the hunter cover the costs of acquiring two new moose, which cost $3,500 each, according to Strathmann. But they will not press charges. Superintendent Katrine Grimes told CNN that the man could still be prosecuted under Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s Wildlife Act, which regulates humane hunting.

On 7 October, the hunter  whose name has not yet been released by police  was with a group who had specially trained dogs to track the animals, according to CNN. After one of the dogs caught the scent of the moose and went under the zoos fence, the hunter fired a shot. The bullet passed through one of the animals and was lodged in the others stomach. The first died immediately, the second had to be euthanized. The Polar Park Arctic Wildlife Center in northern Norway originally had five moose, according to the Local, a Norwegian news site. Following the incident, the head of the hunting group approached Polar Park staff and explained what happened. I was surprised. I had my mouth open for a while, Polar Parks CEO, Heinz Strathmann, told CNN. This has never happened before  and I dont think it will happen ever again. It is a one of a kind. Strathmann told the Local that the incident was very sad and not OK. But Arne Nysted, chairman of the wildlife tribunal in Troms County, said that it was a regrettable mistake made in connection with lawful hunting on the outside of the park. Hunting is popular but strictly regulated in Norway. Hunters must be over 16 years old and pass a proficiency test. The practice has been under increased scrutiny worldwide following the killing of Cecil, one of Africas most famous lions, by a Minnesota dentist. The zoo has asked that the hunter cover the costs of acquiring two new moose, which cost $3,500 each, according to Strathmann. But they will not press charges. Superintendent Katrine Grimes told CNN that the man could still be prosecuted under Norways Wildlife Act, which regulates humane hunting.

webTitle: Euro 2016 qualifier: Italy recover to consign Norway to play-offs
trailText: Italy have come from behind to beat Norway 2-1 and to extend their run of unbeaten home qualifiers to 50 while consigning their opponents to the Euro 2016 play-offs
headline: Euro 2016 qualifier: Italy recover to consign Norway to play-offs
standfirst: NA
body:
Alex Tettey opened the scoring for Norway midway through the first half in Rome but Alessandro Florenzi and Graziano Pell<83><92><82> both struck for the Azzurri in the final 16 minutes to secure top spot in Group H and send Norway into the play-offs.

It also spared Italy the embarrassment of a first home defeat in a qualifying match for nine years.

Norway kicked off in the second and final automatic place and ahead of Croatia by two points. And they appeared on course for France when Tettey, of Norwich City, opened the scoring in the 23rd minute. The midfielder hit a low shot beyond Gianluigi Buffon to put Italy<83><82><82><82><84>s streak of 49 consecutive unbeaten home qualifying matches under threat.

Related: Holland miss out on Euro 2016 play-offs with defeat by Czech Republic

But Antonio Conte<83><82><82><82><84>s side dominated thereafter and equalised through Florenzi<83><82><82><82><84>s close-range effort in the 74th minute. The comeback was completed nine minutes later with a shot from Southampton<83><82><82><82><84>s Graziano Pell<83><92><82> that flew into the top-right corner. It also ensured qualification for Croatia <83><82><82><82><80><9c> who won 1-0 in Malta <83><82><82><82><80><9c> while Norway finished third and will have to do it the hard way, through the play-offs.

<83><82><82><82><93>We did what we had to do,<83><82><82><82><9d> Conte said later. <83><82><82><82><93>We didn<83><82><82><82><84>t deserve to lose. I always want this intensity and this nastiness. We<83><82><82><82><84>re on the right road. It<83><82><82><82><84>s important to have this approach, whether you win or lose.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Italy won the group with 24 points and Croatia, who had a point deducted for a swastika that was painted on the pitch before June<83><82><82><82><84>s 1-1 draw against Italy in Split, finished second with 20. Norway took third place with 19 points.

<83><82><82><82><93>They were much better than us in the 90 minutes and they, of course, deserved to win,<83><82><82><82><9d> the magnanimous coach of Norway, Per-Mathias Hogmo, said.

Italy<83><82><82><82><84>s last defeat in a qualifying match was 3-1 to France in September 2006.

Conte was without several key midfielders, with Daniele De Rossi suspended and injuries to Andrea Pirlo and Marco Verratti. Still, his team were able to take control and create several chances before Tettey gave Norway the lead.

A header from Pell<83><92><82> that went narrowly wide in the 35th minute was Italy<83><82><82><82><84>s best chance of the first half.

Roberto Soriano then had a long shot pushed wide by Orjan Nyland, who also negated efforts from Pell<83><92><82> and Florenzi in the second half before the equaliser arrived. The substitute Sebastian Giovinco crossed from the left and Haitam Aleesami attempted to stop it with his chest, leaving the ball for Florenzi to poke in.

Less than 10 minutes later Giovinco was again involved as Pell<83><92><82> finished off a counterattack following a cross from Florenzi. Norway finished with only one shot on target, Tettey<83><82><82><82><84>s goal.
text: Alex Tettey opened the scoring for Norway midway through the first half in Rome but Alessandro Florenzi and Graziano Pell both struck for the Azzurri in the final 16 minutes to secure top spot in Group H and send Norway into the play-offs. It also spared Italy the embarrassment of a first home defeat in a qualifying match for nine years. Norway kicked off in the second and final automatic place and ahead of Croatia by two points. And they appeared on course for France when Tettey, of Norwich City, opened the scoring in the 23rd minute. The midfielder hit a low shot beyond Gianluigi Buffon to put Italys streak of 49 consecutive unbeaten home qualifying matches under threat.  Related: Holland miss out on Euro 2016 play-offs with defeat by Czech Republic  But Antonio Contes side dominated thereafter and equalised through Florenzis close-range effort in the 74th minute. The comeback was completed nine minutes later with a shot from Southamptons Graziano Pell that flew into the top-right corner. It also ensured qualification for Croatia  who won 1-0 in Malta  while Norway finished third and will have to do it the hard way, through the play-offs. We did what we had to do, Conte said later. We didnt deserve to lose. I always want this intensity and this nastiness. Were on the right road. Its important to have this approach, whether you win or lose. Italy won the group with 24 points and Croatia, who had a point deducted for a swastika that was painted on the pitch before Junes 1-1 draw against Italy in Split, finished second with 20. Norway took third place with 19 points. They were much better than us in the 90 minutes and they, of course, deserved to win, the magnanimous coach of Norway, Per-Mathias Hogmo, said. Italys last defeat in a qualifying match was 3-1 to France in September 2006. Conte was without several key midfielders, with Daniele De Rossi suspended and injuries to Andrea Pirlo and Marco Verratti. Still, his team were able to take control and create several chances before Tettey gave Norway the lead. A header from Pell that went narrowly wide in the 35th minute was Italys best chance of the first half. Roberto Soriano then had a long shot pushed wide by Orjan Nyland, who also negated efforts from Pell and Florenzi in the second half before the equaliser arrived. The substitute Sebastian Giovinco crossed from the left and Haitam Aleesami attempted to stop it with his chest, leaving the ball for Florenzi to poke in. Less than 10 minutes later Giovinco was again involved as Pell finished off a counterattack following a cross from Florenzi. Norway finished with only one shot on target, Tetteys goal.

webTitle: Norway confirms $900bn sovereign wealth fund's major coal divestment
trailText: Parliamentâs move come as analysis shows largest fossil fuel divestment yet will affect 122 companies across the world, including SSE and Drax in the UK
headline: Norway confirms $900bn sovereign wealth fund's major coal divestment
standfirst: Parliamentâs move come as analysis shows largest fossil fuel divestment yet will affect 122 companies across the world, including SSE and Drax in the UK
body:
Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s parliament has formally endorsed the move to sell off coal investments from its $900bn sovereign wealth fund, the world<83><82><82><82><84>s biggest.

It is the largest fossil fuel divestment yet, affecting 122 companies across the world, and marking a new success for the fast-growing and UN-backed climate change campaign.

A new analysis said the fund would sell off over $8bn (<83><80><9a><82>5bn) of coal-related investments as a result.

The biggest single sell-off from Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s fund will be the UK utility SSE, in which the fund holds $956m of shares. The fund is also set to sell its $49m stake in Drax, which runs the UK<83><82><82><82><84>s biggest coal-fired power station.

Other major energy companies identified in the analysis by German and Norwegian NGOs are Germany<83><82><82><82><84>s E.ON ($685m) and RWE ($320m) and the Danish company Dong ($30m), which is often associated with wind energy but has a significant coal business.

Sweden<83><82><82><82><84>s Vattenfall and Italy<83><82><82><82><84>s Enel are also set to be affected by the coal ban as are 35 groups in the US, including Duke Energy ($434m). A dozen coal-related companies on China are set to lose their Norwegian investment, as are eight in Japan and five in Australia.

The decision to divest Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s $945m fund from coal assets was made on 27 May, when an agreement between political parties was reached. It was formally passed by a parliamentary vote on Friday. Svein Flaatten, of the governing Conservative party, said coal investments were both a global warming risk and financial risk. A global deal to cut carbon emissions at a crunch UN summit in December could leave some fossil fuel reserves unburnable and worthless.

The fossil fuel divestment campaign seeks to persuade investors to dump stocks on the basis that current reserves of coal, oil and gas are already several times greater than could be safely burned. It has seen a string of successes, including last Friday<83><82><82><82><84>s commitment from French financial services giant Axa sell to $560m of coal-related investments.

The Guardian<83><82><82><82><84>s Keep it in the Ground campaign is calling on the world<83><82><82><82><84>s two largest medical charities <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the Gates Foundation and the Wellcome Trust <83><82><82><82><80><9c> to divest their endowments from fossil fuels. The Guardian Media Group pledged to divest its own $1bn fund from all fossil fuels in April.

Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s finance committee decided the nation<83><82><82><82><84>s fund, known as the Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG), should sell stakes in companies for which mining or burning coal makes up more than 30% of their business, or have projects in development that would tip them over the 30% threshold. The measures are to be implemented on 1 January 2016.

The NGO<83><82><82><82><84>s Urgewald, Greenpeace and Framtiden applied these criteria to the more than 9,000 companies owned by the GPFG to create their list of 122 companies. It calculates the combined value of the holdings to be sold at $8.7bn. The GPFG is funded by revenues from Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s large oil and gas production.

<83><82><82><82><93>This is the biggest divestment from coal in history and it should pave the way for other investors and countries to follow suit,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Truls Gulowsen, head of Greenpeace in Norway.

<83><82><82><82><93>The significance of the Norway decision is that, because of their size and reach, this will act as a major signal for other investors to follow. This will certainly create a wave,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Mark Campanale, founder of the Carbon Tracker Initiative, which has pioneered analysis of the financial risks of fossil fuels.

Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s finance ministry is reported to have calculated that $9bn-$10bn of investments would be affected by the divestment, suggesting that the NGO analysis may be an underestimate.

Some major mining companies, such as Anglo American and BHP Billiton, have very large coal reserves and production but are not affected by the new GPFG rules. This is because coal makes up less than 30% of their total mining operations across the world.

It is the largest fossil fuel divestment yet, affecting 122 companies across the world, and marking a new success for the fast-growing and UN-backed climate change campaign. A new analysis said the fund would sell off over $8bn (5bn) of coal-related investments as a result. The fund is also set to sell its $49m stake in Drax, which runs the UKs biggest coal-fired power station. Other major energy companies identified in the analysis by German and Norwegian NGOs are Germanys E.ON ($685m) and RWE ($320m) and the Danish company Dong ($30m), which is often associated with wind energy but has a significant coal business.  Swedens Vattenfall and Italys Enel are also set to be affected by the coal ban as are 35 groups in the US, including Duke Energy ($434m). A dozen coal-related companies on China are set to lose their Norwegian investment, as are eight in Japan and five in Australia. It has seen a string of successes, including last Fridays commitment from French financial services giant Axa sell to $560m of coal-related investments.  The Guardians Keep it in the Ground campaign is calling on the worlds two largest medical charities  the Gates Foundation and the Wellcome Trust  to divest their endowments from fossil fuels. The measures are to be implemented on 1 January 2016. It calculates the combined value of the holdings to be sold at $8.7bn. The GPFG is funded by revenues from Norways large oil and gas production.
