Norways wealth fund owns 1.3% of the entire worlds traded stocks and the new policy is likely to see it shed investments in companies all over the world, including Germanys RWE, Chinas Shenhua, Duke Energy in the US, AGL Energy in Australia, Reliance Power in India and Japans Electric Power Development Corporation. We expect that billions of euros will be withdrawn from the coal industry, says Truls Gulowsen from Greenpeace. This is a huge win for the divestment movement and a real sign of hope that investment patterns can be changed. Bill McKibben, co-founder of 350.org, the organisation leading the global fossil fuel divestment campaign, said: If youd told any of us, three years ago, that the planets largest sovereign wealth fund would begin divesting, we would have laughed. Theres much work to be done taking on coal, oil, and gas but the momentum is definitely on our side. Organisations that have cut or curbed coal investments recently include insurance giant Axa, the Church of England and Oxford University. The Guardian, which is running a campaign asking the worlds biggest health charities to divest, is owned by the Guardian Media Group, which announced it would divest its 800m fund from all fossil fuels in April.

webTitle: We are taking the island back: Norways long road back to Utya
trailText: Four years after Anders Behring Breivik murdered 69 people on the island of UtÃ¸ya, the political youth group he attacked has returned for its annual summer camp for the first time. Will their defiance in the face of such horror bolster the countryâs uneasy healing process?
headline: âWe are taking the island backâ: Norwayâs long road back to UtÃ¸ya
standfirst: Four years after Anders Behring Breivik murdered 69 people on the island of UtÃ¸ya, the political youth group he attacked has returned for its annual summer camp for the first time. Will their defiance in the face of such horror bolster the countryâs uneasy healing process?
body:
The cheers of 1,300 Norwegian teenagers carry far over the still grey waters where, on 22 July 2011, children swam for their lives.

They are returning to Ut<83><92><82>ya to re-establish the Labour party youth wing<83><82><82><82><84>s annual summer camp on the island. Their return is a show of defiance to Anders Behring Breivik and a tribute to the 69 people he killed <83><82><82><82><80><9c> most of them teenagers, the youngest just 14. The organisers of this year<83><82><82><82><84>s event include survivors of that day, but the camp has attracted many new faces.

<83><82><82><82><93>We are sending a message that we are taking the island back, there<83><82><82><82><84>s a good energy,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Victoria <83><92><82><9c>verland, 17, here for her first camp. There were anxious moments when she and her friends boarded the ferry to the island, but the camp spirit quickly took over.

Related: Ut<83><92><82>ya four years on: what's the mood in Norway?

<83><82><82><82><93>It is a part of the grieving process to take back the place where terrible things happened,<83><82><82><82><9d> <83><92><82><9c>verland says. <83><82><82><82><93>Everyone here is aware of what took place and they have been through a process in their head, though for some people it is really hard.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The camp<83><82><82><82><84>s return marks a turning point in a national tragedy that is still unfolding. It is the culmination of a long and painful attempt to find a balance between politics and grief, courage and remembrance, youth and parenthood, moving on and looking back.

Ut<83><92><82>ya has posed the question of how, when the fabric of society has been torn, the threads can be woven back together. It has forced Norwegians to weigh the concerns of those directly affected against the wider needs of a nation living with the knowledge that Breivik came from within, and that the virus that spawned him has not gone away.

For some, a refusal to <83><82><82><82><93>reclaim<83><82><82><82><9d> the island would be a victory for terrorism and an affront to the dead. Others want Ut<83><92><82>ya left as a memorial, unable to countenance laughter, music and selfies on the site of slaughter.

<83><82><82><82><93>I don<83><82><82><82><84>t think Ut<83><92><82>ya will ever be that paradise again,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Lisbeth R<83><92><82>yneland, whose daughter Synne lost her life, aged 18. R<83><92><82>yneland is happy the camp is re-opening, and that young people are getting on with their lives.

<83><82><82><82><93>On the other hand, for me it is a time with many feelings, because Synne isn<83><82><82><82><84>t with them anymore,<83><82><82><82><9d> says R<83><92><82>yneland, who chairs the national support group for survivors and relatives. <83><82><82><82><93>But because of the memorial, the 69 who were killed that day will never be forgotten.<83><82><82><82><9d>

In a quiet clearing on the island<83><82><82><82><84>s highest point, suspended from three tall pines, is a massive steel ring cut with the names and ages of the dead. In the circle no one is first, and no one last. The soil below has been planted with flowers to attract butterflies. When the thick mist pours into Tyrifjord, it condenses, and the steel weeps.

The spot was proposed by Kolbein Fridtun, who lost his 19-year-old daughter, Hanne, on the island; a dozen parents of children who died have worked to clear the site. But space on the ring remains for seven names missing from the memorial <83><82><82><82><80><9c> for some it is still too soon, and the emotions too raw, to imagine their child<83><82><82><82><84>s absence fixed in metal. Each person<83><82><82><82><84>s despair moves at its own pace.

<83><82><82><82><93>The parents feel their loss in very fibre of their bodies,<83><82><82><82><9d> says <83><92><82><80>sne Seierstad, novelist and author of a bestselling book on the massacre . <83><82><82><82><93>Maybe there are longer periods now when they don<83><82><82><82><84>t think about their children <83><82><82><82><80><9c> half an hour or perhaps an hour <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but it is there every day.<83><82><82><82><9d>

And for most of them, Ut<83><92><82>ya is not their main concern, she said. It was never their island <83><82><82><82><80><9c> it belonged to the young people who went there every year, the island of AUF, the Labour party<83><82><82><82><84>s youth organisation, since 1932, and many future Labour leaders cut their political teeth at the annual summer camp. It is not a place you can just visit to remember.

<83><82><82><82><93>These young people were so in love with the island,<83><82><82><82><9d> Seierstad explains. <83><82><82><82><93>The terrorist killed them because they were there, so strong, so political and independent-minded. They would probably have wanted their names to be on the memorial.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The decision to return was taken on the day after the attacks, says Mani Hussaini, leader of the AUF. This will be the biggest summer camp ever, with talks and workshops on internationalism, feminism and anti-racism, preparation for the next elections <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and a lot of fun. <83><82><82><82><93>Our response is more openness and more democracy in our fight for equal rights. Ut<83><92><82>ya is at the heart of Labour youth.<83><82><82><82><9d>

But the left have had to temper their passion to reclaim the ground that Breivik took away. On the day after the attacks, the then prime minister, Jens Stoltenberg, said he would camp out on Ut<83><92><82>ya in a year<83><82><82><82><84>s time. There was a rush to commission a memorial and prepare for an uninterrupted return to the island.

The following year a firm of architects called Fantastic Norway presented sketches of bright new buildings and smiling young people. Buildings where children died would be torn down. It was too much, too soon. Plans to commemorate the first anniversary on the island excluded the parents of the dead. <83><82><82><82><93>It seems they did not understand the force of grief,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Seierstad. <83><82><82><82><93>For traumatised young people, it was all about moving on. That mistake destroyed a lot.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Ragnhild Kaski, the AUF<83><82><82><82><84>s general secretary, who was 21 when she fled from Breivik on the island, admits blunders were made.

<83><82><82><82><93>The project has changed. It needed to change,<83><82><82><82><9d> she explains. <83><82><82><82><93>The things you think are right at first are not necessarily the right things to do a few years later <83><82><82><82> It has been a bumpy road for many of us. Our plans have changed and we have changed as well.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Related: Wounded landscape: how Norway is remembering its 2011 Ut<83><92><82>ya massacre

Talking to the parents helped them to find a balance between learning how to shape Ut<83><92><82>ya<83><82><82><82><84>s future and remembering its past, Kaski says. Tens of millions of krona have been donated by unions, businesses and individuals to build conference and learning centres as a resource for the labour movement. Meanwhile, for the past two years Labour youth have held a summer camp on the mainland.

<83><82><82><82><93>When they came forward in 2012 with the plans for a new Ut<83><92><82>ya, almost all the survivors and relatives of the dead said they needed more time,<83><82><82><82><9d> R<83><92><82>yneland says. <83><82><82><82><93>We talked to Labour youth and gave them our advice, which they followed <83><82><82><82><80><9c> after that we have had very good communication with them.<83><82><82><82><9d>

With the re-opening of the camp this weekend, earlier divisions about the reconstruction have been laid to rest. The event has re-awakened public debate, which had died down since Breivik<83><82><82><82><84>s trial in 2012. In last year<83><82><82><82><84>s extravagant bicentenary celebrations of the Norwegian constitution, the nation<83><82><82><82><84>s unity after the attacks was barely mentioned.

But there have been moments that threatened to undermine the consensus in Norway around how to respond to the attacks. On the third anniversary last year, 19 mothers of the island<83><82><82><82><84>s dead wrote to Conservative prime minister Erna Solberg asking for Ut<83><92><82>ya to stay closed, and to remain as a place of remembrance. Just north of the island, residents are attempting to sue the government to prevent a national memorial on the mainland. Some locals picked up survivors, the dead and dying from the fjord, and feel that a proposal to dissect a peninsular of rock at S<83><92><82>rbr<83><92><82>ten <83><82><82><82><80><9c> creating a symbolic wound in the landscape <83><82><82><82><80><9c> would aggravate their trauma.

At the new July 22 Centre in downtown Oslo, inaugurated last month, there are also seven blank spaces where parents have asked that their children be excluded from photographs of the Ut<83><92><82>ya dead. Disagreements broke out about whether or not to exhibit artefacts of the attacks in the very office block that Breivik bombed. There were rumours that the museum planned to exhibit the gun he used, and that it could become a traumatic, daily reminder to civil servants. The exhibit that visitors now see includes the remains of the car bomb Breivik detonated outside the prime minister<83><82><82><82><84>s office just hours before the Utoya shootings, killing eight people.

John Christian Elden, a lawyer whose firm represented most of the victims at Breivik<83><82><82><82><84>s trial, branded it the <83><82><82><82><93>museum of Breivik<83><82><82><82><9d>, and likens displaying his possessions to placing photographs of Hitler at Auschwitz.

For others, labelling it the Breivik museum is just as absurd as calling the 9/11 memorial at Ground Zero in New York a museum to Osama Bin Laden. The blown-out windows of the office buildings awaiting demolition at the Oslo bomb site are a far more visible reminder to workers than the museum, tucked away in the wrecked basement of the central block. Since its opening on 22 July, it has received around 1,000 visitors a day, the museum said <83><82><82><82><80><9c> big numbers in this country of 5 million people.

Rather than a story of division, however, the new museum and the coming together of parents and activists for the camp in July represent a remarkable tale of unity in facing up to the tragedy. <83><82><82><82><93>The 9/11 memorial took a decade to agree, and lots of conflict,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Seierstad. <83><82><82><82><93>For us it has been four years. It could have been so much worse.<83><82><82><82><9d>

And yet doubts linger that the deep scar on the national consciousness can heal without concerted effort at the top of Norwegian society. <83><82><82><82><93>The nature and magnitude of the crime mean that the response to the tragedy cannot be decided only by those directly affected,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Arne Johan Vetlesen, professor of philosophy at Oslo University.

For survivors and relatives, wounds inflicted by Breivik might not be visible, but they are no less real. They find it hard to hold down jobs or study, and there is lasting depression, anxiety and post-traumatic stress.

<83><82><82><82><93>They have had a lot of problems, there is still quite a long way to go before they are back to their normal health status,<83><82><82><82><9d> says professor Grete Dyb of the Norwegian Centre for Violence and Traumatic Stress Studies in Oslo.

She has followed survivors and their parents, and advised Labour youth leaders on how to approach the big decisions they have faced. Tears will flow on Ut<83><92><82>ya island this weekend, Dyb says, but she is confident that the organisers have taken every precaution to ensure any outpouring of emotion will be healthy.

Elisabeth Haukeland<83><82><82><82><84>s eldest son and daughter both survived the massacre, and they aren<83><82><82><82><84>t going back to Ut<83><92><82>ya. But her youngest daughter is. Just 13 at the time of the attack, she went straight out to join the Labour youth.

Related: Breivik victims' parents too traumatised to work four years on, research shows

<83><82><82><82><93>I think she is very brave,<83><82><82><82><9d> Haukeland tells me. All the same, she tries not to dwell on the thought of her daughter on the island this weekend, in a place where her other children suffered so much. <83><82><82><82><93>I am convinced it would be worse if she was afraid and didn<83><82><82><82><84>t want to get out and do things.<83><82><82><82><9d> The keenness of AUF leaders to get back on to the island makes sense, Haukeland says, because with each passing year the numbers of survivors eligible to attend the camp will fall, and the memory of 2011 needs to be passed on. Without a grasp of Ut<83><92><82>ya<83><82><82><82><84>s enormous significance to the labour movement, she adds, it could seem provocative to stress the need for continuity.

But despite the strong association of Ut<83><92><82>ya with the left, party politics are largely absent from the public debate in Norway about Breivik. Despite the attacks, in 2013 the country elected a rightwing coalition, which, for the first time, included the anti-immigrant Progress party, of which Breivik was a member for nine years until 2005.

People did not vote for the right because they were sympathetic to Breivik, Seierstad says. He has never been cited in political debate, even on immigration or jihadism. The Progress party is less extreme today, she explains, and in any case, has never been linked to the attacks. <83><82><82><82><93>The Progress party has never been made to pay for Breivik<83><82><82><82><84>s membership <83><82><82><82><80><9c> people are too decent in Norway.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Even the youth wing, which is to the left of the Labour party on immigration, has moderate views on asylum. <83><82><82><82><93>We want more liberal asylum policies, but we also have an understanding that too-liberal policies will cause rightwing ideas to grow, if you can<83><82><82><82><84>t accept 20,000 each year and integrate them,<83><82><82><82><9d> says H<83><92><82>kon Knudsen, 23, a survivor of the attack and a member of the Labour youth leadership.

Outside the July 22 museum, people queue up at lunchtime to get in; as they emerge, many are tearful.

<83><82><82><82><93>It<83><82><82><82><84>s difficult, but to see it makes it more real,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Karolina, 27, who works in an Oslo law firm. It is important to see the car bomb itself and its effects, and the faces of the dead, she says.

<83><82><82><82><93>For me it<83><82><82><82><84>s a way to show respect for the victims and their families, it<83><82><82><82><84>s important for Norway to remember that these things can also happen here.<83><82><82><82><9d>

On the island this weekend, the fresh crop of teenage socialists is more interested in the football tournament and making new friends than discussing the unspeakable presence who robbed their movement of its innocence.

<83><82><82><82><93>No one is talking about him,<83><82><82><82><9d> <83><92><82><9c>verland says. <83><82><82><82><93>It<83><82><82><82><84>s really surreal <83><82><82><82><80><9c> I know that it happened but I can<83><82><82><82><84>t imagine that someone would come here and do that to young people.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The tragedy has changed her perspective on politics, she says, especially on the extreme right, which she fears is growing.

<83><82><82><82><93>It made me think, OK, I can make a difference here. I have to join, I have to do something, I have to help. Everyone is trying to grow from this experience.<83><82><82><82><9d>
text: The cheers of 1,300 Norwegian teenagers carry far over the still grey waters where, on 22 July 2011, children swam for their lives. They are returning to Utya to re-establish the Labour party youth wings annual summer camp on the island. Their return is a show of defiance to Anders Behring Breivik and a tribute to the 69 people he killed  most of them teenagers, the youngest just 14. The organisers of this years event include survivors of that day, but the camp has attracted many new faces. We are sending a message that we are taking the island back, theres a good energy, says Victoria verland, 17, here for her first camp. There were anxious moments when she and her friends boarded the ferry to the island, but the camp spirit quickly took over.  Related: Utya four years on: what's the mood in Norway?  It is a part of the grieving process to take back the place where terrible things happened, verland says. Everyone here is aware of what took place and they have been through a process in their head, though for some people it is really hard. The camps return marks a turning point in a national tragedy that is still unfolding. It is the culmination of a long and painful attempt to find a balance between politics and grief, courage and remembrance, youth and parenthood, moving on and looking back. Utya has posed the question of how, when the fabric of society has been torn, the threads can be woven back together. It has forced Norwegians to weigh the concerns of those directly affected against the wider needs of a nation living with the knowledge that Breivik came from within, and that the virus that spawned him has not gone away. For some, a refusal to reclaim the island would be a victory for terrorism and an affront to the dead. Others want Utya left as a memorial, unable to countenance laughter, music and selfies on the site of slaughter. I dont think Utya will ever be that paradise again, says Lisbeth Ryneland, whose daughter Synne lost her life, aged 18. Ryneland is happy the camp is re-opening, and that young people are getting on with their lives. On the other hand, for me it is a time with many feelings, because Synne isnt with them anymore, says Ryneland, who chairs the national support group for survivors and relatives. But because of the memorial, the 69 who were killed that day will never be forgotten. In a quiet clearing on the islands highest point, suspended from three tall pines, is a massive steel ring cut with the names and ages of the dead. In the circle no one is first, and no one last. The soil below has been planted with flowers to attract butterflies. When the thick mist pours into Tyrifjord, it condenses, and the steel weeps. The spot was proposed by Kolbein Fridtun, who lost his 19-year-old daughter, Hanne, on the island; a dozen parents of children who died have worked to clear the site. But space on the ring remains for seven names missing from the memorial  for some it is still too soon, and the emotions too raw, to imagine their childs absence fixed in metal. Each persons despair moves at its own pace. The parents feel their loss in very fibre of their bodies, says sne Seierstad, novelist and author of a bestselling book on the massacre . Maybe there are longer periods now when they dont think about their children  half an hour or perhaps an hour  but it is there every day. And for most of them, Utya is not their main concern, she said. It was never their island  it belonged to the young people who went there every year, the island of AUF, the Labour partys youth organisation, since 1932, and many future Labour leaders cut their political teeth at the annual summer camp. It is not a place you can just visit to remember. These young people were so in love with the island, Seierstad explains. The terrorist killed them because they were there, so strong, so political and independent-minded. They would probably have wanted their names to be on the memorial. The decision to return was taken on the day after the attacks, says Mani Hussaini, leader of the AUF. This will be the biggest summer camp ever, with talks and workshops on internationalism, feminism and anti-racism, preparation for the next elections  and a lot of fun. Our response is more openness and more democracy in our fight for equal rights. Utya is at the heart of Labour youth. But the left have had to temper their passion to reclaim the ground that Breivik took away. On the day after the attacks, the then prime minister, Jens Stoltenberg, said he would camp out on Utya in a years time. There was a rush to commission a memorial and prepare for an uninterrupted return to the island. The following year a firm of architects called Fantastic Norway presented sketches of bright new buildings and smiling young people. Buildings where children died would be torn down. It was too much, too soon. Plans to commemorate the first anniversary on the island excluded the parents of the dead. It seems they did not understand the force of grief, says Seierstad. For traumatised young people, it was all about moving on. That mistake destroyed a lot. Ragnhild Kaski, the AUFs general secretary, who was 21 when she fled from Breivik on the island, admits blunders were made. The project has changed. It needed to change, she explains. The things you think are right at first are not necessarily the right things to do a few years later  It has been a bumpy road for many of us. Our plans have changed and we have changed as well.  Related: Wounded landscape: how Norway is remembering its 2011 Utya massacre  Talking to the parents helped them to find a balance between learning how to shape Utyas future and remembering its past, Kaski says. Tens of millions of krona have been donated by unions, businesses and individuals to build conference and learning centres as a resource for the labour movement. Meanwhile, for the past two years Labour youth have held a summer camp on the mainland. When they came forward in 2012 with the plans for a new Utya, almost all the survivors and relatives of the dead said they needed more time, Ryneland says. We talked to Labour youth and gave them our advice, which they followed  after that we have had very good communication with them. With the re-opening of the camp this weekend, earlier divisions about the reconstruction have been laid to rest. The event has re-awakened public debate, which had died down since Breiviks trial in 2012. In last years extravagant bicentenary celebrations of the Norwegian constitution, the nations unity after the attacks was barely mentioned. But there have been moments that threatened to undermine the consensus in Norway around how to respond to the attacks. On the third anniversary last year, 19 mothers of the islands dead wrote to Conservative prime minister Erna Solberg asking for Utya to stay closed, and to remain as a place of remembrance. Just north of the island, residents are attempting to sue the government to prevent a national memorial on the mainland. Some locals picked up survivors, the dead and dying from the fjord, and feel that a proposal to dissect a peninsular of rock at Srbrten  creating a symbolic wound in the landscape  would aggravate their trauma. At the new July 22 Centre in downtown Oslo, inaugurated last month, there are also seven blank spaces where parents have asked that their children be excluded from photographs of the Utya dead. Disagreements broke out about whether or not to exhibit artefacts of the attacks in the very office block that Breivik bombed. There were rumours that the museum planned to exhibit the gun he used, and that it could become a traumatic, daily reminder to civil servants. The exhibit that visitors now see includes the remains of the car bomb Breivik detonated outside the prime ministers office just hours before the Utoya shootings, killing eight people. John Christian Elden, a lawyer whose firm represented most of the victims at Breiviks trial, branded it the museum of Breivik, and likens displaying his possessions to placing photographs of Hitler at Auschwitz. For others, labelling it the Breivik museum is just as absurd as calling the 9/11 memorial at Ground Zero in New York a museum to Osama Bin Laden. The blown-out windows of the office buildings awaiting demolition at the Oslo bomb site are a far more visible reminder to workers than the museum, tucked away in the wrecked basement of the central block. Since its opening on 22 July, it has received around 1,000 visitors a day, the museum said  big numbers in this country of 5 million people. Rather than a story of division, however, the new museum and the coming together of parents and activists for the camp in July represent a remarkable tale of unity in facing up to the tragedy. The 9/11 memorial took a decade to agree, and lots of conflict, says Seierstad. For us it has been four years. It could have been so much worse. The nature and magnitude of the crime mean that the response to the tragedy cannot be decided only by those directly affected, says Arne Johan Vetlesen, professor of philosophy at Oslo University. For survivors and relatives, wounds inflicted by Breivik might not be visible, but they are no less real. They find it hard to hold down jobs or study, and there is lasting depression, anxiety and post-traumatic stress. They have had a lot of problems, there is still quite a long way to go before they are back to their normal health status, says professor Grete Dyb of the Norwegian Centre for Violence and Traumatic Stress Studies in Oslo. She has followed survivors and their parents, and advised Labour youth leaders on how to approach the big decisions they have faced. Tears will flow on Utya island this weekend, Dyb says, but she is confident that the organisers have taken every precaution to ensure any outpouring of emotion will be healthy. Elisabeth Haukelands eldest son and daughter both survived the massacre, and they arent going back to Utya. But her youngest daughter is. Just 13 at the time of the attack, she went straight out to join the Labour youth.  Related: Breivik victims' parents too traumatised to work four years on, research shows  I think she is very brave, Haukeland tells me. All the same, she tries not to dwell on the thought of her daughter on the island this weekend, in a place where her other children suffered so much. I am convinced it would be worse if she was afraid and didnt want to get out and do things. The keenness of AUF leaders to get back on to the island makes sense, Haukeland says, because with each passing year the numbers of survivors eligible to attend the camp will fall, and the memory of 2011 needs to be passed on. Without a grasp of Utyas enormous significance to the labour movement, she adds, it could seem provocative to stress the need for continuity. But despite the strong association of Utya with the left, party politics are largely absent from the public debate in Norway about Breivik. Despite the attacks, in 2013 the country elected a rightwing coalition, which, for the first time, included the anti-immigrant Progress party, of which Breivik was a member for nine years until 2005. People did not vote for the right because they were sympathetic to Breivik, Seierstad says. He has never been cited in political debate, even on immigration or jihadism. The Progress party is less extreme today, she explains, and in any case, has never been linked to the attacks. The Progress party has never been made to pay for Breiviks membership  people are too decent in Norway. Even the youth wing, which is to the left of the Labour party on immigration, has moderate views on asylum. We want more liberal asylum policies, but we also have an understanding that too-liberal policies will cause rightwing ideas to grow, if you cant accept 20,000 each year and integrate them, says Hkon Knudsen, 23, a survivor of the attack and a member of the Labour youth leadership. Outside the July 22 museum, people queue up at lunchtime to get in; as they emerge, many are tearful. Its difficult, but to see it makes it more real, says Karolina, 27, who works in an Oslo law firm. It is important to see the car bomb itself and its effects, and the faces of the dead, she says. For me its a way to show respect for the victims and their families, its important for Norway to remember that these things can also happen here. On the island this weekend, the fresh crop of teenage socialists is more interested in the football tournament and making new friends than discussing the unspeakable presence who robbed their movement of its innocence. No one is talking about him, verland says. Its really surreal  I know that it happened but I cant imagine that someone would come here and do that to young people. The tragedy has changed her perspective on politics, she says, especially on the extreme right, which she fears is growing. It made me think, OK, I can make a difference here. I have to join, I have to do something, I have to help. Everyone is trying to grow from this experience.

webTitle: More than 11,000 Norwegians line up to shoot 16 wolves
trailText: Norwegian hunters outnumber wolves 763 to one, according to new figures for licences to kill population that could be as low as 30
headline: More than 11,000 Norwegians line up to shoot 16 wolves
standfirst: Norwegian hunters outnumber wolves 763 to one, according to new figures for licences to kill population that could be as low as 30
body:
Wolves have emerged as the most sought-after animal for Norwegian hunters this season, with 11,571 people registering for licences to shoot 16 animals <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a ratio of 723 hunters per wolf.

The animals <83><82><82><82><80><9c> of which Norway may have as few as 30 living in the wild <83><82><82><82><80><9c> top the league in new figures that reveal a trigger-happy community of hunters.

The Norwegian brown bear comes in a close second with 10,930 registered licence holders keen to hunt down 18 individuals, followed by 10,820 licence holders interested in 141 wolverines, according to the country<83><82><82><82><84>s register for hunters.

Related: The bloodlust of modern-day hunters is a disaster for the planet | Philip Hoare

The number of those registering to hunt wolves in the 2015-16 season compares with just under 10,000 people registered for the 2013-14 season <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the last for which figures are available, according to the Norwegian Association for Fishing and Hunting.

In Norway, the wolf-hunting season begins on 1 October and ends on 31 March.

Norway has a strong tradition of hunting and more than 200,000 registered hunters, most of whom have signed up for automatic notification once the licences are issued. It is viewed as a thrill <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and definitely a male domain. Only about 500 women have registered for this year<83><82><82><82><84>s hunt, although the proportion of female hunters in Norway is growing steadily.

The main pack of wolves is based in the south-eastern part of Norway, where they also have a designated habitat. However, many individuals wander into other areas of the country <83><82><82><82><80><9c> risking their lives in doing so.

Wolves that enter Sweden, Finland or Russia might be luckier since those countries are considered more concerned with sustainability of such fragile animal populations. While neither the wolf nor bear populations are yet at the level sought by Norwegian authorities, decisions to hand out hunting licences are made to protect livestock, according to the country<83><82><82><82><84>s environment agency.

While licensed hunting is part of a policy to keep predator populations under control, it is suspected that such populations <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and especially the wolves <83><82><82><82><80><9c> are kept down by illegal hunting, said Petter Wabakken, an internationally acclaimed expert on wolves. He thinks this is particularly disturbing given that Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s wolf population is perhaps as small as 30 animals.

Government policy at present allows three breeding females within the designated area. This is not enough to sustain a healthy population, Wabakken said.

The animals  of which Norway may have as few as 30 living in the wild  top the league in new figures that reveal a trigger-happy community of hunters.  The Norwegian brown bear comes in a close second with 10,930 registered licence holders keen to hunt down 18 individuals, followed by 10,820 licence holders interested in 141 wolverines, according to the countrys register for hunters.  Related: The bloodlust of modern-day hunters is a disaster for the planet | Philip Hoare  The number of those registering to hunt wolves in the 2015-16 season compares with just under 10,000 people registered for the 2013-14 season  the last for which figures are available, according to the Norwegian Association for Fishing and Hunting. In Norway, the wolf-hunting season begins on 1 October and ends on 31 March.  Norway has a strong tradition of hunting and more than 200,000 registered hunters, most of whom have signed up for automatic notification once the licences are issued. It is viewed as a thrill  and definitely a male domain. Only about 500 women have registered for this years hunt, although the proportion of female hunters in Norway is growing steadily. The main pack of wolves is based in the south-eastern part of Norway, where they also have a designated habitat. While neither the wolf nor bear populations are yet at the level sought by Norwegian authorities, decisions to hand out hunting licences are made to protect livestock, according to the countrys environment agency. While licensed hunting is part of a policy to keep predator populations under control, it is suspected that such populations  and especially the wolves  are kept down by illegal hunting, said Petter Wabakken, an internationally acclaimed expert on wolves. He thinks this is particularly disturbing given that Norways wolf population is perhaps as small as 30 animals. Government policy at present allows three breeding females within the designated area. This is not enough to sustain a healthy population, Wabakken said.

webTitle: Centrica signs deal to import more gas from Norway and Russia
trailText: Owner of British Gas increases amount purchased from Statoil by 50%, and from Gazprom by 75%
headline: Centrica signs deal to import more gas from Norway and Russia
standfirst: Owner of British Gas increases amount purchased from Statoil by 50%, and from Gazprom by 75%
body:
The UK<83><82><82><82><84>s increasing reliance on imported gas was underlined on Wednesday when the owner of British Gas announced that it had struck agreements to buy more gas from Norway and Russia.

Centrica<83><82><82><82><84>s 10-year deal, announced in 2011, to bring in 5bn cubic metres (bcm) a year from Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s Statoil, has been increased to 7.3 bcm per annum. The FTSE 100 company has also extended a deal with Gazprom, Russia<83><82><82><82><84>s state-owned gas company, to take delivery of 4.2 bcms each year, up from 2.4bcm.

<83><82><82><82><93>Britain needs around 70 bcm of natural gas each year to heat homes and businesses and to generate electricity, and the UK now needs to import more than half of this,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Centrica.

Fifteen years ago, the UK did not need to import gas, but supplies have been falling since 2000. In 2009, 45% of the natural gas used in the UK was imported, and this is expected to reach almost 70% by 2019.

Statoil will begin its deliveries from October and will provide a total of 73 bcm over the 10 years of the contract. The deal with Gazprom is with its UK arm, Gazprom Marketing & Trading, and is being secured at a time when Russian companies are the subject of sanctions because of the country<83><82><82><82><84>s role in the Ukraine crisis.

Centrica saidthe supply agreements with Statoil and Gazprom would meet the gas needs of 9m British homes a year and take the total amount that Centrica has committed in securing gas and electricity, through a range of suppliers, to over <83><80><9a><82>50bn.
text: The UKs increasing reliance on imported gas was underlined on Wednesday when the owner of British Gas announced that it had struck agreements to buy more gas from Norway and Russia. Centricas 10-year deal, announced in 2011, to bring in 5bn cubic metres (bcm) a year from Norways Statoil, has been increased to 7.3 bcm per annum. The FTSE 100 company has also extended a deal with Gazprom, Russias state-owned gas company, to take delivery of 4.2 bcms each year, up from 2.4bcm. Britain needs around 70 bcm of natural gas each year to heat homes and businesses and to generate electricity, and the UK now needs to import more than half of this, said Centrica. Fifteen years ago, the UK did not need to import gas, but supplies have been falling since 2000. In 2009, 45% of the natural gas used in the UK was imported, and this is expected to reach almost 70% by 2019. Statoil will begin its deliveries from October and will provide a total of 73 bcm over the 10 years of the contract. The deal with Gazprom is with its UK arm, Gazprom Marketing & Trading, and is being secured at a time when Russian companies are the subject of sanctions because of the countrys role in the Ukraine crisis. Centrica saidthe supply agreements with Statoil and Gazprom would meet the gas needs of 9m British homes a year and take the total amount that Centrica has committed in securing gas and electricity, through a range of suppliers, to over 50bn.

webTitle: Swedish islanders seek status update after Facebook dumps them in Norway
trailText: Residents of Gotland bemused by a Facebook glitch that places them just north of Oslo, and local businesses worry it might affect the tourist trade
headline: Swedish islanders seek status update after Facebook dumps them in Norway
standfirst: Residents of Gotland bemused by a Facebook glitch that places them just north of Oslo, and local businesses worry it might affect the tourist trade
body:
Facebook has been accused of a lot of things, from riding roughshod over people<83><82><82><82><84>s privacy to prudishly censoring the most innocuous of photographs.

But it<83><82><82><82><84>s never gone so far as to annex an entire island of 50,000 people and dump it in another country.

A couple of weeks ago, the residents of the sleepy island of Gotland in the Baltic sea off Sweden, started to notice that many of their Facebook entries were listing them as living in Norway, not Sweden.

Before long they realised that, as far as Facebook was concerned, their entire island was in Norway. Search for Gotland on Facebook and the map takes you to a point just north of Oslo on the river Gl<83><92><82>ma.

<83><82><82><82><93>It<83><82><82><82><84>s ridiculous,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Ulrica Fransson Ingelmark, editor of the Gotlands Allehanda newspaper, which first reported the bug.

<83><82><82><82><93>It<83><82><82><82><84>s been weeks since companies and private persons got a new address in Norway, and we talked about it a lot on the island, and nothing changed, and then we wrote about it, and now it<83><82><82><82><84>s a viral success, and Facebook still hasn<83><82><82><82><84>t changed it.<83><82><82><82><9d>

According to Julia Bendelin, who works for an advertising agency on the island, the glitch is causing real inconvenience.

<83><82><82><82><93>Last weekend I started a Facebook account for my son, and the first thing that happened was ads from Norway for young kids in Norwegian, and I was like: <83><82><82><82><9c>No, we<83><82><82><82><84>re in the middle of the Baltic sea, far from Norway.<83><82><82><82><84> We<83><82><82><82><84>ve been hi-jacked by Norway.<83><82><82><82><9d>

<83><82><82><82><93>Of course it<83><82><82><82><84>s a problem for small businesses,<83><82><82><82><9d> she added. <83><82><82><82><93>We live off tourists and we don<83><82><82><82><84>t want them to go to Norway, we want them to come here! We don<83><82><82><82><84>t do fjords.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Mandarva Stenborg, whose public relations company represents Facebook in Sweden, said she was still waiting for a reply from the company, four days after first reporting the problem.

<83><82><82><82><93>I reported it internally to Facebook on Thursday and they haven<83><82><82><82><84>t said anything more,<83><82><82><82><9d> she said. <83><82><82><82><93>I guess that they have escalated it internally, but I don<83><82><82><82><84>t have any more information on whether it is a mistake or a bug or anything like that.<83><82><82><82><9d>

For Bendelin, this isn<83><82><82><82><84>t good enough. <83><82><82><82><93>Don<83><82><82><82><84>t investigate it, change it,<83><82><82><82><9d> she said. <83><82><82><82><93>Give us back our island!<83><82><82><82><9d>
text: Facebook has been accused of a lot of things, from riding roughshod over peoples privacy to prudishly censoring the most innocuous of photographs. But its never gone so far as to annex an entire island of 50,000 people and dump it in another country. A couple of weeks ago, the residents of the sleepy island of Gotland in the Baltic sea off Sweden, started to notice that many of their Facebook entries were listing them as living in Norway, not Sweden. Before long they realised that, as far as Facebook was concerned, their entire island was in Norway. Search for Gotland on Facebook and the map takes you to a point just north of Oslo on the river Glma.  Its ridiculous, said Ulrica Fransson Ingelmark, editor of the Gotlands Allehanda newspaper, which first reported the bug. Its been weeks since companies and private persons got a new address in Norway, and we talked about it a lot on the island, and nothing changed, and then we wrote about it, and now its a viral success, and Facebook still hasnt changed it. According to Julia Bendelin, who works for an advertising agency on the island, the glitch is causing real inconvenience.  Last weekend I started a Facebook account for my son, and the first thing that happened was ads from Norway for young kids in Norwegian, and I was like: No, were in the middle of the Baltic sea, far from Norway. Weve been hi-jacked by Norway. Of course its a problem for small businesses, she added. We live off tourists and we dont want them to go to Norway, we want them to come here! We dont do fjords.  Mandarva Stenborg, whose public relations company represents Facebook in Sweden, said she was still waiting for a reply from the company, four days after first reporting the problem. I reported it internally to Facebook on Thursday and they havent said anything more, she said. I guess that they have escalated it internally, but I dont have any more information on whether it is a mistake or a bug or anything like that. For Bendelin, this isnt good enough. Dont investigate it, change it, she said. Give us back our island!

webTitle: Why is Spar intent on boosting Norway's cruel and dying whaling industry?
trailText: Norwayâs fourth largest food retail brand is using its vast store network to promote whale products in the face of consumer boycotts
headline: Why is Spar intent on boosting Norway's cruel and dying whaling industry?
standfirst: Norwayâs fourth largest food retail brand is using its vast store network to promote whale products in the face of consumer boycotts
body:
Last year, Norway killed more protected whales than any other country <83><82><82><82><80><9c> all for the sake of a marginal and dying industry characterised by cruelty and exploitation of an internationally protected species. Its 2014 catch of 736 minke whales was more than the combined catch of Japan and Iceland <83><82><82><82><80><9c> 447 and 261 whales respectively.

Commercial whaling was banned almost 30 years ago. Norway, however, has consistently flouted bans on commercial whaling and international trade in whale products through reservations to the international agreements under the International Whaling Commission (IWC) and the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species.

Related: Japan accused of falsifying whaling data

Reasons for the Norwegian government<83><82><82><82><84>s continued support for whale meat are complex, but include the fact that key stakeholders in the whaling industry have powerful allies in the government. There is also a misguided belief among senior officials and the fishing industry they serve that killing whales will improve commercial fish catches.

Today, a coalition of NGOs including the Environmental Investigation Agency, Animal Welfare Institute and CarbonFix Foundation is launching a campaign calling on Spar Norway, one of the country<83><82><82><82><84>s leading food retailers, to stop the distribution and sale of whale meat. The ultimate aim of the campaign is to reduce the market for whale meat and thus the incentive for continued whaling.

Spar is an international, multibillion euro enterprise with more than 12,000 stores in 40 countries, the majority of which are overwhelmingly against commercial whaling. Opinion polls in the UK and Germany, for example, found more than 80% of people would be unlikely to buy seafood products from companies linked to whaling.

Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s whaling and associated trade may be technically legal but it is clearly in defiance of international treaties. And the misappropriated methodology used by the country to set its high catch limits has been rejected by the IWC<83><82><82><82><84>s scientific committee as not being in accordance with the agreed scientific basis for ensuring sustainability.

Yet the country manages to mostly avoid international condemnation of its hunts, keeping a low profile at the IWC and allowing Japan and, to some extent, Iceland to take the flak.

Related: Iceland whaling season under way despite protest

Norway has been quietly but steadily increasing its catch in recent years and has its sights set on Japan<83><82><82><82><84>s whale meat market. Japan<83><82><82><82><84>s catches have been drastically reduced after the International Court of Justice ruled that Japan<83><82><82><82><84>s <83><82><82><82><93>scientific<83><82><82><82><9d> whaling was not for the purposes of science, effectively outlawing its Antarctic whale hunt.

A small stumbling block to Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s plans is that Japan has rejected Norwegian minke whale products due to high levels of pesticides, so expanding its limited domestic market is all the more important, although most Norwegians are not that interested in whales as food.

The Norwegian government and private entities have created several marketing campaigns in an effort to boost whale meat sales, promoting it to the hotel, restaurant and catering sectors. A marketing association established in 2012 has focused on improving the packaging, advertising and diversity of whale products to tempt consumers.

Yet despite these efforts, and exports of more than 100 tonnes of whale products, Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s whaling industry remains a marginal business.

This is why Spar Norway and its parent company, NorgesGruppen ASA, play such an important role. As big name brands with hundreds of stores across the country, they are promoting and facilitating the trade of products that otherwise would not occur. Their involvement doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t stop there <83><82><82><82><80><9c> NorgesGruppen is working with one whaling company to develop a marketing strategy for whale meat, presumably in the hope of significant future profits in the event that the export market opens up.

Whale species are increasingly recognised as essential components of healthy, productive marine ecosystems that contribute to increasing fish stocks and play an important role in our climate. Given that, plus the threat of consumer boycotts, the Norwegian fishing industry and government would do well to take a closer look at why the country continues whaling.

Despite its poor reputation, globalisation can be a force for good when major brands spanning multiple countries take a firm stand in favour of conservation and environmental protection. Walmart, Amazon, Rakuten and Tesco have ended their association with the sale of whale products in Japan when prompted by our organisations <83><82><82><82><80><9c> we trust that Spar will do the same.

Its 2014 catch of 736 minke whales was more than the combined catch of Japan and Iceland  447 and 261 whales respectively. Commercial whaling was banned almost 30 years ago. Norway, however, has consistently flouted bans on commercial whaling and international trade in whale products through reservations to the international agreements under the International Whaling Commission (IWC) and the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. The ultimate aim of the campaign is to reduce the market for whale meat and thus the incentive for continued whaling. A marketing association established in 2012 has focused on improving the packaging, advertising and diversity of whale products to tempt consumers. Their involvement doesnt stop there  NorgesGruppen is working with one whaling company to develop a marketing strategy for whale meat, presumably in the hope of significant future profits in the event that the export market opens up.  Whale species are increasingly recognised as essential components of healthy, productive marine ecosystems that contribute to increasing fish stocks and play an important role in our climate. Given that, plus the threat of consumer boycotts, the Norwegian fishing industry and government would do well to take a closer look at why the country continues whaling. Despite its poor reputation, globalisation can be a force for good when major brands spanning multiple countries take a firm stand in favour of conservation and environmental protection. Walmart, Amazon, Rakuten and Tesco have ended their association with the sale of whale products in Japan when prompted by our organisations  we trust that Spar will do the same.

webTitle: Norways Breivik massacre taught me you cant conquer hate with hate | Bjrn Ihler
trailText: As a survivor of the 2011 UtÃ¸ya attack, I feel the pain of those in Paris. But the only way to fight terrorism is to stand together, as humans, spreading peace
headline: Norwayâs Breivik massacre taught me you canât conquer hate with hate
standfirst: As a survivor of the 2011 UtÃ¸ya attack, I feel the pain of those in Paris. But the only way to fight terrorism is to stand together, as humans, spreading peace
body:
We don<83><82><82><82><84>t know everything yet. We know Paris experienced its worst night since the second world war. We know Islamic State claimed responsibility. As a survivor of the Anders Breivik massacre in Norway, I stand with the survivors of the attacks, their families, the families grieving lost loved ones, the people of Paris, the people of France, and all those who wish to live in peace.

Tough times lie ahead. World leaders, French citizens and people all over the world are of course condemning the Paris attack. So am I, but it doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t help anyone to dehumanise the perpetrators, calling this the act of the devil and so on. In dealing with violent extremism it is important to recognise that we all dehumanise one another. Our ability to stop violent extremism is dependent on our ability to see one another as human. Let us retain that ability in the face of terror, and we may be on the right path.

After the 2011 attack in Norway, in which 77 people were killed and I almost lost my life, the Norwegian prime minister spoke of fighting hatred with more love, more democracy and more openness. Whether these ideals were followed or not in the case of Norway can be debated; President Fran<83><92><82>ois Hollande is, however, already on a different path, vowing a ruthless fight as response to the Paris attacks.

<83><82><82><82><93>Hurt people hurt people<83><82><82><82><9d> is a commonly held phrase among those of us working against violent extremism. I learned it from a former violent extremist, Arno Michaelis who has first-hand experience of the subject. By vowing a <83><82><82><82><93>ruthless fight<83><82><82><82><9d> Hollande falls into the same pattern, a pattern that will only lead to further violence, more deaths and more horror.

Related: The French are mourning, but by sticking together we can overcome | Natalie Nougayr<83><92><82>de

I was sitting in my apartment in Turkey as the scenes in Paris unfolded on the screen. When Paris is under attack it seems natural to feel affected. France is our neighbour, a European country from which much of our culture, our philosophies and beliefs originate. To place blame on anyone but the perpetrators seems foolish. It<83><82><82><82><84>s clear that France is the victim in this. But it<83><82><82><82><84>s also foolish not to acknowledge that these acts of violence don<83><82><82><82><84>t occur in a vacuum.

The world is interconnected and actions, perceptions and ideologies of hatred and violent extremism are international phenomena. We have to recognise that what<83><82><82><82><84>s going on, and what our politicians choose to do or not do in Syria, Iraq, Libya, Lebanon and the rest of the world has an impact, not just politically, but also in the grassroots of communities and the individuals they consist of. The interconnectedness, and the international nature of extremism is what makes it possible for kids from France and Belgium, and maybe Syria and other places, to apparently join forces and pull off an attack of this magnitude.

So how do we stop this violence? The world is seemingly bursting at its seams with opposing ideologies, fed and fuelled by fear and hatred stemming from alienation, dehumanisation and destruction. The best thing we can do is to go out there, recognise one another<83><82><82><82><84>s humanity, treat one another with respect and decency. Our response to hate needs to be peace. In my own struggle with surviving violent extremism it has been key to remain true to the principles I believed in. Principles that guide my work for peace, against violent extremism.

Related: The Trollh<83><92><82>ttan killer didn<83><82><82><82><84>t become an extremist overnight. Somebody could have stopped him | Bj<83><92><82>rn Ihler

Across social media people quickly took the leap to blaming Islam and Muslims as a whole. They forget there are 1.5 billion of <83><82><82><82><93>them<83><82><82><82><9d> in this world, and that they mostly wish to live their lives in peace like everyone else. We know the French far right is already exploiting the events, spreading hate, encouraging violence. We know policies will be implemented that will further divide people. We know attacks such as this can be steps in a strategy to divide and conquer. The only way to fight this is by standing together, as humans.

Parisians have shown resilience. They opened their homes to one another on Friday night, helped one another, accepted one another. They saw one another as humans. In the darkest night, people came together and together they created bright spots, showing Paris as the City of Light even in its darkest hours. France, Europe and the world can follow the example of these Parisians.
