webTitle: Norwegian oil town loses direct flights to Texas after slump in crude price
trailText: SAS airline launched flights from Stavanger to Houston last summer at a time when oil price was more than double what it is now
headline: Norwegian oil town loses direct flights to Texas after slump in crude price
standfirst: SAS airline launched flights from Stavanger to Houston last summer at a time when oil price was more than double what it is now
body:
When direct flights from northern Europe<82><84>s oil capital to the heart of Texas launched a year ago, passengers toasted their booming industry with vintage champagnes.

Since then, however, the oil price has more than halved, gouging a hole in Norway<82><84>s economy and forcing the Scandinavian airline SAS to cancel its six flights a week from Stavanger to Houston.

<82><93>As a consequence of reduced activity in the oil industry, SAS has experienced a severe decrease in demand and thus passenger loads on the Stavanger-Houston route. Hence, SAS no longer has sound commercial grounds for continuing this niche route,<82><9d> the airline said in a statement.

When the route started in August 2014, it was aimed at connecting two huge oil markets at a time when the price of crude was $98 a barrel. Now the price is barely $45. The German airline Lufthansa scrapped direct flights between Stavanger and Frankfurt this summer, and Air France ceased direct flights from Paris in May.

The collapse in the oil price has hit Norway<82><84>s economy, which is predicted to grow by little more than 1% this year despite record low interest rates. Around 50% of Norway<82><84>s export income comes from oil, which accounts for 20% of investment.

The effect on Stavanger, Norway<82><84>s fourth largest city, has been pronounced. One in three jobs, around 43,000, are directly or indirectly related to oil and gas in the area. Thousands of jobs have already been lost, and house prices are sliding <82><80><9c> only 16 properties were sold in the city this summer, according to a housing market survey by Samfunns<83>konomisk Analyse.

Related: Oil price crash threatens the future of the North Sea oilfields

Stavanger is an exporter of oil technology and oil-related equipment. According to one estimate, there are 150 Norwegian firms in the Houston area, and 12,000 Norwegians live in or around the Texan city.

Norway<82><84>s investment in oil and gas will decline by more than 30% over the next two years, according to <83><9c>ystein D<83>rum, chief economist at DNB Markets, a financial services group. DNB expects the oil price will pick up to around $65 in 2016, and $70 in 2017, stabilising at between $60 and $80 a barrel.

<82><93>This will provide a skewed hit to the Norwegian economy <82><80><9c> we expect to see a much weaker development in labour and housing markets in western Norway, particularly in Stavanger. But we do not predict a decline in the economy overall,<82><9d> D<83>rum said.

The SAS flight to Houston is the longest by a Boeing 737 aircraft, lasting more than 10 hours. To get the extra range, the airline had to take out 100 seats, leaving only 44, to fit additional fuel tanks. A return ticket costs around NKr25,000 (<82>1,970).

The final flight to Houston will take place on 23 October.

Since then, however, the oil price has more than halved, gouging a hole in Norways economy and forcing the Scandinavian airline SAS to cancel its six flights a week from Stavanger to Houston. As a consequence of reduced activity in the oil industry, SAS has experienced a severe decrease in demand and thus passenger loads on the Stavanger-Houston route. Hence, SAS no longer has sound commercial grounds for continuing this niche route, the airline said in a statement. When the route started in August 2014, it was aimed at connecting two huge oil markets at a time when the price of crude was $98 a barrel. Now the price is barely $45. The German airline Lufthansa scrapped direct flights between Stavanger and Frankfurt this summer, and Air France ceased direct flights from Paris in May. The collapse in the oil price has hit Norways economy, which is predicted to grow by little more than 1% this year despite record low interest rates. Around 50% of Norways export income comes from oil, which accounts for 20% of investment.  The effect on Stavanger, Norways fourth largest city, has been pronounced. One in three jobs, around 43,000, are directly or indirectly related to oil and gas in the area. Thousands of jobs have already been lost, and house prices are sliding  only 16 properties were sold in the city this summer, according to a housing market survey by Samfunnskonomisk Analyse.  Related: Oil price crash threatens the future of the North Sea oilfields  Stavanger is an exporter of oil technology and oil-related equipment. According to one estimate, there are 150 Norwegian firms in the Houston area, and 12,000 Norwegians live in or around the Texan city. Norways investment in oil and gas will decline by more than 30% over the next two years, according to ystein Drum, chief economist at DNB Markets, a financial services group. DNB expects the oil price will pick up to around $65 in 2016, and $70 in 2017, stabilising at between $60 and $80 a barrel. This will provide a skewed hit to the Norwegian economy  we expect to see a much weaker development in labour and housing markets in western Norway, particularly in Stavanger. But we do not predict a decline in the economy overall, Drum said. The SAS flight to Houston is the longest by a Boeing 737 aircraft, lasting more than 10 hours. To get the extra range, the airline had to take out 100 seats, leaving only 44, to fit additional fuel tanks. A return ticket costs around NKr25,000 (1,970).  The final flight to Houston will take place on 23 October.

webTitle: Esperance bushfire: British man, Norwegian student and farmer among dead
trailText: Briton Tom Butcher, 31, died trying to save his girlfriendâs horse from huge fire in the south-west of Western Australia, along with two farm workers
headline: Esperance bushfire: British man, Norwegian student and farmer among dead
standfirst: Briton Tom Butcher, 31, died trying to save his girlfriendâs horse from huge fire in the south-west of Western Australia, along with two farm workers
body:
A British man, a Norwegian student and a German woman have been identified as victims of the Western Australian bushfire that also killed a local farmer on Tuesday. All three were workers at the Karranga Station in Scadden, north of Esperance. A local man also died.

Briton Tom Butcher, 31, died as he tried to save his girlfriend<83><82><82><82><84>s horse from the huge fire near the town of Esperance, his employer told the Australian newspaper. A mechanic who was planning to buy a house with his girlfriend after moving to Australia four years ago, he had been living in the town for the past year.

<83><82><82><82><93>I spoke to him on Friday evening and his last words to me were <83><82><82><82><93>I<83><82><82><82><84>m living the dream mate, I<83><82><82><82><84>m living the dream<83><82><82><82><9d>,<83><82><82><82><9d> his sister, Jess Greenaway, told WA Today.

<83><82><82><82><93>Tom had a heart of gold and he would do anything for anyone.<83><82><82><82><9d>

His girlfriend, Leila Vadnjal, wrote on Facebook that she didn<83><82><82><82><84>t <83><82><82><82><93>go an hour<83><82><82><82><9d> without talking to him. She described Butcher as her hero.

<83><82><82><82><93>Feeling lost is an understatement,<83><82><82><82><9d> she wrote. <83><82><82><82><93>I told you every day I need a cuddle and today I need it most.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The other victims were named as Anna Winther, 29, from Norway, and Julia Kohrs-Lichte, 19, from Germany.

Their employer, Linda Campbell, told the Australian newspaper that she and Butcher thought there was enough time for him to leave the Campbells<83><82><82><82><84> farm with Winther and Kohrs-Lichte and drive towards Esperance to drop off the horse at Vadnjal<83><82><82><82><84>s stables.

Campbell said she had suggested her daughter go with the other three, but she had opted to stay at the farm. The homestead was undamaged.

The local man who died, Kym <83><82><82><82><93>Freddy<83><82><82><82><9d> Curnow, 45, has been hailed as a hero for trying to stop the trio and others driving into danger.

But they and Curnow were overwhelmed by smoke a few kilometres from the farm, apparently after heeding Curnow<83><82><82><82><84>s warning for them to turn around but failing to outrun the rapidly moving fire.

Curnow had stopped several cars driving into the blaze in the Grass Patch and Salmon Gums areas, north of Esperance, on Tuesday.

It is believed Winther and Kohrs-Lichte had arrived to work on the farm only two weeks ago. Perth<83><82><82><82><84>s Curtin university said Winther had graduated with a master<83><82><82><82><84>s degree in human rights last year. She is believed to have been working for Amnesty International, with one of her colleagues, Amelia Freelander, tweeting; <83><82><82><82><93>Very sad to hear that Amnesty Activist Anna Winther was one of 4 to perish in the #EsperanceFires<83><82><82><82><9d>.

Curnow<83><82><82><82><84>s friend Glen Quinlivan held back tears talking about the Scadden farmer on Thursday.

<83><82><82><82><93>We were full tilt in our fire truck, trying to get away from it and only just made it,<83><82><82><82><9d> he told reporters. <83><82><82><82><93>Anyone who was behind us had no chance.

<83><82><82><82><93>It<83><82><82><82><84>s not about heroics, it<83><82><82><82><84>s just you do what you<83><82><82><82><84>ve got to do, and he did what he had to do.

Guy Green, whose family lost farms, machinery and houses, said his life would never be the same without Curnow.

<83><82><82><82><93>Not all heroes wear capes or a suit,<83><82><82><82><9d> he wrote on Facebook. <83><82><82><82><93>We<83><82><82><82><84>ve all lost a great mate and to us younger boys a father figure.

<83><82><82><82><93>You were much more than a hero and risked your life doing what you always did.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Western Australian premier, Colin Barnett, said the deaths were tragic.

<83><82><82><82><93>Foreign nationals who came to Australia to work and have a good time, and tragically and sadly, they<83><82><82><82><84>ve lost their life,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said.

About 135,000 hectares have been burnt by the fire and the alert level remained at <83><82><82><82><93>watch and act<83><82><82><82><9d> on Thursday evening.

The Bureau of Meteorology said temperatures would gradually rise on Saturday and thunderstorms could form on Sunday.
text: A British man, a Norwegian student and a German woman have been identified as victims of the Western Australian bushfire that also killed a local farmer on Tuesday. All three were workers at the Karranga Station in Scadden, north of Esperance. A local man also died. Briton Tom Butcher, 31, died as he tried to save his girlfriends horse from the huge fire near the town of Esperance, his employer told the Australian newspaper. A mechanic who was planning to buy a house with his girlfriend after moving to Australia four years ago, he had been living in the town for the past year. I spoke to him on Friday evening and his last words to me were Im living the dream mate, Im living the dream, his sister, Jess Greenaway, told WA Today. Tom had a heart of gold and he would do anything for anyone. His girlfriend, Leila Vadnjal, wrote on Facebook that she didnt go an hour without talking to him. She described Butcher as her hero. Feeling lost is an understatement, she wrote. I told you every day I need a cuddle and today I need it most. The other victims were named as Anna Winther, 29, from Norway, and Julia Kohrs-Lichte, 19, from Germany.  Their employer, Linda Campbell, told the Australian newspaper that she and Butcher thought there was enough time for him to leave the Campbells farm with Winther and Kohrs-Lichte and drive towards Esperance to drop off the horse at Vadnjals stables. Campbell said she had suggested her daughter go with the other three, but she had opted to stay at the farm. The homestead was undamaged. The local man who died, Kym Freddy Curnow, 45, has been hailed as a hero for trying to stop the trio and others driving into danger. But they and Curnow were overwhelmed by smoke a few kilometres from the farm, apparently after heeding Curnows warning for them to turn around but failing to outrun the rapidly moving fire. Curnow had stopped several cars driving into the blaze in the Grass Patch and Salmon Gums areas, north of Esperance, on Tuesday. It is believed Winther and Kohrs-Lichte had arrived to work on the farm only two weeks ago. Perths Curtin university said Winther had graduated with a masters degree in human rights last year. She is believed to have been working for Amnesty International, with one of her colleagues, Amelia Freelander, tweeting; Very sad to hear that Amnesty Activist Anna Winther was one of 4 to perish in the #EsperanceFires. Curnows friend Glen Quinlivan held back tears talking about the Scadden farmer on Thursday. We were full tilt in our fire truck, trying to get away from it and only just made it, he told reporters. Anyone who was behind us had no chance. Its not about heroics, its just you do what youve got to do, and he did what he had to do. Guy Green, whose family lost farms, machinery and houses, said his life would never be the same without Curnow. Not all heroes wear capes or a suit, he wrote on Facebook. Weve all lost a great mate and to us younger boys a father figure. You were much more than a hero and risked your life doing what you always did. Western Australian premier, Colin Barnett, said the deaths were tragic. Foreign nationals who came to Australia to work and have a good time, and tragically and sadly, theyve lost their life, he said. About 135,000 hectares have been burnt by the fire and the alert level remained at watch and act on Thursday evening. The Bureau of Meteorology said temperatures would gradually rise on Saturday and thunderstorms could form on Sunday.

webTitle: Susanne Sundfr: Ten Love Songs review  brilliant pop from Norwegian megastar
trailText: Susanne SundfÃ¸râs sixth album is a joyously commanding work of pop art that should not be missed
headline: Susanne SundfÃ¸r: Ten Love Songs review â brilliant pop from Norwegian megastar
standfirst: (Sonnet sound)
body: Halfway through Susanne Sundf<83><92><82>r<83><82><82><82><84>s sixth album, the listener stumbles across a monolith: a vast, 10-minute edifice made up of sepulchral organ, weeping strings, Abbaeseque chord changes, a lyric in which Sundf<83><92><82>r asserts she<83><82><82><82><84>s barely noticed <83><82><82><82><93>the cosmic war raging in the sky<83><82><82><82><9d> because she<83><82><82><82><84>s so darned sad about the heartless man who took off her dress, and then <83><82><82><82><80><9c> five minutes in <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a chamber music section that lasts three and a half minutes. Memorial, then, is fittingly titled: it<83><82><82><82><84>s lachrymose almost to the point of self-parody, yet utterly magnificent. Sundf<83><92><82>r is a bona fide star in her native Norway, No 1 albums and all, and it<83><82><82><82><84>s completely understandable. Ten Love Songs shows a command of artpop, chilly synthpop, and that simultaneously joyous and desperate disco that seems to seep out of Scandinavia in an unending flood: it<83><82><82><82><84>s both appealingly direct yet perfectly thought-through. The way the bass hook in Fade Away, a straight pinch from scores of dancefloor hits before, is kept stiff and hard seems to symbolise a mood of thwarted desire. Don<83><82><82><82><84>t miss out on this: it<83><82><82><82><84>s a quite brilliant album.
text: Halfway through Susanne Sundfrs sixth album, the listener stumbles across a monolith: a vast, 10-minute edifice made up of sepulchral organ, weeping strings, Abbaeseque chord changes, a lyric in which Sundfr asserts shes barely noticed the cosmic war raging in the sky becauseshes so darned sad about theheartless man who took off her dress, and then  five minutes in  achamber music section that lasts three and a half minutes. Memorial, then, is fittingly titled: its lachrymose almost to the point of self-parody, yetutterly magnificent. Sundfr isabona fide starin her native Norway,No 1 albumsand all, and itscompletely understandable. TenLove Songs showsacommand ofartpop, chilly synthpop, and that simultaneously joyous and desperate disco that seems to seep out of Scandinavia in an unending flood: its both appealingly direct yet perfectly thought-through. The way the bass hook in Fade Away, astraight pinch from scores of dancefloor hits before, iskept stiff andhard seems to symbolise a moodofthwarted desire. Dont missout on this: its a quite brilliant album.

webTitle: Narrow-minded Sweden hails stage version of acclaimed Norwegian novel
trailText: A book by Karl Ove Knausgaard, who criticised the Swedes, has been successfully taken to Stockholm
headline: âNarrow-mindedâ Sweden hails stage version of acclaimed Norwegian novel
standfirst: A book by Karl Ove Knausgaard, who criticised the Swedes, has been successfully taken to Stockholm
body:
When director Ole Anders Tandberg was asked to stage My Struggle for Stockholm<83><82><82><82><84>s city theatre at the start of this year, his instinct was to refuse.

The six-volume autobiographical novel by the Norwegian writer Karl Ove Knausgaard, with its highly personal voice and frequent shifts between memoir and essay, was something no play could do justice to. <83><82><82><82><93>My first thought was that it<83><82><82><82><84>s impossible. There<83><82><82><82><84>s no way,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said. <83><82><82><82><93>The novel, and the amount of thoughts and reflections in it, was too huge. My second thought was, I<83><82><82><82><84>d like to give it a try.<83><82><82><82><9d>

My Struggle is Scandinavia<83><82><82><82><84>s most celebrated literary work this decade and a bestseller, selling one copy for every nine inhabitants in Tandberg<83><82><82><82><84>s native Norway. Increasingly it is also winning admirers internationally, with the author lionised on his tour to the US earlier this year. Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s own national theatre spent a year trying to adapt it, but abandoned the project.

Tandberg<83><82><82><82><84>s success is largely thanks to his decision to do away with <83><82><82><82><93>parts<83><82><82><82><9d> for the actors. Instead, two men and two women jog on to the stage, dressed as if they had just walked in off the street. They take turns speaking conversationally into a microphone to the audience, reading through Knausgaard<83><82><82><82><84>s description of himself writing in his Malm<83><92><82> apartment, while the others look on and react with shame, embarrassment and laughter. At first it seems like a gimmick, with all four actors, including the women, somehow playing Knausgaard. But it works astonishingly well.

<83><82><82><82><93>Having a woman claiming that she<83><82><82><82><84>s Karl Ove Knausgaard is really to say that this is authentic fiction, that this is not really truth,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Tandberg. <83><82><82><82><93>It becomes evidently clear when there are four people claiming to be one person, that it<83><82><82><82><84>s not really true.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The set is limited to four desks, four chairs, four typewriters, a few microphones and a huge grey boulder which looms throughout. The actors move fluidly between the fragments Tandberg has judiciously picked out of the text. He claims his rule in cutting down the books, a process which took several months, was to <83><82><82><82><93>always keep an eye out for where the pain is the biggest in his writing, where is the place where the knife goes deepest<83><82><82><82> [Knausgaard] is a very self-destructing man. I saw the whole project as a way for this author to find a way for himself to live.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The cut version could have simply been a <83><82><82><82><93>reduced Knausgaard<83><82><82><82><9d> (all 3,600 pages in only 150 minutes) and, indeed, on Thursday, that<83><82><82><82><84>s what many had come to see. <83><82><82><82><93>This seems to be a convenient way not to have to read the books,<83><82><82><82><9d> said <83><92><82><80>sa, a woman in her early 30s. <83><82><82><82><93>Everybody seems to have a quite strong view of this book, so you feel you have to read it, but the sheer volume is intimidating.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Knausgaard is a talking point largely because of a stinging, intemperate article he wrote in response to a feminist attack in May, in which he damned the Swedes as a nation of narrow-minded Cyclopes, <83><82><82><82><93>full of hate and fear<83><82><82><82><9d>, who cannot tolerate ambiguity, and as a result cannot enjoy or understand literature. A reprint of the article takes up more than half of the programme.

Tandberg keeps the scenes which have most enraged feminists, notably Knausgaard<83><82><82><82><84>s claim to have been deprived of sexual potency at a <83><82><82><82><93>baby rhythm<83><82><82><82><9d> class, or his anguish at having his productivity as an artist suffocated by gender-equal childcare.

On stage, though, these scenes were met with laughter rather than disapproval. Indeed, one of the surprises of the production is how funny it is. The actors revel in slapstick depictions of teenage sexual fumbling, premature ejaculation, or loosening a stubborn stool with a finger.

<83><82><82><82><93>Sex is kind of fun on stage and impotence is even funnier. There<83><82><82><82><84>s something about it that suits the theatre,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Tandberg. The novel<83><82><82><82><84>s arresting opening lines <83><82><82><82><80><9c> <83><82><82><82><93>For the heart, life is simple: it beats for as long as it can. Then it stops<83><82><82><82><9d> <83><82><82><82><80><9c> now form the climax of the first act, coming as the young writer considers suicide, cutting lines in his face with a shard of glass.

After its run in Stockholm, Tandberg is hoping to take the play to wherever the novels have had an impact, starting with the rest of Scandinavia, then the US and possibly the UK.

<83><82><82><82> This article was amended on 7 September 2015. An earlier version said that the play was all 3,600 pages of My Struggle in only 200, rather than 150, minutes.
text: When director Ole Anders Tandberg was asked to stage My Struggle for Stockholms city theatre at the start of this year, his instinct was to refuse. The six-volume autobiographical novel by the Norwegian writer Karl Ove Knausgaard, with its highly personal voice and frequent shifts between memoir and essay, was something no play could do justice to. My first thought was that its impossible. Theres no way, he said. The novel, and the amount of thoughts and reflections in it, was too huge. My second thought was, Id like to give it a try. My Struggle is Scandinavias most celebrated literary work this decade and a bestseller, selling one copy for every nine inhabitants in Tandbergs native Norway. Increasingly it is also winning admirers internationally, with the author lionised on his tour to the US earlier this year. Norways own national theatre spent a year trying to adapt it, but abandoned the project. Tandbergs success is largely thanks to his decision to do away with parts for the actors. Instead, two men and two women jog on to the stage, dressed as if they had just walked in off the street. They take turns speaking conversationally into a microphone to the audience, reading through Knausgaards description of himself writing in his Malm apartment, while the others look on and react with shame, embarrassment and laughter. At first it seems like a gimmick, with all four actors, including the women, somehow playing Knausgaard. But it works astonishingly well. Having a woman claiming that shes Karl Ove Knausgaard is really to say that this is authentic fiction, that this is not really truth, says Tandberg. It becomes evidently clear when there are four people claiming to be one person, that its not really true. The set is limited to four desks, four chairs, four typewriters, a few microphones and a huge grey boulder which looms throughout. The actors move fluidly between the fragments Tandberg has judiciously picked out of the text. He claims his rule in cutting down the books, a process which took several months, was to always keep an eye out for where the pain is the biggest in his writing, where is the place where the knife goes deepest [Knausgaard] is a very self-destructing man. I saw the whole project as a way for this author to find a way for himself to live. The cut version could have simply been a reduced Knausgaard (all 3,600 pages in only 150 minutes) and, indeed, on Thursday, thats what many had come to see. This seems to be a convenient way not to have to read the books, said sa, a woman in her early 30s. Everybody seems to have a quite strong view of this book, so you feel you have to read it, but the sheer volume is intimidating. Knausgaard is a talking point largely because of a stinging, intemperate article he wrote in response to a feminist attack in May, in which he damned the Swedes as a nation of narrow-minded Cyclopes, full of hate and fear, who cannot tolerate ambiguity, and as a result cannot enjoy or understand literature. A reprint of the article takes up more than half of the programme. Tandberg keeps the scenes which have most enraged feminists, notably Knausgaards claim to have been deprived of sexual potency at a baby rhythm class, or his anguish at having his productivity as an artist suffocated by gender-equal childcare. On stage, though, these scenes were met with laughter rather than disapproval. Indeed, one of the surprises of the production is how funny it is. The actors revel in slapstick depictions of teenage sexual fumbling, premature ejaculation, or loosening a stubborn stool with a finger. Sex is kind of fun on stage and impotence is even funnier. Theres something about it that suits the theatre, said Tandberg. The novels arresting opening lines  For the heart, life is simple: it beats for as long as it can. Then it stops  now form the climax of the first act, coming as the young writer considers suicide, cutting lines in his face with a shard of glass. After its run in Stockholm, Tandberg is hoping to take the play to wherever the novels have had an impact, starting with the rest of Scandinavia, then the US and possibly the UK.  This article was amended on 7 September 2015. An earlier version said that the play was all 3,600 pages of My Struggle in only 200, rather than 150, minutes.

webTitle: Could Oslo's decision to divest from coal inspire bigger cities to do the same?
trailText: Osloâs move to sell its stocks in coal companies sets a precedent â but the real prize for divestment campaigners would be London or New York
headline: Could Oslo's decision to divest from coal inspire bigger cities to do the same?
standfirst: Osloâs move to sell its stocks in coal companies sets a precedent â but the real prize for divestment campaigners would be London or New York
body:
When Oslo sells the coal investments in its pension portfolio next month, it will set a historic precedent: the first capital city in the world to divest itself of that most polluting of fossil fuels. And the city is just the highest profile in a series of major urban areas that have made bold moves in recent weeks, ridding themselves of fossil fuel investments and becoming more carbon friendly.

Leichardt, Australia voted to completely divest from fossil fuels within three years, while Byron Bay announced the decision to commit to zero emissions. Smaller US cities have already gotten on board in various ways, while last week in London, the GLA passed a motion asking the mayor to approve pulling City Hall<83><82><82><82><84>s pension fund out of all fossil fuel holdings. The list of cities that have divested appears set to grow ever longer.

But does Oslo<83><82><82><82><84>s decision really mean much, given that Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s own pension fund <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the gigantic Norwegian Government Pension Fund Global (GPFG) <83><82><82><82><80><9c> continues to invest in fossil fuels? Is the momentum behind municipal divestment as unstoppable as it seems? And is divestment something that should, or could, be emulated by bigger cities like London?

Erik Lae Solberg, Oslo<83><82><82><82><84>s vice mayor for finance, admits his city<83><82><82><82><84>s decision to sell 40m krone (<83><80><9a><82>3.3m) worth of coal investments in the Oslo Pension Fund isn<83><82><82><82><84>t much. But it sends a signal, he says, that Oslo does not want to contribute to the most climate-damaging fossil fuels, and that the city has a wider goal to be climate-friendly.

<83><82><82><82><93>We<83><82><82><82><84>ve seen that coal is clearly the energy source that is most harmful,<83><82><82><82><9d> Solberg said. <83><82><82><82><93>It<83><82><82><82><84>s been said that the cities of the world contribute about 70% of carbon emissions. So clearly the cities of the world are an important part of the problem of climate change.<83><82><82><82><9d>

In 2011, the council set a goal to reduce the city<83><82><82><82><84>s greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2030, and be climate-neutral by 2050. To do so, it has set out an array of measures, from 258 municipal electric-car charging stations, to recycling household waste for bio-fuel to power the city<83><82><82><82><84>s buses.

Still, it is a conundrum for Norway, a major producer of oil (and, to a lesser extent, coal), which channels its excess petroleum revenues into its own pension fund. The government has so far resisted parliamentary calls for Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s 5.5tn krone (<83><80><9a><82>470bn) nest egg, GPFG <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the world<83><82><82><82><84>s largest sovereign wealth fund <83><82><82><82><80><9c> to divest from fossil fuel. A government-appointed panel recently recommended that the fund not divest from fossil fuels, but rather set up a new climate-related exclusion criterion on a case-by-case basis. It concluded:

<83><82><82><82><93>Energy production constitutes an important basis for our society, and fossil fuels <83><82><82><82><80><9c> both petroleum and coal <83><82><82><82><80><9c> will remain part of the mix for decades to come,<83><82><82><82><9d> the report concluded in December. <83><82><82><82><93>The question is thus not whether investors will own these companies, but which investors are <83><82><82><82><9c>good<83><82><82><82><84> owners of these assets from a financial and ethical perspective.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The giant Norwegian fund held at least 316.7bn (<83><80><9a><82>26.8bn) krone in oil, gas and coal investments in 2014, according to NGOs Urgewald and Future in Our Hands. It did divest from 52 coal companies last year, but Urgewald says it actually ended up increasing the value of its coal holdings, from 82.2bn krone in 2013 to 85.7bn krone last year.

It wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s cities which led the charge to divest, however. The divestment movement here has its roots in the small community of Eid, population 6,000, whose mayor Alfred Bj<83><92><82>rlo took up the cause with its pension fund manager more than two years ago, after he was inspired by a city in the US.

<83><82><82><82><93>It was towards the end of 2012 when, by chance, I read about the Seattle mayor<83><82><82><82><84>s plans to pull out of all coal funds,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Bj<83><92><82>rlo. <83><82><82><82><93>I thought if a city like Seattle could do something like this, then it is fully possible in Norway.<83><82><82><82><9d>

It was indeed Seattle that was the first US city to join the Fossil Free divestment campaign led by 350.org. Mayor Mike McGinn announced in December 2012 that Seattle would not invest any of its $1.4bn operating cashflow in fossil fuel companies, and would seek to divest its $1.9bn pension fund and $700m deferred compensation plan.

Whether the world<83><82><82><82><84>s megacities will follows suit is another question entirely. Last week<83><82><82><82><84>s vote to call on the mayor to divest London<83><82><82><82><84>s<83><82><82><82><84>s <83><80><9a><82>2bn GLA Group Investment Syndicate from fossil fuel investments, as well as to ask the chair of the <83><80><9a><82>4.8bm portfolio London Pension Fund Authority (LPFA) to commit to divestment, falls on Boris Johnson <83><82><82><82><80><9c> whose office pointed out what it considered the drawbacks.

<83><82><82><82><93>The mayor takes climate change extremely seriously,<83><82><82><82><9d> a spokesperson said, adding that the mayor<83><82><82><82><84>s office believed a sudden divestment on London<83><82><82><82><84>s part from fossil fuel investments would cause <83><82><82><82><93>a huge disruption to the world economy, let alone the retirement plans for millions of UK residents<83><82><82><82><9d>. There was, the spokesperson said, <83><82><82><82><93>a realism that there needs to be transition away from fossil fuel and not a sudden cliff-edge<83><82><82><82><9d>.

Danielle Paffard, a campaigner for Fossil Free UK divestment, calls Johnson <83><82><82><82><93>a fossil fuel head<83><82><82><82><9d> and is less than optimistic. But she says that with mayoral elections next year, the issue of divestment could become a big part of the debate. In the meantime, Fossil Free has set its sights on encouraging some European cities, such as Amsterdam, Berlin and Stockholm, to divest. Her US colleague, Amy Miller, points to the progress being made in states such as Massachusetts, which just received the support of the local Great Barrington Select Board; the Minneapolis City Council, which will vote on the issue next week; and great strides being made in Washington DC and her hometown of New York City, which sits on a $160bn pension fund (<83><82><82><82><93>a very big goal,<83><82><82><82><9d> Miller says).

Whether New York is any more likely than London to divest, however, is up in the air, she says. City politicians remain concerned about the possible financial impact of divesting. <83><82><82><82><93>They prefer to remain investors, and to influence through active engagement,<83><82><82><82><9d> she said. <83><82><82><82><93>But it just doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t work. Are you asking [these fossil fuel companies] to leave 80% in the ground?<83><82><82><82><9d>

But it sends a signal, he says, that Oslo does not want to contribute to the most climate-damaging fossil fuels, and that the city has a wider goal to be climate-friendly. Weve seen that coal is clearly the energy source that is most harmful, Solberg said. Its been said that the cities of the world contribute about 70% of carbon emissions. So clearly the cities of the world are an important part of the problem of climate change. In 2011, the council set a goal to reduce the citys greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2030, and be climate-neutral by 2050. To do so, it has set out an array of measures, from 258 municipal electric-car charging stations, to recycling household waste for bio-fuel to power the citys buses. Still, it is a conundrum for Norway, a major producer of oil (and, to a lesser extent, coal), which channels its excess petroleum revenues into its own pension fund. The government has so far resisted parliamentary calls for Norways 5.5tn krone (470bn) nest egg, GPFG  the worlds largest sovereign wealth fund  to divest from fossil fuel. A government-appointed panel recently recommended that the fund not divest from fossil fuels, but rather set up a new climate-related exclusion criterion on a case-by-case basis. It concluded:  Energy production constitutes an important basis for our society, and fossil fuels  both petroleum and coal  will remain part of the mix for decades to come, the report concluded in December. The question is thus not whether investors will own these companies, but which investors are good owners of these assets from a financial and ethical perspective. The giant Norwegian fund held at least 316.7bn (26.8bn) krone in oil, gas and coal investments in 2014, according to NGOs Urgewald and Future in Our Hands. It did divest from 52 coal companies last year, but Urgewald says it actually ended up increasing the value of its coal holdings, from 82.2bn krone in 2013 to 85.7bn krone last year. It wasnt Norways cities which led the charge to divest, however. The divestment movement here has its roots in the small community of Eid, population 6,000, whose mayor Alfred Bjrlo took up the cause with its pension fund manager more than two years ago, after he was inspired by a city in the US. It was towards the end of 2012 when, by chance, I read about the Seattle mayors plans to pull out of all coal funds, said Bjrlo. I thought if a city like Seattle could do something like this, then it is fully possible in Norway. It was indeed Seattle that was the first US city to join the Fossil Free divestment campaign led by 350.org. Mayor Mike McGinn announced in December 2012 that Seattle would not invest any of its $1.4bn operating cashflow in fossil fuel companies, and would seek to divest its $1.9bn pension fund and $700m deferred compensation plan. Whether the worlds megacities will follows suit is another question entirely. Last weeks vote to call on the mayor to divest Londonss 2bn GLA Group Investment Syndicate from fossil fuel investments, as well as to ask the chair of the 4.8bm portfolio London Pension Fund Authority (LPFA) to commit to divestment, falls on Boris Johnson  whose office pointed out what it considered the drawbacks. The mayor takes climate change extremely seriously, a spokesperson said, adding that the mayors office believed a sudden divestment on Londons part from fossil fuel investments would cause a huge disruption to the world economy, let alone the retirement plans for millions of UK residents. There was, the spokesperson said, a realism that there needs to be transition away from fossil fuel and not a sudden cliff-edge.  Danielle Paffard, a campaigner for Fossil Free UK divestment, calls Johnson a fossil fuel head and is less than optimistic. But she says that with mayoral elections next year, the issue of divestment could become a big part of the debate. In the meantime, Fossil Free has set its sights on encouraging some European cities, such as Amsterdam, Berlin and Stockholm, to divest. Her US colleague, Amy Miller, points to the progress being made in states such as Massachusetts, which just received the support of the local Great Barrington Select Board; the Minneapolis City Council, which will vote on the issue next week; and great strides being made in Washington DC and her hometown of New York City, which sits on a $160bn pension fund (a very big goal, Miller says).  Whether New York is any more likely than London to divest, however, is up in the air, she says. City politicians remain concerned about the possible financial impact of divesting. They prefer to remain investors, and to influence through active engagement, she said. But it just doesnt work. Are you asking [these fossil fuel companies] to leave 80% in the ground?

webTitle: Van Gogh + Munch at the Munch Museet, Oslo: shared methods and attitudes
trailText: Even though they never met, exhibition focuses on the relationship between the two iconoclasts of modern painting
headline: Van Gogh + Munch at the Munch Museet, Oslo: shared methods and attitudes
standfirst: Even though they never met, exhibition focuses on the relationship between the two iconoclasts of modern painting
body:
One died in 1890, young and little known, whereas the other lived long and achieved fame, only passing away in 1944. So we don<83><82><82><82><84>t tend to think of them as contemporaries. Yet Vincent van Gogh and Edvard Munch were born only a decade a part, the former in 1853 in the Netherlands, the latter 10 years later in Norway. In the 1880s they were among the many painters seeking a break from the old ways and both chose the same direction, exploring the path previously opened by the impressionists.

Related: The town that drove Van Gogh to art

So they could have met in Paris. Van Gogh arrived there in February 1886, never to leave France. Munch stayed in the capital in 1885, returning several times between 1889 and 1892. But having gone home for the summer, he was out of the country when Van Gogh committed suicide. Their paths never actually crossed, but we may nevertheless ponder what they might have said. They would certainly have spoken of Manet, Monet, Pissarro and the creator of neo-impressionism, Seurat. Van Gogh might have been the first to mention Gauguin to Munch. They would undoubtedly have agreed that the teaching at art school was terribly outdated. The backdrop for such an encounter might have been a Montmartre brasserie or somewhere closer to Saint-Cloud, where Munch was living in 1889.

But this was not to be. Much later, however, Munch paid tribute to Van Gogh, suggesting a parallel between them. In autumn 1933 he wrote: <83><82><82><82><93>During his short life, Van Gogh did not allow his flame to go out. Fire and embers were his brushes during the few years of his life, whilst he burned out for his art. I have thought, and wished <83><82><82><82><80><9c> in the long term, with more money at my disposal than he had <83><82><82><82><80><9c> to follow in his footsteps.<83><82><82><82><9d> At the time Munch had good reason to recall his fellow artist, for once again they had plenty in common. After diligently collecting their works from the start of the century onwards, German museums had begun taking them down. Both were soon condemned as <83><82><82><82><93>degenerate<83><82><82><82><9d>.

So there are plenty of good reasons to exhibit their work jointly and see what sparks fly. Oddly enough this is the first time anyone has actually done so. Drawing on their own immense collections, enriched by loans from elsewhere in Europe and the United States, the Munch Museet in Oslo and Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam have joined forces to stage Van Gogh + Munch. The show is already open in Oslo and will move to Amsterdam in the autumn. It is divided into two parts, the first placing the two artists in the context of 1880 in order to show how they cast off convention, with diligent imitations and discreet harmony, somewhat sombre in the case of the Dutchman, nearly white with his Scandinavian counterpart.

Unknowingly, they already agree on several points: no more subjects inspired by myth or religion, instead pictures from real life <83><82><82><82><80><9c> farmers eating potatoes, a young woman sitting on her bed, a weaver, the local welfare office. These are everyday sights, but they stir anger or compassion. Neither painter seems concerned with flattering portraits, charming set pieces, tidy landscapes. The curators have judiciously added pieces by three uncompromising realists: Millet, Isra<83><92><82>ls and Krohg.

That works by Manet, Monet and Pissarro should appear just afterwards is equally pertinent. When Van Gogh and Munch first arrived in Paris they came face to face with a new way of representing the world, a way that was modern and direct. Formally this meant more striking chromatic contrasts, and therefore simpler, more compact shapes. Each brushstroke must be more definite, more visible making the surface of the picture rougher. There was no longer any question of suggestion, it was time to be assertive. Painting was not a matter of pleasing, it was a means of self-expression targeting anyone who happened to come within its range <83><82><82><82><80><9c> an art to be felt by all, at the risk of upsetting the sensibility of those who imagined that they alone were qualified to judge.

This conviction brought Van Gogh a series of setbacks, culminating in his demise. For years Munch met with public hostility and, although it did not kill him, he suffered periods of anxiety and depression.

Having set forth this founding principle, the exhibition moves into its second part, which is far longer. It compares the techniques and effects by which, as Munch put it, it is possible to use fire and embers as his brushes. Here the question of colour is central. First Van Gogh, then Munch a little later, cast off the need to imitate the hues found in nature. The sky can be green, faces too. The ground may be violet, much as the trees. At nightfall forms are reduced to equivocal lines. On the other hand, when fully exposed to the sun they may shatter.

The underlying lines need to be clear and unbroken for the representation of the world to hold up despite the chromatic shifts and explosions of light. Van Gogh refined his technique in superb India-ink drawings using either a pen or reed. Munch preferred woodcuts and sinuous watercolours. Both artists set out the structure of their compositions on paper, reaching visual paroxysm on canvas.

In the case of Van Gogh this side of his work is well known, if only because the work he did at Arles and Auvers has achieved legendary status. The exhibition rightly provides a forcible reminder, but no one will be surprised. The situation is different for Munch, however well known the Scream, with its russet sky, may be. One of the merits of the show is to reveal the extent and variety of his experiments. Some of the works bear no resemblance to what was going on at the time. In 1907 he did a painting entitled Cupid and Psyche, in which a man and a woman face one another nude. Long strokes of colour <83><82><82><82><80><9c> green, purple, red <83><82><82><82><80><9c> run down their bodies. Other equally assertive strokes criss-cross behind them. But <83><82><82><82><93>behind<83><82><82><82><9d> suggests that there is space in this canvas: in fact there is none. The sense of oppression and confrontation are all in the surface of the painting.

No one else was painting like this in 1907, not even Die Br<83><92><82>cke, a group of young German expressionists led by Kirchner and Heckel. In 1905 they had laid claim to both Van Gogh and Munch as sources of common inspiration. Indeed, a snowy landscape by Munch from this period could be by Van Gogh, much as the Dutchman<83><82><82><82><84>s Sower might be the work of the Norwegian. Sometimes the connection seems so obvious it must be deliberate: Munch<83><82><82><82><84>s Starry Night of 1922-24 is a tribute to his fellow<83><82><82><82><84>s Starry Night over the Rhone of 1888. There are striking similarities in some of their portraits too: the same composition, tight close-up view, disregard for any seductive charm, the same preference for tired faces, bony features with sunken eyes. Which brings us back to our starting point, the determination to strip bare the human condition, that of the painter with savage self-portraits and, just as brutally, that of his fellows.

In 1908 Munch defined painting as a means of representing a powerful emotional state simply working from nature <83><82><82><82><80><9c> or rather after nature seen under the influence of that powerful emotional state. Much as for Van Gogh painting was a terrible trial for the nerves.

Van Gogh + Munch is at the Munch Museet, Oslo, until 6 September, then at the Van Gogh Museum, Amsterdam, until 17 January 2016

This article appeared in Guardian Weekly, which incorporates material from Le Monde

webTitle: Mari Boine on Smiland, northern Norway
trailText: The wild beauty of SÃ¡miland (or Lapland) is way more magical than the Santa-themed tourism flogged to visitors, says the musician
headline: Mari Boine on SÃ¡miland, northern Norway
standfirst: The wild beauty of SÃ¡miland (or Lapland) is way more magical than the Santa-themed tourism flogged to visitors, says the musician
body:
The term Lapland is a word foreigners gave this area. We call it S<83><92><82>miland, as it<83><82><82><82><84>s the huge area (the north of Norway, Finland, Sweden and Russia) that belonged to the S<83><92><82>mis. The Norwegian part, the northernmost county Finnmark, is as big as Denmark. I grew up there, close to the Finnish border. We had relatives living on the other side; the border meant nothing to us.

My home now is in beautiful Porsanger, in S<83><92><82>miland. I<83><82><82><82><84>ve lived here for 30 years and I would recommend the area to tourists. It<83><82><82><82><84>s very spacious, wild and you can see far, far away. The further north you go, the more magnificent the view. Further south, everything is private, and you can<83><82><82><82><84>t really go to certain places, but here it<83><82><82><82><84>s still free. You can walk and just be in nature.

If you only come here for a short while, you will not see anything. You need to spend time. There are few restaurants or things that you<83><82><82><82><84>d find in the city, but you will have a special experience. Nature here is so wild, it forces you to meet yourself as there<83><82><82><82><84>s nothing to hide behind; you meet your own vulnerability, but also your grandness.

In summer, I love fishing and where I live there are a lot of salmon rivers. I have a view from my house of one of them, Stabburselva, coming down into the fjord. In many areas, to buy a card for fishing is very expensive, but here it<83><82><82><82><84>s not too bad and you can catch salmon weighing up to 20kg. The biggest I<83><82><82><82><84>ve caught is 2kg. There are some beautiful boat trips along the river, and it<83><82><82><82><84>s also wonderful for hiking, and an important area for migrating birds. They come all the way from South Africa. There<83><82><82><82><84>s a nature centre and viewpoint for watching them. As a child, I was fascinated by the arctic tern, which nests here then spends three months flying to South Africa. I also love fishing at Anarjohka, my childhood river.

This time of year is really for rough ones, tough people. It can get very cold. There<83><82><82><82><84>s not a lot to do in winter time but it<83><82><82><82><84>s magical. I love it. I live next to Stabbursdalen national park, a 130-mile drive from Ivalo (in Finland), where you fly to. There<83><82><82><82><84>s a resort with wooden cottages to rent, and you can go for walks, ski, go snowmobiling and watch the aurora borealis.

I<83><82><82><82><84>ve been seeing the aurora all my life. When we grew up, the S<83><92><82>mi told us we should not point at them because they are the dancing souls of those who have passed away. There are a lot of stories connected to them. It sometimes looks like a hand painting on the sky. I am very inspired by the whole of nature here. Sometimes I go out and it<83><82><82><82><84>s like there are songs hanging in the trees or the sky, or they come with the wind.

In January, there is a fantastic S<83><92><82>mi film festival in Inari, 25 miles from Ivalo, called Skabmagovat, which means the special time when the sun leaves us for two months, and there is just blue light. Films from the S<83><92><82>mi and other indigenous communities from around the world are shown in a theatre made from snow. Also in Inari is a shop called Samekki, selling S<83><92><82>mi handicrafts in silver, wood and leather, made by my friend Petteri Laiti.

There is a lot of beauty in our culture and it is very, very ancient. We have similarities to Native Americans and Inuits: for example we have tipis, called laavus, and tourists should try sleeping in one. I have one with a fireplace in my garden. Now it<83><82><82><82><84>s too cold to sleep out all night, but for New Year<83><82><82><82><84>s Eve I<83><82><82><82><84>m having lots of people over, and we will sit around the fire, talk, sing, drink beer <83><82><82><82><80><9c> I will have a lot of artists and neighbours to visit.

Christianity really wiped out our traditions and rituals. But we still celebrate the time when the sun returns and, at Easter, we go to a place called Kautokeino where they have a very special festival. (s<83><92><82>mieasterfestival.com). This was the time the reindeer herders came down from the mountains, socialised, and baptised the children. It<83><82><82><82><84>s a festival in that spirit. You can see traditional weddings and people wear colourful clothes. Couples walk in procession, and there<83><82><82><82><84>s reindeer racing and concerts. And we have this ancient singing, the yoik. The yoik is pentatonic, it can sound very monotonous, it doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t have a lot of words. It<83><82><82><82><84>s the way you sing just a few words that tells the story. We say that with a yoik, we don<83><82><82><82><84>t sing about a person, we sing the person. We go inside the feeling, we are the feeling when we sing, we don<83><82><82><82><84>t describe. That<83><82><82><82><84>s the difference between western and indigenous culture. I make modern music inspired by this, and take this philosophy with me. The yoik was also part of the shamanistic rituals. Every child that was born got a yoik, as well as a name. It was a way of remembering the person. They also had yoiks for nature. When the words are limited, it helps you express something. It<83><82><82><82><84>s for overwhelming feelings. My parents were Christian, they banned this devilish music, I didn<83><82><82><82><84>t grow up with it, I was told it was from the devil. But when I started singing I really rebelled. I started searching and found that I had a beautiful heritage.

The Santa Claus thing is something that the Finns made up for tourism. They have been very clever!. People need dreams, but that should go hand in hand with information about the people and the culture that is really here. I don<83><82><82><82><84>t like the way the Finns have done fake S<83><92><82>mi tourism. They dress up in fake S<83><92><82>mi clothes and colour themselves with coal to look like <83><82><82><82><93>dirty<83><82><82><82><9d> S<83><92><82>mis. Travellers should do research and find smaller travel companies that are authentic. I want people to experience this beautiful area and learn about us, as long as we are not just decoration, and they come with respect, not just to consume. I am prouder of the northern lights tourism, it<83><82><82><82><84>s something real and more magical.

My favourite places to go out in Troms<83><92><82> are Arctandria, a very good fish restaurant, and Raketten, Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s smallest bar, which a friend opened this year in a renovated old kiosk. He serves beer from the local Mack brewery, and sausages made from reindeer and elk. In July, there<83><82><82><82><84>s a wonderful festival close to Troms<83><92><82>, called Riddu Riddu, which means <83><82><82><82><93>a little storm by the coast<83><82><82><82><9d> <83><82><82><82><80><9c> it was set up by people from the Sea S<83><92><82>mi community, which was really, really oppressed. It<83><82><82><82><84>s now 20 years old and they invite indigenous people from all over the world, which has been very important for S<83><92><82>mis to see. When we compare ourselves to Norwegians, we feel very different, but when we compare ourselves to other indigenous people around the world, we don<83><82><82><82><84>t feel so alienated. There are not many hotels, but there is a campsite, and many people stay in laavus there.

S<83><92><82>mi people today live in modern houses, fewer people are working in reindeer herding. And there<83><82><82><82><84>s a real a fight on because there are so many companies who have found minerals here, there<83><82><82><82><84>s a danger they will want to mine the land.

S<83><92><82>mis have a lot of worries that we would have to give up our ancient culture and reindeer herding, and that would be a big loss, for everybody. Because this is an ancient ancient culture with a lot of wisdom.

For information on Mari Boine<83><82><82><82><84>s music, visit mariboine.no
text: The term Lapland is a word foreigners gave this area. We call it Smiland, as its the huge area (the north of Norway, Finland, Sweden and Russia) that belonged to the Smis. The Norwegian part, the northernmost county Finnmark, is as big as Denmark. I grew up there, close to the Finnish border. We had relatives living on the other side; the border meant nothing to us. My home now is in beautiful Porsanger, in Smiland. Ive lived here for 30 years and I would recommend the area to tourists. Its very spacious, wild and you can see far, far away. The further north you go, the more magnificent the view. Further south, everything is private, and you cant really go to certain places, but here its still free. You can walk and just be in nature. If you only come here for a short while, you will not see anything. You need to spend time. There are few restaurants or things that youd find in the city, but you will have a special experience. Nature here is so wild, it forces you to meet yourself as theres nothing to hide behind; you meet your own vulnerability, but also your grandness. In summer, I love fishing and where I live there are a lot of salmon rivers. I have a view from my house of one of them, Stabburselva, coming down into the fjord. In many areas, to buy a card for fishing is very expensive, but here its not too bad and you can catch salmon weighing up to 20kg. The biggest Ive caught is 2kg. There are some beautiful boat trips along the river, and its also wonderful for hiking, and an important area for migrating birds. They come all the way from South Africa. Theres a nature centre and viewpoint for watching them. As a child, I was fascinated by the arctic tern, which nests here then spends three months flying to South Africa.
