webTitle: Wayne Rooney ready to reboot Roy Hodgsons England against Norway
trailText: The England captain says he is excited about his new responsibility and hopes Englandâs World Cup disappointment will stand the youthful squad in good stead for the future
headline: Wayne Rooney ready to reboot Roy Hodgsonâs England against Norway
standfirst:
â¢ Rooney: England about to start new chapter
â¢ Friendly could see record low attendance at new Wembley
â¢ Jordan Henderson: England must create fear factor
â¢ Captain stands tall in shallow end of shrinking talent pool
body:
Wayne Rooney will lead England out into a half-full Wembley stadium for Wednesday evening<83><82><82><82><84>s friendly against Norway wearing the armband for the first time as permanent captain and intent upon convincing a sceptical public that the national side can thrive following their traumatic World Cup campaign in Brazil.

The Manchester United striker, by 68 caps the most experienced outfield player in Roy Hodgson<83><82><82><82><84>s team, remains convinced he can still fulfil an ambition to claim silverware with England and will attempt to start the process of re-engaging with a support left disaffected by the side<83><82><82><82><84>s worst performance at a World Cup. The home team will seek to demonstrate evidence of promise and progress against Norway before travelling to Switzerland for Monday<83><82><82><82><84>s awkward Euro 2016 qualifier, with Rooney eager to take on the added responsibility demanded by the captaincy.

The Football Association expects a crowd of around 40,000 for the game against Norway, ranked 53 in the world and in a similar state of transition to the hosts, with captain and manager acknowledging that the fans<83><82><82><82><84> faith must be restored after the summer<83><82><82><82><84>s setbacks in Manaus, S<83><92><82>o Paulo and Belo Horizonte. <83><82><82><82><93>The World Cup didn<83><82><82><82><84>t go as well as we wanted and there<83><82><82><82><84>s obviously a backlash from that, but the crowd will still be great considering that disappointment,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Rooney. <83><82><82><82><93>We wanted to do better in Brazil. We didn<83><82><82><82><84>t. We<83><82><82><82><84>re all still devastated but now we have to put the summer behind us and move on.

<83><82><82><82><93>Hopefully we can repay them with some good performances over the next two years, and exciting attractive football to qualify for Euro 2016. That<83><82><82><82><84>s the aim. This is a young squad but, apart from John Stones, all of those starting this game were at the World Cup and felt that disappointment. We<83><82><82><82><84>d gone into the tournament with high hopes and were expecting better than we produced but we<83><82><82><82><84>re going to continue on the road along which we<83><82><82><82><84>ve started. We knew it would be tough but we have young players coming into the squad and it<83><82><82><82><84>s exciting.

<83><82><82><82><93>I look at my career and judge it as how successful we are as a team. I<83><82><82><82><84>ve always said I don<83><82><82><82><84>t want to finish with England having not won anything. I<83><82><82><82><84>ve always wanted to win a trophy with my country, and if I can lead us to do that, that<83><82><82><82><84>ll be the pinnacle of my career. That will be very difficult, yes, but I really do think it<83><82><82><82><84>s achievable. Look at the players we<83><82><82><82><84>ve got. They<83><82><82><82><84>re exciting players. They have to do what they do for their clubs with England and we have to bring that together. Of course it<83><82><82><82><84>s very difficult, it is for any country, but that has to be our aim. It<83><82><82><82><84>s pointless not having that as your aim or your desire.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Hodgson will hand Stones a first start for his country at right-back, with Phil Jones partnering Gary Cahill at centre-half and Jack Wilshere paired with Jordan Henderson in central midfield. Danny Welbeck, Arsenal<83><82><82><82><84>s <83><80><9a><82>16m deadline day signing from Manchester United, rolled an ankle towards the end of the training session at London Colney on Tuesday and is unlikely to feature. The uncapped Newcastle United midfielder Jack Colback is unavailable against Norway as he recovers from a knock suffered in his club<83><82><82><82><84>s 3-3 draw with Crystal Palace. The team that start tonight are, injuries permitting, also expected to begin the match in Basel.

This will be the third time that Rooney has led out his country but the first as official captain with the United forward <83><82><82><82><80><9c> who has also taken up the armband for his club this term <83><82><82><82><80><9c> having apparently learned from players such as Gary Neville, David Beckham and Steven Gerrard and intent upon setting the right example to those younger members of the squad.

The 28-year-old refused to rise to comments made by the Norway centre-half Vegard Forren, once of Southampton, who told TV2.no: <83><82><82><82><93>Rooney looks a bit chubby.<83><82><82><82><9d> Forren failed to make a first-team appearance at St Mary<83><82><82><82><84>s, with the club unconvinced by his levels of fitness during his brief stay in England before selling him back to Molde.

Yet Rooney conceded there would be even greater scrutiny on him from now on in as captain of club and country. <83><82><82><82><93>I<83><82><82><82><84>m sure that will go up a notch,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said. <83><82><82><82><93>I<83><82><82><82><84>ve had to deal with a lot in my career, and I<83><82><82><82><84>m used to a lot of things, so I<83><82><82><82><84>m ready for that. I<83><82><82><82><84>m ready for that responsibility. It<83><82><82><82><84>s my time. I<83><82><82><82><84>ve played a lot of games for United and England, and I<83><82><82><82><84>m ready to accept that responsibility and ready to lead both teams to success.

<83><82><82><82><93>I hope that it makes me a better player. I<83><82><82><82><84>ve always played my game, been vocal, demanded a lot from myself and been harsh on myself, and I<83><82><82><82><84>m harsh on my team-mates and have demanded a lot of them too.

<83><82><82><82><93>But now there is that added responsibility. It<83><82><82><82><84>s a great honour to captain my country, something I<83><82><82><82><84>m extremely proud of. I want to be a successful captain and for this team to be successful. This game is the start of a new chapter.<83><82><82><82><9d>
text: Wayne Rooney will lead England out into a half-full Wembley stadium for Wednesday evenings friendly against Norway wearing the armband for the first time as permanent captain and intent upon convincing a sceptical public that the national side can thrive following their traumatic World Cup campaign in Brazil. The Manchester United striker, by 68 caps the most experienced outfield player in Roy Hodgsons team, remains convinced he can still fulfil an ambition to claim silverware with England and will attempt to start the process of re-engaging with a support left disaffected by the sides worst performance at a World Cup. The home team will seek to demonstrate evidence of promise and progress against Norway before travelling to Switzerland for Mondays awkward Euro 2016 qualifier, with Rooney eager to take on the added responsibility demanded by the captaincy. The Football Association expects a crowd of around 40,000 for the game against Norway, ranked 53 in the world and in a similar state of transition to the hosts, with captain and manager acknowledging that the fans faith must be restored after the summers setbacks in Manaus, So Paulo and Belo Horizonte. The World Cup didnt go as well as we wanted and theres obviously a backlash from that, but the crowd will still be great considering that disappointment, said Rooney. We wanted to do better in Brazil. We didnt. Were all still devastated but now we have to put the summer behind us and move on. Hopefully we can repay them with some good performances over the next two years, and exciting attractive football to qualify for Euro 2016. Thats the aim. This is a young squad but, apart from John Stones, all of those starting this game were at the World Cup and felt that disappointment. Wed gone into the tournament with high hopes and were expecting better than we produced but were going to continue on the road along which weve started. We knew it would be tough but we have young players coming into the squad and its exciting. I look at my career and judge it as how successful we are as a team. Ive always said I dont want to finish with England having not won anything. Ive always wanted to win a trophy with my country, and if I can lead us to do that, thatll be the pinnacle of my career. That will be very difficult, yes, but I really do think its achievable. Look at the players weve got. Theyre exciting players. They have to do what they do for their clubs with England and we have to bring that together. Of course its very difficult, it is for any country, but that has to be our aim. Its pointless not having that as your aim or your desire. Hodgson will hand Stones a first start for his country at right-back, with Phil Jones partnering Gary Cahill at centre-half and Jack Wilshere paired with Jordan Henderson in central midfield. Danny Welbeck, Arsenals 16m deadline day signing from Manchester United, rolled an ankle towards the end of the training session at London Colney on Tuesday and is unlikely to feature. The uncapped Newcastle United midfielder Jack Colback is unavailable against Norway as he recovers from a knock suffered in his clubs 3-3 draw with Crystal Palace. The team that start tonight are, injuries permitting, also expected to begin the match in Basel. This will be the third time that Rooney has led out his country but the first as official captain with the United forward  who has also taken up the armband for his club this term  having apparently learned from players such as Gary Neville, David Beckham and Steven Gerrard and intent upon setting the right example to those younger members of the squad. The 28-year-old refused to rise to comments made by the Norway centre-half Vegard Forren, once of Southampton, who told TV2.no: Rooney looks a bit chubby. Forren failed to make a first-team appearance at St Marys, with the club unconvinced by his levels of fitness during his brief stay in England before selling him back to Molde. Yet Rooney conceded there would be even greater scrutiny on him from now on in as captain of club and country. Im sure that will go up a notch, he said. Ive had to deal with a lot in my career, and Im used to a lot of things, so Im ready for that. Im ready for that responsibility. Its my time. Ive played a lot of games for United and England, and Im ready to accept that responsibility and ready to lead both teams to success. I hope that it makes me a better player. Ive always played my game, been vocal, demanded a lot from myself and been harsh on myself, and Im harsh on my team-mates and have demanded a lot of them too. But now there is that added responsibility. Its a great honour to captain my country, something Im extremely proud of. I want to be a successful captain and for this team to be successful. This game is the start of a new chapter.

webTitle: Great British Bake Off batters the England v Norway game
trailText: The England v Norway game on ITV was battered in the ratings by the Great British Bake Off on the BBC which had an average of 8.3m viewers against the footballâs average of 4.5m
headline: Great British Bake Off batters the England v Norway game
standfirst:
â¢ BBC programme is watched by 8.3m
â¢ ITVâs football attracts average of 4.5m
â¢ England echo around a half-empty Wembley
â¢ Roy Hodgson defends tepid display
â¢ Barney Ronay on Englandâs new order
body:
It was not just the Wembley crowd that voted with their feet on Wednesday night.

The England v Norway game on ITV was battered in the ratings by the Great British Bake Off on the BBC which had an average of 8.3m viewers against the football<83><82><82><82><84>s average of 4.5m.

The friendly international, England<83><82><82><82><84>s first game since their wretched World Cup showing in Brazil, attracted a crowd of just 40,181, the lowest figure since the new Wembley opened seven years ago.

The top tier of the ground was cordoned off and the stands were half empty as England laboured to a 1-0 victory courtesy of a penalty by their new captain Wayne Rooney.
text: It was not just the Wembley crowd that voted with their feet on Wednesday night. The England v Norway game on ITV was battered in the ratings by the Great British Bake Off on the BBC which had an average of 8.3m viewers against the footballs average of 4.5m. The friendly international, Englands first game since their wretched World Cup showing in Brazil, attracted a crowd of just 40,181, the lowest figure since the new Wembley opened seven years ago. The top tier of the ground was cordoned off and the stands were half empty as England laboured to a 1-0 victory courtesy of a penalty by their new captain Wayne Rooney.

webTitle: Roy Hodgson defends Englands tepid display against cautious Norway
trailText: Roy Hodgson is convinced that his team is capable of scoring goals despite only managing two shots on target at Wembley
headline: Roy Hodgson defends Englandâs tepid display against cautious Norway
standfirst:
â¢ Hodgson convinced team is capable of scoring goals
â¢ âThese players have the potential to excite football crowdsâ
â¢ Match report: England 1-0 Norway
â¢ Barney Ronay: Englandâs new order looks like the old
body:
Roy Hodgson has suggested England may be forced into playing <83><82><82><82><93>like Norway<83><82><82><82><9d> in Monday<83><82><82><82><84>s awkward Euro 2016 qualifier against Switzerland, with the national manager and his captain, Wayne Rooney, admitting the team must perform better if they are to prevail in Basel.

The Manchester United striker scored his 41st goal for his country, a second-half penalty, to defeat a stubborn Norway team and hoist himself above Michael Owen into outright fourth place on the all-time England scorers<83><82><82><82><84> list. He did so in front of the lowest crowd for an England match at Wembley, 40,181, since it was re-opened in 2007. The hosts dominated possession but laboured for long periods despite securing a first win in six matches, with Rooney conceding they <83><82><82><82><93>all could have done better<83><82><82><82><9d>.

Hodgson was prickly through his post-match media duties and was particularly infuriated when it was pointed out his team had mustered only two shots on target: the penalty and a shot from the substitute Danny Welbeck, which was saved by Orjan Haskjold Nyland. <83><82><82><82><93>Don<83><82><82><82><84>t give me that one,<83><82><82><82><9d> he said. <83><82><82><82><93>Two shots on target? What about all the ones they threw themselves in front of, or the near misses? Don<83><82><82><82><84>t hit me with statistics. When we had that much possession, and you talk about two shots on target? We<83><82><82><82><84>re not scoring a lot of goals at the moment but we<83><82><82><82><84>re not playing against teams who come out against us a lot.

<83><82><82><82><93>This team will score goals. They<83><82><82><82><84>ll score goals. Rooney will score goals. Welbeck will score goals. [Daniel] Sturridge will score goals. [Raheem] Sterling will score goals. Switzerland will need to beat us. If anything, we might be Norway on Monday. We might be pushed back and won<83><82><82><82><84>t be able to attack and dominate for long periods, as we did tonight. I don<83><82><82><82><84>t know. But it might be the case. I don<83><82><82><82><84>t think the mindset of the Swiss team, playing us in Basel, will be the same as the mindset of the Norwegians today.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Yet, while patience will be required with his inexperienced lineup, there remain serious doubts over the partnership between Rooney and Sturridge. The latter arguably appeared more comfortable playing alongside Welbeck and with the excellent Sterling switched to a central No10 role over the latter stages. The new captain<83><82><82><82><84>s performance was rather peripheral, reflecting his form for his club, with England struggling for long periods to offer much encouragement to those who had attended the friendly fixture.

<83><82><82><82><93>In the first half we moved the ball quite well,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Rooney, who converted the penalty awarded when Omar Elabdellaoui tripped Sterling. <83><82><82><82><93>The second half we started really sloppily, which was disappointing, but we got the win in the end. The young players in the team will learn. We<83><82><82><82><84>re all still learning. Raheem Sterling is a threat, he gets at players. It doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t always come off but he<83><82><82><82><84>s an exciting player to watch. We all could have done better, but it<83><82><82><82><84>s a night where it was important to win.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Hodgson, asked about his captain<83><82><82><82><84>s display and whether he may consider playing Welbeck alongside Sturridge instead in Basel, said: <83><82><82><82><93>The fact is it was a big night for Wayne, with a lot of responsibility weighing on his shoulders, not least with the penalty, which he knew he had to score to secure the win. It<83><82><82><82><84>s early days. If every time we play I<83><82><82><82><84>ve either got to praise a player to the skies or criticise a player and say a partnership is not going to work, that<83><82><82><82><84>s a bit harsh. Wayne will tell you he can play better than that. Of course he can. We know what kind of player he is. But you<83><82><82><82><84>re not always going to give the best performance and you don<83><82><82><82><84>t become a bad player if you don<83><82><82><82><84>t put in the performance you wanted.

<83><82><82><82><93>I thought the performance was quite good. I was pleased with the first half, when we probed well and had good movement. I was disappointed with the start of the second half when we didn<83><82><82><82><84>t do anything like as well for the first 15 minutes, but then we changed things, changed the formation slightly, and finished the game strongly. Yes, I was happy with Danny Welbeck and he was very lively when he came on. And when Sterling moved into the centre he showed the full range of his dribbling ability, so it<83><82><82><82><84>s nice to know we have these options and won<83><82><82><82><84>t be totally restricted to one way of playing.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Hodgson is confident Gary Cahill, who was substituted near the end and applied ice to an ankle, will be fit for the game against Switzerland <83><82><82><82><80><9c> ranked ninth in the world to England<83><82><82><82><84>s 20th and Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s 53rd <83><82><82><82><80><9c> with John Stones, on his first start, having suffered cramp late on. England will be without Jack Colback, however, after the Newcastle midfielder failed to recover from a calf problem and returned to Tyneside for treatment.

<83><82><82><82><93>We<83><82><82><82><84>ll find it hard to bring attendances back to a very high level because of the opponents we<83><82><82><82><84>re playing in qualifying <83><82><82><82><80><9c> they won<83><82><82><82><84>t be exciting the public,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Hodgson, with games against San Marino, Estonia, Slovenia, Lithuania and the Swiss ahead. <83><82><82><82><93>They<83><82><82><82><84>re not the kind of teams who normally attract full houses. But if my team works as hard as they did tonight, show the appetite and desire, the aggression in the defending, the exciting moves that were there for all to see, then the crowd aren<83><82><82><82><84>t foolish.

<83><82><82><82><93>They know what they<83><82><82><82><84>re seeing. They<83><82><82><82><84>ll come back to see Sterling, Sturridge and [Jack] Wilshere. These players have the potential to lead us forward and excite football crowds. Although I risk being in a group of one, I have been watching football for a long time and nothing you say will change what I see.<83><82><82><82><9d>
text: Roy Hodgson has suggested England may be forced into playing like Norway in Mondays awkward Euro 2016 qualifier against Switzerland, with the national manager and his captain, Wayne Rooney, admitting the team must perform better if they are to prevail in Basel. The Manchester United striker scored his 41st goal for his country, a second-half penalty, to defeat a stubborn Norway team and hoist himself above Michael Owen into outright fourth place on the all-time England scorers list. He did so in front of the lowest crowd for an England match at Wembley, 40,181, since it was re-opened in 2007. The hosts dominated possession but laboured for long periods despite securing a first win in six matches, with Rooney conceding they all could have done better. Hodgson was prickly through his post-match media duties and was particularly infuriated when it was pointed out his team had mustered only two shots on target: the penalty and a shot from the substitute Danny Welbeck, which was saved by Orjan Haskjold Nyland. Dont give me that one, he said. Two shots on target? What about all the ones they threw themselves in front of, or the near misses? Dont hit me with statistics. When we had that much possession, and you talk about two shots on target? Were not scoring a lot of goals at the moment but were not playing against teams who come out against us a lot. This team will score goals. Theyll score goals. Rooney will score goals. Welbeck will score goals. [Daniel] Sturridge will score goals. [Raheem] Sterling will score goals. Switzerland will need to beat us. If anything, we might be Norway on Monday. We might be pushed back and wont be able to attack and dominate for long periods, as we did tonight. I dont know. But it might be the case. I dont think the mindset of the Swiss team, playing us in Basel, will be the same as the mindset of the Norwegians today. Yet, while patience will be required with his inexperienced lineup, there remain serious doubts over the partnership between Rooney and Sturridge. The latter arguably appeared more comfortable playing alongside Welbeck and with the excellent Sterling switched to a central No10 role over the latter stages. The new captains performance was rather peripheral, reflecting his form for his club, with England struggling for long periods to offer much encouragement to those who had attended the friendly fixture. In the first half we moved the ball quite well, said Rooney, who converted the penalty awarded when Omar Elabdellaoui tripped Sterling. The second half we started really sloppily, which was disappointing, but we got the win in the end. The young players in the team will learn. Were all still learning. Raheem Sterling is a threat, he gets at players. It doesnt always come off but hes an exciting player to watch. We all could have done better, but its a night where it was important to win. Hodgson, asked about his captains display and whether he may consider playing Welbeck alongside Sturridge instead in Basel, said: The fact is it was a big night for Wayne, with a lot of responsibility weighing on his shoulders, not least with the penalty, which he knew he had to score to secure the win. Its early days. If every time we play Ive either got to praise a player to the skies or criticise a player and say a partnership is not going to work, thats a bit harsh. Wayne will tell you he can play better than that. Of course he can. We know what kind of player he is. But youre not always going to give the best performance and you dont become a bad player if you dont put in the performance you wanted. I thought the performance was quite good. I was pleased with the first half, when we probed well and had good movement. I was disappointed with the start of the second half when we didnt do anything like as well for the first 15 minutes, but then we changed things, changed the formation slightly, and finished the game strongly. Yes, I was happy with Danny Welbeck and he was very lively when he came on. And when Sterling moved into the centre he showed the full range of his dribbling ability, so its nice to know we have these options and wont be totally restricted to one way of playing. Hodgson is confident Gary Cahill, who was substituted near the end and applied ice to an ankle, will be fit for the game against Switzerland  ranked ninth in the world to Englands 20th and Norways 53rd  with John Stones, on his first start, having suffered cramp late on. England will be without Jack Colback, however, after the Newcastle midfielder failed to recover from a calf problem and returned to Tyneside for treatment. Well find it hard to bring attendances back to a very high level because of the opponents were playing in qualifying  they wont be exciting the public, said Hodgson, with games against San Marino, Estonia, Slovenia, Lithuania and the Swiss ahead. Theyre not the kind of teams who normally attract full houses. But if my team works as hard as they did tonight, show the appetite and desire, the aggression in the defending, the exciting moves that were there for all to see, then the crowd arent foolish. They know what theyre seeing. Theyll come back to see Sterling, Sturridge and [Jack] Wilshere. These players have the potential to lead us forward and excite football crowds. Although I risk being in a group of one, I have been watching football for a long time and nothing you say will change what I see.

webTitle: Englands travails against Norway echo around a half-empty Wembley
trailText: Despite the best marketing efforts of the FA, the atmosphere at Wednesday nightâs friendly was nearly as muted as Englandâs performance
headline: Englandâs travails against Norway echo around a half-empty Wembley
standfirst: Despite the best efforts of the FA, the atmosphere at Wednesday nightâs friendly was nearly as muted as Englandâs performance
body:
The band played on. And, depressingly, on. But the ever present parp of England<83><82><82><82><84>s musical accompaniment was just about the only thing that remained from the guarded optimism of the last time England fans gathered at Wembley, when more than 83,000 had seen Roy Hodgson<83><82><82><82><84>s men off to Brazil.

The pre-match mood at a half-empty <83><80><9a><82>757m national stadium that is one of the finest in the world but remains some way from having a team to match could not have been more different. Its top tier was cordoned off and tumbleweed blew down Olympic Way before the match.

On the pitch, however, it felt like business as usual rather than the bright new dawn rather optimistically promised by the pre-publicity.

Steven Gerrard and Frank Lampard, whose presence together in midfield in that dead rubber against Costa Rica seemed to somehow symbolise the dashed hopes of the <83><82><82><82><93>golden generation<83><82><82><82><9d>, were gone. But 4-4-2 was back. As were most of the players who failed in Brazil. Most worryingly, so too was the air of self-delusion that had been allowed to creep into Hodgson<83><82><82><82><84>s Brazilian post-mortem.

His programme notes referred, desperately, to the <83><82><82><82><93>potential<83><82><82><82><9d> he had spied among his young charges in that dismal 0-0 draw against the already qualified Costa Ricans. And 15 of the 23 players selected by Hodgson had also been among those who were smuggled back into the country following their all too brief Brazilian sojourn. That number would have been higher still but for injuries.

Never mind the much-derided corporate <83><82><82><82><93>indifference<83><82><82><82><9d> <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the 17,000 Club England seats that are so important to Wembley<83><82><82><82><84>s business plan <83><82><82><82><80><9c> there was a danger that the entire imposing bowl would echo to the sound of muted mumbling.

In the end there was relief among the FA blazers that the attendance topped the 40,000 mark by 181 fans, but it remained the lowest figure since the new Wembley opened seven years ago.

If there were points for marketing effort then England would be world beaters rather than also-rans. England<83><82><82><82><84>s players and manager were rolling out some of their best loved lines before a match that, ironically, had far more meaning than the last time the side pulled on their shirts in a World Cup tie.

The manager, the captain, the Football Association, the rights holding broadcaster, the official sponsors, even the somewhat plaintive and redundant touts at the foot of the Wembley Park tube station steps <83><82><82><82><80><9c> all were sticking to the script.

<83><82><82><82><93>Every Match Matters<83><82><82><82><9d> yelled the full page ads in the programme, as the FA tried to excite interest in not only Wednesday night<83><82><82><82><84>s brave new world but the home qualifying matches against San Marino and Slovenia that will follow.

<83><82><82><82><93>A new dawn, a new day, a new England<83><82><82><82><9d> insisted ITV, desperately contemplating the prospect of having to go up against the Great British Bake Off with international football<83><82><82><82><84>s equivalent of a soggy bottom.

The players were singing from the same hymn sheet before the match. Rooney spoke of a <83><82><82><82><93>new chapter<83><82><82><82><9d>, Raheem Sterling said it was time to <83><82><82><82><93>move on<83><82><82><82><9d>, Jordan Henderson promised they would <83><82><82><82><93>step up<83><82><82><82><9d>.

The tone from FA chairman Greg Dyke and Hodgson was one of respectful regret at the showing in Brazil followed by an insistence that things weren<83><82><82><82><84>t as bad as they seemed.

But the new Wembley, that towering 90s monument to Cool Britannia excess <83><82><82><82><80><9c> its huge banqueting halls, endless corporate boxes and iconic arch - not for the first time felt out of kilter with the downbeat fare on the pitch.

Those ambling up to the office to buy a ticket at 5.30pm reported no queues and there was a funereal atmosphere on Wembley High Road. Inside, the PA announcer ran through his usual repertoire of bombastic introductions to nothing but silence.

Yet easy as it is to poke fun at the endless expanses of red empty seats around Wembley, some context is required. It is always remarkable to leave the ground at midnight and hear the jumble of accents planning their journey home. For how much longer remains to be seen.

Perhaps it might have made more sense to slash prices to a tenner, or let kids in for a quid. But any such scheme will never get off the drawing board in the FA<83><82><82><82><84>s brainstorming sessions because of the need for Wembley to pay its way.

The Club England managing director, Adrian Bevington, had spent the morning on Twitter trying to persuade fans not to give up on the national team.

But in the process he admitted that the idea of taking England games away from Wembley, on which there are still <83><80><9a><82>200m in loans outstanding, was a non-starter. <83><82><82><82><93>We have to play games at Wembley to pay for the stadium and home games to meet broadcast contracts as well.<83><82><82><82><9d>

So that<83><82><82><82><84>s that then. England fans are nothing if not perverse, however, and there was a defiance about the determination with which the packed lower tier got behind their (not so) new look England side. Yet at half time there was a smattering of boos amid the rush to the bars.

The ever-hopeful PA announcer tried to excite interest in winning a pair of <83><82><82><82><93>front row tickets<83><82><82><82><9d> to the San Marino qualifier. Good luck with that.

As the second half wore on, Hodgson sat slumped on the bench wearing the grimace that had become so familiar in Brazil. The atmosphere picked up after Rooney celebrated taking on the captain<83><82><82><82><84>s armband with a goal from the spot and those present resolved to enjoy themselves regardless <83><82><82><82><80><9c> even if the biggest cheers of the night were reserved for the reviled Mexican wave. There was even a debutant or two to cheer.

But as the match ambled to a conclusion, you could almost hear the sound of those touts on the steps of Wembley Park underground station sobbing ahead of a qualifying campaign that looks a hard sell for all sorts of reasons.
text: The band played on. And, depressingly, on. But the ever present parp of Englands musical accompaniment was just about the only thing that remained from the guarded optimism of the last time England fans gathered at Wembley, when more than 83,000 had seen Roy Hodgsons men off to Brazil. The pre-match mood at a half-empty 757m national stadium that is one of the finest in the world but remains some way from having a team to match could not have been more different. Its top tier was cordoned off and tumbleweed blew down Olympic Way before the match. On the pitch, however, it felt like business as usual rather than the bright new dawn rather optimistically promised by the pre-publicity. Steven Gerrard and Frank Lampard, whose presence together in midfield in that dead rubber against Costa Rica seemed to somehow symbolise the dashed hopes of the golden generation, were gone. But 4-4-2 was back. As were most of the players who failed in Brazil. Most worryingly, so too was the air of self-delusion that had been allowed to creep into Hodgsons Brazilian post-mortem. His programme notes referred, desperately, to the potential he had spied among his young charges in that dismal 0-0 draw against the already qualified Costa Ricans. And 15 of the 23 players selected by Hodgson had also been among those who were smuggled back into the country following their all too brief Brazilian sojourn. That number would have been higher still but for injuries. Never mind the much-derided corporate indifference  the 17,000 Club England seats that are so important to Wembleys business plan  there was a danger that the entire imposing bowl would echo to the sound of muted mumbling. In the end there was relief among the FA blazers that the attendance topped the 40,000 mark by 181 fans, but it remained the lowest figure since the new Wembley opened seven years ago. If there were points for marketing effort then England would be world beaters rather than also-rans. Englands players and manager were rolling out some of their best loved lines before a match that, ironically, had far more meaning than the last time the side pulled on their shirts in a World Cup tie. The manager, the captain, the Football Association, the rights holding broadcaster, the official sponsors, even the somewhat plaintive and redundant touts at the foot of the Wembley Park tube station steps  all were sticking to the script. Every Match Matters yelled the full page ads in the programme, as the FA tried to excite interest in not only Wednesday nights brave new world but the home qualifying matches against San Marino and Slovenia that will follow. A new dawn, a new day, a new England insisted ITV, desperately contemplating the prospect of having to go up against the Great British Bake Off with international footballs equivalent of a soggy bottom. The players were singing from the same hymn sheet before the match. Rooney spoke of a new chapter, Raheem Sterling said it was time to move on, Jordan Henderson promised they would step up. The tone from FA chairman Greg Dyke and Hodgson was one of respectful regret at the showing in Brazil followed by an insistence that things werent as bad as they seemed. But the new Wembley, that towering 90s monument to Cool Britannia excess  its huge banqueting halls, endless corporate boxes and iconic arch - not for the first time felt out of kilter with the downbeat fare on the pitch. Those ambling up to the office to buy a ticket at 5.30pm reported no queues and there was a funereal atmosphere on Wembley High Road. Inside, the PA announcer ran through his usual repertoire of bombastic introductions to nothing but silence. Yet easy as it is to poke fun at the endless expanses of red empty seats around Wembley, some context is required. It is always remarkable to leave the ground at midnight and hear the jumble of accents planning their journey home. For how much longer remains to be seen. Perhaps it might have made more sense to slash prices to a tenner, or let kids in for a quid. But any such scheme will never get off the drawing board in the FAs brainstorming sessions because of the need for Wembley to pay its way. The Club England managing director, Adrian Bevington, had spent the morning on Twitter trying to persuade fans not to give up on the national team. But in the process he admitted that the idea of taking England games away from Wembley, on which there are still 200m in loans outstanding, was a non-starter. We have to play games at Wembley to pay for the stadium and home games to meet broadcast contracts as well. So thats that then. England fans are nothing if not perverse, however, and there was a defiance about the determination with which the packed lower tier got behind their (not so) new look England side. Yet at half time there was a smattering of boos amid the rush to the bars. The ever-hopeful PA announcer tried to excite interest in winning a pair of front row tickets to the San Marino qualifier. Good luck with that. As the second half wore on, Hodgson sat slumped on the bench wearing the grimace that had become so familiar in Brazil. The atmosphere picked up after Rooney celebrated taking on the captains armband with a goal from the spot and those present resolved to enjoy themselves regardless  even if the biggest cheers of the night were reserved for the reviled Mexican wave. There was even a debutant or two to cheer. But as the match ambled to a conclusion, you could almost hear the sound of those touts on the steps of Wembley Park underground station sobbing ahead of a qualifying campaign that looks a hard sell for all sorts of reasons.

webTitle: Two players die at world chess event in Norway
trailText: Competitor dies in the middle of a match during Chess Olympiad in Norway and another is found dead in hotel room
headline: Two players die at world chess event in Norway
standfirst: Competitor dies in the middle of a match during Chess Olympiad in Norway and another is found dead in hotel room
body:
The most prestigious international tournament in chess, at which the world's top players compete alongside amateurs to win honours for their country, has ended on a sombre note after two players died suddenly within hours of each other, one while he was in the middle of a match.

Hundreds of spectators attending the 41st Chess Olympiad in Troms<83><92><82>, Norway, and countless others watching live TV coverage on Norway's state broadcaster, reacted with shock after Kurt Meier, 67, a Swiss-born member of the Seychelles team, collapsed on Thursday afternoon, during his final match of the marathon two-week contest. Despite immediate medical attention at the scene he died later in hospital.

Hours later, a player from Uzbekistan who has not yet been named was found dead in his hotel room in central Troms<83><92><82>. Norwegian police and the event's organisers said on Friday they were not treating the deaths as suspicious.

"We regard these as tragic but natural deaths," said Jarle Heitmann, a spokesman for the Chess Olympiad. "When so many people are gathered for such a long time, these things can happen."

The Olympiad involved 1,800 competitors from 174 countries, accompanied by more than 1,000 coaches, delegates and fans.

The event sees players compete in national teams over 11 rounds, often playing matches that last for up to six hours, and claims a worldwide online audience of tens of millions.

There were brief scenes of panic in the hall after Meier's collapse, when spectators reportedly mistook a defibrillator for a weapon. Play was briefly suspended before his death was marked with a minute's silence during the closing ceremony.

While the causes of the two men's deaths are still unknown, they will raise questions about the mental and physical stress that tournaments place on players.

Meier is not the first player to die in the middle of a match; in 2000 Vladimir Bagirov, a Latvian grandmaster, had a fatal heart attack during a tournament in Finland, while in the same year, another Latvian, Aivars Gipslis, suffered a stroke while playing in Berlin from which he later died.

One of Australia's leading players, Ian Rogers, retired abruptly from chess in 2007, saying he had been warned by his doctors that the stress of top-level competition was causing him serious health problems.

Tarjei J Svensen, a reporter for chess24.com who attended the Olympiad, said the event had a reputation for heavy drinking. "There are two rest days during the competition, and particularly the night before the rest days there tends to be a lot of drinking," he said.

A favourite attraction for delegates was the now-legendary "Bermuda party", he added, hosted at each Olympiad by a member of the Bermudan delegation.

The Olympiad was big news in Norway, with the state broadcaster, NRK, carrying hours of live coverage each day, and the country's government paying 87m kroner (<83><80><9a><82>8.5m) for the privilege of hosting the event.

Last week the women's team from Burundi were disqualified after failing to show up for their round six and seven matches; they remain unaccounted for, Heitmann said on Friday.

"It has been an eventful Olympiad, certainly," said Svensen.

Hundreds of spectators attending the 41st Chess Olympiad in Troms, Norway, and countless others watching live TV coverage on Norway's state broadcaster, reacted with shock after Kurt Meier, 67, a Swiss-born member of the Seychelles team, collapsed on Thursday afternoon, during his final match of the marathon two-week contest. Despite immediate medical attention at the scene he died later in hospital. Hours later, a player from Uzbekistan who has not yet been named was found dead in his hotel room in central Troms. Norwegian police and the event's organisers said on Friday they were not treating the deaths as suspicious. "We regard these as tragic but natural deaths," said Jarle Heitmann, a spokesman for the Chess Olympiad. "When so many people are gathered for such a long time, these things can happen." The Olympiad involved 1,800 competitors from 174 countries, accompanied by more than 1,000 coaches, delegates and fans. The event sees players compete in national teams over 11 rounds, often playing matches that last for up to six hours, and claims a worldwide online audience of tens of millions. There were brief scenes of panic in the hall after Meier's collapse, when spectators reportedly mistook a defibrillator for a weapon. Play was briefly suspended before his death was marked with a minute's silence during the closing ceremony. While the causes of the two men's deaths are still unknown, they will raise questions about the mental and physical stress that tournaments place on players. Meier is not the first player to die in the middle of a match; in 2000 Vladimir Bagirov, a Latvian grandmaster, had a fatal heart attack during a tournament in Finland, while in the same year, another Latvian, Aivars Gipslis, suffered a stroke while playing in Berlin from which he later died. One of Australia's leading players, Ian Rogers, retired abruptly from chess in 2007, saying he had been warned by his doctors that the stress of top-level competition was causing him serious health problems. Tarjei J Svensen, a reporter for chess24.com who attended the Olympiad, said the event had a reputation for heavy drinking. "There are two rest days during the competition, and particularly the night before the rest days there tends to be a lot of drinking," he said. A favourite attraction for delegates was the now-legendary "Bermuda party", he added, hosted at each Olympiad by a member of the Bermudan delegation. The Olympiad was big news in Norway, with the state broadcaster, NRK, carrying hours of live coverage each day, and the country's government paying 87m kroner (8.5m) for the privilege of hosting the event. "It has been an eventful Olympiad, certainly," said Svensen.

webTitle: Norway's amazing hiking cabins
trailText: As the Norwegian Trekking Association opens a dramatic, contemporary mountain hideaway, we look at some of the other stunning walkersâ cabins operated by the organisation
headline: Norway's amazing hiking cabins
standfirst: As the Norwegian Trekking Association opens a dramatic, contemporary mountain hideaway, we look at some of the other stunning walkersâ cabins operated by the organisation
body:
Jutting out of the mountain, as stark as the landscape in which it sits, the Rabot Cabin is the latest addition to Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s collection of spectacular refuges for hikers.

Located in Hemnes, in the north of the country, the contemporary structure, which opened to the public this week, is a welcome retreat for those trekking across the difficult terrain.

The cabin, which is only accessible on foot or skis, was designed by Jarmund/Vigsn<83><92><82>s Arkitekter, who drew inspiration from the rugged surroundings. The shape of the chimneys deliberately mimic the outline of the mountains behind it and huge windows overlook the Okstindbreen glacier.

Fittingly, it is named after Charles Rabot, a French glaciologist and geographer known for his explorations of the mountainous area. And the remote location is not without its risks; a rescue hut is located 50 metres away should the main cabin be destroyed by extreme conditions.

Rabot is just one of 500 affordable cabins offering basic shelter and accommodation to trekkers and skiers that is operated by the Norwegian Trekking Association. We<83><82><82><82><84>ve rounded up five more amazing hideaways run by the organisation that you can stay in.

Mount Sk<83><92><82>la Tower

Located on a 1,843-metre peak, with views over the fjords and glaciers that surround it, the Mount Sk<83><92><82>la tower was recently voted the most original tourist cabin by visitors according to the Norway tourist board. The 20-bed, self-catered tower was built in 1891, the brainchild of Dr Hans Henrik Gerhard Kloumann, who conceived it as a place for visitors to rest body and soul. The tower is also a welcome sight for athletes competing in the brutal Sk<83><92><82>la Up race <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Europe<83><82><82><82><84>s toughest uphill race, which takes place on the mountain every August.
visitnorway.com

Breidablik Cabins

With a distinct Middle Earth feel, the Breidablik Cabins (there are two at the site) are a unique pair of constructions built from stone which was lugged up the 1,160m mountain. The grass-roofed huts enjoy panoramic views and are only open during the spring and summer; in winter the risk of landslides means it<83><82><82><82><84>s unsafe to visit.
ut.no

Preikestolen Tree Camp

A bit like a Nordic take on the futuristic jungle homes from the film Avatar, the Preikstolen Tree Camp consists of five pods that can each sleep up to three people. Constructed from steel frames wrapped in canvas, with wooden floors inside, the pods are connected by a hanging walkway.
preikestolenfjellstue.no

Preikestolen Mountain Camp

Another dramatic accommodation option at the Preikestolen base camp, the mountain camp is a vertigo-inducing construction of mesh and metal rigged to a cliff face. Up to 15 people can bed down for the night in what resembles a lobster trap from the inside <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but looks remarkably minimal from the outside, blending in with the stony mountain. As for those who toss and turn at night, fear not; there are nets around the edge too, so you don<83><82><82><82><84>t need to worry about rolling out of bed.
preikestolenfjellstue.no

Vasstindbu Cabins

Exposed to the elements on a mountain ridge, the builders of this pair of cabins between the Horndalen and the Kj<83><92><82>vdalen valley were forced to come up with new solutions, constructing them without the use of nails. Described as so solid <83><82><82><82><93>it<83><82><82><82><84>ll stand till Doom<83><82><82><82><84>s Day<83><82><82><82><9d>, the first of the two cabins has stood on this spot since 1974.
ut.no

Cabins can be booked through the Norwegian Trekking Association . Prices for self-catered cabins include basic food (crispbreads, tea, coffee) and cost <83><80><9a><82>18 a night for members, <83><80><9a><82>28 for non-members. A dorm bed in a serviced cabin, where you need to bring all your food, start at <83><80><9a><82>13 for members and <83><80><9a><82>18 for non-members. Membership is <83><80><9a><82>55 per year and can be bought at turistforeningen.no.

Most cabins cannot be booked in advance, apart from those in and around Oslo , but no one is turned away, even if the cabin is full. Still, if you<83><82><82><82><84>re using a serviced cabin it is worth contacting it in advance to make sure it is open.

The cabin, which is only accessible on foot or skis, was designed by Jarmund/Vigsns Arkitekter, who drew inspiration from the rugged surroundings. A dorm bed in a serviced cabin, where you need to bring all your food, start at 13 for members and 18 for non-members. Membership is 55 per year and can be bought at turistforeningen.no. Most cabins cannot be booked in advance, apart from those in and around Oslo , but no one is turned away, even if the cabin is full. Still, if youre using a serviced cabin it is worth contacting it in advance to make sure it is open.

webTitle: From Norways passports to hipsters: whats hot and whats not this week
trailText: We heart: Studio 10, Norwayâs passports, Miley and Patrick. We hate: outdoor clothes, pretty perfume bottles, branding everything as hipster
headline: From Norwayâs passports to hipsters: whatâs hot and whatâs not this week
standfirst: We heart: Studio 10, Norwayâs passports, Miley and Patrick. We hate: outdoor clothes, pretty perfume bottles, branding everything as hipster
body:
Going up

New Mac product smell Can someone get Comme des Gar<83><92><82>ons to turn this into a perfume?

The red leather coat from Charlotte Gainsbourg<83><82><82><82><84>s Current/Elliott collection Cheery Christmas-walk outerwear with gallic chic.

Miley Cyrus and Patrick Schwarzenegger Celebrity next-gen couple du jour. Hopefully this means Arnie and Billy Ray will be spending Christmas together.

Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s passports Incredibly chic <83><82><82><82><80><9c> especially the very Ed Ruscha inside spreads. HM Passport Office, please start your mood board.

Studio 10 makeup Essentials that actually work. The lip collection and contour palette make excellent gifts for both experts and beginners.

Charlotte Simone<83><82><82><82><84>s Bon Bon bag A pink fluffy bag that looks like a massive sweet. What<83><82><82><82><84>s not to like?

Going down

Cranberries in everything Fine on the Christmas dinner table. Not so much in brownies. One seasonal ingredient we<83><82><82><82><84>d be happy to lose.

Your outdoor clothes It<83><82><82><82><84>s Christmas week. Posh comfort dressing only.

Pretty perfume bottles Pah. Toy by Moschino <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a fluffy teddy whose head must be removed to access the scent <83><82><82><82><80><9c> has set the bar for subversion.

Branding anything remotely different as hipster For 2015 we recommend being discerning in your labelling of what<83><82><82><82><84>s <83><82><82><82><93>hipster<83><82><82><82><9d>. It<83><82><82><82><84>s confusing and straight-up lazy.

<83><82><82><82><9c>Ethnic<83><82><82><82><84> as an adjective Too many brands seem to think this is an acceptable way to describe garments. It<83><82><82><82><84>s not. Fix up.
text: New Mac product smell Can someone get Comme des Garons to turn this into a perfume? The red leather coat from Charlotte Gainsbourgs Current/Elliott collection Cheery Christmas-walk outerwear with gallic chic. Miley Cyrus and Patrick Schwarzenegger Celebrity next-gen couple du jour. Hopefully this means Arnie and Billy Ray will be spending Christmas together. Norways passports Incredibly chic  especially the very Ed Ruscha inside spreads. HM Passport Office, please start your mood board. Studio 10 makeup Essentials that actually work. The lip collection and contour palette make excellent gifts for both experts and beginners. Charlotte Simones Bon Bon bag A pink fluffy bag that looks like a massive sweet. Whats not to like? Cranberries in everything Fine on the Christmas dinner table. Not so much in brownies. One seasonal ingredient wed be happy to lose. Your outdoor clothes Its Christmas week. Posh comfort dressing only. Pretty perfume bottles Pah. Toy by Moschino  a fluffy teddy whose head must be removed to access the scent  has set the bar for subversion. Branding anything remotely different as hipster For 2015 we recommend being discerning in your labelling of whats hipster. Its confusing and straight-up lazy. Ethnic as an adjective Too many brands seem to think this is an acceptable way to describe garments. Its not. Fix up.

webTitle: Norway to give Liberia $150m to fight illegal logging that may spread Ebola
trailText: Funds will be used to improve forest governance as some scientists speculate that deforestation may be linked to disease
headline: Norway to give Liberia $150m to fight illegal logging that may spread Ebola
standfirst: Funds will be used to improve forest governance as some scientists speculate that deforestation may be linked to disease
body:
Norway will give Liberia up to $150m (<83><80><9a><82>92.1m) over the next six years to fund protective measures aimed at stamping out illegal logging in its agricultural sector, which some scientists believe may have contributed to the worst Ebola outbreak in history.

The funds will <83><82><82><82><93>improve forest governance, strengthen law enforcement, and support efforts in reducing greenhouse gas emissions from deforestation and forest degradation<83><82><82><82><9d>, both governments said.

West Africa is gripped by an outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus that has claimed the lives of 2,917 people so far, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO). Scientists have speculated that the crisis could have been driven by illegal logging that unleashed Ebola-infected fruit bats into contact with people, sending the outbreak out of control.

<83><82><82><82><93>Inhabitants in the region do indeed anecdotally report an exceptionally arid and prolonged dry season, perhaps linked to the extreme deforestation of the area over recent decades. At present, we can only speculate that these drier ecologic conditions somehow influence the number or proportion of Ebola virus<83><82><82><82><80><9c>infected bats and/or the frequency of human contact with them,<83><82><82><82><9d> according to a study co-published in July by Daniel Bausch, associate professor of Tropical Medicine at Tulane University and Lara Schwarz of Canada<83><82><82><82><84>s McGill University.

On Tuesday a new study projected that Ebola could kill up to 1.4 million people by mid-January next year.

<83><82><82><82><93>Particularly at this difficult time, we are proud and happy to enter into this partnership with Norway, further consolidating our decision to embark on a green, sustainable development path,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Liberian president Ellen Johnson Sirleaf.

<83><82><82><82><93>We have a tunnel vision right now focusing on the Ebola crisis. But Liberia has the largest remaining rainforest in west Africa. This deal helps a lot [to preserve the rainforest],<83><82><82><82><9d> said Axel Addy, Liberia<83><82><82><82><84>s minister of commerce and industry.

Liberia<83><82><82><82><84>s government says its forests make up 43% of the Upper Guinea forests, which are a vital source of the earth<83><82><82><82><84>s carbon.

<83><82><82><82><93>This partnership holds promise not only for the forest and climate; but for forest communities that have been marginalised for generations. The partnership<83><82><82><82><84>s commitment to respecting and protecting communities rights with respect to forests is laudable,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Silas Siakor, a Liberian environmental activist.

The deal will see both sides <83><82><82><82><93>contribute to sustainable development in Liberia through protecting natural forests, restoring degraded lands, and developing Liberia<83><82><82><82><84>s agricultural sector through enhancing sustainable agricultural management, and greening supply chains,<83><82><82><82><9d> according to a letter of intent signed by both countries.

Residents and experts worry that the Ebola crisis could wreak havoc on West African economies, as quarantines prevent people from working.

But Patrick Alley, director of Global Witness, said efforts to preserve Liberia<83><82><82><82><84>s forests could reap huge economic rewards.

<83><82><82><82><93>For decades Liberia<83><82><82><82><84>s forests have been more of a curse than a blessing. Timber revenues funded Charles Taylor<83><82><82><82><84>s regime during Liberia<83><82><82><82><84>s brutal civil war. Since then the experiment to generate economic development through industrial scale logging has failed, with logging companies routinely logging illegally, skirting taxes, and causing huge damage to forests and forest communities,<83><82><82><82><9d> Alley said.

<83><82><82><82><93>If Liberia delivers on this promise it could help spur the country<83><82><82><82><84>s economy and set development on a sustainable path at such a difficult time,<83><82><82><82><9d> he added.

The negotiations on the partnership we launched today have been ongoing since long before the Ebola crisis,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Jens Fr<83><92><82>lich Holte, a political adviser to the Norwegian ministry of climate and environment. <83><82><82><82><93>Of course, dealing with the [Ebola] crisis has to be the top priority.<83><82><82><82><9d>
text: Norway will give Liberia up to $150m (92.1m) over the next six years to fund protective measures aimed at stamping out illegal logging in its agricultural sector, which some scientists believe may have contributed to the worst Ebola outbreak in history. The funds will improve forest governance, strengthen law enforcement, and support efforts in reducing greenhouse gas emissions from deforestation and forest degradation, both governments said. West Africa is gripped by an outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus that has claimed the lives of 2,917 people so far, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO). Scientists have speculated that the crisis could have been driven by illegal logging that unleashed Ebola-infected fruit bats into contact with people, sending the outbreak out of control. Inhabitants in the region do indeed anecdotally report an exceptionally arid and prolonged dry season, perhaps linked to the extreme deforestation of the area over recent decades. At present, we can only speculate that these drier ecologic conditions somehow influence the number or proportion of Ebola virusinfected bats and/or the frequency of human contact with them, according to a study co-published in July by Daniel Bausch, associate professor of Tropical Medicine at Tulane University and Lara Schwarz of Canadas McGill University. On Tuesday a new study projected that Ebola could kill up to 1.4 million people by mid-January next year. Particularly at this difficult time, we are proud and happy to enter into this partnership with Norway, further consolidating our decision to embark on a green, sustainable development path, said Liberian president Ellen Johnson Sirleaf. We have a tunnel vision right now focusing on the Ebola crisis. But Liberia has the largest remaining rainforest in west Africa. This deal helps a lot [to preserve the rainforest], said Axel Addy, Liberias minister of commerce and industry. Liberias government says its forests make up 43% of the Upper Guinea forests, which are a vital source of the earths carbon. This partnership holds promise not only for the forest and climate; but for forest communities that have been marginalised for generations. The partnerships commitment to respecting and protecting communities rights with respect to forests is laudable, said Silas Siakor, a Liberian environmental activist. The deal will see both sides contribute to sustainable development in Liberia through protecting natural forests, restoring degraded lands, and developing Liberias agricultural sector through enhancing sustainable agricultural management, and greening supply chains, according to a letter of intent signed by both countries. Residents and experts worry that the Ebola crisis could wreak havoc on West African economies, as quarantines prevent people from working. But Patrick Alley, director of Global Witness, said efforts to preserve Liberias forests could reap huge economic rewards. For decades Liberias forests have been more of a curse than a blessing. Timber revenues funded Charles Taylors regime during Liberias brutal civil war. Since then the experiment to generate economic development through industrial scale logging has failed, with logging companies routinely logging illegally, skirting taxes, and causing huge damage to forests and forest communities, Alley said. If Liberia delivers on this promise it could help spur the countrys economy and set development on a sustainable path at such a difficult time, he added. The negotiations on the partnership we launched today have been ongoing since long before the Ebola crisis, said Jens Frlich Holte, a political adviser to the Norwegian ministry of climate and environment. Of course, dealing with the [Ebola] crisis has to be the top priority.

webTitle: Euro 2016 qualifiers: Czechs stun Holland and Italy beat Norway
trailText: The Czech Republic snatched a last-gasp 2-1 victory over Holland after a mistake by Daryl Janmaat while Antonio Conteâs Italy won 2-0 in Norway
headline: Euro 2016 qualifiers: Czech Republic stun Holland and Italy beat Norway
standfirst:
â¢ Cyprus spoil Edin Dzekoâs debut as Bosnia captain
â¢ Gylfi Sigurdsson scores in Icelandâs win over Turkey
â¢ Bale double rescues feeble Wales in Andorra
body:
The Czech Republic snatched a last-gasp 2-1 victory over Holland after Vaclav Pilar pounced on a dreadful mistake by Daryl Janmaat to score the winner in added time in Prague.

The Newcastle United defender attempted to cushion a header back to Jasper Cillessen inside the area but it beat the Dutch keeper, struck the post and fell for Pilar to tuck the rebound into the net.

The Czechs had started brightly and were rewarded in the 22nd minute when David Lafata controlled a cross in the box before laying it off to Borek Dockal, whose left-footed shot flew into the net off a post. The Dutch, third-place finishers at the World Cup in Brazil, equalised through a Stefan de Vrij header from a Daley Blind cross but the Czechs snatched victory through Pilar.

The match was Guus Hiddink<83><82><82><82><84>s first competitive game in charge since his return to the national side after Louis van Gaal stepped down to take charge of Manchester United. <83><82><82><82><93>The Czechs played well,<83><82><82><82><9d> Hiddink said. <83><82><82><82><93>We have to learn our lesson but it is too soon to analyse what happened. It [the winner] was an unlucky goal but the system doesn<83><82><82><82><84>t matter if you make individual mistakes.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Simone Zaza and Leonardo Bonucci gave Antonio Conte a 2-0 victory over Norway in his first competitive game as Italy coach. The visitors took the lead in the 16th minute when Zaza<83><82><82><82><84>s tame shot deflected off Haavard Nortveidt and wrong-footed Orjan Nyland. Norway enjoyed plenty of possession but failed to create any clearcut chances and Italy<83><82><82><82><84>s captain Bonucci made it 2-0 after 62 minutes, rising unmarked to power home a downward header from Manuel Pasqual<83><82><82><82><84>s cross.

Dimitris Christofi scored twice against the run of play to give unfancied Cyprus a smash-and-grab 2-1 win in Bosnia and Herzegovina in Edin Dzeko<83><82><82><82><84>s first game as captain. Bosnia seemed to be cruising after a Vedad Ibisevic header gave them an early lead but they spurned several chances before Christofi beat Asmir Begovic with a header. Bosnia laid siege to the Cyprus defence after the break but were again caught out at the other end when Christofi raced clear to beat the advancing Begovic with a cool finish. Miralem Pjanic saw a weak penalty kick saved by Antonis Georgallides in the 89th minute to complete a miserable night for the hosts.

Croatia recorded a 2-0 home win over 10-man Malta with goals from Luka Modric and the emerging 23-year-old striker Andrej Kramaric. Modric celebrated his 29th birthday by breaking the deadlock with a sizzling low shot in the 46th minute before the second-half substitute Kramaric capped a fine individual performance with a late goal on his competitive debut.

Gylfi Sigurdsson was on target as Iceland beat 10-man Turkey 3-0 to go top of Group A ahead of Italy on goal difference. Jon Dadi Bodvarsson scored in the 18th minute and Iceland<83><82><82><82><84>s task of defending their lead was made easier when Omer Toprak was sent off in the 59th minute for his second yellow card. Sigurdsson doubled the lead in the 76th minute and Kolbeinn Sigthorsson completed the scoring a minute later.

Ventsislav Hristov came off the substitutes bench to score a late header which earned Bulgaria a 2-1 victory in Azerbaijan. Kazakhstan and Latvia played out a 0-0 draw in Almaty.

The match was Guus Hiddinks first competitive game in charge since his return to the national side after Louis van Gaal stepped down to take charge of Manchester United. The Czechs played well, Hiddink said. We have to learn our lesson but it is too soon to analyse what happened.
