webTitle: Roy Hodgson angered by criticism of England players after Norway win
trailText: Roy Hodgson has delivered the most impassioned defence of his England team since becoming manager, saying his squad contains several âtop players in the makingâ
headline: Roy Hodgson angered by criticism of England players after Norway win
standfirst:
â¢ Manager delivers impassioned defence of young players
â¢ Hodgson says squad contains âtop players in the makingâ
â¢ Match report: England 1 Norway 0
â¢ Joe Hart backs Wayne Rooney as captain
body:
Roy Hodgson has launched a spiky and impassioned defence of his England players, arguing they do not deserve the criticism that is coming their way and accusing the media of exaggerating the team<83><82><82><82><84>s deficiencies in light of what happened in the World Cup.

Hodgson, as angry as at any time in his England tenure, spoke out in response to the reaction to the 1-0 defeat of Norway at Wembley and was particularly annoyed at having to answer a question about the fact his team had managed only two shots on target, describing the statistic as <83><82><82><82><93>fucking bollocks<83><82><82><82><9d>. The England manager believes the disappointments of the summer have led to unfair analysis, adding to the negativity swirling around a team whose first game since the World Cup was played in front of a half-empty stadium, with their lowest crowd since Wembley reopened in 2007.

England<83><82><82><82><84>s performance has led to scrutiny of Hodgson<83><82><82><82><84>s decision to revert to a 4-4-2 system and the form of Wayne Rooney, who scored the decisive goal from the penalty spot but has started the season slowly. Hodgson believes the striker struggled with the pressures of being the team<83><82><82><82><84>s new captain, something Louis van Gaal has also said at Manchester United, but the national team manager was still aggrieved about what he perceived to be undue negativity.

<83><82><82><82><93>I am entitled to [be annoyed], aren<83><82><82><82><84>t I? When you have questions like: <83><82><82><82><9c>You had only two shots on target <83><82><82><82><83><82><82><82><84> We can<83><82><82><82><84>t get rid of the baggage, we can<83><82><82><82><84>t change the fact we had a bad World Cup, we can<83><82><82><82><84>t play those games against Italy and Uruguay again, but I think you will have to give me the entitlement at least.

<83><82><82><82><93>If we had played badly, if a lot of players had had really poor performances, if the quality of our passing and our movement was nothing like I wanted to see and if our defending wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t as compact, aggressive and organised as it was for large periods, I would be the first to say so. But I am not going to say it<83><82><82><82><84>s not that, just because we had a bad World Cup.

<83><82><82><82><93>You have seen an England team dominate for 45 minutes against a good opponent. You have seen us work very hard to create chances, you have seen players get in behind defenders in wide areas and miss crosses and, yes, I am not terribly happy about that. I would have liked the crosses to be a little bit better. I would have liked two of three of those shots to get past the blocking player and whizz past the goal. I would have liked Daniel Sturridge<83><82><82><82><84>s magnificent effort, from that wonderful [Raheem Sterling] pass, not to land on the roof of the net.

<83><82><82><82><93>I saw a ten-to-15-minute period in the second half when I thought we were nowhere near what I wanted to see. I thought we lost the aggression in our defending and we didn<83><82><82><82><84>t attack anywhere near as well. Joe had to make a good save from a corner, and Norway almost scored again from a Gary Cahill back pass. But we saw a different system then. We changed it around and I saw some very positive moments.

<83><82><82><82><93>John Stones, who has played hardly any games recently for Everton, stepped out at right-back and gave a very strong performance and when Chambers came on he did well, too. Henderson and Wilshere, in my book, were excellent. Delph came in to play his first game and showed some very good things going forward and, of course, Sturridge was excellent throughout. All I<83><82><82><82><84>m saying is I want to judge every game as it is.

<83><82><82><82><93>Welbeck came on and showed his potential, so there were a lot of good things but the bottom line is this: before the World Cup, with all the euphoria, we were getting 75,000 people to see us play Peru. Now we have 40,000 to see us play against a much more difficult opponent. I can<83><82><82><82><84>t put that right because I can<83><82><82><82><84>t turn the clock back, but what I can do is analyse what I have seen and judge that through my eyes and not because someone is telling me: <83><82><82><82><9c>Well, you had only two shots at goal<83><82><82><82><84> because, for me, that is absolute fucking bollocks, I<83><82><82><82><84>m sorry.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Hodgson, who has arranged for the psychiatrist Dr Steve Peters to talk to his squad on Friday at St George<83><82><82><82><84>s Park as they prepare for England<83><82><82><82><84>s first Euro 2016 qualifier in Switzerland on Monday, went on to cite some of the players who were missing through injury. Jack Colback and Ben Foster have both had to withdraw from the original 22-man squad and Hodgson has decided not to bring in replacements before the team fly to Basel.

<83><82><82><82><93>The fact of the matter is that we haven<83><82><82><82><84>t got many more. There are four or five very good players who are not here through injury: Chris Smalling and Luke Shaw in defence, and Ross Barkley and Lallana in central midfield. There is Jon Flanagan, who we like and hope to see back soon, and of course the longer-term injuries with [Jay] Rodriguez.

<83><82><82><82><93>I am talking to people here who have followed England for many years, and follow the Premier League football every week, and there is no chance of pulling wool over the eyes of people who know what top-class players look like. But I will continue to say, so long as they continue to give performances like that, some of these players are top, top players in the making. But they are players in the making. You can<83><82><82><82><84>t play five games for England, be a regular in the Liverpool team for six or seven months, and be David Beckham. You can<83><82><82><82><84>t come in like Phil Jones after all the injuries and nail down a place in the central defence of Manchester United and become John Terry. You can<83><82><82><82><84>t be Jack Wilshere, who has lost all that football through injury, and all of a sudden be Bryan Robson.

<83><82><82><82><93>Let<83><82><82><82><84>s be fair about these things, that is all I am asking. But also, allow me to be excited by what they can do and allow me when they do play well to stand in front of an assembled press conference and say: <83><82><82><82><9c>I think they did well<83><82><82><82><84> even though there might be some cynicism out there. Maybe it wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t as good [as you wanted], fine. That is up to you, just as long as you don<83><82><82><82><84>t expect me to go down the same route.<83><82><82><82><9d>
text: Roy Hodgson has launched a spiky and impassioned defence of his England players, arguing they do not deserve the criticism that is coming their way and accusing the media of exaggerating the teams deficiencies in light of what happened in the World Cup. Hodgson, as angry as at any time in his England tenure, spoke out in response to the reaction to the 1-0 defeat of Norway at Wembley and was particularly annoyed at having to answer a question about the fact his team had managed only two shots on target, describing the statistic as fucking bollocks. The England manager believes the disappointments of the summer have led to unfair analysis, adding to the negativity swirling around a team whose first game since the World Cup was played in front of a half-empty stadium, with their lowest crowd since Wembley reopened in 2007. Englands performance has led to scrutiny of Hodgsons decision to revert to a 4-4-2 system and the form of Wayne Rooney, who scored the decisive goal from the penalty spot but has started the season slowly. Hodgson believes the striker struggled with the pressures of being the teams new captain, something Louis van Gaal has also said at Manchester United, but the national team manager was still aggrieved about what he perceived to be undue negativity. I am entitled to [be annoyed], arent I? When you have questions like: You had only two shots on target  We cant get rid of the baggage, we cant change the fact we had a bad World Cup, we cant play those games against Italy and Uruguay again, but I think you will have to give me the entitlement at least. If we had played badly, if a lot of players had had really poor performances, if the quality of our passing and our movement was nothing like I wanted to see and if our defending wasnt as compact, aggressive and organised as it was for large periods, I would be the first to say so. But I am not going to say its not that, just because we had a bad World Cup. You have seen an England team dominate for 45 minutes against a good opponent. You have seen us work very hard to create chances, you have seen players get in behind defenders in wide areas and miss crosses and, yes, I am not terribly happy about that. I would have liked the crosses to be a little bit better. I would have liked two of three of those shots to get past the blocking player and whizz past the goal. I would have liked Daniel Sturridges magnificent effort, from that wonderful [Raheem Sterling] pass, not to land on the roof of the net. I saw a ten-to-15-minute period in the second half when I thought we were nowhere near what I wanted to see. I thought we lost the aggression in our defending and we didnt attack anywhere near as well. Joe had to make a good save from a corner, and Norway almost scored again from a Gary Cahill back pass. But we saw a different system then. We changed it around and I saw some very positive moments. John Stones, who has played hardly any games recently for Everton, stepped out at right-back and gave a very strong performance and when Chambers came on he did well, too. Henderson and Wilshere, in my book, were excellent. Delph came in to play his first game and showed some very good things going forward and, of course, Sturridge was excellent throughout. All Im saying is I want to judge every game as it is. Welbeck came on and showed his potential, so there were a lot of good things but the bottom line is this: before the World Cup, with all the euphoria, we were getting 75,000 people to see us play Peru. Now we have 40,000 to see us play against a much more difficult opponent. I cant put that right because I cant turn the clock back, but what I can do is analyse what I have seen and judge that through my eyes and not because someone is telling me: Well, you had only two shots at goal because, for me, that is absolute fucking bollocks, Im sorry. Hodgson, who has arranged for the psychiatrist Dr Steve Peters to talk to his squad  on Friday at St Georges Park as they prepare for Englands first Euro 2016 qualifier in Switzerland on Monday, went on to cite some of the players who were missing through injury. Jack Colback and Ben Foster have both had to withdraw from the original 22-man squad and Hodgson has decided not to bring in replacements before the team fly to Basel. The fact of the matter is that we havent got many more. There are four or five very good players who are not here through injury: Chris Smalling and Luke Shaw in defence, and Ross Barkley and Lallana in central midfield. There is Jon Flanagan, who we like and hope to see back soon, and of course the longer-term injuries with [Jay] Rodriguez. I am talking to people here who have followed England for many years, and follow the Premier League football every week, and there is no chance of pulling wool over the eyes of people who know what top-class players look like. But I will continue to say, so long as they continue to give performances like that, some of these players are top, top players in the making. But they are players in the making. You cant play five games for England, be a regular in the Liverpool team for six or seven months, and be David Beckham. You cant come in like Phil Jones after all the injuries and nail down a place in the central defence of Manchester United and become John Terry. You cant be Jack Wilshere, who has lost all that football through injury, and all of a sudden be Bryan Robson. Lets be fair about these things, that is all I am asking. But also, allow me to be excited by what they can do and allow me when they do play well to stand in front of an assembled press conference and say: I think they did well even though there might be some cynicism out there. Maybe it wasnt as good [as you wanted], fine. That is up to you, just as long as you dont expect me to go down the same route.

webTitle: England 1-0 Norway: Five things we learned from Wembley friendly
trailText: Dominic Fifield: Reconciliation with the fans will be a drawn-out process, while defensive issues remain ahead of Switzerland test
headline: England 1-0 Norway: Five things we learned from Wembley friendly
standfirst: Reconciliation with the fans will be a drawn-out process, while defensive issues remain ahead of Switzerland test
body:
1 It will take time for the side to reconnect with the public

This really was evidence of a World Cup hangover, with the contest played out to an eerily flat atmosphere inside the national stadium and the banks of empty seats swallowing what noise the support could drum up. The English have hosted games in front of fewer spectators than the 40,181 here, but not in their rebuilt home. There were some mitigating circumstances, like this being the first day of the new school year, but there is apathy among the fanbase. The Euro 2016 qualifying group will hardly have the juices flowing <83><82><82><82><80><9c> roll on the mooted high-profile friendlies against Germany, Spain, France, Holland and Italy <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but there is a desperate need to revive some enthusiasm in the wake of Brazil. This downbeat occasion, even in victory, was not the best of starts.

2 This is no time to pin hopes on a good old-fashioned 4-4-2

More appealing would be to produce more exhilarating style of football, and Roy Hodgson has the players to do just that. Take Raheem Sterling, so devastating for Liverpool at Tottenham Hotspur on Sunday and sprightly again here. The teenager is a gem of a player, all low centre of gravity and extravagant skill, and coaxed the penalty out of Omar Elabdellaoui. But would he not be better employed at the tip of a diamond, as he was late on, rather than in his rather rigid 4-4-2? To that end, it was interesting to note Sir Trevor Brooking, the FA<83><82><82><82><84>s outgoing director of football development, stating in his farewell programme notes that England play a 4-3-3 <83><82><82><82><93>throughout the age groups<83><82><82><82><9d>. Here the seniors went against the grain.

3 Switzerland may fancy their chances against this defence

Hodgson had described this as a dress rehearsal for Monday<83><82><82><82><84>s qualifier in Basel. <83><82><82><82><93>That<83><82><82><82><84>s the team I want to play against the Swiss,<83><82><82><82><9d> he had said pre-match, and he would have been hoping for more inspiring fare from those in whom he had placed his faith. They will be seriously tested by Vladimir Petkovic<83><82><82><82><84>s side, the likes of Xherdan Shaqiri and Josip Drmic eager to ruffle the inexperienced John Stones and Phil Jones. Both players have the potential to excel yet, for now, they are raw, will make mistakes and are heavily reliant upon Gary Cahill at their side for reassurance. The Chelsea player still labours in unfamiliar partnerships, and this rearguard can appear vulnerable, but England desperately need him to step up and lead from the back. So the sight of him substituted and sitting with an ice pack on his right ankle was unnerving.

4 Can the Wilshere and Henderson combination work?

While Sterling and Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain sprinted down their flanks, England<83><82><82><82><84>s central midfield still appeared a work in progress. Jack Wilshere offered flashes of quality and tidy distribution as well as energy <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and should have won a penalty <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but Jordan Henderson still feels shackled. He was invariably the deeper of the two here yet, as at White Hart Lane on Sunday, it is his dynamism that marks him out. He needs the licence to burst forward like a young Steven Gerrard, not the restriction of sitting deep as his club captain has done in the latter stages of his career. Perhaps he and Wilshere were supposed to dovetail more regularly, but they still felt a combination whose potential had not been tapped by the system.

5 Rooney will have to wait to make his mark as captain

The new captain had said all the right things pre-match, talking of a <83><82><82><82><93>new chapter<83><82><82><82><9d> and stressing <83><82><82><82><93>this is my time<83><82><82><82><9d>. But, while he converted the penalty which finally broke the deadlock, he was worryingly peripheral here. England<83><82><82><82><84>s most potent attacks were mustered by the busy Sterling in combination with Daniel Sturridge, with the captain displaying very little coherent combination play with the Liverpool forward. Rooney<83><82><82><82><84>s experience <83><82><82><82><80><9c> this was his 96th cap <83><82><82><82><80><9c> makes him invaluable to this team, but they need him to contribute more on the pitch than merely say the right things off it. He must conjure better than this in Basel.

This downbeat occasion, even in victory, was not the best of starts. More appealing would be to produce more exhilarating style of football, and Roy Hodgson has the players to do just that. Take Raheem Sterling, so devastating for Liverpool at Tottenham Hotspur on Sunday and sprightly again here. The teenager is a gem of a player, all low centre of gravity and extravagant skill, and coaxed the penalty out of Omar Elabdellaoui. But would he not be better employed at the tip of a diamond, as he was late on, rather than in his rather rigid 4-4-2? To that end, it was interesting to note Sir Trevor Brooking, the FAs outgoing director of football development, stating in his farewell programme notes that England play a 4-3-3 throughout the age groups. Here the seniors went against the grain. Hodgson had described this as a dress rehearsal for Mondays qualifier in Basel. Thats the team I want to play against the Swiss, he had said pre-match, and he would have been hoping for more inspiring fare from those in whom he had placed his faith. They will be seriously tested by Vladimir Petkovics side, the likes of Xherdan Shaqiri and Josip Drmic eager to ruffle the inexperienced John Stones and Phil Jones. Rooneys experience  this was his 96th cap  makes him invaluable to this team, but they need him to contribute more on the pitch than merely say the right things off it. He must conjure better than this in Basel.

webTitle: Oil tax: Norway could teach Australia a thing or two about managing wealth |
trailText: Oliver Milman: Thanks to natural resources, Norway is a country of five million trustifarians â with each person theoretically being a millionaire. In Australia, mining benefits a selected few
headline: Oil tax: Norway could teach Australia a thing or two about managing wealth
standfirst: Thanks to natural resources, Norway is a country of five million trustifarians â with each person theoretically being a millionaire. In Australia, mining benefits a selected few
body:
Given the number of visiting delegations that troop into the Australian parliament to watch the occasionally bruising debate, it<83><82><82><82><84>s perhaps fortunate that there were a distinct lack of Norwegians present when Joe Hockey announced the demise of the mining tax on Tuesday.

Anyone involved in policy formation in the Nordic country would probably have been baffled and even dismayed that an advanced democracy such as Australia could<83><82><82><82><84>ve strayed so far from Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s stellar example on how to manage the dumb fortune of a resources boom.

Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s government Pension Fund Global was created in 1990 to make the most of the windfall of striking oil in the North Sea. Companies looking to extract Norwegian oil pay handsomely for the privilege.

The Norwegian government sums up the fund with the rather lengthy fortune cookie-like phrase <83><82><82><82><93>One day the oil will run out, but the return on the fund will continue to benefit the Norwegian population.<83><82><82><82><9d>

The bulging sovereign wealth fund, managed by the Norwegian government, is set to top $1trn within this decade. At the end of 2013, its value stood at 5.2trn kroner <83><82><82><82><80><9c> that<83><82><82><82><84>s $903.4bn.

With the money invested more than 8,000 businesses and properties last year, the fund currently owns 1% of all the world<83><82><82><82><84>s stocks. The fund managers recently purchased a slab of London<83><82><82><82><84>s ritzy west end, including Savile Row, famed for its sharp suits and the former office of the record label Apple <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the rooftop venue for the Beatles<83><82><82><82><84> last live performance.

The fund<83><82><82><82><84>s average annual return has been 5.7%. Last year was a bumper one, with the money pot swelling by 15%.

Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s oil piggy bank is worth more than the GDP of Switzerland. More even than the US<83><82><82><82><84> gargantuan annual military budget. In effect, Norway is a country of five million trustifarians <83><82><82><82><80><9c> with each person theoretically being a millionaire (in kroner, that is).

Such largesse invariably raises the challenge of how to spend the money. The government is limited to spending just 4% of the fund each year, with the rest hoarded for future disasters that may befall the Scandinavian country.

Regardless, Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s publicly funded safety net is lavishly embroidered. Parental leave lasts 46 weeks at 100% of pay. Almost every child has access to childcare. Farmers are subsidised to the extent that they can keep cows in heated barns in the Arctic.

Despite the relatively robust health of the Australian economy, there is no such opportunity for Scrooge McDuck behaviour, largely because of the botched way Australia has managed its once in a generation mining boom.

In scrapping the mining tax, treasurer Joe Hockey called it a <83><82><82><82><93>testament to a failed Labor government, failed economic policy, failed taxation policy and a failed treasurer.<83><82><82><82><9d> Tony Abbott called it a <83><82><82><82><93>stupid<83><82><82><82><9d> tax.

In many respects, Hockey and Abbott are onto something. In Norway, companies drilling for North Sea oil pay a 78% tax rate on income, compared with a corporate tax rate of 28%.

By contrast, the much-derided Minerals Resource Rent Tax placed a 22.5% <83><82><82><82><93>super profits<83><82><82><82><9d> tax on coal and iron ore producers.

But the nature of the system meant that it raised very little money. Indeed, last financial year it raised nothing at all and was projected to bring in just $450m this year.

This kind of flaw isn<83><82><82><82><84>t that surprising when, uniquely among businesses, the mining companies were allowed to write their own tax code by a callow Labor government terrified of marauding mining magnates on the back of Utes.

Where Hockey is on less firm ground is when he states the scrapping of the mining tax is a <83><82><82><82><93>damn good deal.<83><82><82><82><9d>

When you consider the Norwegian example, it seems farcical that parliament has spent the week squabbling over associated superannuation and childcare benefits when the obvious source of revenue was turned down for short-term political expediency and then abandoned entirely.

This wasted opportunity extends to other areas. The outcry over changes to university fees, or welfare or payments to see the GP would surely be rendered unnecessary if the previous government had crafted a proper mining tax and spent it wisely.

It<83><82><82><82><84>s also to the detriment of Australia<83><82><82><82><84>s national intelligence that the idea of the mining tax as a jobs and growth-destroying handicap was given credence, all while being derided for raising no money.

Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s GDP is set to grow by 2.7% this year, while Australia<83><82><82><82><84>s will grow by 2.5%. Both countries rode through the global financial crisis relatively unscathed. Unemployment and inflation has remained low in both countries, although they both have come under recent pressure in Australia and Norway, respectively.

These results were similar even though Norway taxes its oil firms at 78% and Australia<83><82><82><82><84>s MRRT was 22.5%. There was no stampede of resource investment away from Norway due to its high tax rate, and it managed to insulate itself from any recession for coming generations to boot.

Like Australia, Norway had an incoming conservative government last year. However, the language of the two governments appears to be from different planets, let alone ideologies.

<83><82><82><82><93>I would like to look into the budget to see if there are enough investments in education, research and infrastructure. And also the framework for small and medium sized enterprises,<83><82><82><82><9d> said Jan Tore Sanner, finance spokesman for the Norwegian Conservatives after the party<83><82><82><82><84>s election victory.

<83><82><82><82><93>We really need to have strong investments not only in the petroleum industry but also in the other sectors of the economy.<83><82><82><82><9d>

This could<83><82><82><82><84>ve been the outcome for Australia, had there not been such a catastrophic failure in long-term thinking and such timidity in facing up to rent-seeking self interest.

This couldve been the outcome for Australia, had there not been such a catastrophic failure in long-term thinking and such timidity in facing up to rent-seeking self interest.

webTitle: World's first Arctic arts festival to open for one year in northern Norway
trailText: Salt festival will take place on remote island celebrating an 'Arctic state of mind' through art, music, architecture and food
headline: World's first Arctic arts festival to open for one year in northern Norway
standfirst: Salt festival will take place on remote island celebrating an 'Arctic state of mind' through art, music, architecture and food
body:
The world's largest sauna, a black-metal band playing rocks, deer-hide drums and a goat horn, and experimental films projected onto a giant rack for drying fish are just some of the attractions hoping to lure visitors to Salt, the world's first Arctic arts festival.

From Friday, the 400-strong population of Sandhorn<83><92><82>ya, a remote Norwegian island 90 minutes' drive from the nearest big town, promises to be swelled by festivalgoers ready to explore what organisers call "an Arctic state of mind" through art, music, architecture and food.

Most of the action will be concentrated on a beach on the island's northern tip, 2km long and 300 metres wide. "It has this really special white sand," said architect and artist Joar Nango, who is Sami, the indigenous people of the area. "Right behind there's a 500-metre-tall, black mountain wall which is totally vertical. In the wall, there are eight pairs of eagles nesting. It's a magical place."

Nango has built three shelters on the beach where visitors will be able to stay. Sleeping four apiece, they are based on traditional Sami storage houses called njalla. Nango's dwellings are built on skis so can be pulled around the beach, and have a glass roof to view the northern lights.

Other accommodation includes traditional Sami tents, with a floor of reindeer skin laid over birch twigs. "It gives a lot of warmth to the room," said Nango.

For the festival, Sami Rintala of Rintala Eggertsson Architects has built three "arctic pyramids", all based on traditional fish-drying racks, a nod to the area's first dominant industry exporting dried, salted cod to countries like Spain and Brazil. One has been designed to show a video installation by the Chinese artist Yang Fudong, which will be projected on it throughout the night.

The second building is a concert hall, and the third is what Rintala, a Finn, claims is the world's biggest sauna.

"The Finnish military might have something for 50-100 people but we are 110-120, depending on how close you want to sit to someone half-naked." Thanks to a glass wall at the end of the building, Rintala added, festivalgoers will be able to sweat watching the sun set in the Arctic Atlantic.

The festival was co-founded by Erlend Mog<83><92><82>rd-Larsen and curator Helga-Marie Nordby, who got the idea after working on an art biennial in Lofoten, Norway in 2010. The pair spent two years searching northern Norway for a suitable location before alighting on Sandhorn<83><92><82>ya.

"When we came here there was no doubt," said Nordby on the eve of the festival. "Right now the sun is shining and it's totally quiet <83><82><82><82><80><9c> normally there is a lot of wind. It's just amazing."

Despite the island's small population, Nordby and Rintala say that the local populace have embraced the festival. "The mayor <83><82><82><82><80><9c> he's more like a sheriff <83><82><82><82><80><9c> welcomed us with open arms," said Nordby. "There are 24 people who own the rights to the beach and all of them immediately said they wanted us to do [the building projects]."

"I'm representing the local voices and I feel very respected and listened to," said Nango. "The festival is a wonderful initiative that's done something a lot of art projects have tried to do, which is a global, contemporary cultural theme with a very grounded local context."

Indigenous performers like the Sami singer Elle M<83><92><82>rj<83><92><82> Eira will be playing with acts like "arctic ambient" musician Biosphere; Wardruna, a black-metal-affiliated band who play traditional Norwegian instruments; and musicians from the Arctic Philharmonic Orchestra, who will be performing on the beach.

The festival will continue for a full year before moving to seven more northern locations for a year apiece. Greenland is next, with locations in Scotland and Ireland being pondered by Nordby and Mog<83><92><82>rd-Larsen.

Before that, Salt has to brave its first winter. Temperatures on Sandhorn<83><92><82>ya can plunge to -20C (-4F), and the festival's architecture will be buffeted by the sea. "It can get quite rough. Dealing with the weather is part of the project, but it's stronger than us," said Nordby, adding that she would be philosophical if Salt ended up getting washed out to sea. "If you're getting too cold you can just jump into the sauna."

Rintala, who lives locally, said that the island was more than ready for its first arts festival. Far from worrying that visitors will spoil it, "we want to show the beauty of nature here to people who wouldn't otherwise come. Art, music and good food are the basic pillars of civilisation, and we feel very comfortable supporting them."

webTitle: Per-Mathias Hogmo aims for Norway resurgence the Manchester City way
trailText: The Norwegian FA have finally accepted a need to move on from the Egil Olsen-paradigm and in Per-Mathias Hogmo they have big plans to return towards the top of the Fifa rankings
headline: Per-Mathias Hogmo aims for Norway resurgence âthe Manchester City wayâ
standfirst:
The Norwegian FA have finally accepted a need to move on from the Egil Olsen-paradigm and have big plans to return to the top
â¢ Roy Hodgson calls up new boys for England squad
body:
Since the advent of TV all nations have built up a catalogue of shared moments, moments firmly etched into the collective memory. For Norwegians, one of these occurred on the 23 June 1998.

Most, if not all, will know where they were and who they were with when Norway beat Brazil 2-1 at the World Cup in France. In fact, some can even recite passages from Arne Scheie<83><82><82><82><84>s commentary. <83><82><82><82><93>He is cold, like a fish<83><82><82><82><9d> was the line as Kjetil Rekdal stepped up to take the deciding penalty 10 minutes from time. <83><82><82><82><93>Kick the ball into the Mediterranean for the last couple of minutes,<83><82><82><82><9d> Lars Tjaernas, the co-commentator, urged after the penalty went in. This being Egil Olsen<83><82><82><82><84>s Norway, it would not have been much of a departure from the original gameplan.

Before Olsen took charge in 1990, Norway was a largely obscure footballing nation. This made sense, as it has a small population and a climate that is more suited to skiing than football. However, under him they suddenly started winning.

As a player, Olsen had represented Norway under the management of the former Southampton inside forward George Curtis. His 1971-74 reign as Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s manager was a failure but Olsen the player was fascinated by his ideas. He was also deeply fascinated by the work of the retired RAF wing-commander Charles Reep, an English pioneer of statistical analysis and the long-ball game.

Olsen combined ideas from the two: from Curtis the back four and zonal marking, from Reep the idea that moves with three passes or fewer were more likely to result in a goal. To this he added findings from his own studies at the Norwegian University of Sport and Physical Education. <83><82><82><82><93>I discovered that it would appear that where the ball was on the pitch was just as important as who was in possession of it. To an extent that was in line with Reep<83><82><82><82><84>s theories, that if you get the ball into the box as often as possible then you will win the game,<83><82><82><82><9d> Olsen explained in an interview with The Blizzard.

Throughout the 90s, Olsen<83><82><82><82><84>s band of vikings repeatedly sacked more illustrious opponents <83><82><82><82><80><9c> England, Italy, Holland, Brazil, Mexico and others among them. Norway twice ascended as high as second place in the Fifa rankings and qualified for consecutive World Cups in 1994 and 1998. Other countries had more technically gifted players, were more comfortable in possession, but through hard work and a fiendish devotion to Olsen<83><82><82><82><84>s plan, Norway prospered again and again.

His plan became a national phenomenon. People with only a casual interest in football became familiar with his tactical concepts and Olsen<83><82><82><82><84>s way became Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s default tactic. His disciples would go on to dominate Norwegian football.

When Olsen stepped down in 1998 he was succeeded by his assistant, Nils Johan Semb. Of the two squads Olsen had taken to World Cups almost every player became a coach, manager, administrator or prominent media voice in the Norwegian game.

However, as with so many pioneers before him, the world caught up with Olsen and his ideas. In the 90s his Norway set new standards for defensive organisation, and their ultra-cynical, counterattacking tactic was unfamiliar to opponents.

As football moved on, other countries developed both tactically and technically. Players became fitter and teams learned to cope with the Norwegian way <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but rather than moving with the times, Norway stood still. <83><82><82><82><93>We fell asleep, tightly wrapped in a duvet of self-aggrandisement and contentment,<83><82><82><82><9d> wrote Tj<83><92><82>rnas , Olsen<83><82><82><82><84>s assistant at Wimbledon, in a brutal recent column for the Norwegian newspaper Aftenposten.

<83><82><82><82><93>We were so pleased with ourselves, we thought the roughly 200 members of Fifa could come to us and learn. We lost a few years, and a generation, to those thoughts.<83><82><82><82><9d> It is no coincidence that very few technically gifted players emerged from the generation that grew up in a climate where anti-possession football ruled.

Age Hareide, who played for Manchester City and Norwich in the early 80s, made tentative efforts to improve things between 2003 and 2008 but his reign as national manager was ultimately unsuccessful. With his departure came an opportunity for reform, for an injection of fresh ideas.

The FA instead rehired Olsen but his return resulted in Norway failing to qualify for Euro 2012 and they finished below Slovenia and Iceland in the qualifying group for the Brazil World Cup this summer. In 2013 Norway won three out of 13 games, two of them friendlies.

In February they were 60th in the Fifa-rankings, an all-time low, but the relentless misery of the past few seasons did, if nothing else, impress upon the Norwegian FA the need to break away from the past.

Per-Mathias Hogmo was hired as the manager and under him a new philosophy is slowly being implemented. <83><82><82><82><93>The way we defend is a lot like Atl<83><92><82>tico Madrid,<83><82><82><82><9d> he explained in January, <83><82><82><82><93>with 4-4-2 and an extreme movement of blocks. This demands a lot of us but this is what we want to do.<83><82><82><82><9d>

And their new attacking game is, according to Hogmo, meant to be like <83><82><82><82><93>the way Manchester City attack, almost in a 2-2-4-2<83><82><82><82><9d>. He also wants Norway to be proactive, to dictate their games. It is an ambitious concept but with only one win in his first 10 games (2-1 in a friendly against Moldova) there is more than a hint of emperor<83><82><82><82><84>s new clothes about this new dawn.

It does, however, show that the FA finally accepts the need to move on from the outdated Olsen paradigm. Plus, the emergence of technically gifted players such as Mats Moller Daehli and the 15-year-old prodigy Martin Odegaard has fans dreaming of a time when Norway can be successful while playing a brand of football that is not wholly based on cynical exploitation.

Lars Sivertsen is a Norwegian football writer who works for Norway<83><82><82><82><84>s TV2, Josimar and The Blizzard among others

Per-Mathias Hogmo was hired as the manager and under him a new philosophy is slowly being implemented. The way we defend is a lot like Atltico Madrid, he explained in January, with 4-4-2 and an extreme movement of blocks. This demands a lot of us but this is what we want to do. And their new attacking game is, according to Hogmo, meant to be like the way Manchester City attack, almost in a 2-2-4-2. He also wants Norway to be proactive, to dictate their games. It is an ambitious concept but with only one win in his first 10 games (2-1 in a friendly against Moldova) there is more than a hint of emperors new clothes about this new dawn. It does, however, show that the FA finally accepts the need to move on from the outdated Olsen paradigm. Plus, the emergence of technically gifted players such as Mats Moller Daehli and the 15-year-old prodigy Martin Odegaard has fans dreaming of a time when Norway can be successful while playing a brand of football that is not wholly based on cynical exploitation. Lars Sivertsen is a Norwegian football writer who works for Norways TV2, Josimar and The Blizzard among others

webTitle: England could face Norway with record low attendance at new Wembley
trailText: The Football Association are expecting an attendance of between 35,000-40,000 spectators for Englandâs friendly with Norway, which would be a record low at the new Wembley
headline: England could face Norway with record low attendance at new Wembley
standfirst:
â¢ FA expect between 35,000 and 40,000 for friendly
â¢ Roy Hodgson could introduce uncapped players for England
â¢ Four new boys called up to England squad
â¢ England manager tells players to banish negativity
body:
A record low attendance for an England match at the new Wembley is expected for the friendly against Norway on Wednesday night, as Roy Hodgson<83><82><82><82><84>s side return to action for the first time since their disappointing World Cup campaign.

The Football Association believes between 35,000 and 40,000 spectators will attend, which would be a new low at the stadium since it was rebuilt in 2007. Club Wembley members will count towards the attendance, although the full 17,000 contingent may not watch a game that comes weeks after England crashed out at the World Cup group stage.

The FA hopes its estimation will be surpassed by late ticket purchases, yet the expectations are that Hodgson<83><82><82><82><84>s side are unlikely to receive the kind of support on offer before their campaign in Brazil.

The lowest attendance for an England match at Wembley since 2007 was the friendly against Sweden in November 2011, when 48,876 watched a first victory over the Scandinavian nation since 1968.

Before then, the last time fewer than 50,000 people watched England at Wembley was for the 2-0 win over the Czech Republic in November 1998, a friendly fixture attended by 38,535.

A half-empty Wembley will be a blow for Hodgson, who is hoping to start the post-World Cup era with a good performance that could provide an opportunity to hand first caps to a number of players.

England<83><82><82><82><84>s last game before Brazil at Wembley was watched by more than 80,000, but the atmosphere of cautious optimism for the friendly against Peru was punctured in South America by defeats by Italy and Uruguay that consigned them to an early World Cup exit.

England play in Switzerland in their first Euro 2016 qualifying match on Monday before their next competitive game at Wembley, against San Marino in October.

The Football Association believes between 35,000 and 40,000 spectators will attend, which would be a new low at the stadium since it was rebuilt in 2007. Club Wembley members will count towards the attendance, although the full 17,000 contingent may not watch a game that comes weeks after England crashed out at the World Cup group stage. The FA hopes its estimation will be surpassed by late ticket purchases, yet the expectations are that Hodgsons side are unlikely to receive the kind of support on offer before their campaign in Brazil. The lowest attendance for an England match at Wembley since 2007 was the friendly against Sweden in November 2011, when 48,876 watched a first victory over the Scandinavian nation since 1968. Before then, the last time fewer than 50,000 people watched England at Wembley was for the 2-0 win over the Czech Republic in November 1998, a friendly fixture attended by 38,535. A half-empty Wembley will be a blow for Hodgson, who is hoping to start the post-World Cup era with a good performance that could provide an opportunity to hand first caps to a number of players. Englands last game before Brazil at Wembley was watched by more than 80,000, but the atmosphere of cautious optimism for the friendly against Peru was punctured in South America by defeats by Italy and Uruguay that consigned them to an early World Cup exit. England play in Switzerland in their first Euro 2016 qualifying match on Monday before their next competitive game at Wembley, against San Marino in October.

webTitle: Wounded landscape: how Norway is remembering its 2011 Utya massacre
trailText: Cameron Robertson: Artist Jonas Dahlberg has been chosen to create three memorials, one of which cuts a 3.5m slit in the landscape, to remember the victims of Anders Behring Breivik
headline: Wounded landscape: how Norway is remembering its 2011 UtÃ¸ya massacre
standfirst: Artist Jonas Dahlberg has been chosen to create three memorials, one of which cuts a 3.5m slit in the landscape, to remember the victims of Anders Behring Breivik
body:
A Swedish artist has been selected to create official memorials at the sites of the 2011 Norwegian massacres carried out by right-wing extremist Anders Behring Breivik.

The competition, called Memorial Sites After 22 July, was won by Jonas Dahlberg, who will create three artworks at a cost of 27m Norwegian kroner (<83><80><9a><82>2.7m) to the government in Oslo.

The most striking memorial is called Memory Wound. The 43-year-old artist has sliced a three-and-a-half-metre-wide slit into the S<83><92><82>rbr<83><92><82>ten peninsula, which faces the island of Ut<83><92><82>ya where Breivik killed 69 people. It marks a "symbolic wound" in the landscape.

One hundred cubic metres of the stone cut from S<83><92><82>rbr<83><92><82>ten will be transferred to the governmental quarter in Oslo, where another memorial will mark the spot where a car bomb was detonated by Breivik that resulted in eight deaths.

A temporary pathway in the capital, between Grubbegata and Deichmanske library, will also be made by Dahlberg, who will later take trees from S<83><92><82>rbr<83><92><82>ten to create a permanent amphitheatre in the government quarter called Time and Movement.

Breivik, now serving a 21-year prison sentence, told an Oslo court in 2012 that his victims <83><82><82><82><80><9c> many of whom were teenagers attending the Labour party's annual summer camp <83><82><82><82><80><9c> were facilitating the "Islamisation of Norway".

The jury for the competition, who reached a unanimous decision, included representatives of the Labour party and victim support groups. Dahlberg beat 300 other entries, including former Turner prize winner Jeremy Deller. Two memorials will be unveiled on 22 July 2015 <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the fourth anniversary of the attacks <83><82><82><82><80><9c> with the amphitheatre to come at a later date.

"It is a big responsibility and in many ways the most important work I have done," Dahlberg told the Guardian. "I was already honoured to be considered when I was invited to be in the competition, so to have won now is a bit hard to grasp."

The Swedish artist, who lives and works in Stockholm, said he hoped the memorial would provide a state of reflection through its "poetic rupture". He said: "It should be difficult to see the inherent beauty of the setting, without also experiencing a sense of loss. It is this sense of loss that will physically activate the site."

The headland of the S<83><92><82>rbr<83><92><82>ten memorial will be engraved with names of all the victims; visitors will be able to read them but not reach to touch them. "People will find their own way through the landscape around the cut," said Dahlberg, "looking down at the channel and at the victims' names from high up, or looking out to Ut<83><92><82>ya, establishing their own private ways of seeing and remembering."

Mari Aaby West of the Norwegian Labour party youth league and John Hestnes, of the national support group for victims of the 22 July attacks, had passed on positive feedback from victims' families who had viewed the designs, said Dahlberg, who did not speak directly to the relatives.

A statement from the jury for Public Art Norway, which included West and Hestnes, said Dahlberg's idea to make a physical incision in the landscape stood like a "symbolic wound".

It said: "The void that is created evokes the sense of sudden loss combined with the long-term missing and remembrance of those who perished. The proposal is radical and brave, and evokes the tragic events in a physical and direct manner."

Designs for two memorials in the government quarter are not finalised, but Dahlberg explained his temporary pathway would lie beside an existing walkway, taking pedestrians off their usual path.

"The design physically relates to the interruption that occurred in the everyday life flow of Norwegian society," he said. "Yet it is indeed everyday life that must carry on."

Breivik received the maximum sentence available under Norwegian law. His prison term will be reviewed every two years after he completes a decade in jail.

webTitle: Norway to trial nasal spray antidote to heroin overdose
trailText: Country with western Europe's worst heroin overdose rate to trial Naloxone spray in Oslo and Bergen, its two most populous cities
headline: Norway to trial nasal spray antidote to heroin overdose
standfirst: Country with western Europe's worst heroin overdose rate to trial Naloxone spray in Oslo and Bergen, its two most populous cities
body:
Norway is poised to start trials of a nasal spray that reverses the effect of a heroin overdose, in a move that could encourage other countries to follow suit.

Despite its oil wealth, well-funded drug rehabilitation programmes and generous welfare safety net, Norway has western Europe's worst overdose rate. Campaigners have long been urging the government to approve the rollout of the nasal spray, which administers Naloxone to people who have taken an overdose, in effect acting as a kind of liquid defibrillator.

Now, regulatory approval permitting, the Norwegian trials will offer the kit in Norway's two most populous cities, Oslo and Bergen, later this year. Philipp Lobmaier, the doctor leading the trials, said that while Naloxone was no silver bullet, he was confident it would cut down the number of ambulance cases. "I hope we will soon be able to show fewer incidents of paramedics being called out for overdoses," he said.

Britain's Advisory Council on the Misuse of Drugs has been saying since 2012 that it would like Naloxone to be available to UK users without prescription. Addicts in Wales and Scotland are given injecting kits on prescription. The nasal spray is considered superior, however, as it is easier for the uninitiated to use and reduces the likelihood of needle pricks spreading hepatitis C or worse.

Since 2002, about 240 people have died each year in Norway from heroin overdoses, more than have died from traffic accidents.

Naloxone counteracts the effect of opioids on the central nervous system. The kits will be available from non-medical environments where users are more likely to feel safe, such as drop-in centres, hostels and Oslo's safe injecting room. Critically, according to Martin Blindheim, who is drawing up the national overdose strategy for the Norwegian health directorate, friends and families will also be able to obtain kits and be trained to use them. "The most important people will be the mothers," he said.

In Vestby, just south of Oslo, Wivian Koppang, whose 21-year-old daughter Madeleine died from an overdose three years ago, welcomed the Naloxone trial but said the government was still dragging its feet on other solutions. "It must do more to save our children," she said. Calls from treatment centres and hospitals in Bergen to allow doctors to prescribe heroin to the most at-risk cases have been flatly rejected. There is also no appetite at national level to have safe injecting rooms in cities outside Oslo.

Last year, Oslo's injecting centre was renovated to allow users to smoke the drug there as well. But since the new Conservative-led government came into office in October the change in regulations to allow the new smoking booths to be used has been kicked into the long grass.

In a still conservative country, harm reduction strategies are seen by many as inevitable steps towards a fully fledged libertarian drug policy. Like preaching celibacy to tackle teenage pregnancy, abstinence and rehabilitation are regarded as the key. "In the long term we all want rehabilitation," said Blindheim. "But dead people cannot be rehabilitated."

webTitle: Just add SALT: Norways new Arctic arts and music festival
trailText: At a year-long arts festival in northern Norway, Will Coldwell finds that itâs nature that remains the headline act
headline: Just add SALT: Norwayâs new Arctic arts and music festival
standfirst:
At a year-long arts festival in northern Norway, Will Coldwell finds that itâs nature that remains the headline act
â¢ See more stunning pictures of the festival
body:
It has been some hours since sunset on the island of Sandhorn<83><92><82>ya, just inside the Arctic Circle, and I<83><82><82><82><84>m standing on the beach with a near-naked Norwegian, debating the temperature of the water I<83><82><82><82><84>ve just jumped into. <83><82><82><82><93>I was told it was 14C,<83><82><82><82><9d> I say. <83><82><82><82><93>Well, a friend told me it was just nine,<83><82><82><82><9d> he replies, adjusting his underwear. Shivering, we settle for 11 <83><82><82><82><80><9c> about average for an icy plunge pool <83><82><82><82><80><9c> before sprinting back to the sauna as my feet go numb in the sand.

It<83><82><82><82><84>s the opening weekend of SALT, a year-long arts festival in remote northern Norway. Consisting of a series of striking architectural structures (including the world<83><82><82><82><84>s largest sauna, naturally), a site-specific art installation and a programme of contemporary music, the project is almost as dramatic as the landscape that surrounds it.

<83><82><82><82><93>We travelled for almost two years around the north of Norway looking for the right place for the festival,<83><82><82><82><9d> co-founder Helga-Marie Nordby tells me. <83><82><82><82><93>But it wasn<83><82><82><82><84>t until we came here ...<83><82><82><82><9d> She pauses. <83><82><82><82><93>Well ... it<83><82><82><82><84>s special.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Although the island can be reached by a long drive over bridges, pine forests and fjords, you get a better sense of its remoteness and ruggedness if you arrive by boat from Bod<83><92><82>, capital of Nordland county. As you turn into the bay, the festival site comes into view: three giant triangular prisms made of wood stand on the clean, white sand beneath a looming cliff.

<83><82><82><82><93>You see contemporary art all over the world, but this kind of scenery, not so often,<83><82><82><82><9d> says Nordby, who wants the festival to create an awareness of the region<83><82><82><82><84>s history, present and future. <83><82><82><82><93>If you bring something humanmade into that scenery, it<83><82><82><82><84>s not just about nature, but about our role in that landscape.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Nordby conceived the idea for SALT, which she founded along with cultural entrepreneur Erlend Mog<83><92><82>rd-Larsen, in 2010 while the pair were curating the Lofoten International Art Festival. In many ways SALT functions more as a venue than a festival. On weekends throughout the year, monthly and bi-monthly events will take place, ranging from classical concerts and lectures to club nights and theatre performances. The sauna, bar and restaurant will be open throughout, and visitors can come for the day from the mainland, rent a cabin on the beach, or camp for free.

After its stint in Norway, SALT will move on to Greenland, Iceland, Scotland and Alaska, where location-specific installations will be commissioned.

The <83><82><82><82><93>pyramids<83><82><82><82><9d> on Sandhorn<83><92><82>ya are designed by Finnish architect Sami Rintala, based on the traditional fish-drying racks of the region. The largest is currently home to an installation by Chinese artist Yang Fudong, who has produced a series of haunting films that show local dancers drifting like spirits around the island. Yang<83><82><82><82><84>s work <83><82><82><82><80><9c> if it survives the winter storms <83><82><82><82><80><9c> will stay on the site for six months, and after that will be replaced by a new commission.

Sitting cross-legged, drawing spirals in the sand with his finger, Yang, who has spent a month living and working on the island, explains through an interpreter that the instant he landed there all his plans for the installation changed. <83><82><82><82><93>I had imagined true peace in the past,<83><82><82><82><9d> he says. <83><82><82><82><93>But when I moved on to the island, it was the first time I had experienced it in reality.<83><82><82><82><9d>

Yang<83><82><82><82><84>s sentiments seem to be unanimously shared by all the visitors I speak to, who are scattered around the beach, investigating the structures, watching Yang<83><82><82><82><84>s films, or lying in the sand. Children are climbing up the wooden frames to get a better view of the performances, and smoke drifts out of the top of the sauna, which is warming up for the evening.

Behind the stage two young girls in Scandi jumpers are selling torrfisk <83><82><82><82><80><9c> dried cod <83><82><82><82><80><9c> from a stand made from old wood with a hand-drawn sign. The wizened fish is hammered with a mallet to soften it so you can pull it off in strips to eat. I buy some (it tastes like fishy polystyrene, but is pretty satisfying to gnaw on) and walk over to the concert venue, where a violist and cellist from the Arctic Philharmonic Orchestra are creating conceptual classical sound waves with their bows.

Other acts in the largely alternative line up that weekend included Lonnie Holley, an African-American artist who grew up in poverty in Birmingham, Alabama in the 1950s <83><82><82><82><80><9c> his found-object sculptures and warbling atmospheric blues have won him worldwide acclaim <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and Biosphere, a Norwegian electronic musician known for his Arctic-inspired ambient techno.

While admiring the concert venue, I bump into one of its builders, Tomas. <83><82><82><82><93>We built that in 19 hours,<83><82><82><82><9d> he says proudly, clenching his biceps through his thermal jacket. <83><82><82><82><93>Now feel this.<83><82><82><82><9d>

When night falls, the festival takes on even more Norwegian earthiness. There<83><82><82><82><84>s a bonfire, but, having come slightly underprepared for the cold that evening, I head to the <83><82><82><82><93>amphisauna<83><82><82><82><9d> to warm up properly. I sip on a warm beer (with a polar bear on the can) in the prism-like oven, which can fit up to 120 people and has a huge triangular window at the front so you can look out over the beach. With a bar at the back and deep house music pumping, it feels more like a club than a sauna, the only difference being that rather than cooling off in the smoking area, people dash into the sea instead.

As the weekend draws to a close those still on the island are treated to a sight that outdoes both the art and the landscape. In the early hours, during the short period when the horizon is in total darkness, an unusually strong display of northern lights <83><82><82><82><80><9c> surprising even the locals <83><82><82><82><80><9c> dances in the sky.

Eventually I retire for the night. I<83><82><82><82><84>m staying in a mobile home called a njalla, designed by artist and architect Joar Nango, which sits on wooden skis that allow you to drag it to a spot of your choosing. Inside is a woodburning stove and a bed consisting of reindeer pelt on a surprisingly comfortable layer of dry branches. I look up through its glass ceiling, drifting off as the northern lights fade into darkness. Barely two hours later, the sun rises.


<83><82><82><82> The trip was provided by SALT, which is at Sandhorn<83><92><82>ya until 6 September 2015. Njalla cabins sleep up to four and cost <83><80><9a><82>125 a night for one person, plus <83><80><9a><82>20 for each extra person. Event tickets from <83><80><9a><82>15. A day package with transfers from Bod<83><92><82>, guided tour, dinner and sauna costs <83><80><9a><82>126pp. Book at salted.no. Norwegian Airlines (norwegian.com) flies to Oslo from Gatwick and Manchester from <83><80><9a><82>70 return, and from Oslo to Bod<83><92><82> from <83><80><9a><82>145 return. Singles Bod<83><92><82> to Sandhorn<83><92><82>ya costs <83><80><9a><82>19.50 ferry, <83><80><9a><82>13 bus

While admiring the concert venue, I bump into one of its builders, Tomas. We built that in 19 hours, he says proudly, clenching his biceps through his thermal jacket. Now feel this. When night falls, the festival takes on even more Norwegian earthiness. Theres a bonfire, but, having come slightly underprepared for the cold that evening, I head to the amphisauna to warm up properly. I sip on a warm beer (with a polar bear on the can) in the prism-like oven, which can fit up to 120 people and has a huge triangular window at the front so you can look out over the beach. With a bar at the back and deep house music pumping, it feels more like a club than a sauna, the only difference being that rather than cooling off in the smoking area, people dash into the sea instead. As the weekend draws to a close those still on the island are treated to a sight that outdoes both the art and the landscape. In the early hours, during the short period when the horizon is in total darkness, an unusually strong display of northern lights  surprising even the locals  dances in the sky. Eventually I retire for the night. Im staying in a mobile home called a njalla, designed by artist and architect Joar Nango, which sits on wooden skis that allow you to drag it to a spot of your choosing. Inside is a woodburning stove and a bed consisting of reindeer pelt on a surprisingly comfortable layer of dry branches. I look up through its glass ceiling, drifting off as the northern lights fade into darkness. Barely two hours later, the sun rises.   The trip was provided by SALT, which is at Sandhornya until 6 September 2015. Njalla cabins sleep up to four and cost 125 a night for one person, plus 20 for each extra person. Event tickets from 15. A day package with transfers from Bod, guided tour, dinner and sauna costs 126pp. Book at salted.no. Norwegian Airlines (norwegian.com) flies to Oslo from Gatwick and Manchester from 70 return, and from Oslo to Bod from 145 return. Singles Bod to Sandhornya costs 19.50 ferry, 13 bus

webTitle: Norway's sovereign wealth fund snaps up London landmarks
trailText: Savile Row and Cork Street, a 4-acre part of the Pollen Estate, bought by Norges Bank Investment Management for Â£343m
headline: Norway's sovereign wealth fund snaps up London landmarks
standfirst: Savile Row and Cork Street, a 4-acre part of the Pollen Estate, bought by Norges Bank Investment Management for Â£343m
body:
Two of London's most famous streets are now part-owned by Norway's sovereign wealth fund after it paid <83><80><9a><82>343m to snap up a share in an estate covering four acres of the capital's West End.

Savile Row, the Mayfair street renowned for its men's tailors and for hosting the Beatles' final live performance at the former Apple offices, and the gallery-studded Cork Street are part of the Pollen Estate in which Norges Bank Investment Management (NBIM) has bought a 57.8% stake. The fund, which is the world's biggest sovereign wealth fund and invests government money from the oil industry, already has investments in a neighbouring Regent Street portfolio.

The share in the Pollen Estate was bought from the Church Commissioners for England, which also sold a 6.4% share to the Crown Estate, raising a total of <83><80><9a><82>381m, making it the largest ever property sale by the group. It said more than 990 parties had received the sale brochure and 86 interested parties including banks, pension funds and charitable foundations had toured the estate.

"As we expected, the depth and calibre of international interest in the estate was impressive, with a range of buyers showing a strong interest in the commissioners' majority holding," said Joseph Cannon, chief surveyor of the Church Commissioners for England. "We are very pleased to have sold to Norges Bank Investment Management and the Crown Estate who see the long-term value of the estate."

NBIM's investment follows a similar venture into prime London real estate in 2010. It owns 25% of the Regent Street portfolio, with the Crown Estate owning the majority share.

The Pollen Estate dates back to 1622 when William Maddox bought 35 acres of undeveloped land for <83><80><9a><82>1,450. Since then it has been passed down through the Pollen family and shrunk, so that it is now made up of 43 retail and office buildings between Regent Street and Bond Street. The area includes some of London's most upmarket shopping streets,

David Shaw, head of the Regent Street Portfolio said: "Savile Row and Cork Street have international reputations for their focus on tailoring and art galleries respectively and the success of these two streets is crucial to the ongoing success of London's West End as an international destination."

"As we expected, the depth and calibre of international interest in the estate was impressive, with a range of buyers showing a strong interest in the commissioners' majority holding," said Joseph Cannon, chief surveyor of the Church Commissioners for England. The area includes some of London's most upmarket shopping streets, David Shaw, head of the Regent Street Portfolio said: "Savile Row and Cork Street have international reputations for their focus on tailoring and art galleries respectively and the success of these two streets is crucial to the ongoing success of London's West End as an international destination."

webTitle: The Familiar - Dark Eyes: New music from Norway
trailText: Seductive synth-pop made by a duo who 'barely know each other'
headline: The Familiar - Dark Eyes: New music from Norway
standfirst: From The Line of Best Fit, one of our team of experts bringing you the best new music from around the world: Seductive synth-pop made by a duo who 'barely know each other'
body:
Brooklyn-via-Troms<83><92><82> pair Ruthy Mirsky and Mads Martinsen wowed us with their debut effort as The Familiar, back in November and now, with the New Year in full swing, have returned with a video to accompany its seductive tones.

Filmed in Brooklyn by the Norwegian filmmaker Carl Christian Lein St<83><92><82>rmer, the video for Dark Eyes follows Ruth through warm, sepia landscapes, almost as if she is being compelled by the song's delicate synth fluctuations and rolling rhythms.

Very little is known about the pair but they did send us some words about how The Familiar were born: "Ruth and Mads have never worked on music in the same room and hardly know each other. In fact, they have only met a handful of times. Mads lives in Troms<83><92><82>, Norway above the Arctic Circle and Ruth is a Norwegian-American who lives in Brooklyn <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but in spite of all those miles between them, something magical happened when they began sending tracks back and forth over e-mail, and ultimately The Familiar was born.<83><82><82><82><9d>

<83><82><82><82> More from The Line of Best Fit
text: Brooklyn-via-Troms pair Ruthy Mirsky and Mads Martinsen wowed us with their debut effort as The Familiar,back in November and now, with the New Year in full swing, have returned with a video to accompany its seductive tones. Filmed in Brooklyn by the Norwegian filmmaker Carl Christian Lein Strmer, the video for Dark Eyes follows Ruth through warm, sepia landscapes, almost as if she is being compelled by the song's delicate synth fluctuations and rolling rhythms. Very little is known about the pair but they did send us some words about how The Familiar were born: "Ruth and Mads have never worked on music in the same room and hardly know each other. In fact, they have only met a handful of times. Mads lives in Troms, Norway above the Arctic Circle and Ruth is a Norwegian-American who lives in Brooklyn  but in spite of all those miles between them, something magical happened when they began sending tracks back and forth over e-mail, and ultimately The Familiar was born. More from The Line of Best Fit

webTitle: Norway criticised over snub to Dalai Lama during Nobel committee visit
trailText: No representatives of Norwegian government will meet spiritual leader when he visits after row with China over Nobel prize
headline: Norway criticised over snub to Dalai Lama during Nobel committee visit
standfirst: No representatives of Norwegian government will meet spiritual leader when he visits after row with China over Nobel prize
body:
The Norwegian government is facing increasing pressure over its decision to snub the Dalai Lama when he arrives in the country on Wednesday, despite the fact that he has been invited by the Nobel committee to mark the 25th anniversary of his Nobel peace prize.

When the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader arrives in Norway on a three-day visit, he will not meet any representatives of the Norwegian conservative-led coalition government. The decision stems from the repercussions of the 2010 peace prize awarded to the Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo, which angered the Chinese government to such an extent that it imposed an unofficial partial trade embargo on Norwegian salmon and froze trade talks.

In 2010 Norway enjoyed almost a monopoly on salmon exports to China, with a market share of 92% worth over 450m Norwegian kroner (<83><80><9a><82>45m) a year. Over the following three years this fell to 29%.

"It's a big challenge doing business here after the shutdown from the Chinese authorities," said Sigmund Bj<83><92><82>rgo, director of the Norwegian Seafood Council in China. "The Chinese population is expected to increase their salmon consumption by 30% per year. Sashimi is a growing trend which is becoming increasingly fashionable, and salmon is an important part of that. Though not the Norwegian kind."

The foreign minister, B<83><92><82>rge Brende, announced last month that no representatives of the Norwegian authorities would officially meet the Dalai Lama during his visit, citing "the extraordinary situation where there is no real political contact between Norway and China".

Critics have accused the government of cowardice in the face of the seeming benefits of trade with China.

On Monday, the prime minister, Erna Solberg, defended her position, arguing that it was more important to keep the door open for dialogue with China. "It has been a difficult situation that we have not been able to work internationally with China for four years. Before 2010 we had a running dialogue with China about human rights issues. Norwegian experts were helping the Chinese to develop a better justice system. After 2010 we haven't been able to do this," she said.

Audun Lysbakken, the leader of the Socialist Left party, said: "We can't be dictated to by China in the sense of exchanging human rights for salmon. I am strongly in favour of improving relations with China, but this has to be founded on mutual respect."

An unofficial reception in a meeting room at the parliament on Friday is expected to be standing room only.

The decision stems from the repercussions of the 2010 peace prize awarded to the Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo, which angered the Chinese government to such an extent that it imposed an unofficial partial trade embargo on Norwegian salmon and froze trade talks. In 2010 Norway enjoyed almost a monopoly on salmon exports to China, with a market share of 92% worth over 450m Norwegian kroner (45m) a year. Over the following three years this fell to 29%. "It's a big challenge doing business here after the shutdown from the Chinese authorities," said Sigmund Bjrgo, director of the Norwegian Seafood Council in China. "The Chinese population is expected to increase their salmon consumption by 30% per year. Sashimi is a growing trend which is becoming increasingly fashionable, and salmon is an important part of that. Though not the Norwegian kind." The foreign minister, Brge Brende, announced last month that no representatives of the Norwegian authorities would officially meet the Dalai Lama during his visit, citing "the extraordinary situation where there is no real political contact between Norway and China". Norwegian experts were helping the Chinese to develop a better justice system. After 2010 we haven't been able to do this," she said. Audun Lysbakken, the leader of the Socialist Left party, said: "We can't be dictated to by China in the sense of exchanging human rights for salmon. I am strongly in favour of improving relations with China, but this has to be founded on mutual respect." An unofficial reception in a meeting room at the parliament on Friday is expected to be standing room only.

webTitle: Travel news roundup: Norway's beach festival, kids' bike shares in Paris
trailText: Plus Croatia's beach scene, summers in Latvia, an Antarctic safari and unsinkable sunglasses
headline: Travel news roundup: Norway's beach festival, kids' bike shares in Paris
standfirst: Plus Croatia's beach scene, summers in Latvia, an Antarctic safari and unsinkable sunglasses
body:
Escapism

Art installations, fireside storytelling and live music sessions, and a bar and restaurant serving locally caught and foraged food are all part of SALT, a year-long beach festival on the Arctic island of Sandhorn<83><92><82>ya, near Bod<83><92><82> in northern Norway. You can visit on a day trip from Bod<83><92><82> or stay in a wooden beach lodge.
<83><82><82><82> 28 August 2014-31 September 2015, then touring other Nordic countries, salted.no

What's new?

Family fun
Paris has launched the world's first children's bike share scheme <83><82><82><82><80><9c> think Boris bikes for kids. There are four models, including no-pedal balance bikes for tinies, and bigger ones with and without stabilisers, available at green and pedestrianised locations all around Paris. Fingers crossed that other cities follow suit.
<83><82><82><82> From <83><82><80><9a><82>4 an hour, <83><82><80><9a><82>7 a half-day and <83><82><80><9a><82>10 a day, blog.velib.paris.fr

Food and drink
The latest addition to up-and-coming Lone Bay, a gorgeous beach just south of Rovinj, in Croatia, is a new beach club, Mulini Beach, offering Croatian cuisine, cocktails and live music. This redesigned strip of coastline has a new promenade, snack bars and a couple of boutique hotels.
<83><82><82><82> montemulinihotel.com

Destination
Latvia may not be the first country that springs to mind when you're planning a family holiday, but a new trip from Baltic Holidays ticks all the right boxes: sandy beaches; fun activities, such as a barefoot woodland safari; warm dry summers; and reasonable prices. You even get to spend a night in a pod on the beach.
<83><82><82><82> From <83><80><9a><82>488pp, including flights, accommodation, car hire and activities, balticholidays.com

How much?!

A collection of immersive safaris allows you to get much closer to the animals, including swimming with blue whales in Sri Lanka and floating among grizzlies on the salmon run in Alaska. But these once-in-a-lifetime experiences don't come cheap <83><82><82><82>
<83><82><82><82> From <83><80><9a><82>1,450 for a week's ocean safari in South Africa to <83><80><9a><82>40,975 for a nine-day Antarctica safari, naturalworldsafaris.com

Travel trash

Strange but true: sunglasses don't float. Or at least they didn't, until one company injected theirs with a special formula to stop them sinking. They look a lot more stylish than goggles, too.
<83><82><82><82> From <83><80><9a><82>135, dragonalliance.com

Cheap date

Still think hostels mean sweaty dorm rooms in dreary buildings? Think again: Hostelling International's network includes treehouses in Turkey, converted railway carriages in New Zealand, a converted jumbo jet in Sweden and a lighthouse in Canada.
<83><82><82><82> From <83><80><9a><82>10 a night, blog.hihostels.com

Holiday costs

What works out cheaper overall, all-inclusive or B&B? According to a survey by the Post Office, B&B is your best bet (everywhere but Mallorca, weirdly), thanks to the extras people splash out on during so-called all-inclusive trips. For example, a B&B family holiday to the Algarve costs on average <83><80><9a><82>342 less than the all-in equivalent.
<83><82><82><82> Details at media.postoffice.co.uk

Travel trend

Apparently we are a lot more cultured on holiday than at home. According to a survey by Opinion Matters, city-breakers cram more than a third of their annual "culture intake" <83><82><82><82><80><9c> galleries, museums, festivals, events, etc <83><82><82><82><80><9c> into a single weekend away.

webTitle: Norway finds a new way with music at the European Press Prize
trailText: Peter Preston: It may not have won â but local daily Namdalsavisa's triumphant initiative for local bands was an inspiration in its own way
headline: Norway finds a new way with music at the European Press Prize
standfirst: It may not have won â but local daily Namdalsavisa's triumphant initiative for local bands was an inspiration in its own way
body:
The garlands, of course, go to the victors: from Ukraine, Croatia, Turkey and Denmark inter alia, after two full years of the European Press Prize. But often the entries that don't quite win have their own attraction. Take "Bandwagon", from a little local daily, Namdalsavisa, in Namsos, an equally small Norwegian town.

Two years ago they gave young local musicians and songwriters a chance to upload their music via new profile pages on the paper's website. Then <83><82><82><82><80><9c> feeling enthusiasm mount <83><82><82><82><80><9c> they persuaded 26 other local papers to join in a bigger competition. Today more then 70 papers are on board and the Bandwagon rolls on, mixing mobile, tablet and print <83><82><82><82><80><9c> an X Factor in your home town. That's local branding that helps define papers for a new audience. It may not be journalism, but it puts journalism on fresh agendas; and it clearly works, so long as the papers, too, sharpen up their generational act.

Namdalsavisa's wheeze doesn't push innovation too far. It's simple, modest, human. Not a winner from the creative edge, maybe. Not a notion that will set Silicon Valley aflame. But it could surely work just as well in Nuneaton as Namsos. And hey! What's not to like?
