'It's impossible to effectively prevent disease transmission,' she says. 'Not every virus, bacteria or parasite can be avoided by vaccinations, nor are they only introduced by people  but by clothes, belongings, equipment and food too.' Moreover, it is widely accepted that IPVI exist in the Napo-Tigre region and Repsol's apparent doubt is contradicted by reports by regional indigenous organization ORPIO  the successor to ORAI  and national indigenous organization AIDESEP, which include testimonies from local people about sightings and physical proof such as gardens, meat remains, shelters, paths, footprints and crossed spears.  The GPFG is considered by some to be the world's largest sovereign wealth fund and it was recently reported to have passed 5,000 billion Norwegian kroner, or approximately US$818 billion. It prides itself on its ethical guidelines and responsible investment, particularly its 'exclusion mechanism', which blacklists companies which commit, among other things, 'severe environmental damage' and 'serious or systematic human rights violations.' To date, 60 companies are currently excluded from the GPFG, including Lockheed Martin Corp, Boeing Co, British American Tobacco Plc, Wal-Mart Stores Inc, Rio Tinto Ltd and Vedanta Resources Plc.  Norway's Ministry of Finance declined to comment.

webTitle: Germany win Euro 2013 final against Norway - as it happened
trailText: Nadine Angerer saved two Norway penalties as Germany won the tournament thanks to Anja Mittag's second-half goal
headline: Germany win Euro 2013 final against Norway - as it happened
standfirst: Nadine Angerer saved two Norway penalties as Germany won the tournament thanks to Anja Mittag's second-half goal
body:
5.08pm BST

So an exceptional tournament comes to an end with a final worthy of it, and a goalkeeping performance for the ages. This German side might not be quite as good as previous incarnations, and the rest are getting closer, but they're still deserving winners. Otherwise, that's us - thanks for your company.

5.05pm BST

Interesting lift - almost like a golf swing. There follows ticker-tape, to make sure no one can see properly.

5.03pm BST

The players bounce as we wait for Angerer, who'll lift the trophy. I'm fairly sure she won't drop it.

5.03pm BST

And up go Germany, led by Silvia Neid. This is her eighth European Championship win as player, assistant coach and coach.

5.01pm BST

Norway ascend the stairs and accept their medals from Michel Platini, who is swept, tanned and rotund. There is a man whose job it is to pick them up and pass them to him.

4.58pm BST

I'd take a hug from Silvia Neid.

4.56pm BST

The Germans are prancing around. There is a laudable lack of indulgent crying from either side.

4.55pm BST

There can't have been many better goalkeeping displays than that of Nadine Angerer. Two penalty saves, absurd - but even aside from that (not remotely aside from that), she was confident, composed, and most significantly of all, decisive.

4.53pm BST

6 [SIX] IN A ROW! GERMANY ARE EUROPEAN CHAMPIONS!

That is just thoroughly ridiculous.

4.52pm BST

90+4 min Germany keep the ball well, but Norway are chasing the game like a team who don't know how to chase games - they're just not playing with the urgency you need. The German players on the touchline are readying their celebrations...

4.51pm BST

90+2 min Since going behind, Norway haven't quite managed to muster momentum, Germany doing well to occupy their defenders with serious attacks not just aimed at wasting time.

4.49pm BST

90+1 min Still Norway play their football, but are now at the point where it makes more sense to stick as many players as possible into the box.

4.48pm BST

90 min There shall be four additional minutes.

4.48pm BST

89 min Kaurin wriggles past a challenge on the right and finds Hansen, who's been quiet this half. She jiggles some space, again waving her right foot over the ball, then crosses low, only to see it blocked behind for a corner that comes to nothing.

4.46pm BST

87 min Brilliant defending from Krahn, levering Hergerberg away from the ball after Mjelde arced over a cross from the right. Germany then do well to smuggle the ball downfield, Mittag larruping a shot over the bar from 20 yards.

4.44pm BST

86 min After threatening an equaliser when Thorsnes came on, Norway have struggled to create much in the last few minutes, Germany a little less excited in possession. They actually look the likelier scorers now.

4.43pm BST

84 min Final change for Norway, Kaurin replacing Christensen.

4.42pm BST

82 min That so almost morphed into that. Germany released Maier down the right, and she cut back a cross, Akerhaugen miscalculating how close she needed to be to Kessler. But measuring a finish into the far corner, her connection was slightly awry, the ball skipping into the base of the far post and away.

Updated at 4.43pm BST

4.40pm BST

81 min Germany looked very nervous when hanging on against Sweden in the semi-final - and today, even Silvia Neid is pacing on the touchline with brooding intensity.

4.38pm BST

78 min Considering the appalling circumstances they've inflicted upon themselves, Norway have shown exceptional composure. It would be very easy, and justifiable, for them to quit existing, but there's been no panic, and they're still playing sensible, considered stuff, getting the ball forward quickly, but passing it inteligently once it gets there.

4.35pm BST

78 min There are only 12 minutes remaining. For shame.

4.35pm BST

77 min "Re: your question about missing two penalties in a final," says Willem Cleven. "Not a final, but a European Cup semi: Holland v Italy, 2000. We missed two penalties during the game before shanking another three during the resulting shootout. De Boer missed two, and Stam famously blasted one into the rafters. Terrible stuff." 

And yet, so very, beautifully Dutch. Winning is beneath them.

4.34pm BST

75 min Change apiece. Stensland off, Isaksen off for Norway, Laudehr off, Schmidt off for Germany - very slowly.

4.32pm BST

72 min Dearie, dearie Norway. This is brilliant route-one football, a perfect long ball from Ronning finding Thorsnes between back-four and keeper. With Angerer charging towards her like billy-o, she arrives first and chucks a foot at it post-bounce - it's a goal! No it's not! Somehow, despite every appearance to the contrary, the ball skips wide of the right-hand post. Again, that's great keeping - had Angerer been any slower, Thorsnes would've had time to pick her spot. Like taking a penalty.

Updated at 4.33pm BST

4.29pm BST

71 min A moment of calm.

4.28pm BST

69 min Marozsan invents some space, left of centre and 25 yards from goal. Immediately, she looks up and shoots, catching it beautifully with her laces, and the ball is not far wide - taken there only by an inadvertent deflection.

4.26pm BST

68 min Change for Norway, Thorsnes replacing Gulbrandsen. She looks a little peaky, it's fair to say.

4.25pm BST

67 min What a half this has been so far. When did a team last miss two penalties in a final?

4.24pm BST

65 min Norway think they've scored! They've not scored! They turn the German left flank - they've been threatening down that side all game - and Mjelde skips clear, crossing low. The ball is turned in almost from under the bar - but Hergerberg had pulled offside, Sian Massey noticing and flagging immediately. Basically, England are champions.

Updated at 4.25pm BST

4.21pm BST

First things first. Norway broke down their right, and Hansen attacked the space between Cramer and Marozsan, inhaling deeply and bursting between them on the corner of the box. Between the two of them, they sent her sprawling, and this time Gulbrandsen stepped up. Again, the shot was firm and central, a little higher this time, and again, Angerer moved to her left, this time thrusting up an arm to thump the ball away. What a thoroughly remarkable keeper she is.

Updated at 4.57pm BST

4.18pm BST

ANGERER SAVES AGAIN! WHAT A SAVE!

....

4.18pm BST

PENALTY TO NORWAY!

....

4.18pm BST

57 min Off the line! Germany win a corner on the right, swung out to the middle of the box. For reasons known best to themselves, no one in the Norwegian defence felt that marking Da Mbabi was an activity worth of their pursuit, and she stepped back and headed firmly towards goal, Stensland deflecting it over the bar.

And the second corner was hit almost identically, Da Mbabi again making it her business to pick up the ball first, this time shooting, only for Akerhaugen to deflect it over the top.

4.14pm BST

54 min Here's an MBM rarity - a real, live person, at the game. Here's Benj Gerdes: "My Swedish wife and I are at the match. It appears a lot of Swedes have bought Norwegian flags and jerseys in the past four days as I thought I was sitting in the middle of a bunch of Norwegian fans until the Swedish team was brought out at half-time to do a thank you lap, prompting the strange spectacle of a bunch of Swedes wanting to cheer for their team but having nothing but big Norwegian flags to wave..."

It was a little odd, that lap of honour, all a bit John Terry. You want to run round waving at the crowd in the final, win it.

4.11pm BST

52 min Norway need to be careful here, because Germany are on it. Again, they find space down the left, Laudehr the runner this time - but she's strayed marginally offside.

4.09pm BST

What a goal this is, and what a change that was. Germany break down the left, three sharp passes finding Marozsan on the touchline and allowing Laudehr to send Da Mbabi galloping away, the various defenders chugging along behind with no hope of stopping her. Looking up, she sees someone in the middle, squaring when she might have shot, and Mittag allows the ball across her body and across the inside of her foot, sending it spinning high past Hjelmseth.

Updated at 5.00pm BST

4.07pm BST

GOAL! Germany 1-0 Norway (Mittag, 48)

...

4.07pm BST

47 min Norway keep up the pressure, forcing a corner, which Laudehr heads behind at the near post with her eyes closed. But it was a useful intervention, because there was a collection of her pals waiting to head home. The following corner came to nothing.

4.05pm BST

47 min Hansen finds Dekkerhus with a short pass and scurries off into the box, the clipped return finding her and sitting up. She slams a shot goalwards, but can't quite keep it down.

4.03pm BST

46 min And off we pootle.

4.03pm BST

German substitution: Mittag replaces Lotzen.

4.00pm BST

Yes, hard drinking, good po-lice but with a liberal interpretation of the legalities of procedure.

3.53pm BST

Not a bad half of football that, though Germany need to locate a little more gumption. When they force the play, they look likely to score - the Norway defence is really struggling with the movement of Marozsan and Da Mbabi. But Norway are equally dangerous when they can find space around the box, and more surprisingly, are holding their own in midfield. The second half ought to be better and oughtn't to be goalless.

3.49pm BST

HALF-TIME: GERMANY 0-0 NORWAY

...

3.49pm BST

45+1 min Lovely from Germany, Marozsan making a smart run in behind the Norway defence, and spinning to receive a pass on the left of the box. She immediately lays back for the onrushing Da Mbabi, who drills an immediate shot with her laces, but it's straight at Hjelmseth.

3.46pm BST

45 min There shall be a single, sole, solitary additional minute.

3.46pm BST

44 min A long, diagonal pass finds Hansen in the inside-right position, and she feints inside and out to fashion a shooting opportunity. But then she callously ruins literally everything by dragging a shot wide of the near post.

Updated at 3.46pm BST

3.44pm BST

42 min Germany have upped their work-rate in the last few minutes, and win the ball back high up the pitch. Kessler sees a bit of space ahead of her, so advances, before welting a shot well over the bar from outside the box.

3.41pm BST

40 min Silvia Neid, the Germany coach, is becoming angry - she's on the touchline glowering for quite some time now. Her players are getting told about themselves at half-time, you'd expect.

Updated at 3.42pm BST

3.40pm BST

38 min Marozsan, who's been quiet, gallops away down the right and espies Da Mbabi, loitering in the box. She crosses low, but Da Mbabi is crowded out - Germany coiuld do with sending more players in the box.

3.37pm BST

35 min What a curious half this has been so far, superiority switching almost every five minutes. It's Norway who're in charge at the moment, so by the time I've finished typing, it'll probably be Germany back on top.

3.36pm BST

32 min Despite the miss, Norway are uncowed, and almost immediately supply the best passage of play so far. Hegerberg takes possession outside the box, and cleverly waves her foot over the ball to buy herself some time, waiting for Stensland to accelerate into the box before finding her with a perfect slide-rule pass. She zips past Basrtusiak, taking her through on goal, but again, Angerer is alert, dashing out to smother at her feet. Handy behaviour all round.

3.32pm BST

ANGERER SAVES!

And what a save! Ronning's kick is hammered down the middle, and she begins moving to her left, then flings up a knee and prangs it away. That's a brilliant piece of improvisation.

3.30pm BST

After a free-kick isn't properly clearedm Dekkerhus barges into the box on the right, and Da Mbabi comes into tackle. There's a minor fusion of ankles, then a major jumping onto the grass a stride later, and the ref points to the spot. There is anger - lots of it.

Updated at 3.50pm BST

3.29pm BST

PENALTY TO NORWAY!

....

3.28pm BST

27 min We've seen very little of Solveig Gulbrandsen so far - Norway will be hoping to address this - and she's fouled by Kessler. The free-kick comes to nothing.

3.27pm BST

26 min Minor heat experienced by Nadine Angerer, after the ref wrongly awards Norway a corner. For this she is allocated a ticking-off, then comes to punch the corner, ends up on the ground, and wins a free-kick. All's well that ends well.

3.26pm BST

24 min It's been a good few minutes for Germany, who are controlling the midfield now, playing from the back. Norway are trying to get the ball into the German half more quickly, and then dealing with it from there.

3.23pm BST

21 min Da Mbabi could score! Da Mbabi doesn't score! But this is a really good effort, peeling away towards the near post and reaching Laudehr's corner first, introducing brow to ball and heading only just wide.

3.22pm BST

20 min Da Mbabi should score! Da Mbabi doesn't score. A long, raking ball finds Kessler, pulling away from her marker and inside the box on the left. With no one remotely concerned, she knocked down superbly for the advancing Da Mbabi, who couldn't quite get her knee over the ball, and skelped over the top.

3.19pm BST

17 min Caroline Hansen is finding her way into the game now, diddling her man and putting the ball into space, then nutmegging Krahn. She couldn't convert her skill into opportunity, but Germany will be concerned at the space she found.

3.18pm BST

16 min "Afternoon Daniel," says Simon McMahon. "It's a wonder that the BBC don't have John Inverdale and Colin Murray on commentary." I'm hoping for a feature at half-time.

3.16pm BST

14 min Another good situation for Norway, Hansen sending Mjelde away down the right. Shooting early and low, from just outside the box, Angerer got down to save easily enough, then managed to spill it for no reason, claiming at the second attempt.

3.14pm BST

11 min Norway's first attack of note, Hegland hanging up a cross towards the back post, Hansen losing Krahn who found herself stranded underneath it. Her forehead could only send the ball over the top, but Norway will feel a little better now.

Updated at 3.14pm BST

3.11pm BST

9 min Suddenly Germany spring, Lotzen finding some space just outside the box, right of centre, and wiping her foot across a shot aimed at the far post. But she doesn't quite hit it as planned, and the ball goes wide. Then, Goessling plays a lovely ball between full-back and centre-back that almost sets Lotzen free down the right, but it's a little too strong. Great idea, though.

3.09pm BST

8 min The game's not really settled down yet, neither side's passing hitting the mark. Germany's midfielders are getting a little closer to one another and pressuring the ball, while Norway are dropping deeper when not in possession.

3.07pm BST

6 min There is very little on the planet worse than that "Let's go Whoever, let's go" chant.

3.07pm BST

5 min After all those smiles, Norway have begun nervously.

3.05pm BST

4 min Da Mbabi gets her first chance of the game, darting in behind the Norwegian defence and running onto Laudehr's pass, meeting it on the right of the box. But she doesn't quite get hold of her shot, which bobbles wide of the far post.

Updated at 3.06pm BST

3.04pm BST

1 min Germany hit the bar! They win a free-kick on the right-hand side, plenty far from goal, but when it's swung across, the defenders all do nothing whatsoever, leaving Krahn alone in the box. She does well to loop a header towards the top-right corner, and Hjelmseth is slow to react, folding herself underneath it, not getting to it, and relieved to see it bounce against the face of the bar.

Updated at 3.04pm BST

3.01pm BST

1 min Germany get us underway. For those watching in black and white, Norway are in the red shirts.

3.00pm BST

Question: why do sportsfolk always do that angled handshake? And is it at all possible to employ one and be an acceptable, moral person?

Updated at 3.01pm BST

2.58pm BST

This Norway team remind me a little of Zambia's Cup of Nations winners - they're actually enjoying themselves. Who ever heard of such a thing? Disgraceful.

Updated at 2.58pm BST

2.54pm BST

The players are in the tunnel. Some staring and stretching.

2.53pm BST

Interesting. Even Pellerud reckons Norway's women have done so well historically because of the relatively early emancipation of women in the country. In England, meanwhile, the FA decided that "the game of football is quite unsuitable for females and ought not to be encouraged."

2.49pm BST

Germany have scored five goals in the competition, three of those against Iceland - but then they've only conceded one. Norway have managed seven, letting in three.

Updated at 2.49pm BST

2.40pm BST

But back to the aforementioned ball-kicking (my apologies). A pair of fascinating semi-finals suggested that Norway have a really good chance of winning this game. Germany were far from convincing in beating Sweden, only avoiding extra-time by virtue of a narrow offside, a couple of convenient bounces of the ball and some poor finishing. Norway, on the other hand, did have to play an additional half-hour, after a late Denmark equaliser pegged them back, but their overall display was convincing and fearless.

2.27pm BST

Preamble They say that familiarity breeds familiarity, and these two teams are familiar with one another, so accordingly, familiarity is present. They last met just three weeks ago, in the group stages of this competition, a game for which Norway, already through to the quarter-finals, made six changes to their starting XI - and still won.

Incredibly, the defeat was Germany's first in the competition for 20 years - incredibly, they've won the last five - and are hot favourites to add a sixth this afternoon. Norway, on the other hand, are just chuffed to be there - even their coach, Even Pellerud, admitted that he didn't expect the team to do so well.

But, of course, this could just be a version of the MIND GAMES that are so inconceivably mindy and gamish. Mind games. Mind games. Mind games. It's just aggravating that all this ball kicking gets in the way.

Updated at 2.28pm BST

She crosses low, but Da Mbabi is crowded out - Germany coiuld do with sending more players in the box.  3.37pm BST 35 min What a curious half this has been so far, superiority switching almost every five minutes. It's Norway who're in charge at the moment, so by the time I've finished typing, it'll probably be Germany back on top.  3.36pm BST 32 min Despite the miss, Norway are uncowed, and almost immediately supply the best passage of play so far. Hegerberg takes possession outside the box, and cleverly waves her foot over the ball to buy herself some time, waiting for Stensland to accelerate into the box before finding her with a perfect slide-rule pass. She zips past Basrtusiak, taking her through on goal, but again, Angerer is alert, dashing out to smother at her feet. Handy behaviour all round.  3.32pm BST And what a save! Ronning's kick is hammered down the middle, and she begins moving to her left, then flings up a knee and prangs it away. That's a brilliant piece of improvisation.  3.30pm BST After a free-kick isn't properly clearedm Dekkerhus barges into the box on the right, and Da Mbabi comes into tackle. There's a minor fusion of ankles, then a major jumping onto the grass a stride later, and the ref points to the spot. There is anger - lots of it. Updated at 3.50pm BST  3.29pm BST ....  3.28pm BST 27 min We've seen very little of Solveig Gulbrandsen so far - Norway will be hoping to address this - and she's fouled by Kessler. The free-kick comes to nothing.  3.27pm BST 26 min Minor heat experienced by Nadine Angerer, after the ref wrongly awards Norway a corner. For this she is allocated a ticking-off, then comes to punch the corner, ends up on the ground, and wins a free-kick. All's well that ends well.  3.26pm BST 24 min It's been a good few minutes for Germany, who are controlling the midfield now, playing from the back. Norway are trying to get the ball into the German half more quickly, and then dealing with it from there.  3.23pm BST 21 min Da Mbabi could score! Da Mbabi doesn't score! But this is a really good effort, peeling away towards the near post and reaching Laudehr's corner first, introducing brow to ball and heading only just wide.  3.22pm BST 20 min Da Mbabi should score! Da Mbabi doesn't score. A long, raking ball finds Kessler, pulling away from her marker and inside the box on the left. With no one remotely concerned, she knocked down superbly for the advancing Da Mbabi, who couldn't quite get her knee over the ball, and skelped over the top.  3.19pm BST 17 min Caroline Hansen is finding her way into the game now, diddling her man and putting the ball into space, then nutmegging Krahn. She couldn't convert her skill into opportunity, but Germany will be concerned at the space she found.  3.18pm BST 16 min "Afternoon Daniel," says Simon McMahon. "It's a wonder that the BBC don't have John Inverdale and Colin Murray on commentary." I'm hoping for a feature at half-time.  3.16pm BST 14 min Another good situation for Norway, Hansen sending Mjelde away down the right. Shooting early and low, from just outside the box, Angerer got down to save easily enough, then managed to spill it for no reason, claiming at the second attempt.  3.14pm BST 11 min Norway's first attack of note, Hegland hanging up a cross towards the back post, Hansen losing Krahn who found herself stranded underneath it. Her forehead could only send the ball over the top, but Norway will feel a little better now. Updated at 3.14pm BST  3.11pm BST 9 min Suddenly Germany spring, Lotzen finding some space just outside the box, right of centre, and wiping her foot across a shot aimed at the far post. But she doesn't quite hit it as planned, and the ball goes wide. Then, Goessling plays a lovely ball between full-back and centre-back that almost sets Lotzen free down the right, but it's a little too strong. Great idea, though.  3.09pm BST 8 min The game's not really settled down yet, neither side's passing hitting the mark. Germany's midfielders are getting a little closer to one another and pressuring the ball, while Norway are dropping deeper when not in possession.  3.07pm BST 6 min There is very little on the planet worse than that "Let's go Whoever, let's go" chant.  3.07pm BST 5 min After all those smiles, Norway have begun nervously.  3.05pm BST 4 min Da Mbabi gets her first chance of the game, darting in behind the Norwegian defence and running onto Laudehr's pass, meeting it on the right of the box. But she doesn't quite get hold of her shot, which bobbles wide of the far post. Updated at 3.06pm BST  3.04pm BST 1 min Germany hit the bar! They win a free-kick on the right-hand side, plenty far from goal, but when it's swung across, the defenders all do nothing whatsoever, leaving Krahn alone in the box. She does well to loop a header towards the top-right corner, and Hjelmseth is slow to react, folding herself underneath it, not getting to it, and relieved to see it bounce against the face of the bar. Updated at 3.04pm BST  3.01pm BST 1 min Germany get us underway. For those watching in black and white, Norway are in the red shirts.  3.00pm BST Question: why do sportsfolk always do that angled handshake? And is it at all possible to employ one and be an acceptable, moral person? Updated at 3.01pm BST  2.58pm BST This Norway team remind me a little of Zambia's Cup of Nations winners - they're actually enjoying themselves. Who ever heard of such a thing? Disgraceful.  Updated at 2.58pm BST  2.54pm BST The players are in the tunnel. Some staring and stretching.  2.53pm BST Interesting. Even Pellerud reckons Norway's women have done so well historically because of the relatively early emancipation of women in the country. In England, meanwhile, the FA decided that "the game of football is quite unsuitable for females and ought notto be encouraged."   2.49pm BST Germany have scored five goals in the competition, three of those against Iceland - but then they've only conceded one. Norway have managed seven, letting in three. Updated at 2.49pm BST  2.40pm BST But back to the aforementioned ball-kicking (my apologies). A pair of fascinating semi-finals suggested that Norway have a really good chance of winning this game. Germany were far from convincing in beating Sweden, only avoiding extra-time by virtue of a narrow offside, a couple of convenient bounces of the ball and some poor finishing. Norway, on the other hand, did have to play an additional half-hour, after a late Denmark equaliser pegged them back, but their overall display was convincing and fearless.  2.27pm BST Preamble They say that familiarity breeds familiarity, and these two teams are familiar with one another, so accordingly, familiarity is present. They last met just three weeks ago, in the group stages of this competition, a game for which Norway, already through to the quarter-finals, made six changes to their starting XI - and still won. Incredibly, the defeat was Germany's first in the competition for 20 years - incredibly, they've won the last five - and are hot favourites to add a sixth this afternoon. Norway, on the other hand, are just chuffed to be there - even their coach, Even Pellerud, admitted that he didn't expect the team to do so well. But, of course, this could just be a version of the MIND GAMES that are so inconceivably mindy and gamish. Mind games. Mind games. Mind games. It's just aggravating that all this ball kicking gets in the way. Updated at 2.28pm BST

webTitle: Daredevils perform stunts on Troll's Tongue in Norway  in pictures
trailText: Adventurers perform stunts on the tip of Trolltunga, or Troll's Tongue in Odda, in the Norwegian fjords
headline: Daredevils perform stunts on Troll's Tongue in Norway â in pictures
standfirst: Adventurers perform stunts on the tip of Trolltunga, or Troll's Tongue, in Odda, in the Norwegian fjords. The rock ledge extends out over the valley floor 2,500ft below, and is accessible by a network of steep hiking trails

webTitle: Women's Euro 2013: Group B preview  Germany, Iceland, Norway, Holland
trailText: The women's European Championship starts in Sweden on Wednesday and the Guardian has teamed up with journalists across the continent to bring you the best previews
headline: Women's Euro 2013: Group B preview â Germany, Iceland, Norway, Holland
standfirst: The women's European Championship starts in Sweden on Wednesday and the Guardian has teamed up with journalists across the continent to bring you the best previews
body:
Germany

Two years after the home World Cup ended with a shock <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a totally unexpected 1-0 defeat in the quarter-finals by the eventual champions Japan <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the German team wants to get back to success at its favourite tournament. Seven out of 10 European Championships in women's football have been won by Germany and, although this time there is strong opposition from France, Sweden and England, Silvia Neid's team should have been one of the big favourites.

But then the preparation for the tournament turned into a nightmare. Babett Peter, Verena Faisst, Viola Odebrecht, Alexandra Popp, Linda Bresonik and Kim Kulig <83><82><82><82><80><9c> six first-team regulars were sidelined because of injury or illness. Therefore, a very young team with an average age of 23.5 years will start for Germany. They are talented for sure but not really experienced. And it will be down to the veterans to ensure that everyone is smiling at the end of the tournament. The key ones are the goalkeeper Nadine Angerer, the midfielder Fatmire Bajramaj and, finally, Celia Okoyino da Mbabi, the only striker in Neid's beloved 4-2-3-1.

Key player Celia Okoyino da Mbabi

Coach Silvia Neid (since July 2005)

Did you know? The Bundesliga, once the promised land of women's football, has its problems now. Bad Neuenahr, home of the star player Okoyino, is out of the league because of financial problems and Duisburg were only saved at the very last minute.

Jens Kirschneck, 11Freunde

Iceland

Iceland have qualified for the finals again after making their debut in Finland 2009 and are hoping for a better outcome this time after losing all three matches four years ago. The squad is experienced with some 10 players who started one or more of the matches in Finland still included. The captain, Katrin Jonsdottir, who plays for Umea in Sweden, is Iceland's most capped player with 128 appearances and the record scorer Margret Lara Vidarsdottir is scoring goals again for Kristianstad in Sweden after having surgery last winter. Vidarsdottir has scored 69 goals in 88 matches for the country. Most of Iceland's key players play in Sweden, Norway and England but there have been some doubts surrounding the team's preparation for the tournament. They have lost six of their seven matches in 2013, which is the worst spell since Sigurdur Ragnar Eyjolfsson took over as coach in 2007, and with key players struggling with injuries, it looks like he will be deprived of some his best players in the first and most crucial match against Norway.

Key player Sara Bjork Gunnarsdottir (midfielder)

Coach Sigurdur Ragnar Eyjolfsson (January 2007)

Did you know? Key defender Sif Atladottir is the daughter of Atli Edvaldsson, Iceland's former men's coach and captain, who played for Dortmund, D<83><92><82>sseldorf and Bayer Uerdingen in the Bundesliga. Her brother, Emil Atlason, is a key player in Iceland's Under-21 team.

Vidir Sigurdsson, Morgunbladid (@vidirsig)

Norway

These are exciting times for the Norway team. The coach, Even Pellerud, won the Euros back in 1993 and the World Cup in 1995 and is now back in the same job. He is in charge of a team with a mix of experience and young promising players. One player who stands out is the striker Ada Stolsmo Hegerberg. She plays for Turbine Potsdam in Germany and recently scored against the Euro hosts Sweden. Another good young player is Caroline Graham Hansen who will probably play out wide at the Euros and has the potential to be one of the stars of the tournament. There is also a lot of experience in the team. Solveig Gulbrandsen will play at her fourth European Championship and was part of the side that won the Olympics in Sydney in 2000. Finally, all good teams need a good goalkeeper and Norway have one in Ingrid Hjelmeseth. She plays for Stabaek, who are top of the Norwegian league, and had an excellent summer when Norway reached the semi-finals in 2009.

Key player Caroline Graham Hansen (winger)

Coach Even Pellerud (since Jan 2013 )

Did you know? Maren Mjeldes' brother plays for Lillestrom at the highest level in Norway.

Patrick Sten Rowlands , NRK Sport

Holland

Holland, being Holland, obviously prefer to play in a classic Dutch 4-3-3 with two attacking wingers and a central playmaker, although Roger Reijners' team can also switch to a formation with two holding midfielders and one attacking midfielder with the three attacking players remaining intact. There are some obvious leaders in this team, such as the goalkeeper Loes Geurts, the defensive linchpin Daphne Koster and Kirsten van de Ven, who is normally trusted with the No10 role. The all-time top scorer Manon Melis supported by wingers Sylvia Smit and Lieke Martens up front.

Koster, the captain, recently spoke about how the team has changed to adopt a more attacking shape. "Since 2009 quite a lot has changed," she said. "In 2009 we played very defensive football <83><82><82><82><80><9c> defend, defend and then get out on the counter. We had to do that because we wanted to get good results, and that was the quickest way to get them.

"But we wanted more as a team, and the route we have chosen with Roger Reijners is especially about football, playing the position game, really assuming your own strengths and how good you are."

Key player Daphne Koster

Coach Roger Reijners (Since November 2010)

Did you know? Dutch all-time record goal-scorer Manon Melis' father, Harry, was a professional player at Feyenoord and Den Haag in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

Berend Scholten

The all-time top scorer Manon Melis supported by wingers Sylvia Smit and Lieke Martens up front. Koster, the captain, recently spoke about how the team has changed to adopt a more attacking shape. Key player Daphne Koster Coach Roger Reijners (Since November 2010) Did you know? webTitle: Travel news round-up: Peru's coast, Norway made easy, and Swiss ski-yoga
trailText: Plus: flight connections to the US from Cambridge, great deals to Budapest and bubble tents near Bordeaux
headline: Travel news round-up: Peru's coast, Norway made easy, and ski-yoga â¦
standfirst: Plus flight connections to the US from Cambridge, great deals to Budapest and bubble tents near Bordeaux
body:
Escapism

New tour operator Miraviva is tipping M<83><92><82>ncora, a small fishing village in northern Peru, as a hotspot. Surfers and backpackers dominate the centre, but Las Pocitas, 10 minutes' drive away, has sophisticated hotels such as honeymoon-friendly Arennas Mancora.
<83><82><82><82> From <83><80><9a><82>1,125pp (based on two sharing) for four nights including flights from London, internal flights, transfers and breakfast with miravivatravel.com

What's new?

Accommodation
Sleep among the trees at Cabanes de la Romaningue <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a new collection of caravans, pods and cabins in the Gironde vineyards near Bordeaux, France. Futuristic bubble tents with a terrace start from <83><82><80><9a><82>130 a night. There are also three treehouses, one accessed via zipwire, also from <83><82><80><9a><82>130.
<83><82><82><82> cabanes.laromaningue.fr

Flight connection
The little-known international airport at Cambridge is now offering one-stop connections to a number of US destinations, including LA and New York, via Paris or Amsterdam. And thanks to an agreement between Cambridge carrier Darwin Airline and Air France, passengers can check their bags in at Cambridge and have them sent straight to a final destination airport in America, with just a short layover in Paris.
<83><82><82><82> cambridgeairport.com

Website
The fjords, ski resorts and northern lights of Norway have long made the country popular with tour groups. But a new website aims to help make its attractions easier to access for independent travellers too. Flydrivenorway.co.uk lists restaurants, hotels, car hire companies and weather forecasts for the whole country, and offers discounts on partner accommodation, car hire and flights booked through the site.

Snow watch

Hot on the heels of acro-yoga and yog-aqua comes ski-yoga, a dubious-sounding mix of meditation and stretching carried out atop a mountain <83><82><82><82><80><9c> while still on your skis. Four-day packages at the swish Grand Hotel Kronenhof in the Swiss resort of Pontresina cost from <83><80><9a><82>885, including daily indoor and outdoor yoga sessions, lift pass and massages in the hotel's spa, but not flights.

Cheap date

Starboard is a new collection of luxury boats from self-catering specialist Hoseasons. The 20 vessels <83><82><82><82><80><9c> at four bases in Norfolk and Oxfordshire <83><82><82><82><80><9c> come with a champagne welcome pack, binoculars, iPod docks, nice linen, and even space for your bikes, all from <83><80><9a><82>549 a week for four people, <83><80><9a><82>365 for a short break. Booking from December.
<83><82><82><82> 0844 847 1100, hoseasons.co.uk

Travel trash

Don't forget to pack your Sled Buddies if you're taking the kids somewhere snowy this winter. The cute penguin- and polar bear-shaped sledges are light (500g), fit into a suitcase (they're 90cm long) and, crucially, feature "Arctic Groove Technology". Whatever that might be.
<83><82><82><82> For ages eight and over, <83><80><9a><82>24.99, atbshop.co.uk

Win a holiday

The Guardian Cottages and Villas website, which lists more than 1,400 self-catering properties in the UK and Europe, is offering three readers a cottage stay worth up to <83><80><9a><82>350. Winners can take their prize at any property on the site. Enter now at theguardian.com/cottage-competition.

webTitle: World Cup 2014 qualifier: Iceland face date with destiny against Norway | Sachin Nakrani
trailText: Sachin Nakrani: Iceland's exciting crop of young players believe they can qualify for their first World Cup, but they must tame Norway on Tuesday to make the play-offs
headline: World Cup 2014 qualifier: Iceland face date with destiny against Norway
standfirst: Iceland's exciting crop of young players, under the experienced coach Lars Lagerback, believe they can qualify for their first World Cup, but they must tame Norway to make the play-offs
body:
The streets of Reykjavik are expected to be deserted on Tuesday night, not a soul to be seen except for stray cats, and even they may be indoors given the sense of anticipation gripping Iceland's World Cup qualifier against Norway. The fixture has been described as the most important in the national team's history and, as such, essential viewing for those across Iceland's capital city, surrounding towns, villages and outposts. For 90 minutes, all that will matter to a country renowned for fishing and volcanoes will be the action from Oslo.

Should Iceland win they will definitely retain second place in Group E and subsequently qualify for the World Cup play-offs. A draw or defeat would also be fine should third-place Slovenia fail to better their result against leaders Switzerland in Berne. Switzerland have little to play for given they have already secured their place for next summer's finals in Brazil, but neither do Norway who, stranded in fourth place, just have pride at stake. Little wonder, then, that there is confidence within Iceland's ranks that they can get the job done and put themselves within a two-legged tie of reaching a major tournament for a first ever time.

"There is a lot of excitement around this match, everyone in Iceland will be watching," said Vidir Sigurdsson, sports editor of Morgunbladid, one of country's largest daily newspapers. "This is the most important game we have played in for many years <83><82><82><82><80><9c> getting to the play-offs would represent a big step for us and one that most people here, including myself, did not see coming so soon."

Indeed, this campaign was simply meant to be a further learning experience for Iceland. Under the former manager Olafur Johannesson, a younger, more dynamic squad had been put together for the Euro 2012 qualifiers. Little was expected from them and little was delivered, with Iceland picking up just four points from a group containing Denmark, Portugal and, again, Norway. But the principal aim was to give the likes of Johann Gudmundsson, Kolbeinn Sigthorsson, Alfred Finnbogason, Birkir Bjarnason and the Premier League duo of Gylfi Sigurdsson and Aron Gunnarsson experience of playing competitive international games together, with the expectation that they would collectively peak during qualifying for Euro 2016. Instead, under the charge of former Sweden coach Lars Lagerback, they have made their mark two years in advance.

"We are young and we do not scare easily," said Cardiff City's Gunnarsson in a manner befitting the captain of a side that has blown apart expectations. "We have already put pressure on ourselves and now we just have to handle it. The Norwegians will not give us anything, like we wouldn't give them anything. They have nothing to lose but we just have to think about our game, stay cool and everything will be OK."

Iceland can take hope from their 2-0 victory over Norway in their opening Group E fixture 13 months ago, a triumph that was followed by a disappointing defeat away to Cyprus and the sense once again that this was a team which stood little or no chance of competing for a qualification spot. But back-to-back away victories against Albania and Slovenia revived hope and soon came Iceland's defining moment <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the 4-4 draw in Switzerland in September. The visitors had found themselves 4-1 down after 54 minutes only for a goal from Sigthorsson and two from Gudmundsson in the final 22 minutes of the contest <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the last of which was a sumptuous curling drive delivered in stoppage time <83><82><82><82><80><9c> to secure a shock point for Lagerback's men.

"That was a turning point," said Vidir Sigurdsson. "Suddenly people in Iceland started to really believe that the team could do amazing things. One second they had been swearing at the TV; the next they were screaming with excitement, and since then the positive atmosphere around the team has built and built."

In that regard, Lagerback impact cannot be underestimated. The Swede was announced as Johannesson's replacement in October 2011 and officially took over the reigns the following January. He came with pedigree having led Sweden to two previous World Cups, in 2002 and 2006, as well as having managed Nigeria at the 2010 finals in South Africa. But, according to Vidir Sigurdsson, Lagerback's key asset has been instilling Iceland with belief.

"Lars has been a very good influence on the young players in particular," he said. "He has given them a very professional outlook based on a strong work ethic and on going into every match thinking they can win. He has never been afraid to say 'we can qualify for the play-offs', and even 'we can fight for first place'. That has given everyone in Iceland confidence."

It has also helped having the country's greatest ever player back in the fold. Eidur Gudjohnsen had become something of a forgotten figure in his homeland after suffering a fractured tibia and fibula while playing for AEK Athens against local rivals Olympiakos in October 2011. The injury ruled him out for the rest of that campaign and 12 months later, following a brief spell at Seattle Sounders, the 34-year-old joined Belgium team Cercle Brugge, where it was presumed he would bring his career to a gentle close. Instead the former Chelsea and Barcelona forward shone and, having moved to Club Brugge, returned to the international scene for Iceland's 2-1 defeat in Slovenia on 22 March. In total, Gudjohnsen has featured in fives of Iceland qualification games and started in the last two; the 2-1 win against Albania last month and Friday's 2-0 victory over Cyprus.

"It is like Eidur is enjoying a new lifetime," said Vidir Sigurdsson. "Most people in Iceland thought he was fading out but he has impressed since coming back and been a very positive influence on the side. It helps that for the first time in his international career, Eidur is surrounded by many good players. Finnbogason and Sigthorsson, for instance, are two of the top scorers in Holland, while Bjarnason plays for Sampdoria in Serie A and Gylfi Sigurdsson is an important player for Tottenham in the Premier League. We have never had so many players who feature for top clubs across Europe."

Vidir Sigurdsson largely puts this down to the overhauling of Iceland's infrastructure, which was carried out by the country's governing body, the KSI, in 2000 and saw a range of artificial pitches built across Iceland and an emphasis put on small-sided games to improve the technique of young players. Alongside this, there was also a drive to increase the number of homegrown Uefa-qualified coaches, which has also borne fruit.

Subsequently, Iceland's Under-21 side has strengthened significantly and in the past four years provided the first team with 17 players, many of whom are now part of an attractive, attacking unit <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Iceland have scored 16 times during qualifying, more than Spain, France and Croatia <83><82><82><82><80><9c> that stands a slim but realistic chance of representing a nation of just 328,000 people at the next World Cup.

Getting to Brazil would be particularly remarkable given Iceland were among the lowest-ranked nations when the qualification groups were drawn, lower even than Liechtenstein, and would have to get past a seeded team, such as Sweden and Portugal, in the play-offs.

"We are just thinking one step at a time," said Vidir Sigurdsson. "But the players have shown that they are fighters and we are sure they will fight to achieve as much as they can, starting with beating Norway."
text: The streets of Reykjavik are expected to be deserted on Tuesday night, not a soul to be seen except for stray cats, and even they may be indoors given the sense of anticipation gripping Iceland's World Cup qualifier against Norway. The fixture has been described as the most important in the national team's history and, as such, essential viewing for those across Iceland's capital city, surrounding towns, villages and outposts. For 90 minutes, all that will matter to a country renowned for fishing and volcanoes will be the action from Oslo. Should Iceland win they will definitely retain second place in Group E and subsequently qualify for the World Cup play-offs. A draw or defeat would also be fine should third-place Slovenia fail to better their result against leaders Switzerland in Berne. Switzerland have little to play for given they have already secured their place for next summer's finals in Brazil, but neither do Norway who, stranded in fourth place, just have pride at stake. Little wonder, then, that there is confidence within Iceland's ranks that they can get the job done and put themselves within a two-legged tie of reaching a major tournament for a first ever time. "There is a lot of excitement around this match, everyone in Iceland will be watching," said Vidir Sigurdsson, sports editor of Morgunbladid, one of country's largest daily newspapers. "This is the most important game we have played in for many years  getting to the play-offs would represent a big step for us and one that most people here, including myself, did not see coming so soon." Indeed, this campaign was simply meant to be a further learning experience for Iceland. Under the former manager Olafur Johannesson, a younger, more dynamic squad had been put together for the Euro 2012 qualifiers. Little was expected from them and little was delivered, with Iceland picking up just four points from a group containing Denmark, Portugal and, again, Norway. But the principal aim was to give the likes of Johann Gudmundsson, Kolbeinn Sigthorsson, Alfred Finnbogason, Birkir Bjarnason and the Premier League duo of Gylfi Sigurdsson and Aron Gunnarsson experience of playing competitive international games together, with the expectation that they would collectively peak during qualifying for Euro 2016. Instead, under the charge of former Sweden coach Lars Lagerback, they have made their mark two years in advance. "We are young and we do not scare easily," said Cardiff City's Gunnarsson in a manner befitting the captain of a side that has blown apart expectations. "We have already put pressure on ourselves and now we just have to handle it. The Norwegians will not give us anything, like we wouldn't give them anything. They have nothing to lose but we just have to think about our game, stay cool and everything will be OK." Iceland can take hope from their 2-0 victory over Norway in their opening Group E fixture 13 months ago, a triumph that was followed by a disappointing defeat away to Cyprus and the sense once again that this was a team which stood little or no chance of competing for a qualification spot. But back-to-back away victories against Albania and Slovenia revived hope and soon came Iceland's defining moment  the 4-4 draw in Switzerland in September. The visitors had found themselves 4-1 down after 54 minutes only for a goal from Sigthorsson and two from Gudmundsson in the final 22 minutes of the contest  the last of which was a sumptuous curling drive delivered in stoppage time  to secure a shock point for Lagerback's men. "That was a turning point," said Vidir Sigurdsson. "Suddenly people in Iceland started to really believe that the team could do amazing things. One second they had been swearing at the TV; the next they were screaming with excitement, and since then the positive atmosphere around the team has built and built." In that regard, Lagerback impact cannot be underestimated. The Swede was announced as Johannesson's replacement in October 2011 and officially took over the reigns the following January. He came with pedigree having led Sweden to two previous World Cups, in 2002 and 2006, as well as having managed Nigeria at the 2010 finals in South Africa. But, according to Vidir Sigurdsson, Lagerback's key asset has been instilling Iceland with belief. "Lars has been a very good influence on the young players in particular," he said. "He has given them a very professional outlook based on a strong work ethic and on going into every match thinking they can win. He has never been afraid to say 'we can qualify for the play-offs', and even 'we can fight for first place'. That has given everyone in Iceland confidence." It has also helped having the country's greatest ever player back in the fold. Eidur Gudjohnsen had become something of a forgotten figure in his homeland after suffering a fractured tibia and fibula while playing for AEK Athens against local rivals Olympiakos in October 2011. The injury ruled him out for the rest of that campaign and 12 months later, following a brief spell at Seattle Sounders, the 34-year-old joined Belgium team Cercle Brugge, where it was presumed he would bring his career to a gentle close. Instead the former Chelsea and Barcelona forward shone and, having moved to Club Brugge, returned to the international scene for Iceland's 2-1 defeat in Slovenia on 22 March. In total, Gudjohnsen has featured in fives of Iceland qualification games and started in the last two; the 2-1 win against Albania last month and Friday's 2-0 victory over Cyprus. "It is like Eidur is enjoying a new lifetime," said Vidir Sigurdsson. "Most people in Iceland thought he was fading out but he has impressed since coming back and been a very positive influence on the side. It helps that for the first time in his international career, Eidur is surrounded by many good players. Finnbogason and Sigthorsson, for instance, are two of the top scorers in Holland, while Bjarnason plays for Sampdoria in Serie A and Gylfi Sigurdsson is an important player for Tottenham in the Premier League. We have never had so many players who feature for top clubs across Europe." Vidir Sigurdsson largely puts this down to the overhauling of Iceland's infrastructure, which was carried out by the country's governing body, the KSI, in 2000 and saw a range of artificial pitches built across Iceland and an emphasis put on small-sided games to improve the technique of young players. Alongside this, there was also a drive to increase the number of homegrown Uefa-qualified coaches, which has also borne fruit. Subsequently, Iceland's Under-21 side has strengthened significantly and in the past four years provided the first team with 17 players, many of whom are now part of an attractive, attacking unit  Iceland have scored 16 times during qualifying, more than Spain, France and Croatia  that stands a slim but realistic chance of representing a nation of just 328,000 people at the next World Cup. Getting to Brazil would be particularly remarkable given Iceland were among the lowest-ranked nations when the qualification groups were drawn, lower even than Liechtenstein, and would have to get past a seeded team, such as Sweden and Portugal, in the play-offs. "We are just thinking one step at a time," said Vidir Sigurdsson. "But the players have shown that they are fighters and we are sure they will fight to achieve as much as they can, starting with beating Norway."

webTitle: Norway's solution to elk collisions: disco poles
trailText: Devices with flashing lights and rhythmic sounds to be installed in attempt to cut collisions between animals and cars
headline: Norway's solution to elk collisions: disco poles
standfirst: Devices with flashing lights and rhythmic sounds to be installed in attempt to cut collisions between animals and cars
body:
North Norway is famed for its midnight sun, northern lights, stunning landscapes and rich flora and fauna, but one of its best-known creatures has been causing problems. Elk, which can grow to more than two metres and weigh more than 600kg, pose a real danger to drivers on the region's roads.

Between 2005 and 2011, 315 people were injured in collisions with the giant deer in Norway. Insurance companies put the average damage to a car at about 150,000 kroner (<83><80><9a><82>15,600). In terms of personal injury, loss of working hours, taxes, hospital treatment and clearing roads, the cost is more like 9.5m kroner for a serious injury, according to the Norwegian public roads administration. Transport officials have long racked their brains for a way to keep elk off the highways and have tried everything from traditional fences to motion-sensing technology to alert drivers.

Fences were effective but at the point where they ended, elk would dart on to the road and the number of collisions would rise, while motion sensors were prone to false alarms from low-flying birds or trees moving in the wind.

Now there is a flashier solution. Henrik Wildenschild, of the region's roads administration, read that LED traffic poles used in Austria to deter deer reduced collisions by 90%. He wondered whether a similar system might work for Bambi's big cousin. "These solar-panel-powered devices, nicknamed 'disco poles', react to car headlights and emit a high-pitched, rhythmic sound and flash LED lights in blue and yellow to frighten elk away," he says. "Since it's the law that headlights must be on day and night in Norway, this should work perfectly. Even a 30% reduction in collisions would be a success for us."

The scaled-up "elk disco poles" are in production and will be installed on four main roads in a trial in November. If successful, they could be introduced across Scandinavia.

"We'd need more testing in densely populated areas," warns Wildenschild. "We're a bit worried about how domestic cats and dogs will respond and don't want to be held responsible for people's pets running off."

webTitle: England 1-3 Norway | European Under-21 Championship match report
trailText: England have no chance of advancing to the latter stages of the European Under-21 Championship after they lost 3-1 to Norway
headline: Stuart Pearce's England Under-21s eliminated after defeat by Norway
standfirst:
England 1 (Dawson 57 pen)
Norway 3 (Berge 15 Berget 34 Eikrem 51)
byline: Stuart James at Ha Moshava Stadium
body:
The only thing missing was a Norwegian commentator shouting into his microphone: "Your boys took one hell of a beating." This result may not go down in history in quite the same way as that famous Norway victory over Ron Greenwood's senior side in Oslo in 1981 but it was a humiliating defeat for England Under<83><82><82><82><80><98>21s nonetheless.

Vanquished by a far superior Italy side in the opening group game, England turned in another hugely disappointing performance against Norway and can now pack their bags in preparation for a return flight home after Tuesday's final group game against Israel in Jerusalem. So much for England getting lucky with the draw and avoiding the leading nations. Stuart Pearce's side have been eliminated from these finals at the earliest opportunity and, with the manager's contract up at the end of the month, this will surely bring an end to his six-year reign.

Roy Hodgson, who flew into Israel before the game, must have been wondering why he had bothered. Sat alongside Sir Trevor Brooking, the FA's director of football development, the England manager looked on as Norway, courtesy of goals from Fredrik Semb Berge, Jo Inge Berget and Magnus Wolff Eikrem, punished some shambolic defending. Craig Dawson pulled a goal back with a penalty in the 57th minute but by that point the damage was done. England never looked capable of mounting a comeback.

Forget the argument about England not having their best players available for this tournament. Four of Norway's most talented players started on the bench after playing in the senior team's 1-1 draw in Albania on Friday night; they flew into Israel on the morning of this game. The brutal truth is that, once again, England were simply not good enough. They have now failed to win any of their past eight matches at the Under-21 European Championship finals in normal time.

It goes without saying that the availability of Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, Phil Jones and Jack Rodwell would have improved England's chances against Italy and Norway, but the talent pool at this level must be pretty shallow if this is the best the country can produce in their absence. The return of Wilfried Zaha, Tom Ince and Danny Rose to the starting lineup made England look stronger on paper but the end result was the same.

Although England saw much more of the ball than they did against Italy, they lacked penetration going forward and there was a vulnerability about the defence whenever Norway got anywhere near the penalty area. The opening goal was a sign of things to come. If Jack Butland looked unconvincing when he just about got his fingertips to Stefan Johansen's corner from the right, the defending that followed from the corner on the other side of the pitch was even worse. Eikrem, a former Manchester United academy graduate now playing for Molde, delivered a cross from the left and, with England's defence at sixes and sevens, the ball broke for Semb Berge, who was able to take a touch before turning and shooting beyond Butland.

Berge went close to adding a second with a glancing header but England still failed to heed the warning. Havard Nielsen showed adroit close control to lift the ball away from Adam Smith and pick out Berget, who took the ball on his chest, sprinted away from Steven Caulker and crashed a powerful left-footed volley past Butland and into the corner of the net.

Despite dominating possession <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Pearce's side enjoyed 74% of it in the opening 45 minutes <83><82><82><82><80><9c> England created little before the break. Orjan Nyland, Norway's goalkeeper, was finally called upon to make a notable save early in the second half, when Jordan Henderson's thumping left-footed shot was parried.

Normal service, however, quickly resumed as Norway went up the other end and added a third. Marcus Pedersen, who beat Dawson far too easily on the right flank, cut the ball back for Eikrem to thrash a sublime first-time shot into the roof of the net.

England finally had something to show for their efforts when Dawson beat Nyland from the penalty spot, after the West Bromwich Albion defender was fouled by Semb Berge. Not that it felt like much of a consolation for Pearce and his players.

Not that it felt like much of a consolation for Pearce and his players.

webTitle: Travel tips: head for the Hebrides, live it up on London or take a trip to Norway | Joanne O'Connor
trailText: Perfect seascapes in Scotland, and short breaks at home and away, chosen by Joanne O'Connor
headline: Travel tips: head for the Hebrides, live it up on London or take a trip to Norway
standfirst: Perfect seascapes in Scotland, and short breaks at home and away
body:
Take me there: Isle of Coll, Inner Hebrides

Why go?
Coll inspired the popular Katie Morag children's books, which have just been made into a series for CBeebies. Go before the "Balamory effect" kicks in and you'll have the white-sand beaches, wild Atlantic seascapes and impossibly starry skies all to yourself.

What to do
As the endearingly honest visitor website points out, there are no "attractions" (visitcoll.co.uk). It's about the simple things: wildlife spotting, shore walks and star gazing. Coll has just been designated Scotland's first Dark Sky island with plans to launch regular astronomy events in the new year (darkskies.visitcoll.co.uk).

Where to stay
The Coll Hotel is the island's only hotel and has just six simple, comfy rooms, views of the bay, a cosy bar and memorable breakfasts (collhotel.com). A good budget alternative is the shiny new Coll Bunkhouse, with spotless dorms (collbunkhouse.com).

Where to eat
The Gannet Restaurant at the Coll Hotel (see previous entry) is your best bet for seafood and a menu which makes the most of island produce.

Insider tip
"My favourite beach is Toraston," says Julie Oliphant, owner of the Coll Hotel. "It's got lots of character, and it's easily accessible and safe for kids. You often see basking sharks and as soon as the seals hear voices they'll swim over to take a look."

Give me a break

Live it up in London Assuming there's still life left in the credit card following the annual Christmas shopping splurge, book yourself into the Cumberland Hotel in London's West End for a January sales break. Guests booking a two-night stay at the hotel before 31 March are being offered a <83><80><9a><82>50 Selfridges voucher. Rooms start at <83><80><9a><82>219 per night and Oxford Street is on your doorstep (guoman.com/shopping).

Northern lights luxury trip Book by 31 December and save <83><80><9a><82>100 on a northern lights break to Norway with the Mighty Fine Company (mightyfinecompany.com). The four-night break will cost <83><80><9a><82>1,292pp and features snowshoeing, cross-country skiing, a wildlife rib safari, a meal with Sami farmers and the chance to spot the aurora borealis. The trip departs on 16, 23 and 27 February.

webTitle: Norway's disturbing lurch to the right  | Alf Gunvald Nilsen
trailText: Alf Gunvald Nilsen: The anti-immigration party's electoral success shows the country has not dealt with the roots of Anders Breivik's crimes
headline: Norway's disturbing lurch to the right
standfirst: The anti-immigration party's electoral success shows the country has not dealt with the roots of Anders Breivik's crimes
body:
The results from today's Norwegian elections are more or less clear: with some 26.8% of the vote, the Conservative party (H<83><92><82>yre) is poised to head Norway's next coalition government. The first thing to note about Norway's unsettling rightward turn is the fact that the Progress party (Fremskrittspartiet) is set to join as junior partner in a coalition government. Disturbingy, a political party whose platform is marked above all else by an ardent anti-immigration agenda is capable of making such headway little more than two years after neofascist Anders Breivik carried out his heinous terrorist attacks.

The events that left 77 people dead, prompted public debate to focus on a deeply troubling question: what was it about Norwegian society that had made 22/7 possible? Breivik's extensive links to far-right groups and anti-Muslim networks prompted the recognition that his actions and ideology could not be understood in a vacuum. Rather, it seemed clear that he had emerged from the fertile ground of a racism and an Islamophobia that had attained a degree of respectability in public debate in Norway. This, it was argued, demanded a collective response: Norwegian society had to confront deep-seated xenophobic attitudes and embrace the fact that cultural and ethnic diversity had come to stay.

For a time, this was a recognition that seemed to hold sway. The most significant indication of this shift was the fact that electoral support for the Progress party <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a party of which Breivik had been a member for a number of years, and whose warnings against the "sneak-Islamisation" of Norwegian society resonated with the main tenor of Breivik's ideology <83><82><82><82><80><9c> was significantly reduced in the local elections of September 2011.

However, the fact that the party now seems destined to become the second largest player in Norway's new ruling coalition raises the question of why 22/7 failed to become more of a watershed in Norwegian politics. A very likely reason is the fact that Norway has failed to take the lessons of the attacks that befell us that dreadful day to heart. Breivik's actions and ideology were quickly pathologised and turned into an aberration <83><82><82><82><80><9c> indeed, the court proceedings against him were remarkable for their studious avoidance of questions relating to the broader context in which Breivik had flourished. An aberration, of course, is not something that weighs down on a nation's collective conscience. Norwegian society could move along, safely ensconced in its affluent comfort zone. And this should be a matter of great concern for those of us who were hoping for a more tolerant society to emerge from the trauma of 22/7.

But it's not only the advance of the far-right Progress party that gives cause for concern. It is equally disconcerting that victory has been claimed by a conservative political party that advocates tax cuts, privatisation, deregulation, and a substantial reduction of public spending on welfare. This agenda is of course familiar in these austerity-ridden times, but the paradox is this: there is no crisis to warrant such policies. Under its current "red-green" government, Norway has in fact steered clear of the economic and social debacle that has mired the EU project since 2008. Growth rates have been stable over the past five years and unemployment is lower in Norway than in any of the countries in the European Union.

This is not to say that there are not challenges ahead for Norway's economy. For example, there is still inequality and poverty amid plenty, and immigrants and minority communities suffer its consequences disproportionally. However, there is no conceivable way in which the neoliberal agenda touted by the Conservatives can address such challenges.

On the contrary <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the eager pursuit of such an agenda in the current context shows what the objective for the Conservatives really is, namely, a project geared towards redistributing wealth in favour of society's elites. In doing so, this project will undermine what has been an enduring and valuable feature of Norwegian society <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and a key reason why the country topped the UNDP's human development index in 2013 <83><82><82><82><80><9c> which is a social infrastructure that ensures the availability of crucial public goods and underpins the country's relative egalitarian social structure.

In other words, the 2013 elections have thrown up a marriage of neoliberal conservatism and rightwing populism that threatens to entrench that which we need to rid ourselves of and erode that which we should struggle to keep.

The most significant indication of this shift was the fact that electoral support for the Progress party  a party of which Breivik had been a member for a number of years, and whose warnings against the "sneak-Islamisation" of Norwegian society resonated with the main tenor of Breivik's ideology  was significantly reduced in the local elections of September 2011. However, the fact that the party now seems destined to become the second largest player in Norway's new ruling coalition raises the question of why 22/7 failed to become more of a watershed in Norwegian politics. A very likely reason is the fact that Norway has failed to take the lessons of the attacks that befell us that dreadful day to heart. Breivik's actions and ideology were quickly pathologised and turned into an aberration  indeed, the court proceedings against him were remarkable for their studious avoidance of questions relating to the broader context in which Breivik had flourished. An aberration, of course, is not something that weighs down on a nation's collective conscience. Norwegian society could move along, safely ensconced in its affluent comfort zone. And this should be a matter of great concern for those of us who were hoping for a more tolerant society to emerge from the trauma of 22/7. But it's not only the advance of the far-right Progress party that gives cause for concern. It is equally disconcerting that victory has been claimed by a conservative political party that advocates tax cuts, privatisation, deregulation, and a substantial reduction of public spending on welfare. This agenda is of course familiar in these austerity-ridden times, but the paradox is this: there is no crisis to warrant such policies. Under its current "red-green" government, Norway has in fact steered clear of the economic and social debacle that has mired the EU project since 2008. Growth rates have been stable over the past five years and unemployment is lower in Norway than in any of the countries in the European Union. This is not to say that there are not challenges ahead for Norway's economy. For example, there is still inequality and poverty amid plenty, and immigrants and minority communities suffer its consequences disproportionally. However, there is no conceivable way in which the neoliberal agenda touted by the Conservatives can address such challenges. On the contrary  the eager pursuit of such an agenda in the current context shows what the objective for the Conservatives really is, namely, a project geared towards redistributing wealth in favour of society's elites. In doing so, this project will undermine what has been an enduring and valuable feature of Norwegian society  and a key reason why the country topped the UNDP's human development index in 2013  which is a social infrastructure that ensures the availability of crucial public goods and underpins the country's relative egalitarian social structure. In other words, the 2013 elections have thrown up a marriage of neoliberal conservatism and rightwing populism that threatens to entrench that which we need to rid ourselves of and erode that which we should struggle to keep.

webTitle: FTSE 100 falters on Syria concerns while BG hit by problems in Egypt and Norway
trailText: Gases giant slides 4% as unrest in Egypt and delays in Norway lead to cut in production estimates
headline: FTSE 100 falters on Syria concerns while BG hit by problems in Egypt and Norway
standfirst: Gases giant slides 4% as unrest in Egypt and delays in Norway lead to cut in production estimates
body:
Leading shares have slipped lower despite positive economic news from China and Japan, as Syrian jitters continue to unsettle investors.

BG is heading the fallers, down 51p or nearly 4% to <83><80><9a><82>12.31, after the gases group warned delays in Egypt and Norway would cut 2014 production by around 30,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. This amounts to around 5% of this year's expected output (it has not forecast production targets for 2014).

Ahead of an investor presentation later, BG said it was on track to meet expectations for 2013 but the current instability in Egypt would delay the start of production due next year, while its Knarr project in Norway will come onstream in the second half of the year.

It also plans to reduce output from the US in 2014 due to low natural gas prices there. Andrew Whittock at Liberum Capital said:

An unhelpful update and next year's earnings will be hit.

Neill Morton at Investec issued a sell note, saying:

BG's shares have had a strong run into this afternoon's liquefied natural gas/exploration update. This surprised us as we expected little new versus the recent strategy presentation in May. In the event, production guidance for 2014 has been cut by 7% (with a smaller knock-on effect in 2015), highlighting the perils of forecasting. We expect to cut our forecasts by 3%-4%. Despite strong earnings and cash flow growth, on our current forecasts BG is still trading on a 25% PE premium versus the Euro sector in 2017.

The company disappointed the market last year and again in February over its production targets. But last week its shares were lifted by vague takeover speculation.

Overall the FTSE 100 has dipped 11.95 points to 6535.38, after last week's positive move. Friday's poor US non-farm payroll figures left investors wondering when the Federal Reserve would end its $85bn a month bond buying programme, adding to the uncertainty. Ishaq Siddiqi at ETX Capital said:

Syria and [Fed] tapering concerns [are] being balanced off by the overnight gains in Asian markets after data from China and Japan enthused the market over the outlook for both economies. Data out of China indicated that inflation remained subdued while exports data released Sunday showed a better increase than forecast, painting a better outlook for the second half of 2013 than previous anticipated. After the rocky first half of the year for China, both data points soothed worries about the economic outlook for the world's second largest economy, lifting resource shares in the European session.

Meanwhile Japan's second quarter GDP figures were revised up from 0.6% to 0.9%, on top of the country being announced as the host of the 2020 Olympic Games.

Following the China figures, miners are among the risers, with Rio Tinto up 40.5p at 3137.5p and Anglo American adding 21p to <83><80><9a><82>16.02.

Associated British Foods had fallen 30p to <83><80><9a><82>18.21 despite saying its second half profit would be ahead of expectations thanks to a continuing strong performance from its Primark discount fashion chain.

But Burberry has risen 33p to <83><80><9a><82>16.33, pushing it to the top of the FTSE 100, following an upgrade from HSBC which lifted its price target from <83><80><9a><82>17.50 to <83><80><9a><82>19.00. The bank said:

Conservative guidance and cautious sell-side make this stock more solid than it appears. In the short term, the first half trading statement should be fine; long term, strategic initiatives are coming together and digital vision sets the group apart.

It said Burberry was now an "HSBC Europe Super Ten stock", which sounds impressive.

Elsewhere GlaxoSmithKline has slipped 8p to <83><80><9a><82>16.43 as it confirmed the sale of its Ribena and Lucozade brands to Japan's Suntory for <83><80><9a><82>1.35bn.

Ahead of an investor presentation later, BG said it was on track to meet expectations for 2013 but the current instability in Egypt would delay the start of production due next year, while its Knarr project in Norway will come onstream in the second half of the year. It also plans to reduce output from the US in 2014 due to low natural gas prices there. Andrew Whittock at Liberum Capital said: Neill Morton at Investec issued a sell note, saying: The company disappointed the market last year and again in February over its production targets. But last week its shares were lifted by vague takeover speculation. Overall the FTSE 100 has dipped 11.95 points to 6535.38, after last week's positive move.
