Associated British Foods had fallen 30p to 18.21 despite saying its second half profit would be ahead of expectations thanks to a continuing strong performance from its Primark discount fashion chain. But Burberry has risen 33p to 16.33, pushing it to the top of the FTSE 100, following an upgrade from HSBC which lifted its price target from 17.50 to 19.00. The bank said: It said Burberry was now an "HSBC Europe Super Ten stock", which sounds impressive. Elsewhere GlaxoSmithKline has slipped 8p to 16.43 as it confirmed the sale of its Ribena and Lucozade brands to Japan's Suntory for 1.35bn.

webTitle: Travel tips: savour the snow in Norway, go to a Christmas market, and the rolling hills of south-east England | Joanne O'Connor
trailText: The land of Santa's reindeer, seasonal fairs, and four places to stay on the North Downs. By Joanne O'Connor
headline: Travel tips: savour the snow in Norway, go to a Christmas market, and the rolling hills of south-east England
standfirst: The land of Santa's reindeer, seasonal fairs, and four places to stay on the North Downs
body:
Take me there: Finnmark, Norway

Why go
The Arctic landscapes, spectacular fjords and S<83><92><82>mi culture of Norway's far north, where reindeer outnumber people two to one, provide the inspiration for Disney's new animation, Frozen (in cinemas this week). Come here for the pristine winter wilderness and, if you're lucky, a glimpse of the aurora borealis.

What to do
Join a husky sledding or snowmobiling safari across the frozen tundra. Explore remote fishing villages on the Hurtigruten coastal voyage (hurtigruten.co.uk). Don't miss the extraordinary titanium-clad Cathedral of the Northern Lights in Finnmark's capital, Alta.

Where to stay
Every January the Sorrisniva Igloo Hotel is carved from ice on the banks of the River Alta, only to melt away in spring (<83><80><9a><82>220pp per night, sorrisniva.no). There's an ice bar and a sauna to warm up in. A cosy alternative is the Kongsfjord Guesthouse: simple but charming rooms in a 19th-century farmhouse in a tiny fishing village overlooking a fjord (doubles from <83><80><9a><82>100, kongsfjord-gjestehus.no).

Where to eat
For no-frills Nordic cuisine, Alfa Omega is a popular choice in the centre of Alta. The house speciality is ole mattis h<83><92><82>tta <83><82><82><82><80><9c> smoked reindeer steak served on garlic bread with cranberries (alfaomega-alta.no). For a memorable meal freshly plucked from the Barents Sea, join a king crab safari in Kirkenes.

Insider tip
"For a true wilderness experience, try a husky safari with Birk Husky (birkhusky.no) on the Russian border," says Russell Davies, product manager for tour operator Discover the World (discover-the-world.co.uk). "You stay in wooden cabins and they are renowned for their cuisine."

Festive feasting: Seasonal fairs to get you into the Christmas spirit

Why limit the season of goodwill and gluttony to the 12 days of Christmas when you can start expanding your waistline now?

Abergavenny kicks things off with its Christmas Fair <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a more intimate version of its famous Food Festival, with 90 stalls of seasonal goodies, food demonstrations and a celebration of British sweets (8 December, abergavennyfoodfestival.com). In the Cotswolds, Chipping Campden's miniBITE weekend offers a perfect Christmas appetiser, with an artisan food fair, workshops at Daylesford Cookery School, a masterclass with Sophie Grigson, and a pop-up Peruvian restaurant (5-7 December, thebite.co).

The ever-popular Winter Festival will be returning to London's Southbank Centre with a Chocolate Festival (7-9 December) and a series of festive farmers' markets (14-16 and 20-23 December) where you can try out a range of cheeses (pictured), charcuteries, chutneys and other tasty things that don't begin with "ch".

If you live in the southwest, find out what's happening at your local National Trust property, as several, including Killerton in Devon, Tyntesfield near Bristol and Montacute House in Somerset, are hosting food and craft markets (nationaltrust.org.uk).

If it's serious inspiration you're after, check out the festive cookery courses at the Bodnant Welsh Food Centre, where you can master the art of everything from edible gifts to the ultimate festive dessert (from <83><80><9a><82>75pp, bodnant-welshfood.co.uk).

If you love rolling hills, head for... the North Downs, Kent

Octavia Hill Bunkhouse, Westerham This National Trust-run bunkhouse sits in the peaceful grounds of a former hop farm dating back to the 15th century, complete with listed oast house. It sleeps up to 14 in two dorms <83><82><82><82><80><9c> a great budget option for groups or families, with a communal kitchen/dining room with Aga and hot showers. Walk in the stunning Kent Downs. <83><80><9a><82>250 per night for the bunkhouse (nationaltrust.org.uk)

Thorpe Farm Shepherd's Hut, Faversham Your neighbours are a flock of Hebridean sheep at this charming shepherd's hut on a five-acre smallholding. A woodburner keeps things cosy, while a double bed with White Company bedding, Bose sound system and flushable loo (in an adjacent beach hut) provide home comforts. Breakfast can be delivered on request. <83><80><9a><82>60 a night or <83><80><9a><82>150 for three nights (thorpefarm.org)

Five Bells Inn, Brabourne This lovely 16th-century inn, popular with locals and walkers, offers beautifully prepared Kentish produce, local beers, wines and ciders on tap, open fires and, a refreshingly laid-back approach to dogs, muddy boots and kids. Last year it added five colourful, contemporary bedrooms <83><82><82><82><80><9c> it's worth staying for the breakfast alone. From <83><80><9a><82>100 a night (fivebellsinnbrabourne.com)

Thurnham Keep, Maidstone Old-fashioned elegance without a hint of stuffiness prevails at this Edwardian country-house B&B set in beautiful gardens. Bedrooms are large and airy, with antique beds and views of the Downs. Breakfast is served in the morning room and often includes fruit from the kitchen garden, honey from the owner's hives and eggs from the resident chickens. Doubles from <83><80><9a><82>130 a night (thurnhamkeep.co.uk)

Breakfast can be delivered on request. 60 a night or 150 for three nights (thorpefarm.org) Five Bells Inn, Brabourne This lovely 16th-century inn, popular with locals and walkers, offers beautifully prepared Kentish produce, local beers, wines and ciders on tap, open fires and, arefreshingly laid-back approach to dogs, muddy boots and kids. Bedrooms are large and airy, withantique beds and views of the Downs. Breakfast is served in the morning room and often includes fruit from the kitchen garden, honey from the owner's hives and eggs from the resident chickens. Doubles from 130 a night (thurnhamkeep.co.uk)

webTitle: Norway's mission reposition: state says date nights key to good marriage
trailText: Oslo government channels Cupid and Barry White and says parents must make time to be lovers too, as divorce rate rises
headline: Norway's mission reposition: state says date nights key to good marriage
standfirst: Oslo government channels Cupid and Barry White and says parents must make time to be lovers too, as divorce rate rises
body:
The secret to a long-lasting marriage is not humour, patience, shared interests or an equal division of household chores. It's government intervention.

That, at least, is the hope of Norway's ruling Populist party, which is promoting date nights as a cure for flagging marriages in an attempt to reduce the country's divorce rate.

The new minister for children, equality and social inclusion, Solveig Horne, said the government needed to cut divorce rates <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and that encouraging couples to try date nights was a good place to start: "It is important to find small pockets of time where parents can be lovers," she said.

Divorce rates are at 40% in Norway, with those aged 40 to 44 most likely to split from their partners.

Since taking up her post earlier this month, Horne has announced her intention to campaign for increased funding for family counselling to help prevent divorces. "With state-run counselling offices, couples can learn more about how to be together before they have problems and talk things through when problems do arise," she said.

There are no plans to implement mandatory date nights for Norwegian couples. Horne said: "It's not something the government can tell you to do; it's something that couples need to do on their own." However, she is an advocate for couples taking time out together.

"In a busy life of work and family, the week can feel too short to attend to your relationship with your partner, so each couple needs to decide what sort of a date night they should have, whether it's a night at the movies or a walk together without the kids for a couple of hours," she said.

Having been through a divorce herself, Horne is convinced that allocating time to a partner can have a huge impact on a relationship: "Maybe I didn't have success [in marriage] because we didn't have any date nights!" she said.

Horne's proposal has been cited by country's media as further proof of the new government's centre-right bias, with many seeing parallels to a date night campaign started up by US conservative groups such as the National Marriage Project. It claims that married men and women who have "couple time" at least weekly were 3.5 times more likely to report being very happy in their marriages than those who struggled to spend time together.

Horne said she was more inspired by a 2010 romantic comedy starring Tina Fey and Steve Carell. "I saw the movie Date Night where an American couple try to go out to keep their relationship alive," said Horne. "In the film, everything goes wrong <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but I thought it was a good idea.

"My sister lives in the US and she told me that she and her husband have a weekly date night and it really works. Date night isn't really something that's done in Norway, but I think it could be a good way to keep marriages together."

Horne's initiative is the latest headline-grabbing moment for the minister since her appointment earlier this month, with the Norwegian press revisiting two controversial gaffes.

Horne has been criticised for comments about rape made in 2011 on Norwegian public television when she was recorded as saying: "Girls are responsible for the situation they put themselves in, but boys also have a responsibility to respect a 'no'. I think both boys and girls have equal responsibility."

Horne also offended Norway's lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender community after the re-emergence of a tweet that she sent in 2010 about a children's book that included gay characters: "I wonder if it's okay that kindergartens are reading gay adventures for young children?"

She denied accusations of homophobia, saying: "I will be the minister for gays, lesbians, transgender and heterosexual people. People should be allowed to judge me when they have got to know me."

webTitle: UK playwright plans show drawing on Anders Breivik's Norway killings
trailText: Controversial play will relocate Norwegian mass murders to Scotland in bid to examine 'limits of empathy'
headline: UK playwright plans show drawing on Anders Breivik's Norway killings
standfirst: Controversial play will relocate Norwegian mass murders to Scotland in bid to examine 'limits of empathy'
byline: Vanessa Thorpe, arts and media correspondent
body:
One of Britain's acclaimed writers for the stage, David Greig, has created a musical show based on the murders in Norway committed in 2011 by Anders Breivik.

Greig, who has also written the book for the new Sam Mendes film musical of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, researched the project on Ut<83><92><82>ya island and in Oslo, visiting the country with the director Ramin Gray three months after the atrocity that saw the lone killer end the lives of 77 people.

Called The Events, the show examines the limits of human empathy and will be premiered this summer at Edinburgh's Traverse Theatre, before it travels to London for a run at the Young Vic.

"I was most interested in how Norwegian society was feeling," said Greig this weekend. "Oslo is not a huge city and everybody pretty much knows everybody else, so almost everyone we spoke to had been affected. Some people asked us not to write or talk about Breivik. I am not at all certain whether we give him a victory by ignoring him or trying to understand him. That is what I wanted to question."

Greig and Gray, who already shared an interest in Norway, spoke to many who had lost friends and relatives. As a result, the writer eventually decided not to name Breivik in the show and to relocate the atrocity to his native Scotland.

His story centres on a woman, described as being "at the centre of the events", who has to try to decide on her response to the impact of a politically and racially motivated mass murder.

Gray, who commissioned Greig to write the piece for the Actors Touring Company, recalled that on their Norwegian trip they talked to a journalist who revealed that he had been at school with Breivik and was able to give them detailed information.

"We had a lot of angst about whether it was at all right to even do something on this," he said. "It was such a devastating incident, but David wanted to ask whether there are limits to empathy and whether it can even become destructive itself."

Musical theatre has often approached dark subjects. Spring Awakening, a show based on the controversial German novel by Frank Wedekind, deals with teen rape, suicide and abortion, while a recent National Theatre production, London Road, was written in response to the murders of five prostitutes in Ipswich in 2006.

The score for The Events has been composed by John Brown and involves the voices of a community choir. "Choirs seemed to be the right way to represent that basic faith in the group," said Greig. "They are also theatrically interesting because of the Greek and Brechtian traditions of the chorus, and also the chorus lines of musical theatre."

"Breivik's violence was done to an entire society," he added. "I was interested in how people responded. Norway seems to be a poster boy for the liberal west. It represents the Scandinavian social democratic ideal and the attack seemed to be aimed at that."

In proportional terms, said Greig, the Norwegian murders were akin to the 9/11 attacks on New York. "Americans responded one way, and Norway responded with democracy. I wanted to look at whether trying to understand a crime of this nature is really the best way," he said. The writer said he hoped the show would give the audience an experience almost the opposite of a Greek tragedy, which follows a character's thirst for revenge. "Instead, this woman searches for understanding <83><82><82><82><80><9c> but I wanted to question that impulse too," he said.

The playwright's earlier work Dunsinane was recently produced for the Hampstead Theatre by the Royal Shakespeare Company and he is working on plays for the National Theatre of Scotland and the Royal Court in London. He hopes The Events will make audiences wonder whether a mass murderer such as Osama bin Laden is so different to a lone killer such as Breivik <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and that the show will make a wider connection, to the horrors of Dunblane, Hungerford and Sandy Hook elementary school.

<83><82><82><82> This article was amended on Sunday 24 March 2013 to change the headline.

His story centres on a woman, described as being "at the centre of the events", who has to try to decide on her response to the impact of a politically and racially motivated mass murder. Gray, who commissioned Greig to write the piece for the Actors Touring Company, recalled that on their Norwegian trip they talked to a journalist who revealed that he had been at school with Breivik and was able to give them detailed information. "We had a lot of angst about whether it was at all right to even do something on this," he said. "It was such a devastating incident, but David wanted to ask whether there are limits to empathy and whether it can even become destructiveitself." Musical theatre has often approached dark subjects. Spring Awakening, a show based on the controversial German novel by Frank Wedekind, deals with teen rape, suicide and abortion, while a recent National Theatre production, London Road, was written in response to the murders of five prostitutes in Ipswich in 2006. The score for The Events has been composed by John Brown and involves the voices of a community choir. "Choirs seemed to be the right way to represent that basic faith in the group," said Greig. "They are also theatrically interesting because of the Greek and Brechtian traditions of the chorus, and also the chorus lines of musical theatre." "Breivik's violence was done to an entire society," he added. "I was interested in how people responded. Norway seems to be a poster boy for the liberal west. It represents the Scandinavian social democratic ideal and the attack seemed to be aimed at that." In proportional terms, said Greig, the Norwegian murders were akin to the 9/11 attacks on New York. "Americans responded one way, and Norway responded with democracy. I wanted to look at whether trying to understand a crime of this nature is really the best way," he said. The writer said he hoped the show would give the audience an experience almost the opposite of a Greek tragedy, which follows a character's thirst for revenge. "Instead, this woman searches for understanding  but I wanted to question that impulse too," he said. The playwright's earlier work Dunsinane was recently produced for the Hampstead Theatre by the Royal Shakespeare Company and he is working on plays for the National Theatre of Scotland and the Royal Court in London. He hopes The Events will make audiences wonder whether a mass murderer such as Osama bin Laden is so different to a lone killer such as Breivik  and that the show will make a wider connection, to the horrors of Dunblane, Hungerford and Sandy Hook elementary school.  This article was amended on Sunday 24 March 2013 to change the headline.

webTitle: Norway's sovereign wealth fund 'is example for oil-rich nations'
trailText: Former PM Jens Stoltenberg says indebted European nations should look to Norway's Â£460bn fund to avert 'curse of oil'
headline: Norway's sovereign wealth fund 'is example for oil-rich nations'
standfirst: Former PM Jens Stoltenberg says indebted European nations should look to Norway's Â£460bn fund to avert 'curse of oil'
body:
Norway has much to teach spendthrift nations such as the UK, its outgoing prime minister has said.

Jens Stoltenberg said indebted European nations should look to Norway, which has become one of the wealthiest countries in the world mainly by refusing to spend its huge oil revenues and placing them instead in a sovereign wealth fund.

"That way the fund lasts for ever," he said in a speech at Harvard University. "The problem in Europe with the deficits and the debt crisis is that many European countries have spent money they don't have. The problem in Norway is that we don't spend money we do have. That requires a kind of political courage."

Norway's sovereign wealth fund is the biggest in the world at <83><80><9a><82>460bn. The fund generates money from its ownership of petroleum fields, taxes on oil and gas, and dividends from a 67% stake in Statoil, the country's largest energy company. Norway is the world's second-largest gas exporter and the seventh-largest oil exporter.

Stoltenberg, a Labour party member who served two consecutive four-year terms as prime minister, said his administration restricted itself to spending the investment gains made by the fund.

He said the fund was the main reason Norway sidestepped the "curse of oil" that has plagued many other resource-rich nations, particularly in the developing world.

"There are many, many other countries in the world that are in similar positions, that are facing the same kinds of challenges that we are facing: huge temporary income from natural resources," he said. "So, if there is a danger of an oil curse, Norway is really exposed to that danger. But we have managed to avoid it. The oil industry has been a blessing for Norway."

Maintaining the policy has not been pain-free for the nation. In 2009, the fund's value slumped in the wake of the Lehman Brothers crash. The loss of <83><80><9a><82>56bn was equivalent to <83><80><9a><82>11,000 per person. Since then, its investment strategy has widened its scope to include Asian assets, and property including a multimillion-pound purchase of shop leases on London's Regent Street.

Argument raged during the recent election over how much of the fund's revenues to invest. The far-right Progress party, which is expected to enter a coalition with the more mainstream Conservative party, wants to spend more of the fund on welfare to enable tax cuts. A broad consensus among politicians of all major parties that spending the oil funds would corrupt the nation and encourage young people to become dissolute means the proposal is unlikely to gain much traction.

Britain, too, had the luxury of significant oil and gas funds, but successive governments have faced criticism for frittering them away on maintaining inefficient industries rather than saving the money in a sovereign wealth fund. Britain became a net importer of oil in 2003 and has faced a worsening balance of payments deficit and decline in tax revenues as a result, without a wealth fund to soften the blow.

webTitle: Trash to cash: Norway leads the way in turning waste into energy
trailText: UK cities pay to send rubbish to Norwegian incinerators, but green campaigners warn of dangers
headline: Trash to cash: Norway leads the way in turning waste into energy
standfirst: UK cities pay to send rubbish to Norwegian incinerators, but green campaigners warn of dangers
body:
For a country blessed with bountiful oil supplies, it may appear incongruous. But Norway is importing as much rubbish as it can get its hands on, in an effort to generate more energy by burning waste in vast incinerators.

The Eurotrash business may sound like an unpromising enterprise, but it's one that is increasingly profitable. The UK paid to send 45,000 tonnes of household waste from Bristol and Leeds to Norway between October 2012 and April this year. "Waste has become a commodity," says P<83><92><82>l Spillum, head of waste recovery at the Climate and Pollution Agency in Norway. "There is a big European market for this, so much so that the Norwegians are accepting rubbish from other countries to feed the incinerator."

He refuses to divulge the sums involved, saying only that the market is growing. Spillum is "considering requests" to burn waste from other UK towns. "As a rule we generate about 50% of our income from the fee we receive to take the waste and about 50% from the sale of the energy we create," he says.

Norway is not alone. Waste to energy has become a preferred method of rubbish disposal in the EU, and there are now 420 plants in Europe equipped to provide heat and electricity to more than 20 million people. Germany ranks top in terms of importing rubbish, ahead of Sweden, Belgium and the Netherlands. But it's Norway that boasts the largest share of waste to energy in district heat production, according to Danish government-funded State of Green.

Oslo's waste incinerator was built with extra capacity to cater for future growth. "With more and more countries in Europe moving away from using landfill, we assume that there will be growth in waste to energy," says Christoffer Back Vestli, communications adviser for the Oslo municipality. "At the moment, the city of Oslo can take 410,000 tonnes of waste a year and we import 45,000 tonnes from the UK. Europe as a whole currently dumps 150m tonnes of waste in landfills every year, so there is clearly great potential in using waste for energy."

Spillum adds: "It is cheaper [for some UK towns] to pay for us to take their waste than to pay landfill fees."

The incinerator only takes "clean trash" and the municipality is careful to filter out anything that could be hazardous. Norwegians are meticulous about their waste and divide household rubbish into three bags <83><82><82><82><80><9c> blue for plastic to be recycled, green for food waste to make biogas and white for everything else that goes to the waste plant. But many are concerned that the rubbish being imported from the UK and Ireland may not be so carefully sorted. "We have no way of knowing whether the rubbish coming in from Bristol or Leeds or Ireland has been properly sorted or is 'clean'," says Henning Reinton, head of Greenpeace in Norway.

There are worries that burning rubbish may discourage recycling. Julian Kirby, of Friends of the Earth, says: "Waste for energy isn't as green as it's made out to be. We estimate that 80% of what's in the average waste stream is easily recyclable." Kirby argues that the incineration system creates confusion: "If you think your waste being burned is a good thing then you are more inclined to just chuck things away rather than recycling them."

Some Norwegians also view the waste-to-energy plant as a blot on the landscape. "People in the city find it quite ugly," says Reinton, who is campaigning against the use of incinerators to generate energy from waste. "The modern facilities are far less polluting and damaging to the environment than the older incinerators, but burning waste is just a shortcut. We need to think about longer-term strategies for minimising it."

But most residents seem comfortable with the idea of burning waste to create fuel, with 71% of the population supporting the renewable energy source. Ove Merg, an electrical engineer in Oslo, says: "We certainly think it's positive that we use an environmentally friendly energy source. It's great that waste can be useful, and that it actually heats our house."

<83><92><82><9c>istein Thomassen, a photographer from the city, adds: "We produce insane amounts of waste every day, so why not use waste as fuel for heat? As long as the benefits outweigh the risks, I think that using waste as an energy source is brilliant."

webTitle: Wilfried Zaha pencilled in for England Under-21 game against Norway
trailText: Stuart Pearce is set to make several changes for England Under-21s' must-win European Championship game against Norway
headline: Wilfried Zaha pencilled in for England Under-21 game against Norway
standfirst:
â¢ Stuart Pearce to ring changes after Italy defeat
â¢ Danny Rose and Thomas Ince back after suspensions
body:
Stuart Pearce has urged a much-changed England Under-21 side, in which Wilfried Zaha is expected to start up front, to play with composure and devilment against Norwayon Saturday evening. With England desperate for a victory after losing to Italy in their opening match, the news that Zaha has recovered from an ankle problem has given Pearce a major boost.

Danny Rose and Thomas Ince also return after serving one-match suspensions, strengthening an England side who were outclassed against Italy. It is also possible that Chelsea's Nathaniel Chalobah will come into midfield alongside Jordan Henderson, and Tottenham Hotspur's Adam Smith will replace Nathaniel Clyne at right-back.

It is Zaha's availability, however, that promises to make the biggest difference. Unable to play any part against Italy, the Manchester United forward's inclusion will inject some much needed creativity and penetration into the team.

"He has been kicking his heels," Pearce said. "We have brought him on slowly over the last couple of days in regard to the slight injury he has had. He was outstanding in training [on Thursday] and it was the same again [on Friday]. He is showing me that he is fit for selection. He has played through the middle a couple of times and it is an option we have."

Pearce has made it clear that he expects to see a major improvement. "We need to see a touch more energy and drive and a bit more confidence on the ball," he said. "We've played some good football over the last few months, irrespective of our results. We've had some good movement and interaction in the team <83><82><82><82><80><9c> that didn't show itself against Italy. I certainly think it will [against Norway].

"We just needed to show a bit more devilment [against Italy] and when we had the ball we needed to show a bit more composure with our movement and our flair. We've got some good players in our team and too many of them didn't show that character. But I'm confident they will [against Norway]."

With Norway drawing 2-2 against Israel in their opening game, England will be eliminated if they lose, which would be particularly galling given that the draw was kind to them.

Pearce went to watch Holland beat Germany 3-2 on Thursday <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Spain and Russia are the other two teams in Group B <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and was full of praise for the standard. "It's probably the highest quality Under-21 match I've ever seen. The Dutch in the first half were scintillating and the character of the German side to fight back into the game <83><82><82><82> It was a great advert for Under-21 football."

England (probable, 4-2-3-1): Butland; Smith, Caulker, Dawson, Rose; Henderson, Chalobah; Redmond, Shelvey, Ince; Zaha. Norway (probable, 4-3-3): Nyland; Elabdellaoui; Strandberg, Semb Berge, Linnes; S Johansen, Konradsen, Eikrem; Nielsen, Pedersen, Berget

Referee S Boiko (Ukr). TV Sky Sports 2, 5pm.

webTitle: Travel news: a cabin retreat in Norway and Peruvian restaurant Ceviche on a UK tour
trailText: Plus: Cycling packages in Austria, trips to the rural Algarve and monsoon experiences in India for those who don't mind the rain
headline: Travel news: a cabin retreat in Norway and Peruvian restaurant Ceviche on a UK tour
standfirst: Plus: Cycling packages in Austria, trips to the rural Algarve and monsoon experiences in India for those who don't mind the rain. And, what Turkish unrest means for holidaymakers
body:
Escapism

Basecamp Nordenski<83><92><82>ld is a five-bedroom cabin in the high Arctic of Svalbard, Norway. Reached by boat from the town of Longyearbyen, it is lit by candles (there's no electricity) and heated by wood fires. Guests can watch polar bears and seals, use the sauna, go on expeditions or just marvel at the view. A two-day all-inclusive stay, including pick-up, costs <83><80><9a><82>640 adult, <83><80><9a><82>382 child.
<83><82><82><82> basecampspitsbergen.com

Cheap date

Austria's Zillertal region is great in summer, with tons of activities. The tourist board's seven-night bike package costs from <83><80><9a><82>266pp, including B&B accommodation in Mayrhofen, a six-day pass for cable cars, trains, buses and more, a guided bike tour, a day's bike hire, a day's guided hike, and a ticket for the Eagle's Stage bird of prey show.
<83><82><82><82> zillertal.at/en/summer/mountainsummer

Weird world

Going on holiday to escape the UK's downpours is the norm. But a new trip promises to whisk Brits away to even rainier climes. India-based sustainable tour company Greener Pastures has two monsoon experience trips: one is to Meghalaya, the rainiest place on the planet, and another to Assam's tea plantations, where rain fills the air with the scent of tea.
<83><82><82><82> thegreenerpastures.com

Where's hot now?

<83><82><82><82> 33C Tunis, Tunisia

<83><82><82><82> 27C Florence, Italy

<83><82><82><82> 25C Split, Croatia

<83><82><82><82> 24C M<83><92><82>laga, Spain

<83><82><82><82> 23C Bournemouth, UK

What's new?

UK food tour
The hit Peruvian restaurant Ceviche, in London's Soho, is taking its spicy fish dishes on the road, with a tour of Britain starting on 1 July. It will open pop-ups in restaurants in 10 destinations, including Bristol, Cardiff, Manchester, North Shields, Loch Fyne and Edinburgh. Dinner costs <83><80><9a><82>48pp including a copy of chef Martin Morales' recipe book, Ceviche Peruvian Kitchen, or <83><80><9a><82>75pp including a cookery masterclass.
<83><82><82><82> cevicheuk.com

Portugal website
The Algarve isn't just about resorts and sunbathing. Holidaymakers looking to explore the rural side of the region might like to know about algarvenatural.pt, a website new for this season, which maps walks, nature activities and the most beautiful scenic spots, such as Praia dos Tres Irmaos.

London bar
Second world war warship HMS Belfast is opening an outdoor terrace bar this summer. Called Upper Deck, it is licensed until 10pm and offers views of Tower Bridge, the Tower of London and the Shard. There's space for 50 drinkers and diners, and snacks such as a British cheeseboard, cured meat selection or a Brixham crab sandwich are available every night. An on-shore cafe bar opened in April.
<83><82><82><82> iwm.org.uk/visits/hms-belfast/eat-drink

Unrest in Turkey: What does it mean for holidaymakers?

As anti-government protests escalate across Turkey, is the country still safe for tourists? The Foreign Office says "further violent protests remain possible", and advises avoiding all demonstrations.

Hotspots are Taksim Square, Istiklal Street and the Besiktas area in Istanbul; the Kizilay district of the capital, Ankara; and the town centre and waterfront of Izmir. Demonstrations in Fethiye, Marmaris and Bodrum have mostly been peaceful. The FCO says protests usually begin in the afternoon/early evening and could disrupt transport (as could strikes), so leave extra time to get to the airport.

The FCO is not advising against travelling to Turkey <83><82><82><82><80><9c> except for certain regions close to the Syrian border, as it has long done.

The Turkish Ministry of Culture and Tourism says: "There are currently no problems with either transport or security in Istanbul [pictured] or any tourism regions and thus every sort of touristic activity is carrying on as normal." It added, "Flights in and out of Turkey are running as scheduled."

Andrew Lee of Turkey specialist Exclusive Escapes said: "Foreign Office advice has not changed for coastal Turkey for many years, and it is entirely safe to travel as normal. Guests have continued to visit Istanbul as planned over recent days, simply avoiding the demonstrations."

A spokesperson for UTracks and World Expeditions said that if people cancel their holiday because of the unrest, they will not be offered a refund. "We are keeping a close eye on what the FCO says and at the moment our trips visit trouble-free areas, so there is no reason to cancel."

Snow watch

We'd left this slot for the winter, then heard that it was still snowing in the Alps <83><82><82><82><80><9c> every day the week before last in Les Deux Alpes, the French ski resort. The glacier opens for summer skiing from 22 June to 31 August, and there's a snowpark and lessons for beginners.
<83><82><82><82> les2alpes.com, day pass <83><82><80><9a><82>36

Travel trash

Can't bear drinking claret from a plastic cup? Handy for picnics, parties or long car journeys (not for the driver though), the Vino2Go is an insulated travel wine glass set within a stable cup, and with a slide-action silicone lid, price <83><80><9a><82>14.99
<83><82><82><82> firebox.com

The Turkish Ministry of Culture and Tourism says: "There are currently no problems with either transport or security in Istanbul [pictured] or any tourism regions and thus every sort of touristic activity is carrying on as normal." It added, "Flights in and out of Turkey are running as scheduled." Andrew Lee of Turkey specialist Exclusive Escapes said: "Foreign Office advice has not changed for coastal Turkey for many years, and it is entirely safe to travel as normal. Guests have continued to visit Istanbul as planned over recent days, simply avoiding the demonstrations." A spokesperson for UTracks and World Expeditions said that if people cancel their holiday because of the unrest, they will not be offered a refund. "We are keeping a close eye on what the FCO says and at the moment our trips visit trouble-free areas, so there is no reason to cancel." We'd left this slot for the winter, then heard that it was still snowing in the Alps  every day the week before last in Les Deux Alpes, the French ski resort. The glacier opens for summer skiing from 22 June to 31 August, and there's a snowpark and lessons forbeginners.les2alpes.com, day pass 36 Can't bear drinking claret from a plastic cup? Handy for picnics, parties or long car journeys (notfor the driver though), the Vino2Go isan insulated travel wine glass set within a stable cup, and with a slide-action silicone lid, price 14.99  firebox.com

webTitle: Stuart Pearce to lose England U-21 job as Norway highlight talent dearth
trailText: Stuart Pearce is set to pay the price for England's exit at the European Under-21 Championship but the lack of opportunity for young players is the deeper problem
headline: Stuart Pearce to lose England U-21 job as Norway highlight talent dearth
standfirst:
â¢ Gareth Southgate or Peter Taylor could be next manager
â¢ Shortage of English U-21s playing in Premier League
body:
Another demoralising defeat, another inquest into where English football is going wrong. Stuart Pearce will almost certainly be a casualty of England's humiliating early exit at the European Under-21 Championship, although anyone who thinks that appointing a new manager will solve everything is deluded.

If it is hard to argue with the idea that it is time for Pearce's six-year reign to come to an end, especially when the manager resorts to asking centre-halfs to play as centre-forwards <83><82><82><82><80><9c> as he did in the final 15 minutes of the sobering 3-1 defeat against Norway on Saturday <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the reality is that the reasons behind the poor performances England have delivered in Israel run deeper than the tactical shortcomings of the man in charge.

First and foremost, the Football Association needs to decide whether it is serious about trying to win the Under-21 European Championship, or if Roy Hodgson, the England coach, and the rest of the governing body are happy to go through the motions every two years and prioritise international friendlies instead. One thing is clear, after failing to win any of their previous eight European Championship tournament matches in normal time, England are not good enough to be competitive at under-21 level with a shadow squad.

Whether Pearce would have got the best out of Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, Phil Jones, Danny Welbeck et al is a matter for debate, but something is clearly wrong when the Italy Under-21 coach is thanking the manager of the senior team for making Marco Verratti, a full international, available for the opening group game in Tel Aviv <83><82><82><82><80><9c> where England gave two teenagers debuts and lost 1-0.

For England, though, the Norway result was the tipping point and suggested there are wider issues to be addressed. While it is understandable to think they will never win the tournament without their best players <83><82><82><82><80><9c> which has been Pearce's message for years <83><82><82><82><80><9c> there is no excuse for losing so abjectly to a Norway side who had four of their regular starters on the bench because they had played for the senior team against Albania the night before.

The Norway defeat was one of those rare occasions when, in the wake of a poor England display, we were not left bemoaning the team's inability to retain the ball. England made 462 completed passes compared with Norway's 156 and enjoyed 69% of possession. A bigger problem was knowing how to use the ball intelligently <83><82><82><82><80><9c> for all their dominance, England registered only one more goal attempt than Norway. At the other end of the pitch, England's defence was, to quote Pearce, "a disaster". A defence that failed to concede in nine matches across 19 months has been breached four times in 62 minutes of football here.

As much as Pearce must carry the can, the England players have hardly covered themselves in glory. Indeed, on the back of the defeats against Italy and Norway the natural conclusion to draw is that, with the star names missing, England have a paucity of talent at under-21 level.

Research carried out by the CIES Football Observatory revealed last week that the playing time of English footballers under the age of 21 in the Premier League has fallen to its lowest ever level. For too long, the Premier League and its member clubs have been preoccupied with serving their own interests, which means generating as much money as possible and focusing on short-term success. The corollary is that homegrown players have fewer chances to break through than in any of the other leading nations.

As for the FA, it is now playing catch up at St George's Park, the national football centre, after finally waking up to the fact that there is a lack of highly qualified coaches in England compared with the other leading nations. Increasing those numbers will take time, as will the benefits of the elite player performance plan, which it is hard to be optimistic about when there are so few pathways to the first team.

In the meantime, Pearce will take charge of the England Under-21 team against Israel on Tuesday evening for what looks like being his final game. Gareth Southgate and Peter Taylor, who had two previous spells in charge of the Under-21s, are leading contenders to replace him, with the FA unlikely to move for either Glenn Hoddle or Steve McClaren, two former England coaches. Whatever happens, much more needs to change than the name of the Under-21 manager.

webTitle: England Under-21s 1-3 Norway U-21s - as it happened
trailText: Minute-by-minute report: England are eliminated from the European Under-21 Championship
headline: England Under-21s 1-3 Norway U-21s - as it happened
standfirst: England are eliminated from the European Under-21 Championship
body:
6.53pm BST

Full-time: England 1-3 Norway

For the second time in two matches, England have been outclassed. And that means they are out of the tournament. They have been a boring presence in it and their sole remaining ambition is to cast a further downer on the hosts' party by beating Israel in their last group game. England need to alter their approach to such tournaments to ensure they have more of their top young players available but smarter tactics are in order too and that probably means a change of manager. Hats off to Norway: we can expect to see a lot more of these players in the coming years.

Updated at 6.54pm BST

6.48pm BST

90+1 min:

Chalobah booked for a foul as Norway pressurised England into a mistake at the back. There will be four more minutes for England to endure.

6.47pm BST

90 min:

Rose launches a freekick into the box from deep. Haskjold claims it again with ease.

6.44pm BST

87 min:

The masterplan almost works, as Caulker nods down a hefty punt and Wickham lets fly. A fine block by Strandberg diverts the ball wide for a corner.

6.43pm BST

86 min:

Ibrahim fires one low and wide from 20 yards.

6.42pm BST

85 min:

England substitution: Dawson off, Wisdom on. Caulker is shifted to centreforward, suggesting England are going to try an aerial bombardment.

6.41pm BST

84 min:

Chance for England! IT came from a set-piece, of course. Shelvey clipped a freekick in from the left, Henderson sent a glancing header narrowly wide from eight yards.

6.40pm BST

83 min:

Norway substitution: Rogne off, on comes Nordtveit, who played for the senior team against Albania last night.

6.39pm BST

82 min:

Henderson booked for diving. England can't even lose with dignity.

6.38pm BST

81 min:

A token shot by Wickham is easily saved by Haskjold. Norway are looking comfortable.

6.37pm BST

79 min:

England slip a quick freekick into the path of Henderson, whose cross from the right is put behind for a corner. Wickham meets the delivery but Norway clear.

6.36pm BST

78 min:

Speaking of pity, here Oleksander Knudsen via email: "Watching the game in Norway as a Norwegian i should be quite pleased. But as most Norwegians I love English football. And the level of this u-21 team from England makes me sad. The players are good enough. The tactics aren`t. And that's the problem with your football. Without the head, the body won`t work. Coaches in England are few and not well educated."

6.34pm BST

77 min:

Norway appeal for a penalty after Nielsen is hauled to the ground in the English box but the ref, perhaps out of pity, allows play to continue.

6.33pm BST

76 min:

Play resumes with a corner kick for England, which Hakjold claims with authority.

6.31pm BST

72 min:

As England knock the ball around with purpose but little penetration, Rogne goes down with cramp. There will be a break in play, during which England's challenge is come up with a plan to offset 30 years of footballing ignorance.

Updated at 6.32pm BST

6.27pm BST

69 min:

Shelvey's first contribution is a good one, as he wins possession in midfield and luanches a rapid England counter-attack. Ince eventually threads the ball through to Zaha, who attempted to curl a shot into the far corner from 15 yards but failed to beat the defender.

6.25pm BST

68 min:

Norway substitution: Eikrem off, Ibrahim on.

6.24pm BST

67 min:

Norway come close to making it four, as Pedersen leaps to meet an in-swinging freekick from deep. His header glides wide.

6.24pm BST

65 min:

Substitutions: Redmond off, Shelvey on, hoping, no doubt, for a much-improved performance to the one he produced on Wednesday. "I'm still amazed that anybody in the halls of footballing power thinks Pearce is a top manager," wibbles Andy Bradshaw. "I mean it's as if all his past glories as footballer out weigh all his more recent, bigger, failures as a manager."

6.21pm BST

63 min:

Zaha, now operating on the right as Ince and Wickham occupy the centre, misguides a cross towards the aforementioned duo.

6.18pm BST

60 min:

England have increased the tempo following the goal, seemingly in the belief that they can get back into this game. They are fooling themselves. Meanwhile, Moses Muchapirei has channeled his immense frustration with this display into a mighty long email. Put your slippers on, sit back and read: "Watching this England performance is depressing, even for a non-England fan," weeps Moses Muchapirei. "They have on the bench, one of the most accomplished passers in his age group but went with Chalobah and Henderson. I can accept Henderson being selected automatically because of his experience and obviously because he's actuallya pretty good player. But it's so easy to see that England need someone who can use the ball positively and can retain it under pressure. Josh McEachran reminded me of a young Cesc Fabregas when I first saw him and confirmed this for me ina stellar season at Boro. He plays well under pressure and despite his slight frame can go past people and open up new angles. If he comes on, he'll be farmed out wide because he is skillful. It's such a waste and anyone with any kind of basic football knowledge can see this.

England must bring in Hoddle to coach the young kids. He always seemed to trust "ball players" and still talks passionately about this aspect of the game. England won the U17 Championship not so long back and McEachran stood out at that tournament as a passer. I don't see him blossoming into a top player because his club won't trust him and he certainly won't be given a chance to make his case at this tournament. A complete waste. I have watched English youth football closely for the past five years and the idea that English youth players are not great at passing the ball is a myth. It's just that the ones who can simply aren't trusted by the coaches who don't see their value. Like Pierce. It's like rejecting gold for iron because it's not 'ard enough you see."

Updated at 6.20pm BST

6.14pm BST

GOAL! England 1-3 Norway (Dawson pen 57)

A perfect penalty by Dawson, who guided it low and hard into the corner beyond the keeper. The fightback begins!

6.13pm BST

PENALTY TO ENGLAND!

For a handball by Semb Berge as he attempted to clear a corner.

6.13pm BST

"Pearce is right to complain about lack of players at this tournament, but there should have been more questions asked of him when he took a team with Welbeck, Sturridge, Jones, Smalling, Cleverley, Walker and others to the last tournament and couldn't get out of the group stages<" storms Tyson Stevens. Question were asked, Tyson, and indeed even after they beat Azerbaijan 6-0 in their first competitive match after that tournament, questions were still asked. I refer you, for example, to this match report by, well, me.

Six goals, six debutants, three points and no sign of a sea change. England could not have wished for a more comfortable start to their attempt to qualify for a fourth successive European Under-21 Championship as they disposed of Azerbaijan with ease, but there was nothing here to suggest that they will fare any better in the 2013 finals in Israel, if they get there, than they did during June's dispiriting performance in the 2011 tournament.

6.10pm BST

GOAL! England 0-3 Norway (Eikrem 51')

That's a great goal and good night England. Pedersen, showing why he is rated so highly [46 mins], scorched down the right, leaving Dawson flailing in his wake, and pulls the ball back to Eikrem, who slams it into the net via the crossbar from 14 yards. England are taking one hell of a beating.

6.07pm BST

49 min:

Strong work by Rose, who beats two down the left before firing a low cross towards the near post. Wickham can't do anything useful with it.

6.04pm BST

47 min:

England make an encouraging start to the half, with Wickham bundling the ball through to Ince, who is poised to shoot before Standberg sticks out of a foot to put the ball behind for a corner. The delivery is cleared as far as Henderson, who unleashes a ferocious left-footed shot from 23 yards, forcing a smart save from the keeper.

6.02pm BST

46 min:

In a bid to trigger an improbable turn-around, Pearce has withdrawn Lowe and replaced him with Wickham, which suggests a switch to 4-4-2. We'll see how it goes. "This is generally thought of as an exciting generation coming through the ranks in Norway," booms Trygve Lie. "The midfielder Stefan Johansen is in my opinion one of the finest young midfielders emerging in our country for the past decade. (If this lot had played Albania last night instead of the mess Egil Olsen selected, I'd bet they'd have won that match!)." I can see where that optimism comes from. Nielsen looks a silky player too, as I recall he also did when Norway beat France 5-3 in the second leg of the qualifying play-off.

5.58pm BST

Half-time food for thought

"Rarely have I seen a better case of possession stats being often useless as a measure of dominance or superiority," writes Terje Hamnes. "England apparently had 74% possession in the first half. To my eyes (admittedly tinted by the fact of being Norwegian) England have barely threatened."

"Psycho has 45 minutes left to avoid the sack - this is the second boring match in a row." - Worse than that, Nicholas, it could be the eighth in a row in the finals in which England have failed to win in normal time. Pearce is right to complain about England's refusal to release all of their best players for this tournament but it is also true that he has not played the hand he has been dealt as well as he could have. His cautious tactics further stifle players constrained by inferior technique and/or game-intelligence.

5.47pm BST

Half-time:

Stuart Pearce described his team's performance against Italy on Wednesday as "awful" ... the only way he could improve on that description here is by adding a few swear words. England have been plod. Watching them really is a chore. 

5.44pm BST

43 min:

As so often, set-pieces are England's main threat. Henderson clips a nice ball towards t he back stick, where Caulker nods into the net ... but only after leaning into the defender so the goal doesn't stand.

5.43pm BST

40 min:

Rose puts in a good block on a shot by Singh as Norway threaten again. They are looking far brighter than England, who are in danger of slumping out of this tournament with a whimper. 

5.39pm BST

37 min:

England remain too slow and predictable. They are not bothering their opponents, just boring viewers. 

5.35pm BST

GOAL! England 0-2 Norway (Berget 35)

Lovely play by Nielsen, who juggled the ball before lifting it over the flat-footed England defender into the path of Berget, who had easily eluded Caulker and then smashed the ball into the net to push England closer to elimination.

Updated at 5.40pm BST

5.32pm BST

33 min:

A long ball into the Norwegian box is met well by Henderson, who nods it down to Zaha, who can't steady himself sufficiently to hit the target, shanking a half-volley wide from 20- yards.

5.31pm BST

31 min:

More hesitate defending from England - this time by Smith - gives Norway another opening. Pedersen blasts wide under pressure from Caulker.

5.30pm BST

29 min:

A slow build-up by England nearly yields sweet fruit when Zaha injects some speed and incision before zipping an astute pass through to the overlapping Smith. The full-back tries to pull it back for Zaha but it's behind the striker.

5.28pm BST

27 min:

A glimpse - just a glimpse - of a threat from England, as Redmond twinkles in from the left and tries to thread a pass through to Zaha. It was slightly over-hit but the idea was laudable.

5.25pm BST

24 min:

This is becoming too easy for Norway. They simply get in position at the back and wait for England to cough the ball up to them and then they spring forward with speed and sharpness. As things stand they look the more likely to score next.

5.22pm BST

22 min:

Norway curl in another corner and it causes more bother, as Semb Berge meets it at the near post but can't guide it onto the target.

5.21pm BST

20 min:

Zaha has been unable to exert any influence on the game so far, partially because England have not used the ball cleverly enough and partly because Norway have defended diligently. "This is an email," begins Paul Morris in case I thought his missive came in a block of cheese. "I was wondering what the weather is like in Israel (or what it looks like on whatever medium you are watching)? Could it be better than it is here in London? I've already been for a run on the Common this morning and am now just hanging out waiting to Skype with my friend travelling in Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. Oh, and hoping to glean some pearls of wisdom from you about the stars of tomorrow (err...and Jordan Henderson)." The sun is shining, the sky is clear and Henderson is not as bad as you suggest - indeed, I'll venture that he made good progress in the season just gone.

5.18pm BST

17 min:

Norway send a freekick into the box, hoping for more dithering from the English defence. But Butland is solid this time, clutching the ball out of the air to soothe his side's anxiety a tad. But they're still facing an early exodus from this tournament if they don't turn things around.

5.17pm BST

GOAL! England 0-1 Norway (Semb Berge 15)

Norway score from their first serious attack of the game. Butland flapped at a corner, conceding another one on the other side and that mistakes was compounded by his defenders' inability to deal with the next delivery. As the ball bobbled around in the box, centreback Semb Berge showed good presence of mind to slot a low shot through a thicket of bodies and into the net from nine yards. 

Updated at 5.40pm BST

5.13pm BST

12 min:

Henderson curls a freekick in from the right. The ubiquitous Rose rises to meet it - but his header is off target.

5.12pm BST

10 min:

Rose, who's seeing plenty of the ball, tonks a long shot high and wide with his right peg, or "foot" in layman's terms. "Didn't you watch our brilliant, erm, draw against, erm, Albania last night?" fumes a man called Egil Olsen. "Anyway, this team plays vastly more expansive football than our seniors, Valon Berisha is a genius in the making, and besides, you're Irish. It's 1320 years to the day since the attack at Lindisfarne that kick-started the Viking age. That's got to mean something. Right?" Yes, it was doubtless the centrepiece of the Norwegian manager's pre-match team-talk.

5.10pm BST

8 min:

Norway threaten for the first time after a bright break down the right, during which Dawson tried but failed to intercept a pass, allowing Elabdellaoui to scamper towards the box and crack a shot ... a few yards over.

5.07pm BST

6 min:

England's pressing continues to prevent Norway from piecing anything together and when England get the ball back, they are making positive use of it. Henderson and Redmond have just produced a dainty piece of interplay to infiltrate the Norwegian box before having to settle for a corner.

5.05pm BST

4 min:

England look the more able team in the early stages, starting to circulate the ball with promise, if not with penetration yet. Rose has been to the fore, twice hurtling down the left and delivering decent crosses.

5.03pm BST

2 min:

The first shot at goal comes from Eikrem and it's not worth writing home about. But clearly good enough for a mbm. Those are the standards, folks, so why not send an email?

5.00pm BST

1 min:

From kick-off, Norway hoof the ball straight into touch. The spirit of Egil Olsen endures ...

4.58pm BST

Pre-match formalities

It's national anthem time and England have decided to stick with God Save the Queen. Why? Fact is it just hasn't been working for them in recent decades. Change is needed. English players just charge out on to the pitch to the sounds of, say, Iron Maiden's The Trooper.

12.30pm BST

Preamble:

This match isn't about entertainment* - it's all about England a win to get their campaign back on track or, at least, avoiding the defeat that would condemn them to an ignominious first-round exit. They played today's opponents, Norway, twice during the qualifiers and won both times but those were tight and tense affairs and the stakes are even bigger today. While Stuart Pearce's sobs about the number of eligible players that he has not been allowed to take, Norway's squad features 15 players who have been capped at senior level <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and they knocked out France in the play-offs so they're nifty enough. Pearce has made five changes to the side that were royally outplayed by Italy on Wednesday, with the inclusions of Wilfried Zaha, Tom Ince and Nathaniel Chalobah all likely to add much-needed flair while Smith and Rose should strengthen the full-back areas.

*Obviously

Teams:

England: Butland, Smith, Caulker, Dawson, Rose, Chalobah,
Henderson, Lowe, Ince, Zaha, Redmond.

Subs: Steele, Clyne, Wisdom, Lees, Robinson, McEachran, Lansbury, Shelvey, Delfouneso, Sordell, Wickham, Rudd.

Norway: Nyland, Elabdellaoui, Rogne, Semb Berge,
Strandberg, Singh, Johansen, Eikrem, Berget, Pedersen, Nielsen.

Subs: Ostbo, Linnes, Berisha, Henriksen, Nordtveit, de Lanlay,
Konradssen, Kastrati, King, Ibrahim.

Referee: Sergiy Boiko (Ukraine)

Updated at 4.26pm BST

Ince eventually threads the ball through to Zaha, who attempted to curl a shot into the far corner from 15 yards but failed to beat the defender.  6.25pm BST Norway substitution: Eikrem off, Ibrahim on.  6.24pm BST Norway come close to making it four, as Pedersen leaps to meet an in-swinging freekick from deep. "I'm still amazed that anybody in the halls of footballing power thinks Pearce is a top manager," wibbles Andy Bradshaw. "I mean it's as if all his past glories as footballer out weigh all his more recent, bigger, failures as a manager."  6.21pm BST Zaha, now operating on the right as Ince and Wickham occupy the centre, misguides a cross towards the aforementioned duo.  6.18pm BST England have increased the tempo following the goal, seemingly in the belief that they can get back into this game. They are fooling themselves. Meanwhile, Moses Muchapirei has channeled his immense frustration with this display into a mighty long email. Put your slippers on, sit back and read: "Watching this England performance is depressing, even for a non-England fan," weeps Moses Muchapirei. "They have on the bench, one of the most accomplished passers in his age group but went with Chalobah and Henderson. I can accept Henderson being selected automatically because of his experience and obviously because he's actuallya pretty good player. But it's so easy to see that England need someone who can use the ball positively and can retain it under pressure. Josh McEachran reminded me of a young Cesc Fabregas when I first saw him and confirmed this for me ina stellar season at Boro. He plays well under pressure and despite his slight frame can go past people and open up new angles. If he comes on, he'll be farmed out wide because he is skillful. It's such a waste and anyone with any kind of basic football knowledge can see this.  England must bring in Hoddle to coach the young kids. He always seemed to trust "ball players" and still talks passionately about this aspect of the game. England won the U17 Championship not so long back and McEachran stood out at that tournament as a passer. I don't see him blossoming into a top player because his club won't trust him and he certainly won't be given a chance to make his case at this tournament. A complete waste. I have watched English youth football closely for the past five years and the idea that English youth players are not great at passing the ball is a myth. It's just that the ones who can simply aren't trusted by the coaches who don't see their value. Like Pierce. It's like rejecting gold for iron because it's not 'ard enough you see." Updated at 6.20pm BST  6.14pm BST A perfect penalty by Dawson, who guided it low and hard into the corner beyond the keeper. The fightback begins!  6.13pm BST For a handball by Semb Berge as he attempted to clear a corner.  6.13pm BST "Pearce is right to complain about lack of players at this tournament, but there should have been more questions asked of him when he took a team with Welbeck, Sturridge, Jones, Smalling, Cleverley, Walker and others to the last tournament and couldn't get out of the group stages and they knocked out France in the play-offs so they're nifty enough. Pearce has made five changes to the side that were royally outplayed by Italy on Wednesday, with the inclusions of Wilfried Zaha, Tom Ince and Nathaniel Chalobah all likely to add much-needed flair while Smith and Rose should strengthen the full-back areas. *Obviously Teams: England: Butland, Smith, Caulker, Dawson, Rose, Chalobah, Henderson, Lowe, Ince, Zaha, Redmond. Subs: Steele, Clyne, Wisdom, Lees, Robinson, McEachran, Lansbury, Shelvey, Delfouneso, Sordell, Wickham, Rudd. Norway: Nyland, Elabdellaoui, Rogne, Semb Berge, Strandberg, Singh, Johansen, Eikrem, Berget, Pedersen, Nielsen.  Subs: Ostbo, Linnes, Berisha, Henriksen, Nordtveit, de Lanlay, Konradssen, Kastrati, King, Ibrahim. Referee: Sergiy Boiko (Ukraine) Updated at 4.26pm BST

webTitle: Norway's freezing landscape where cod is god
trailText: Norway's forward-thinking fisheries policy has created the biggest and fastest-growing cod stock in the world. Felicity Cloake meets the people who catch it, in the community made by it
headline: Norway's freezing landscape where cod is god
standfirst: Norway's forward-thinking fisheries policy has created the largest cod stock in the world â and it's still growing
body:
I'm bobbing about on an open rib in the blank, black water of the Arctic Circle, stylishly attired in salopettes smeared with blood and snow, and grinning like an idiot. The reason for this flaps violently at my feet <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the first fish I've ever caught, a mighty fine halibut.

I'm overjoyed, but no one else seems very interested, perhaps because, as my host, fisherman Kyrre Brun points out, I have travelled 2,000 miles in search of cod.

Not just any old chip-shop cod mind you. I'm talking about migrating fish making their annual pilgrimage to their ancestral spawning grounds around the Lofoten islands in the north-western corner of Norway, followed by a similarly seasonal glut of excited fishermen from all over Scandinavia.

I can hear the alarm bells going off in every good Guardian-reading, Hugh-Fearnley-Whittingstall-following head at this point <83><82><82><82><80><9c> so let me explain. Many cod populations around the UK have indeed been fished to within an inch of existence, but all wild Norwegian cod is certified as sustainable by the Marine Stewardship Council, a fact in part due to Norway's forward-thinking fisheries policy. While the EU only agreed this year to outlaw the scandalous practice of dumping less valuable fish at sea, Norway banned discards back in 1987. The Barents Sea, where the majority of its cod are caught, boasts the largest stock in the world <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and it's growing.

Despite my failure to find one, it's an abundance that becomes very evident in the next 20 minutes, as no fewer than seven lively young fish land on the violently lurching floor of the rib and several more are thrown back to swim another day. Turns out I'm not a prodigy with the rod after all: any fool could catch something out here <83><82><82><82><80><9c> the fish practically leap on to the line.

But all fish are not created equal. To qualify as skrei, the highest grade of cod, identifiable by the tag on its dorsal fin, they need to be fully grown, immaculate ("with no scratches, bruising or injuries") and packed and on their way within 12 hours of being caught.

Although genetically identical to the local coastal cod, hoity-toity male skrei won't mix with them <83><82><82><82><80><9c> "instead, they wait for the arrival of their females a few weeks later to spawn", Espen Klaevik-Pettersen, of the Norwegian Seafood Council tells me. Lean and muscular from their long journey, I imagine them like two supermodels locking eyes over a room of dumpy dull sorts in bad shoes.

Certainly they cause as much excitement round here as any celebrity. Though fish fuel these communities year round, the arrival of the first skrei in January puts everyone into overdrive. Jan-Roger Knutsen, manager of the Gunnar Klo processing plant in Myre, tells me they'll be up till 6am cleaning, grading and packing today's catch, around 10,000kg of cod, most of it caught with long lines from small boats.

The son of a fishermen and a filleter, Jan-Roger started off at the age of five, as many local children still do, cutting cod tongues which, fried, are a local delicacy (gelatinous is the word that springs to mind). Fifteen-year-old, baseball-capped Tobias, who's working today's after-school shift (though children are entitled to 12 hours off to work during the season) tells us, casually scratching the back of his neck with a bloody knife, that he's saving up for a motorbike. Kyrre Brun, whose son also started work in the factory at "five or six", tells me he's heard of kids earning more than 100,000kr (<83><80><9a><82>11,387) a year <83><82><82><82><80><9c> "that's a lot of Xbox games".

In fact, so lucrative are these four months that many of the women busily filleting fish ("women can talk and work at the same time. Men can't," Jan-Roger says darkly as we watch them heave fish about like feather dusters) are housewives for the rest of the year. The whole operation has the fevered atmosphere of a pescatorial gold rush.

All is not completely rosy in the fjords, however. The vast, skeletal, long-house-like structures that dot the coastline, hung with drying cod destined for southern European, South American and African markets are costing Knutsen and others like him, money. Portugal can no longer afford bacalao, and Gunnar Klo is losing 20-30,000kr on each truckload the company sends out.

It seems to be doing well enough though <83><82><82><82><80><9c> and though the British may not have much of an appetite for dried fish these days, we're increasingly helping out with the fresh stuff. Although Knutsen says that we're still "haddock people", 1,300 years after the Vikings first brought it to our shores, skrei is to be found on the fanciest of fish counters (Harrods, Selfridges and Booths, amongothers) and restaurant menus <83><82><82><82><80><9c> Michel Roux Jr has described the fish as "fantastic". As with all cod, it has what is often described as a "delicate" flavour, but even I can tell the texture's something special: glassy smooth and firm, it falls apart on the plate in enormous creamy flakes.

Traditionally the locals serve it poached, along with its roe and a rich, greasy broth of cod liver and onions which I took an unexpected shine to, and copious quantities of aquavit. It's what you might call a party fish, according to retired fisherman Arne Antonsen, as he raises a glass: "You cannot eat skrei alone." A young chef hard at work in the kitchen of Troms's Frenchified Holstuen restaurant admits to me that, for all the sous-vide, olive-oil-poached fillets they serve, his favourite way with skrei remains the old one. "I grew up with it. It's part of me."

Those Norwegians certainly can get emotional about their skrei. Espen, over a glass of aquavit, muses that, "maybe it's my age, but now it's become emotional <83><82><82><82><80><9c> I almost cry when I eat it. When I see little children playing here, I think, if it wasn't for the skrei, none of you would be here."

In this desolate, freezing landscape, the cod really is god.

webTitle: Kenya's Westgate attack: Norway's Progress party faces its first test | Fry Gudbrandsen
trailText: FrÃ¸y Gudbrandsen: If an Islamist Norwegian was involved in the terrorist attack, all eyes will be on how the populist rightwing party deals with it
headline: Kenya's Westgate attack: Norway's Progress party faces its first test
standfirst: If an Islamist Norwegian was involved in the terrorist attack, all eyes will be on how the populist rightwing party deals with it
body:
Two days after the populist rightwing Progress party entered the Norwegian government, it is already facing its first test of how to handle controversial immigration issues now it has power and responsibility.

The facts are still uncertain, but there could be a link between Norwegian radical Islamist activists and the terrorist attack on the Westgate mall in Kenya. If proved, this would not be the first time radical Islamism had made its presence felt in Norway. Islamist individuals and groups have received substantial attention from the security police. In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks in Norway on 22 July two years ago, the police were criticised for having prioritised these groups over radical rightwing extremists. Radical Islamism has been one of several issues in the Norwegian immigration debate, but has never been the dominant theme. That said, Progress party politicians have frequently criticised the Norwegian government for being too soft on people with links to radical networks such as Profetens Umma. Earlier this year, Robert Eriksson, now the minister of labour, was furious that a central person in that group had been in receipt of benefits and demanded an immediate halt to all social security payments to persons with extremist connections.

Under normal circumstances, it is safe to say that any allegation of terrorist activities by a Norwegian citizen would lead to a strong reaction from the Progress party. If the suspicions turn out to be true, the party will have to deal with the issue from a different angle. They now have control over the ministry of justice.

This means that the populist right party also has responsibility for immigration regulation. Progress's entry into government received international attention, and to get rid of its reputation as a radical rightwing party, it even organised a press conference for foreign correspondents in Norway, to clarify the "misunderstanding" that they were anti-immigrant.

There is no doubt that the immigration issue has been central to the rise and popularity of the Progress party. The rhetoric has been unmistakably anti-immigrant. However, the party has a broad portfolio of other policies, such as the lowering of taxes and improving healthcare. It is moderate when compared with other groups of its ilk. Since the shift of leadership in from Carl I Hagen to Siv Jensen in 2006, it has taken further steps in that direction. And the terrorist attacks by Anders Breivik have seen it tone down the anti-immigration rhetoric down to a bare minimum.

The new government's immigration platform is also far more moderate than many had feared. It includes some restrictions, such as on family immigration, but also clear instances of liberalisation for other categories of migrant.

Progress cabinet members are all from the moderate wing of the party, an indication that they are attempting to take on the mantle of a serious and responsible party of the right.

But despite the moderate leadership, certain outspoken politicians make it difficult to paint a credible picture of Progress as a mainstream party. We are yet to see how they will respond to the possibility of terrorist links to Norway.

So far the story has received more attention in Britain than in Norway. Political reaction must come when the security services have concluded their investigation. Has the Progress party matured into a responsible mainstream party, or have we simply witnessed a superficial makeover for the purpose of entering office?

What moves it now makes will give us the very first test score.
